Author: SORENSON
Quote: BARRACOUTA (a) Scientific name: Thyrsites atun. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Sea Pike; Couta; Snoek; Barra Fillets. (c) Other common names: B/couta; Bait. (d) Principal localities where taken: Gisborne, Motueka, Nelson, Timaru, Port Chalmers.
Examples [of acronyms] include B&B, which stands for brace and bit, rhyming slang for fit, drug-users' slang for a hypodermic syringe and needle.
b-bows: Handshears.

Author: MALFROY
Quote:
B.M. .. Board
measure - a term
expressing the board
foot content of
round or
manufactured timber,
and for expressing
the volume of logs,
trees, or stands in
terms of the
estimated amount of
timber which may be
cut therefrom.
`Board foot' is a
unit of measurement
represented by a
board 1 ft. long, 1
ft. wide, and 1 in.
in thickness, or its
equivalent

Author: BURCHFIELD
Quote: babaco /b |b k u/. N.Z. & Austral. [S. Amer. Sp. (Ecuador).] A bright yellow marrow-like fruit, Carica heilbornii pentagona, usu. about 30 cm. long, with a faceted exterior and with a texture like that of a coarse melon.
Carica pentagona is called `babaco' by the natives and is regarded as a great delicacy.
Because of its large fruits .. and because of its habit of producng seedless fruits, the babaco is worthy of attention in other countries.

Author: T. TANAKA
Quote: Carica pentagona .., `Babaco'. The flesh of fruits are nearly white, acid; eaten cooked, preserved or used in sauce. Ecuador & adj. territory.

Group three:
Blueberries,
feijoas, avocado,
tamarillos,
cherries, babaco,
persimmon, Asian
pears, macadamias,
pepino etc.

Babaco orchards will
be limited to
frost-free climate
requirements.
The babaco .. is a perennial shrub of the papaya family (Caricacae) indigenous to the subtropical mountainous regions of Ecuador.
Babaco. Brought to Australia via New Zealand from Equador [sic]... It is a relation of the paw-paw and has been an exceptional crop in New Zealand.

Kay also uses
babacos to make a
"great fruit loaf"
by adding them to
her home made bread.

The babaco grows in
the same climate
range as the
mountain pawpaw, but
has much larger
fruits, comparable
in size with the
tropical papaya.

Of the high-altitude
fruiting plants that
are native of
Ecuador, the Babaco
is the most
promising fruit to
be introduced into
New Zealand from
that country.

[Caption] First
impression gained by
visitors to this
orchard of babacos
has been : "Little
green men from
Mars."

Author: BOLLARD
Quote:
The babaco, which is
grown in Ecuador,
was introduced here
in 1973.

We tried babacos but
they got too large
and started falling
over in their
buckets.

The babaco story
began in 1977 when
Dick Endt, a
nurseryman from
Oratia, near
Auckland, introduced
the first privately
grown species into
New Zealand........
The babaco belongs
to the Caricaceae
family, more
commonly known as
the papaya family.

Author: BURTON
Quote: BABACO... is a hybrid between two papaya (pawpaw) species, Carica pubescens (mountain papaya) and C. stipulata. . . first brought to the attention of the rest of the world by the botanist Heilborn, who named it Carica pentagona, meaning five-sided. The Ecuadorian name babaco (pronounced as in banana) has been retained in New Zealand.

Babaco juice is a
favourite beverage
in Ecuador where it
is served in hotels.

The Babaco industry
is now 10 years old.

A major love in his
garden was his
babaco plants, which
he grew in a
glasshouse. These
tropical melon-like
fruits were an
object of his pride
- and we didn't mind
eating them.

When you [the

Author: NEWLANDS COUNTRY WOMEN'S INSTITUTE
Quote:
In 1922/23 the Baby
Farm scandal broke,
and as a result of
this people did not
want to live in
Newlands, so the
area ceased to grow
for the next 20
years.

The death of Dr.
J.A. Harman, who was

Minnie Dean, with
Winton baby farmer,

Invercargill in

In legal history
[Minnie Deans] has
been known, with

Winton Baby Farmer.
Under the guise of
benevolent motive
she received
unwanted children
and apparently
destroyed them...
For a premium, never
very large, Minnie
Dean adopted
unwanted infants,
but the payment of
the fee invariably
marked the
disappearance of the
child into the care
of a "lady" whose
name or abode was
never disclosed.

The trial of one of

ever lived in New
Zealand was

o'clock today,
Minnie Dean, the now
notorious
baby-farmer, being

for the murder of
Dorothy Edith
Carter.

Author: SHEEHAN
Quote:
Eager eyes were

Author: LAWLOR
Quote:
Tom Long's most
important job was
the hanging of

notorious

Author: PINE
Quote:
The story of Minnie
Dean, Southland's
murderous
baby-farmer and the
only woman ever
hanged by law in New
Zealand, has not

[Hdg] Charge of Baby
Farming.

There has been more
than one case in New
Zealand of what
became known as
"baby- farming" -
the maintenance of
illegitimate
children for a
period followed by
their murder without
the knowledge of
their parents.

Attention is called
to what appears to
be a growing evil in
this colony - viz.,
"baby-farming." That
this evil exists

doubt; and it
appears that
children, either by
advertisement or
otherwise, are
placed in most
unsuitable homes,
where it is
perfectly well
understood that the
sooner the child
dies the better
pleased all
concerned will be.

Six years ago Mrs
Dean appears to have
started baby-farming
at Winton.

It was held by Mr
Justice Chapman that
the Crown
Prosecutor.. could
bring evidence to
prove systematic
baby-farming on the
part of both
accused.

Author: SHEEHAN
Quote:
"The Larches," Mrs.
Dean's home on the

Winton.. was the

- baby-farming case.

First put on the map

Regina versus Minnie

When the mater

Between ridges of

/ like a pink snail

"It's the boat,
bach, beamer

Mr. Baine ..

festivities at Mr.
Jones' bach.

From being a mere
shed, the bach has
become a place at
the seaside, and
today many a bach
has a refrigerator
and wall-to-wall
carpets.

The bach, these
days, tends to be
the name given to
any smallish holiday
house by the beach,
no matter how
sophisticated. But,
in the past, it
meant a small home,
built by the owner -
away out on the edge
- by sea or river.
Usually it was
occupied for just a
few summer weeks
each year... The
great building boom
for the archetypal
bach was after World
War I, with another
boom of more
gentrified, less
interesting baches
after World War II.

I've never set foot
inside a bach. If it
was a common
experience - the new
coat of paint on the
windowsill, the
towels hung over the
front porch to dry,
the tattered books -
then I have only
known it as a myth,
as a New Zealand
that existed as an
advertisement of
itself.

..the bach: a
simple, no-frills
retreat where we can
rediscover our
conection with
nature ... The
architect-designed
technology-filled
modern bach is a
refuge not from the
city but the
wilderness that
surrounds it.

Source: Under the Bridge & Over the Moon
Author: IRELAND

Quote:
This time, it will

cliff above the
Black Bach.

The bach is like a
postage stamp on the
outside of a letter.
It's worthless, but
there is $1.5

A man on his own
could just scrape
along.. if he had
the use of a
buckshee bach.

Tidy baches around

start from around
$300,000.

So, has the coastal
bach boat sailed for

Or when you promise

the woman of your

My girl friend and I

Some suburban bloods

"bach," where six
young men and a

from the door.

Bach theft is not

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
Mrs Clements' and
the Laings' baches
are also wooden and
sandy and smell of
the dry sacking on
the bottoms of the
bunks like ours.

The ubiquitous bach
may instantly spring
to mind as
expressive of NZ DIY
handymanship and
days in the sun or
bush.

All six share
similar design
features, if that is
what you call the
elements comprising
a traditional bach.
Low-pitched roofs,
corrugated iron
walls and recycled
timber fascias are
standard
construction. Some
have tiny gardens of
hardy coprosma, flax
and ice plants
scratched out of the
rocks. Each has a
water tank, various
structures to hold
firewood and fishing
gear, some have a
boat shed or a TV
aerial and each has
a chimney or flue of
some kind.

In those days (when
the old baches were
originally built)
the 'environment',
as they call it now,
wasn't an issue.

To get the full
flavour of baching
you hire a bach as
big as a piano-case
and fill it with
three times as many
people as it will
hold.

At the Egmont County
Council meeting on
Tuesday.. the
popular subject -
"Dirty Baches" was
brought up.

Probably because so
many New Zealanders
either spent
childhood holidays
at their own
parents' bach or at
their friends'
parents' bach, this
national institution
has become infused
with a nostalgic
glow.

We don't leave much
in the bach, it
isn't wise these
days.

Author: KEITH
Quote:
The baches all smelt

wonderful summer

Army huts.

Sure, there's a

Facilities at the
Collins' bach

fridge whose

A corrugated iron

But the recurring

beaches and baches

The feeling is
seaside-dairy-meets-flash-bach,
but the kitchen is
white-uniformed
efficient, serving

brunch that can
slide seamlessly

dinner.

and big, flash
"insensitive" houses
- not owned by arty
types - have gone
up, a worry to every
sensitive creative
person who calls
Paekakariki home.

Author: HARTLEY
Quote:
Teaching a dog to
back sheep is
something for which
provision must be
made in the puppy's
early tuition if
success is to be
certain.

Author: HARTLEY
Quote:
For the first
practice in backing
live sheep, the race
used for fat lamb
picking should be
used.

He is well bred,
very forceful and
will head, hunt and
back.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
This beautiful dog
would head, hunt and
back with almost any
dog I've seen.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
Back: A dog backs
when it leaps up and
runs across on top
of
sheep.(wool-walking)
Hence a backing dog
or wool-walker.

Handy - a dog that
heads a bit, hunts
with a bit of noise
and possibly backs
as well.

Author: RICHMOND
Quote:
Thus our neighbour
Gilmour in the back
bush wants GBP1 per
acre for his
uncleared land ...

Author: JANE RICHMOND
Quote:
Henry's heart seems
a good deal set on
making a palatial
residence in the
back bush, but I
don't know how funds
will be found at
present.

Author: H R RICHMOND
Quote:
I cannot feel that
you will be wise to
come into the back
bush and give up
your profession ...

Author: MCGREGOR
Quote:
The hunter declared
that he wanted Glen
for companionship
while he was camped
out in the back
country bush. [back
country bush]

Author: ACTON-ADAMS
Quote:
I'll provide the
yokes and chains
[for the bullocks];
you would have to
get two wool trucks
and covers. You
would earn at least
GBP.3 a week. as I
pay 50/- a ton for
wool with a lot of
back carting at half
price.

Burke Evans and
Mannering came in
from back country
and his man, Hammond
McMurdock, came,
having left dray and
bullocks on other
side of pass.

T.C.K., C.H.S. and
Hughie went to the
back country to
erect mustering
yards.

Musterers returned
from back country
with mob of about
2000 mixed sheep
(800 woolly.)

Drafted sheep from
back country ...

Author: JOHNSTON
Quote:
Falling 150 acres of
bush on back
country.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
.. nothing had been
done to the great
residue of the
property - the
fifteen or sixteen
thousand acres then
known as the 'back'
country.

I left Christchurch
in company with a
sheep farmer, who
owns a run in the
back country, behind
the Malvern hills.

Author: MONEY
Quote:
.. his station,
which was situated
in what was called
the back country
i.e. close to the
ranges which divide
the east from the
west coast of the
island.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
Backblocks or
backcountry: In the
South Island that
country beyond the
river gorges is
termed back country,
as differing from
front country which
consists of those
hills through whose
gorges the same
rivers wend their
way. Backblocks is
the equivalent North
Island term though
the nature of the
rivers does not
define them so
neatly.

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote:
Back-country. Land
extending beyond and
including the
foothills; land
beyond the river
gorges.

In the North Island
this type of farming
[high-country
farming] is confined
to two small areas,
on the high central
plateau and on some
of the high
back-country in the
Hawke's Bay-Poverty
Bay area.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote:
In the heavy
back-country, the
soil was being swept
off steep faces and
down the big rivers
[back-country]

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
Before I describe
the river I may as
well say a word on
the nature of back
country travelling
in the Canterbury
settlement.

The distant
`back-country'
ranges must have
felt the storm more
severely even than
we have.

Author: POTTS
Quote:
Within the last few
years [the kea] has
discovered the
out-stations of some
of the back-country
settlers.

Author: OWEN
Quote: He considered it a luxury for a man who was often reduced to rou-rou on a back country block.

Author: MULGAN
Quote:
And he saw from a
new angle that these
big sheep people -
whether they owned
their land or leased
it, as many
back-country
squatters did ..
were a distinct
class.

Author: BURDON
Quote:
Back-country runs
were deserted and
became mere breeding
grounds [of
rabbits].

Author: SCOTTER
Quote:
The back-country
part of the original
run had been
renumbered 134A,
some 22,200 acres in
the Otekaike Riding.

Author: BLAKISTON
Quote:
That first back
country winter was
quite an experience.
We lived on meat,
potatoes, bread,
scones and
occasionally some
treacle.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
Of many
memory-pictures of
back-country
loveliness which we
keep stored in the
mind.

Author: GRUNDY
Quote:
Twice each day the
operators at the
[Chatham Island]
radio station called
all the back-country
people. Hence
back-countryman,
also back country
man [nf AND] [OED
1796 US, 1942 NZ.],
one who lives or
works in the
back-country, cf.
backblocksman.

Author: MARSH & BURDON
Quote:
The shepherds,
musterers, shearers
and drovers, the
back-countrymen of
New Zealand.

Author: MARSH
Quote:
They were the
wool-growers, the
run-holders, the
sheep-cockies, the
back-countrymen.

Author: BLAKISTON
Quote:
In those days [1883]
there were no
luxuries like
butter, condensed
milk or jam for back
country men.

Hobson is founding a
town at the Bay of
Islands, but we have
an assurance that
there is no
back-country there.

The land [at
Wellington] rises
suddenly into bold
and rugged hills ...
as to render the
back country
exceedingly
difficult of access.

A good back country
up the Hutt.

The back country is
hilly and woody
apparently with
black birch

Author: BUTLER
Quote: Thus a run situated in the plains over which sheep are being constantly driven ..., will be in more danger [from scab] than one on the remoter regions of the back country. Ibid. iv/48 [OED] At last I have been really in the extreme back country, and positively, right up to a glacier.

It is found at very
considerable
altitudes in `the
back country'.

Author: MONEY
Quote:
[The Canterbury
settler] often spoke
[of] ... some quartz
rocks that he had
observed .. in parts
of his station,
which was situated
in what was called
the back country,
i.e., close to the
ranges which divide
the east from the
west coast of the
island.

Musterers returned
from back country
[of the station]
with mob of about
2000 mixed sheep.

Author: BARLOW
Quote:
There are great
numbers of wild
cattle in the back
country [of
Kaipara].

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
Flax and cabbage
trees belong more to
the front country,
they are not so
characteristic of
the back.

Author: POTTS
Quote:
At present it is
only in the 'back
country' as it used
to be called, that
we can hope to find
its breeding place.

Author: KIRK
Quote:
In back-country
where the mills
depend upon driving
for the supply of
[kauri] logs ... dry
weather ... may
prevent conversion.

Author: McCASKILL
Quote:
I hereby surrender
to the Crown my
licence of the
Tarndale back
country.

But owing to the
repressive measures
adopted there has
been a marked
abatement of the
pest, even on high
back-country.

back country -. The country beyond the river gorges: for instance, Craigie- burn and Mt. White are in the back country, Woodstock and Mt. Torlesse on the front-country. Two new-fangled literary expressions, out back and backblocks, are driving back-country out of newspaper use.

Author: GUTHRIE
Quote:
A good story is told
by a friend who was
going into the back
country on a visit.

Author: BUCK
Quote:
This back-country
[of Canterbury] was
in all probability
...subject to severe
winters.

Author: REED
Quote:
Another wily plan
was to run a fence
up a valley,
adjacent to a
stream, and thus
deprive any
intending purchaser
of water or the use
of the back-country.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
One yarn I heard
tell of but cannot
vouch for, in
connection with
those troublous
times [Hau Hau
rebellion],
concerned a couple
of the general's
shepherds who had
been sent into the
back country to try
and trace some
missing sheep.

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote:
Back country,
suggesting big
Canterbury
sheepruns, is a term
of approval.

Author: WHEELER
Quote:
Activities were once
confined to the
backcountry, but
helicopters now buzz
even the home
paddocks in their
impertinent search
for deer.

Author: PINNEY
Quote:
In 1886 there was a
bad drought ...
Middleton boxed the
9,000 cull ewes with
the wethers, and in
February pushed them
well into the back
country, which was
best in such a dry
year.

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote: Back-country. Land extending beyond and including the foothills; land beyond the river gorges. Remote stations are often referred to as being up the back.

Author: PARKINSON
Quote:
Hone Tuwhare best
captures the essence
of the backcountry
in this poem.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
I'd say that any
woman who has spent
a winter in at Mount
White could easily
qualify as a
back-country woman.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Among back country
men, no one is held
in greater respect
than a crack rough
rider.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Mutton chops, or
hockey sticks as
they are generally
known, are day after
day and month after
month, the back
country man's
breakfast ...

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote:
There's a subtle
difference between
back-country men and
those enslaved to
industry and
commerce.

Author: SHARPE
Quote:
If anything could
faze a back country
man this was it ...

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote:
I have lived among
the ranges, on a
rough back-country
run.

There are the
back-country runs
where the merino
still reigns supreme

The question of the
occupation of back
country runs under
the jurisdiction of
the Land Board by
tenants with
insufficient capital
was introduced by a
member.
[back-country run]

Author: BARKER
Quote:
.. it used not to be
uncommon on
back-country
stations to get up
the fine things with
a flat-stone .. for
an iron.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
After 'cutting out'
the Waimate shed,
they would go on to
the back country
station such as
Morven Hills.

Author: STAPLES
Quote:
Every Friday evening
he dressed up and
was away to the gate
to be picked up by a
transport truck on
its way back from
the back country
stations.
[back-country
station]

Their farming
implements were
limited, and the
plough, harrows,
roller and back
delivery reaper
comprised, in most
cases, the working
plant.

Author: WILSON & FRASER
Quote:
In those early days
the only reaping
machine was the
station
back-delivery. James
Anderson owned the
first back-delivery
in Otama, C O'Hara
had a side-delivery.

Author: WOODHOUSE
Quote:
Later came the
mowing machines,
though the crop
still had to be
bound by hand. After
them came the
'back-delivery' as
it was called.

Author: MARTIN
Quote:
The 'tilter'- also
known as the
'back-delivery'
because it dropped
the sheaves from the
back of a tilting
hinged platform -
was drawn by two
horses and was first
used in the early
1860s.

Author: AYSON
Quote:
Instead of the crops
being cut by the
hook with women and
children sharing the
work, back
deliveries came into
use.

Author: SCOTTER
Quote:
Then at the
beginning of 1869
this firm
demonstrated their
reaping machine; ...
Meek used as many as
ten of these back
deliveries in a
paddock, seven men
were required to
each machine and
perhaps thirty more
were stooking...
When the side
delivery, the
binder, took its
place ...

Author: NEAVE
Quote:
[He] got a job
binding sheaves
behind a back
delivery, an early
[c1868] machine for
cutting crops, and
he got a job on a
farm.

Shearing usually
commences on the
farms near the coast
somewhat earlier
than in the back
districts.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
They live in the
lonely back huts
while they muster
the high tops.

Author: GORDON
Quote:
Taking sheep out of
both valleys meant
the end of an era
for Makarora; no
more camping out in
back huts, for days
at a time, with a
six- to seven-man
gang.

Source: Along the Track: a collection of NZ hunting yarns
Author: AXBEY
Quote:
In one of the
station back-huts
was an old .577
Snider with a box of
ammunition ...
[back-hut]

Of course today we
see the Marangae as
the back-of-beyond,
but you have to
remember that these
people believed
that, within a few
years, they'd be
surrounded by all
the intended
infrastructure of a
viable rural
community...

Author: HISLOP
Quote:
Late that afternoon
saw me over ten
miles of up-hill
road which seemed ..
to be leading to the
back of beyond ...

Author: ELLMERS
Quote:
This area really was
the back of beyond.

It's not the back of
beyond. We have
reticulated water,
electricity ...

Author: David Geary
Quote:
Somehow we got a job
out the back of
beyond.

[Hdg] Back o'
Beyond... From
isolated back
country farms, from
lighthouses and from
the most
inaccessible part
[sic] of the
Dominion, 170 young
people arrived at
New Plymouth today.

`Very good,' I said,
`then you shan't go
home. I'll wheel you
to the back of
beyond. I'll take
you miles.'

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote:
I shall never forget
the small dark man
who took up a run at
the back of beyond,
carted a piano up
there on a bullock
dray, and passed his
solitary evenings
playing Bach's
fugues.
Notes: 1912 Williams Letter in 1919 Jones Samuel Butler 1/85

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
The attraction of
the old land of
enchantment `the
back of beyond' drew
me.

Some, like the
house-sparrow, cling
tenaciously to the
settled areas, while
others, like the
chaffinch ...,
sometimes occur in
the very `back of
beyond.'

Author: LUSK
Quote:
Far away in the
`back of beyond' as
you call it.

Author: HISLOP
Quote:
Late that afternoon
saw me over the ten
miles of up-hill
road which seemed
... to be leading to
the back of beyond,
and arrived ... not
far behind him.

Author: HAMILTON
Quote:
I'd been shifted
down to the bad
boys' camp in the
back of beyond.

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote:
Far away in a remote
area. .in 4;`The
last I heard of him
he was prospecting
on his own, west of
the Red Hills -
miles further on,
away out the back of
beyond.'

Author: MAY
Quote:
Duffer rushes
collapsed so quickly
that storekeepers
could find
themselves in the
back-of-beyond with
a fully-stocked
shanty and no sales
to pay for the cost
of packing-in and
packing-out.
Whykickamoocow: An imaginary town located in the back of beyond; HICKSVILLE, NEW ZEALAND.
Whykickamoocow: An imaginary town located in the back of beyond; HICKSVILLE, NEW ZEALAND.

Author: McGILL
Quote: Eketahuna itself enjoyed the dubious notoriety in the seventies as the back of beyond. Hence, in occas. predicative use, `very remote'.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
This was so back of
beyond they [ = the
railways] still had
a water tank at
Whanga.

Just fancy the
general body of
ratepayers voting
rates for the
purpose of
conveniencing deer
stalkers "way out
the 'back of
beyond'".

Author: ANZAC
Quote:
A soothing liquid
that licks
`forty-rod',
`chained lightning'
or `Cape smoke'
[illicit whiskeys]
to the back of
creation.

Author: PEACHE
Quote:
Front paddock 80
acres Upper paddock
50 acres, Back
paddock 10 acres ...
Notes: Journal in Gray (1970) Quiet With the Hills

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
.. he could have a
look round the sheep
in Ashwin's back
paddock on the way
in or out.

The back paddocks
are usually some way
from the shed and
are ideal for veal
production.

Any [Kaimanawa]
horses that a
veterinarian deemed
unsuitable for
domestic use would
be sent to farms to
live out their days
in back paddocks.

Author: GRAY
Quote:
Front paddock 80
acres Upper paddock
50 [do] Back paddock
10 [do] Middle
paddock 20 [do].
Notes: Peache Journal in 1970 Gray Quiet with Hills 49

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
Of course, by this
route he could have
a look round the
sheep in Ashwin's
back paddock on the
way in or out.

Author: KOEBEL
Quote:
A couple of
shepherds ... were
riding through one
of the
back-paddocks.

Author: FINLAYSON
Quote:
So Uncle Ted ...
goes off to catch
the little brown
pony ... in the
corner of the back
paddock.

Author: WATSON
Quote:
It was quite a walk
from the hut to
where they were
working in the back
paddock; we had to
go along the road
and through a
Taranaki gate and
along a clay road.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
Sometimes he would
ask us if we were
coming out for a
shot in the back
paddock.

Author: MUIR
Quote:
Like the froth on
the creamy buckets
of milk ... when the
handyman brought
them in from the
bails in the back
paddock.

Author: MANTELL
Quote:
Mr Robinson was a
share-milker on a
local farm. He lived
by himself in a bach
on a back paddock.

Author: IHIMAERA
Quote:
He was playing in
the back paddocks
with his sisters and
cousins.

Author: ELDRED-GRIGG
Quote:
The back door opened
not directly into
the yard but into
what we called the
back porch - a sort
of slot in the
house, neither
inside nor really
outside, but just
cold.

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
On the back porch
the boy fingered his
fishing rod while
his father smoked
and puzzled.

Author: POTTS
Quote:
Look about the
slopes of our alpine
back-ranges.

After a number of
years, when sheep
were mustered in
from the back
ranges, it was
noticed that several
would die in the
yards.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
They were now
'between the fences'
and would travel by
back roads where the
feed would be good.

Author: STRONACH
Quote:
We had a hell of a
job rounding them
up, but got every
one in the finish
and travelled by a
back road past
Hanmer to the
accommodation
paddocks ...

Author: HARRISON
Quote:
Sid's cousin, Harry,
had a farm about ten
miles from Sid, up
the back road.

Author: SCANLAN
Quote:
As a last resort,
get under a culvert.
But it is backing
round this way, and
the whare will
probably go later.

Author: MCMILLAN
Quote:
It was after a day
on the muster at a
back run out in the
west.

Author: BAGNALL
Quote:
... the partners
still hoped to
establish their
claim to three runs
in all, namely
Hautotara of 5120
acres as a back run
of 43,500 acres.

Source: Country Bloke and Other Verse, The
Author: MCMILLAN
Quote:
It's often I think
of the time and the
days, when we
mustered the back
runs for sheep.

Your poor, rough,
back section. It has
been forfeited
twice, and you'll
never make a do of
it.

The back settlers
still complain of
Government neglect
with regard to the
roads. The weather
has just suited the
back settlers, who
have managed to get
off some splendid
burns.

Source: George Rhodes of the Levels and His Brothers
Author: WOODHOUSE
Quote:
They settled between
Saltwater Creek and
Leithfield, known in
that part as great
carriers to
back-stations.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
All the back
stations had a store
or shop attached to
the homestead where
they kept a supply
of clothing, towels,
soap, tobacco,
papers, matches and
the like.

Author: HINDMARSH
Quote:
There were also the
district
get-togethers when
the back station
people would come
together for dances,
parties and dog
trials.

Author: HINDMARSH
Quote:
When the bushfelling
was in full swing on
the three back
stations in 1912, it
took eight muttons a
day to satisfy the
total needs.
[back-station]

Source: Crusts: a settler's fare due south
Author: KENNAWAY
Quote: The cattle ... were half-wild, restless brutes, imported from Australian back-stations, or bred on the equally wild ranges to the north of our own island. Ibid. 208 One evening, I remember a neighbouring back-station holder, after a long day's journey, rode up late along the fence-side of our home-paddocks, amidst a chorus of challenge from the sheep-dogs.

The ore-shoots of
all the
approximately
parallel Hauraki
veins occurred in
corresponding
positions in the
veins, and pitched
in the same
direction as the
main shoot. This is
the structure termed
in the older mining
phraseology `ore to
ore', or shoots
`back to back'.

[At Waihi] ... the
shoots being
disposed `back to
back' in these
parallel veins.

Author: SCANLAN
Quote:
Some of the Maoris,
educated in youth
and brought up in
British ways,
returned in later
life `to the mat'.

Author: GASKELL
Quote:
She spoke so
pleasantly that Miss
Brown decided she
must have been
somewhere to a Maori
High School and then
come back to the
mat.
Notes: 1947 Gaskell `School Picnic' in 1978 All Part of the Game 88

Author: SOLJAK
Quote: New Zealand colloquialisms which are of Maori origin include: ... get back on the mat: to go native

Author: GASKELL
Quote:
She spoke so
pleasantly that Miss
Brown decided she
must have been
samewhere to a Maori
High School and then
come back to the
mat.

Author: HILLIARD
Quote: you pakeha say There he goes, back to the pa. You say Back to the mat. That's what you say to each other about us.

Author: MORRIESON
Quote:
`Seems to me people
are right when they
say Maori people
head back to the
mat,' Sam said
rolling cigarette.

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
But eventually
Aramati left us (`to
go back to the mat',
my grandmother
said), and then we
had Edwina who was
quite different.

Author: MASON
Quote:
MIRIAM [to
Hingawaru]: Tribe's
all right, but
tribe's split up.
Stick with the
tribe, it's back to
the mat. Action
songs and a bottle
of beer.

Author: GIFKIN
Quote:
All Pakeha
Taurangians were
superior to all
Maori; even an
educated
'Pakeha-fied' Maori
would end by going
'back to the mat'.

Author: MORRIESON
Quote:
'... They all go
back to the mat in
the end. What's bred
in the bone comes
out in the flesh ...
Eating dried shark
and sleeping on the
mat ... Back to the
mat. I've seen it
time and again.'

Author: HYDE
Quote: `You couldn't have a Maori for a boss, though, they don't know what time means. `Taihoa,' that's what they say, and they all go back to the pa in the long run.'

Ferguson 24 petrol
tractor, runs well,
tidy condition, back
tray, roll bar,
$1,500.

It is well-known
that they always
'back up' to get a
start to butt. Stop
their backing-up and
you disconcert them
entirely .. but on
the attempt to
'back-up' he is
astonished by an
effectual brake in
the rear.

It is well-known
that they always
'back-up' to get a
start to butt. Stop
their backing-up and
you disconcert them
entirely as his
majesty goes
straight ahead about
his business ... but
on the attempt to
'back-up,' he is
astonished by an
effectual brake in
the rear.

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote: In our gang we all used to back up on Barclay because we'd all talked it over and decided to stick together. Ibid. 244 back up. (v) Repeat, reoffend, reinforce.

`Don't you hear her
talkin'?' as a
gentle ticking would
indicate the act of
partition had
commenced. Then the
wedges were `backed
up,' and a few solid
blows from the heavy
mauls would complete

backing him up with
a cross-cut.
Notes: 1864 Weekly News (Auckland) in 1957 Reed Story Kauri 159

Cyrus started
backing the tree up

back of the tree,
from the lean it
had, to the
perpendicular.

Source: Lunesdale: A Bush Farm Community from 1871

...

Ibid. 111 There were four doors - one, judging from the smell, let into the `Store', one onto the `back yard', through the third I saw the bedroom.

Fit the back fence

He backfences as

Benefits of Power

The backing gate is

Author: HUGHES
Quote: I was an Officer Cadet - a grand sounding title, but a cadet is generally acknowledged to be one rank lower than the Regimental cat. Worse yet, I was a baggy on basic. Ibid. 18 As new recruits beginning basic training (baggy-arse trousers gave us our nickname), we comprehended almost none of the myriad abbreviations, acronyms or slang.

The number of hands
to be employed on
each [threshing]
mill is as follows:-
driver, feeder,
three stackmen, two
bagmen, one
strawman, one
waterman and in camp
one cook.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
One season I'd be
bagman. The bagman
weighed the bag and
kept the tallies and
helped the
contractor to make
up the men's times
at the end of the
season.

Author: CARR
Quote:
The mills carry
their own forkers,
band-cutter, weigher
and bagman (one
man), and sewer and
stacker.

Author: MEEK
Quote:
We rarely heard a
bagman's tale- the
saddle made him
sore,

Author: LEE
Quote:
The old Acheron
woolshed was a great
gathering place for
these old bagmen ...
One of the most
noted of these old
swaggers was Spud
Murphy.

Mr English is
accordingly able to
succeed to the
leadership without
visible blood on his
hands. His bagmen
collected the
numbers, reached a
compelling majority
and this was
conveyed to Mrs
Shipley.
Notes: Not in OED or Green in this context

Quote:
Instead Lockwood
Smith and David
Carter - Dr Brash's
bagmen - were
sounding out MPs by
telephone - the
first all-telephonic
coup in the history
of the party.

[Hdg] Kiwi bagmen not too down and out. Journalists reporting on the National Party leadership scuffle swooped on the oddly Kiwi word "bagmen" to refer to the candidates' chief lobbyists in caucus... Elsewhere a bagman can be lot of things, all pretty well removed from getting in the vote for Bill or Don. In Oz it's an alternative to swagman. Elsewhere, it is a commercial traveller. Elsewhere again, and more sinisterly, it is one who collects racketeers' money. In a list of Post Office workers, it appears with porters. The New Oxford Dictionary of New Zealand English reckons it's a man who helps fill sacks of grain. The nearest to our special meaning is a Canadian reference to "political fundraiser".

I hear a united
"bags not" from all
the women of New
Zealand even in the
face of the most
attractive financial
remuneration.

We children slept in
bunks and I
gleefully bagses the
top bunk,

Author: JACKSON
Quote:
Baguish Box, as it
is appropriately
called, is a flat
coastal plain
bordered by an
escarpment, and
resembles the ground
floor of an outsize
packing-case.

Author: FULLARTON
Quote:
The Box ... that
outpost of Egyptian
empire fully a
hundred and fifty
miles from Alex. The
first batch of Kiwis
went there in the
summer of '40 to do
a spot of digging. I
believe they were
bombed once. Anyway,
they strung a few
strands of barbed
wire around their
diggings and called
it the Bagush Box.
They proceeded ...
to wait for Graziani
... who never got
that far.

Source: For the Rest of Our Lives
Author: DAVIN
Quote:
4 and 6 Brigades
back in Baagush box.
Since Bel Hamed and
Sidi Rezegh he
wasn't sure whether
to be proud of being
a New Zealander.
Other terms for places and procedures include.. Bahamas for the pound (solitary confinement cell).

The boar actually
bails the young dog.
The dog doesn't know
what's going on, and
he starts to bail
back, in defence.
Within a few hours
bailing becomes part
of its makeup.

The dogs got on the
scent of a large
boar, that did not
"bail" until it
reached the thick
undergrowth.

The byre itself is a
new-fangled
invention and I
think it is the
first of its kind in
Edendale... It holds
16 cows at one
bailing, and has
double bails on each
side.

All the animals
looked so
intelligent as they
went into the stalls
which were empty and
put their heads
between the bails.

Author: COWLEY
Quote:
She was alone,
chained into a bail
in an empty yard
still awash from the
afternoon milking.

Source: Five Years' Residence in New Zealand
Author: FULLER
Quote:
A heifer being
taught to go into
the milking-bail
usually has a rope
first passed over
her horns by means
of a long stick,
so.. she can be
drawn into the
position required,
where she is secured
by fastening the
bails, and then, her
leg being tied, she
can be milked
safely. This being
repeated a few times
with each cow, is
generally sufficient
to teach them to
walk in of
themselves
afterwards when
driven up to the
bail.

When the last of the
cows are in the
bails I gather up
the jug of milk and
set sail for home.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
A strong bail was
made at the end of
the race to secure
his head.

The same cows
usually came into
the bails first, a
chain was fastened
round the rear end
and the back leg
nearest the milker
was pulled back and
fastened with a leg
rope.

The cows were all in
the bails, teats
washed, ready for
the machines.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
A strong bail was
made at the end of
the race to secure
his head.

He spends an
incredible number of
hours in a draughty
shed that he refers
to as the
"bails."... Several
hours a day must be
spent in the cow
bails and in
mustering the sheep.

Author: ANTHONY
Quote:
Instead of going
into a bail, as she
usually did, she
made for my tin of
milk.

Author: BEACH
Quote:
We could tell it was
a good pig by the
commotion on the way
to the bail. When we
got about 25 yards
away, the other
blokes elected
Russell to go on to
the bail on his own.

Author: BEACH
Quote:
As I hurried down
the face towards the
bail, I heard one of
the dogs let out a
scream and I knew
what caused that.

Author: BEACH
Quote:
Reaching the bail
they had him in a
narrow creek with
six foot high sides.

Provision is made
for bailing up
twenty-two cows.

Many farmers train
the bull when young
to 'bail up' like
the cows.

His treatment was to
confine the victim
to the hospital
paddock, away from
the other cattle.
When treating her,
of course, she had
to be bailed up ...

.. they are brought
into the shed,
bailed up, washed ,
stimulated, and
milked in the same
way each day.

Author: JOHNSTONE-SMITH
Quote:
Bailers are dogs

wild pig.

Quote:
A Captain Cooker (a

his gun and knife

Author: KEENE

When bailed up in a

Author: WATERSON
Quote:
They [dogs] were
also used to finding

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
A beast such as a

It has also been

Source: Constitution of NZ Dog Trial Assoc
Quote:
A dog may be excused
for biting a sheep's

up and refuses to

When the milker has

The Maoris were

I had just got one

Intent on following

Author: O'Sullivan

She remembered

men thought to know

"Falling off is nature's way of telling you you've found your limit," is a philosophical definition of a very pertinent problem to readers of Classic New Zealand Mountain Bike Rides..." Other expressions for the same event, listed in the glossary, are airborne and bail-out.

Author: SHARPE

the forest fringe.

Author: JOHNSTONE-SMITH
Quote:
Bailers are dogs

Author: CARR

Now this is where I

Mine were holding

asking Tony whether

something like an
ear, a leg, or a

keep the mob bailed
up.

Author: HULME
Quote: One thing everybody does know about the Coast is bait. Whitebait. That succulent little fish, quick and lucent, likened in an old haiku to the `spirit of the waters'... When it's a good season, tons are lovingly packed into freezers against the lean, non-bait portion of the year. Ibid. 38 Take half a pound of bait per person, add an egg (two eggs, if you really like them), stir vigorously until fish and egg is a viscous froth full of strange little eyes.

Author: McGILL
Quote: bait layer cook in army; originally station cook. NZA

These furrows have
been made by the

Work started this
year, with the first

kilometres of tracks
built, 1000 bait

Bait stations,

Private land owners

The open farmland

hand using a range

Big Tom McDonald,

In connection with

Quote: Bakshee lance-jack. A lance-corporal: military (esp. Australians' and New Zealanders'): in G.W. 2. Spg Bakchsceach [? F. WW1 : reference here to 1920s.] bakshee leave unofficial or unapproved leave.

conjures up the

punters, who backed

last race. It is
also known as
`balancing'.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Baldy! I refuse (cf English schoolboy's `fain I'): NZ juvenile: late C19-20. B., 1941. No hairs on one's head: nothing to offer.

Author: TURNER
Quote: ... the way to ask for a truce in a game is to call Pax ... At the school I went to, the word was Fritz, and the truce was terminated by the call Fritz all over, but we knew that some schools used Fans (from south-west English dialect fain I or fainits?. Apparently some New Zealand schools use or have used baldy which sounds like a variant of English barley.

Author: BAKER
Quote: Other twentieth century New Zealand expressions of varied use include baldy! a schoolboy term synonymous with the English fain I implying refusal.

was in for a bit
when work began
round the Donald's
woolpress, this very
press where.. dad..
having compressed
laboriously a bale
of wool, knocked off
the top of the press
without sewing down
the top of the bale.

[Hdg] The
Wool-Dumping
Charges... That the
present charge for
dumping wool be
reduced at once from
2s to 1s 9d per
bale.

All the wool clip,
about 17 bales, was
lost.

Author: McNAB
Quote: [The Minerva brought up] 4 bales wool, shorn from the back of sheep at Mayna [Mana] N.Z. and the first imported into this Colony [N.S.W.].
Notes: 1838 Aug 16 Cargo Statements in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 224

Quote:
When these bales
were tightly packed,
pressed, sewn up,
weighed and marked
with the station
stencil, they were
rolled off to the
side of the shed.

Author: ANTHONY
Quote:
I worked out a
year's profits on
paper, making a
rough guess at.. the
number of bales of
wool.

Author: MARSH
Quote:
He would truss the
body, then clear the
tramped wool out of
the pack,.. then
open the front of
the press and get
the body into the
bale.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote: Kath was sitting on a bale of wool beside Mr Smith. Ibid. 154 A detective was looking round a wool and skin buyer's.. and happened to notice the Algidus brand on two bales.

The use of the jute
bale.. does not seem
merely inadvisable.

Read bale feeder,
flat floor very good
condition ...

Double sided big
bale feeders - 3
point linkage for
the farmer who
prefers to feed out
both sides.

Author: WHITE ET AL NZ
Quote:
Bale parks, located
in a corner of a
paddock or along a
fenceline and
protected from stock
by an electric
fence, are now a
common sight
throughout New
Zealand. In a bale
park with a first
tier two bales wide,
a second tier one
bale wide may be
placed on top with
minimal risk of
collapse.

A bale park is a
place where
plastic-wrapped hay
etc is kept.

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
When the bale is
branded enter up on
the bale sheets its
number, grade and
contents. If these
two last points are
not watched, a big
muddle can be made
of a wool clip.

To overcome the
trouble, Messrs
Donald and Sons of
Masterton have
placed on the market
a patent bale
singer. The Donald
woolpack and bale
singer is designed
for removing loose
fibre etc from
woolpacks.

For Sale -
self-loading bale
wrapper.

For sale - new bale
wrappers.

The goats are fed
fresh-cut grass and
lucerne, red clover
and lucerne balage,
grass silage and
palm kernel extract
seven or eight times
a day.

October usually
yields silage
haylage and baleage.
More mature grass is
harvested in
November and
December as hay.

[Hdg] Hay baleage
for a hay buggy...
suitable for hay or
baleage

You'll be starting
to wonder which
paddocks you will be
able to shut up for
sileage baleage or
even hay.

Author: WOODHOUSE
Quote: balehooks
Notes: 1940 Geo Meek `Wool Commander' in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 152

Quote:
Later,I remember the
great excitement
when Dave Benge's
baler came for the
first time making
light work of hay
previously dried and
thrown by fork up
into a stack.

Author: CRANNA
Quote:
We worked together
into the clear
evenings after the
baler had left the
paddocks.

There are always
those ever-present
dangers; some
ghastly exotic
disease from Africa
or "Bali belly" from
Asia ending up in
the middle of a
raging warzone; or
simply tripping over
and twisting your
ankle after a tad
too much Fosters on
the other side of
the Tasman.

Author: BOWMAN
Quote:
His seventy years as
a yachtsman
commenced as "baling
boy" for Wm. Innes..

In this land two
infections assail
all comers and vie
with one another for
first place. These
are known as Malaria
and Balkan Tap
respectively. On the
first we need not
dwell, but a little
information about
the latter may be of
interest. A similar
infection has been
met with elsewhere,
and in Gyppo Land is
known as `magnune',
whilst away in our
own sunny island I
think `dippy' about
covered it. Here we
have a more or less
insidious form of
the disease, and no
one with six months'
residence to his
credit may hope to
escape. There are
two varieties of the
disease, malignant
and benign. In the
latter form the
symptoms are easily
recognised, and are
amenable to
treatment; but with
the malignant type
the victims, quite
unconscious of
infection, blindly
affirm their
condition to be
normal, This form of
the malady has
several unfortunate
features and is
incurable. The
percentage in our
unit is very high.

Author: CHAPMAN
Quote:
The fight we had
been in quest of had
made their
appearance at nine
that morning and had
been at long balls
with the Pa all day
and were just then
retired.

Author: CHURCHILL
Quote:
For the purpose of
turning the breach
to fullest account,
an entirely new
corps, the 10th, was
formed, consisting
of two British
armoured divisions
and the New Zealand
Division - that
`ball of fire' as it
was described to me
by those who had
seen it at work.

Author: SOLJAK
Quote:
In the great Eighth
Army attack of
November 1, the New
Zealand Division,
with two British
armored [sic]
divisions, comprised
the Tenth Corps.
This `ball of fire',
as Montgomery
described it, broke
through on a front
of four miles ...

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
Ball of fire. 2. As
the Ball of Fire:
the 2nd New Zealand
Division: Army in
North Africa:
1941-3.

How does that help
us who roll the old
ball of fire?

When you whose union
see the world ablaze
/ New Zealand's
"Ball of Fire."

In England, not long
before I left, I
heard someone say
that the New
Zealanders were a
'ball of fire'. It
was said by someone
quite impartial.
[Winston Churchill
speaking to the NZ
troops].
(phrase). descriptive of vigour, good health e.g. to feel like a ball of muscle.

Author: SARGESON
Quote: ball: a ball of muscle, fit and energetic.

Author: LELAND
Quote: ball of muscle: usually referring to children: (A) a BALL OF FIRE (complimentary) (B)a hyperactive child (derogatory) Which of the two meanings is employed, depends more on the circumstances than the child.

Author: PLUMMER
Quote:
For three years I
was known as the
chief ball-puller,
or as some people
would say, the chief
ball-sucker.

Equipment used for
emasculating stock -
ball-puller.

Ballarat Seedling:
VARIETIES ... Apples
... Ballarat
Seedling ...
Cleopatra ... Rome
Beauty ...

Source: Mark Twain in Aust and NZ
Quote:
This morning we had
one of those
whizzing green
Ballarat flies in
the room, with his
stunning buzz-saw
noise- the swiftest
creature in the
world ... The New
Zealand may thank
Governor Darling for
having
squelched.[part lost
check orig: not in
BL333a] ?express
train is called the
Ballarat Fly [sc.
the main trunk
train].

Author: WOOD
Quote:
He lit a candle, and
dropped it into the
Ballarat lantern,
and away they went.
[fn] For the benefit
of the unitiated, I
may explain that a
`Ballarat lantern'
is formed by
knocking off the
bottom of a bottle,
and putting a candle
in its neck.

Author: BOREHAM
Quote:
[Reference 1850s]
More than once he
[Selwyn] rushed,
half-clothed, into
some little bush
settlement at dead
of night. In his
hand was a ballarat
- an impromptu
lantern, consisting
of an inverted
bottle with the
bottom broken off,
and a [104] candle
fixed in the neck.

Author: BEGG
Quote:
At the Auckland
Islands in 1864
Captain Thomas
Musgrave noticed
female sealions
disgorging small
pebbles which he
thought must have
been picked up
inadvertently while
catching fish on the
sea floor. ... The
practical sealers
believed that the
stones served to
adjust the buoyancy
of the animals and
referred to the
stone-filled stomach
of the fur seal as
the `ballast bag'.

... a hole left
after excavation of
metal for railway,
quarter-acre
gorse-infested old
ballast-pit sections
are to be sold by
auction shortly.
[check]

Author: MARRINER
Quote:
...I have to wonder
how much face Joe
stands to lose
traipsing through
the party with four
'ballheads' in tow.

Author: KEITH & MAIN
Quote:
Marbles were the
currency of
childhood and there
were an astonishing
number of names for
them, some referring
to the material or
colour, others to
value or function in
the game. There were
agates, aggies,
American alleys,
blood alleys,
bomb-squashers,
bonies, bonsers,
bottlies, bull's
eyes, bum-squashers,
cats-eye, chinkies,
connies, duckies,
eggies, glassies,
Greeks, milkies,
mollies, peelies,
peewees, pisswees,
pretties, Scotties,
smokies, stinkies,
stonies, stripies,
tom-bobblers and
whities. The march
of technology added
ball bearings -
ballies or steelies
- which were
unbeatable when it
came to smashing an
opponent's miserable
glassie. World War
II brought `clayeys'
often imperfectly
spherical they were
pathetic terracotta
substitutes for real
marbles.

Author: SARGESON
Quote: balloon: The balloon came down. The balloon is raised above the number-board by the finishing-post to indicate to the starter that the Tote is closed. It is lowered when the Tote is balanced to indicate that the race can begin.

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
The tote closed. The
balloon went up. The
light low sulkies
flew round the
course.

However, the balloon
is down for both
stocks. In the days
before modern
communications at
the races, a balloon
signalled that the
tote was open. When
it went up it was a
sign that the tote
was closed and the
horses were ready to
race. And as very
punter knew, when
the balloon fell
your money remained
at risk until the
race ended and the
winner was declared.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: GLOBE-FISH Contusus richei (Freminville) ... It has several other popular names such as Balloon-fish and Mouse-fish. In America it is known as Rabbit-fish and Stink-fish. The most humorous name is that of Publican-fish. The names Globe-fish and Balloon-fish were given because of the animal's habit of inflating itself with air to such an extent that the body was like a lamp globe or an inflated balloon.

Author: WILSON
Quote: BALLOONFISH: see Globefish Ibid. BALLOONFISH: see Globefish Ibid. 115 [GLOBE-FISH] ... Other names include Toado, Balloon-fish, Mouse-fish, (N.Z.) Rabbit-fish and Stink-fish (U.S.); and Publican-fish (Aust). Gives off an offensive odour when handled.

[index to common

the play.. starts

he has been

They chased after
ballot farms without

Author: BURDON
Quote:
A hunt Alan and I
did together on a
farm which was
overrun with bambas.

I notice whenever
pork comes in, it's
always referred to
as pig, and I've
certainly heard
venison called
Bambi.
native bamboo ...

Coastal cliffs are

Zealand Bamboo,
<i>Microlaena
polynoda, </>...

Author: GRACE
Quote:
There was a problem
... almost
bamfoozled me.

Incidentally, the
only anti-Chinese
sentiment I've heard
of came from
foreign-born Chinese
against a young
NZ-born Chinese male
who was offended by
being called a
banana "yellow on
the outside, white
on the inside."

Of course it could
end up he's
performing to
ex-pats or what he
calls Bananas -
Asians who are
yellow on the
outside but white in
the middle.

She grew up as a
nana, white on the
inside.

Spencer has also
talked about.. how
he has borrowed from
the leaguies and
their use of the
"banana bender" off
the side of the
boot.

Howlett's first try
came via an
outrageous Joey
Johns-style banana
kick...

Spencer has produced
some of his best
displays there,
engineering the
banana kick and knee
lob.

The latest term
[picked up by
commentators] is the
"banana kick", which
they apply when the
ball is struck off
the side of the
boot... A banana
kick is where the
ball deviates in
mid-air, like a
banana, a la David
Beckham or Roberto
Carlos, the current
most famous
exponents of a
technique long
mastered in soccer.

There was still the
dazzling Spencer
flair: the banana
kick, the no-look
backhand flips, the
stratospheric
snow-covered punts.

The banana
passionfruit plant
may not sound as
terrifying as the
varroa jacobsoni bee
mite or the Asian
gypsy moth, but
Wellington Regional
Council is worried
about the spread of
the pestilent
foreign weed.

Along with such
widely accursed
creepers as old
man's beard,
wandering willie and
barbary, are
sentimental
favourites: heather,
banana passionfruit,
lantana, cathedral
bells, Mexican
daisies and climbing
asparagus.

The plant known as
the banana
passionfruit, P.
mollissima (syn.
Tacsonia mollissima)
is grown commonly in
Australia.

Author: CARR
Quote:
The mills carry
their own forkers,
band-cutter, weigher
and bagman (one
man), and sewer and
stacker.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
band cutter: the man
who feeds the
threshing mill. He
cuts each sheaf band
as he does so.

Whitebait are the
juveniles of our
migratory galaxiid
fishes. These
scaleless fish
species include the
inanga (around much
of the country),
banded kokopu
(especially around
Auckland) and koaro
(especially in
streams draining
bush-covered and
mountain areas.

Author: McDOWALL
Quote: Much less common is the banded kokopu (Galaxias fasciatus) sometimes known as Maori trout or native trout... Some whitebaiters refer to it as "golden bait". IBid. 49 Banded kokopu are also aggressive migrants, climbing high falls and penetrating substantial distances inland, reaching localities that seem inaccessible.

Now they are once
again an undisturbed
habitat for such
creatures as the
banded kokopu. This
native fish hides by
day under
overhanging bush,
emerging at night to
lie in wait for
prey, typically the
larvae of aquatic
insects, or land
invertebrates, such
as caterpillars and
spiders, that fall
into the water.
Banded kokopu (G. fasciatus) and koaro (G. brevipinnis) constitute the bulk of remainder [sic], with very few giant kokopu and shortjaw kokopu being caught.

The banded kokopu is
another whitebait
species reaching 26
cm. Its habitat is a
pool in a small
bush-covered stream
which may be a
considerable [73]
altitude and
distance from the
sea.

Author: DENNIS
Quote: The juveniles of five species of galaxias make up the whitebait catch: inanga (Galaxias maculatus), koaro (G. brevipinnis), banded kokopu (G. fasciatus), giant kokopu (G. argenteus) and short-jawed kokopu (G. postvectis).

The banded kokopu is
another whitebait
species reaching 26
cm. Its habitat is a
pool in a small
bush-covered stream
which may be a
considerable [73]
altitude and
distance from the
sea.
Banded kokopu Galaxias fasciatus Widely distributed in forest streams and swamps. Small amber-coloured whitebait.

On the West Coast,
the season runs from
September 1 till
November 14 to
improve the minor
late-running
species' chance of
reaching coastal
wetlands for giant
kokopu, or
forest-covered
streams for
short-jawed and
banded kokopu, and
koaro.
[caption] Under water: Native fish found in the region's [Wellington] rivers and streams are, clockwise from top left, inanga, redfin bully, torrent fish, banded kokopu, giant kokopu and kaoro.

Inanga are the most
common species, but
whitebaiters may
also capture the
young of giant
kokopu, koaro and
banded kokopu.
"Shortjaw and giant
kokopu are described
as threatened
species. ..."

Big flocks of ducks
had been reported in
the Bay of Plenty,
and in the eastern
region the council
had banded mallard,
grey duck and
paradise shellduck.

Trachypteridae] are

and also oar-fish.

... bus barns for
housing diesel and
trolley-buses.

Jane Godfrey, My
father used to tell
(c 19..) us to
bandicoot about a
bit when he wanted
us to dig out bits
of earth (say around
a post) with our
hands, sort of
pulling the earth
towards the side of
the hole, softening
it, etc.

Another was also
proud of the growth
of his potatoes but
highly amazed and
full of anger when
upon digging them up
he found virtually
nothing underneath.
He was unaware that
some bright sparks
had on one night
bandicooted his
spuds. Bandicooting
as it was called,
was done by
scratching away the
dirt from the spuds,
taking them from
underneath the tops
and replacing the
mulch and everything
looked normal.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
No wonder they
raided the farmer's
orchards, pinched
his eggs and
bandycooted his
potatoes and
vegetables.

Even better was
'bandicooting',
tickling and
scratching under the
plant to extract the
little "newies" to
see if they were big
enough to dig.

Author: HAWES
Quote:
And although his
legs had been a bit
bandy when you saw
him in his shorts,
he was the fastest
boy in the school,
and was very good at
the hop, skip and
jump.

Author: LANCASTER
Quote:
`A dashed
cattle-puncher, I
tell you. He nailed
forty of my calves,
and banged 'em along
with his own mob
'fore I could get on
his trail.'
Notes: 1902 Lancaster Our Lady of the Plains in 1987 Happy Endings 103

Quote:
I think any boy that
works hard on a farm
should get a couple
of holidays a year
if he is "banging
cows."

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
`I don't believe in
gambling.' ...
`Leave the boy
alone,' said a
grey-headed
rollsman. `It's not
hois fault. His old
man's always banging
the Bible.' `Banging
the bishop more
likely,' Gandhi

Spare me it's [sc.

For the past two

The 80 stores would

For Guy Fawkes we

Only people with a

able to purchase

relate to any

principally on
percussion for their

basically include

Some years ago big
"bangers" were
prohibited because
the Government liked
the future citizens
to be as complete as
possible.

The 200 men who

road in 1929 were
armed with tools
ancient Egyptians

wheelbarrows, picks,
and round shovels
the locals call

He performed the

Waihi-Tauranga

specially

varnished `banjo' of

orthodox No. 5 size.

The use of the pick
and `banjo' (as the

useful
accomplishment.

It's a long time
since you handled a
`banjo'.
A banjo: A shovel.

.. a part of the

[fn] long tom: long

crow: large

Quote: banjo shovels special coal shovels with a large round blade. Ibid. 36 ... the gold miners enter ... carrying ... shovels. Their shovels are different from the `banjo' shovels of the coal-miners.

Despite all the
advances in mining
technology that have
happened since men
hewed the coal seams
in these hills with
picks and the broad,
rounded shovels
known as "banjos" a
centruty ago, the
traditional

shift (3-11) and dog
shift (11-7).

See me in a dirty

(with red down the
sides like a
postman), sandbags
for puttees and
hobnail boots,
without a wash or a
shave for five days,
swinging a pick or a
long-handled
'banjo'.

(shovel).

Quote: The job took a lot out of a man, that hard slog at the face with a pick, the laborious shovelling with the wide-mouthed banjo. Ibid.. 128 You filled the tub [with coal], shoving the big banjo into the soft heap at your feet ... Ibid. (Glossary) 242 banjo coal shovel

banjo ... n. (Slang) a shoulder of mutton, also a frying pan. -->(also thus in one of the Collins Contemps) banjo ... n. (Sl.) shoulder of mutton; frying pan; a shovel, hence on the banjo, to be working on the roads.

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
Sometimes, perhaps
half a dozen times
in a year, the river
is what is called
bank and bank; that
is to say, one mass
of water from one
side to the other.

I heard the Rakaia
was bank and bank so
I went to Harman's
to see O.Brien.

bank and bank. A river runs bank and bank when all the streams join into one; i.e., when in high flood (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 73). Hence a banker. The expressions were probably introduced by the shagroons. [Morris Austral English] gives a banker as meaning a river full to the top of its banks. New Zealand rivers, of course, do not get as full as that.

Author: PYKE
Quote:
The Dunstan gold

kinds - technically
known as `beach
claims' and `bank
claims'. The latter

miners sluiced away
bodily for ... the
golden grains
therein deposited.

Author: KITTO

If you are working a
bank claim it is
important that you
keep the hole or
paddock wide. ...
This can only be

Leaving Wellington

We are in a state of

I take a good deal
more notice of the
Bank of New Zealand
than I do of the
other banking
institutions. It is
for the reasons that
it is our own
national
establishment, and
every man, woman,
and child, is
interested in its
welfare and affected
by its management.
Virtually, it
belongs to the
public; the
shareholders,
nominally the
proprietors, are
merely trustees. My
view may be extreme
on this point but I
believe the day is
not far distant when
the people of New
Zealand will take
possession of that
bank in their own
name, and tax all
the others out of
the country - a
protection policy
that would pay well.

Unfortunately where
we don't have
naturally strong
enough bankage we
currently need to
intervene... We have
a responsibility to
ensure these areas
are managed well to
make sure banks and
bankage protection
works will do their
job during a flood.

He sells more than

The Bankdam Romney

for milk, fertility
and growth, and for

It is important to
start planning how

feed.

Author: HECTOR
Quote:
The wash everywhere
resting on
water-worn bars and
ledges of
greenstone.

(j) That on a
favourable bottom
gold will lodge on
the down side of a
bar of rock running
across the bed of a
stream.

In the Thames
district the
distance between the
numerous parallel
veins which traverse
the goldfield seldom
exceeds 200 yards,
and in almost every
instance the veins
are separated from
each other by a
narrow belt of hard
unaltered andesite.
These hard bands, or
`bars' as the miners
term them, possess
the same general
strike and dip as
the veins ...

The country rock separating two veins approximately parallel with each other has, in certain instances, been found to grade laterally from the vein-wall, where it assumes a highly propylitic facies, to a median rib of dark and only slightly altered rock. These ribs or dyke-like masses are the `hard bars' of the miners. In some cases, however, these `hard bars' are probably due to dykes. Ibid. 111The `hard bars' of mining terminology are in most cases merely remnants of less-altered rock, but occasionally as in the case of the `bar' mentioned in the Golden Pah mine, they owe their existence to intrusives.

Further, the `hard'
bars most probably
interrupted the
shoot, more of less
horizontally.

... she came out to

bar ... 21. won't have a bar of. Austral. & N.Z. inf. cannot tolerate; dislike.

camp, known as the
`barbed wire',
behind which she
remained until she
received a clean
[49] bill of health.

Author: PUGSLEY
Quote:
Those inflicted with
venereal disease
were treated as
criminals.(?) A
large venereal
disease hospital was
established near the
Australian lines and
run by the
Australians for both
Australians and New
Zealanders. It was
surrounded by barbed
wire and guards to
prevent men breaking
out. Men unfortunate
enough to be so
caught earned the
sobriquet `barbed
wire' soldiers: `and
it was rumoured that
there were
sufficient officers
and men to form a
whole battalion from
colonel down - not
omitting the padre.'

Author: BARR
Quote:
They have a
prevailing wind at
Greymouth called
"The Barber" which
sweeps down the
Otira Gorge and
smites the
inhabitants hip and
thigh... a keen
biting wind which
cuts like a
sabre-thrust, nips
like an ant, and
stings like a
whip-lash.`What do
you think of `The
Barber'?' in
Greymouth is
synonymous with
`What do you think
of our harbour?' in
Sydney ...

The wind coming off
the river was so
sharp it was called
The Barber, and it
could shave off your
hangover in brisk,
terrible seconds.

There is a wind in
Westland.. so much
colder than freezing
point that they
nickname it "The
Barber".

The wind you get in
Greymouth, the one
they call the
Barber, which slices
along the Grey River
and is so sharp that
it can cure any
hangover known to
man.

A very bitter cold
wind which blows
down the gorge of
the Mawhera and
afflicts the river
front, railway
station, and
adjacent streets of
Greymouth. The
miners and drovers
used the word in the
'sixties, and it is
still in use.
(C.[1890-1910])

Author: PUGH-WILLIAMS
Quote:
A very cold,
slow-moving wind
that comes down to
Greymouth from the
inland of a winter
evening and then
recedes the
following day. It
brings foggy
conditions and is
most unpleasant. I
am unaware of its
origin but locals
inform me that it is
nowhere as bad as
some 20 years ago,
their theory being
that so much of the
bush is cut out with
the result that
rain-saturated
foliage is not
exposed for
fog-generating.

Author: PEARSON

This day was clear.
There was a frost on
the grass in the
morning, and a
`barber' - the keen
wind and night mist
blowing down from
the Grey Valley -
was pushing across
Blakestown ... and
disappearing over
the sea.

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote: There are several local names for winds, the doctor in Perth, ... the barber in Greymouth, N Z, a very cuttng wind, the Canterbury nor'wester resembling the European Fo[diereis]hn wind, ... and the three-day sou'wester in New Zealand, a form of the southerly buster, a name used in both Australia and New Zealand, probably more often in the shortened form a [sic] southerly.
Barber, the n. Greymouth, N.Z. term for a bitter, cold wind.

Quote:
When the word is

feel over the sheep,

shearing-floor, and
commence shearing.
Naturally, the
easiest-shorn sheep
-- `bare-bellies'
and `bare points' --
are selected first.
It is amusing to
watch the tactics of
some of the shearers
to dodge the Kapara
(Cobbler) the last
sheep in the pen,
which, presumably,
is the worst
shearing sheep of
the lot.

Baroona is a funny name for a beer... it is associated with seasickness in the minds of many who squatted in its scrawny, diesel-filled guts, while it pitched and rolled its way across the Waitemata in search of Waiheke Island. Baroona was that ferry, now it is the name of Waiheke Island's one and only beer. There was a time when the residents of some Hauraki Gulf slands referred to the need to regurgitate after a bout of over-indulgence as "gotta have a baroona".

The team a person

barrack... v. in Australia , loudly jeer, banter or criticise in chorus the players of a game; support, cheer; in .N.Z. to encourage, not jeer at. [Prob. from Kiddie language, barrakin, confusion, gibberish; Fr. baraquinier, to jabber].
barrack 2 vb. Brit. & Austral. inf. 1. to criticize loudly or shout against (a team, speaker, etc.); jeer.

Baŕ.rack (b&abreve.ŕ.rak), v. i. [Said to be fr. aboriginal borak banter, badinage; but cf. Prov. Eng. barrackbrag, barracker a braggart. See BARRACK, v. t., BORAK, n. 1. To cheer, shout, or make a din, by way of partisan encouragement or derision, especially at a football game. 2. To give partisan support in any way; as, to barrack for the school. [Colloq.]

Author: SMYTH

`You cut along

Opposition doesn't

to barrack and yell
because, like badly
behaved boys, they
cannot take the

given."
Baŕ.rack, v. t. To deride; to decry by popular clamor. Colloq.]

barrack... v. in Australia , loudly jeer, banter or criticise in chorus the players of a game; support, cheer; in N.Z. to encourage, not jeer at. [Prob. from Kiddie language, barrakin confusion, gibberish; Fr. baraguinier, to jabber].

~ n. shouting and cheering in chorus with a view to encouraging or discouraging one of the participants in a game, such as cricket. - barracker n.- to barrack for v.i. to clamour for; to support or discourage noisily. [Abor. borack, chaff at another's expense]

Vigorous vocal

, e.g. cricket or

physical skill.
`Barracking' also
includes
sternly-voiced
rebukes to the

fair praise for them

skill. .in 4;`Come

off his back! Get
off his back. The
bastard. See that.
Oh! Oh! All he needs
is a pair of spurs!'

Author: McKAY
Quote:
Barracks, as cadet
training was called,
took place early in
his first term, from
the nineteenth to
the twenty-second of
February. ... with
khaki replacing the
school uniform
during barracks, and
on the days for
cadet training
throughout the rest
of the year Baxter
stood out by
appearing in civvies
on the bus, at
assembly, and during
classes.

Barracks were held
in the week
following Easter,
and culminated in a
miniature battle on
Mt Victoria for the
infantry and
machine-gun practice
at Trentham.

Source: History of Waitaki Boys High School
Author: McDONALD
Quote: The second camp, which lasted four days and was held in April was more correctly a "barracks", the boys sleeping in the school buildings. Ibid 234 The Cadet Corps continued to carry out its programme of weekly parades and annual barracks.

Children marching
into class to "the
Invercargill March",
Barracks Week at
secondary schools,
compulsory military
training and the
influence of the RSA
were all considered
normal and
appropriate.

Source: History of Waitaki Boys High School
Author: McDONALD
Quote:

Author: SANGSTER
Quote:
The "barracks" week
the School under
military
administration and
usually immediately
after Easter -
stuttered along from
about 1917 with
occasional gaps of
three or four years
until from 1930
(when cadets were
"astonished" to fall
under a military
regime in the first
week) it became a
regular feature,
though remarkably
often curtailed by
adverse weather.

Besides cod, there

barracoutas.

The barracouta is in

lure] if in a

If you're a saint,

attenuated
tape-worms, and

after being taken
from the body of the
fish.

Baracoota hook

The Moriori used wooden fishhooks but only for kahawai and manga (`barracouter' Thyrsites atun). The `barracouter' hook is a canoe-shaped bit of wood inlaid on the one side with a strip of bright shell of Haliotis.

His book included an
account of
"barrelling", or
organised
beatings... The
cadet said time and
place of barrelling
would be spread
among the cadets,
and the staff would
disappear. A cadet
of the early 1880s,
Mike, describes a
"lesser barrelling",
which involved being
tied to a bed, taken
outside and leaned
up against a wall.
Shaving cream,
toothpaste, nugget
and even excrement
were rubbed on the

hosed off.
Notes: 1980s not 1880s presumably (and he would be very hosed off I should imagine) TD

Quote:
Justice Morris says
some of the 81
former cadets he
interviewed told him
of instances of
physical and sexual
abuse including:
nuggetting,
spooning,
barrelling, beatings
and kicking, verbal
abuse, extortion,
forced showering,
cigarette burns, and
beatings with brooms
and rifles.

Barrelling: Forcing
a cadet to run the
gauntlet of other
cadets, who punch
and hit him.

The tag name
'Barrier skink' was
given to these
skinks. These
'Barrier skinks'
were medium to large
in size (reaching up
to 81 mm SVL [snout
to vent length],
179mm TL, and
weighting up to 12.1
g.) they were mainly
black dorsally and
laterally, with
yellowish, green,
cream or brown
flecks, and white
ventrally, with
occasional black
speckles...
Notes: http://csl.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/drds304.pdf Alpine lizard research in Fiordland National Park: February - March 2007. Bell, T.P.; Patterson, G.; Jewell, T. 2008. DOC Research & Development Series 304 NZ Dept of Conservation, Wellington.

Barrow.- To shear or partly shear a sheep for a shearer. `No barrowing allowed on the board' was at one time a rule which the Shearers' Union got into the award. Boys often finish or begin a sheep for a shearer, who, of course, is responsible for its being properly shorn. (C.)
barrow 4 v.i. NZ & Austral. complete the shearing of a sheep for a shearer. [orig. unkn.]
sc. of wild pig : barrowing was going on in 1850 Being out of meat we sallied forth to the chase and caught 2 boars and 1 barrow near the `Eaikuku'.

[=pig], While both
barrows and boars,
and sows by the
scores/ Cut their
sticks with the wind
at their tail./

Quote:

which has been

often catch young
pigs and perform

barrow 3 n. NZ & Austral. castrated male pig. [OE]

As far as capital
for breaking in the
land was concerned,
Jack was in the same

of the bush
settlers; he just
didn't have any.

Barrow - to shear or
partly shear a sheep
for a shearer.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
barrow: to begin or
finish a sheep for a
shearer. The
practice of bellying
a sheep so that a
shearer can time his
catch is unfair to
others, and if it is
finished for him and
is done poorly he
has to bear the
responsibility.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
He may, in order to
time this catch,
have previously
chosen a rosella or
perhaps someone had
barrowed one for
him.

Each of the other

'barrowing' for

The following day,
Jim (later Sir
Eruera [Tirikatene])
became my
`barrow-boy' and
washed and dried my
used gear each run
for the privilege of
shearing the first
sheep.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
The wool rollers and
fleece pickers who
were paid by the
week spent the smoko
spell resting. Some
of the more
energetic tried
their hand at
shearing, a practice
known as
`barrowing'. Usually
these sheep went to
the learner['s
tally] or to any of
the older or slower
shearers.
barrowing: A term to describe the action of a shed hand who finishes off a sheep for a shearer after the bell has gone for the end of a run.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote: There were always a number of `barrowmen' and `learners' ... [fn] Friends of the shearers who came onto the board for a chat and, while yarning, frequently shore a few sheep for their pals. Ibid. 129 There were always a certain number of `barrowmen' and `learners' on the board, ... [fn] Friends of the shearers, who came on to the board for a chat and, while yarning, frequently shore a few sheep for their pals.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
There was always a
certain number of
'barrowmen' and
'learners' on the
board, and some of
the old shearers had
no conscience where
the beginners were
concerned.

Years ago, in a
callow, Barry Crump
phase of youth, he
accidentally shot a
native duck for a
campfire dinner.

Then caver ingenuity
came to the rescue
in the form of
Hamilton
speleologist Barry
Weir. Weir came up
with a 100w helmet
light set like a
cherry in an
aluminium throwaway
pie dish which when
charged will give
20-30 minutes'
illumination. These
45c battery-powered
devices even
provided light when
caving divers went
underwater ... The
device has been so
successful it has
been used
subsequently. The
inventor now has his
name in lights.
Crews in Dunedin
refer to them as
`Barry lights'.

There are ten native
species of rata in
New Zealand all in
the genus
Metrosideros. Four
of these form trees
(northern rata,
southern rata,
Bartlett's rata and
Parkinson's rata)
and the remaining
six species are all
lianes.

Hundreds of people
voted in the New
Zealand Plant
Conservation
Network's annual
quest for the
country's favourite
native plant ..
Bartlett's rata got
the vote because it
was less "boring"
than its relative
the pohutukawa ...

The tree ratas
include the
widespread northern
rata and southern
rata and the rare
North Cape
Metrosideros
bartletti,
distinguished by its
small white flowers.
The critically threatened Bartlett's rata (Metrosideros bartletti) grows at the very tip of the North Island, with only 30 adult trees remaining of this species.

Bartlett's rata
(Metrosideros
bartletti) grow at
the very tip of the
North Island only 30
adult trees remain
of this species
[sic].

The rarest of New Zealand's 12 species of Metrosideros was discovered less than 20 years ago by Papakura teacher and botanist the late John Bartlett... Like the northern rata, M. robusta, Bartlett's rata usually starts life as an epiphyte perched in the branches of another tree or ponga... Although some of New Zealand's shrub ratas have white flowers, this species is the only tree to have them.

Without dedicated
effort and intrepid
plant "hunters",
such as those who
make up the New
Zealand Plant
Conservation
Network, we might
never enjoy such
strange and
wonderful sights as
.. the blaze of
late-spring blaze
[sic] of Barrett's
[sic] rata
Metrosideros
bartlettii
(nationally
critical).

... in 1900 wooden
gates were being

of the `Taranaki'

Author: DAVIN

`The working class
can kiss my arse,
I've got a bludger's
job at last,' sang
Smithy to the tune

`All the boys sing

pass Bludger's Hill.

... `Almost makes a

nice quiet life.
Nothing to do except
get up in the
morning and get the
shaving water, make
the bed, polish some
buttons to keep away
from parade, queue
for a feed, siesta,
tea, a beer at the
Naafi in the
evening, a game of
two-up and so to
bed'.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
`I tell ya I know a
bit about the
Luger', I reply ...
`You wouldn't get
close enough to the
sharp end to see
one', he snaps.
`Base walloper I
bet. Bet you never
even seen one'.

two-timin',
