Author: TURNER
Quote: In New Zealand, the term bash for a party where drink is the chief attraction is heard (or was, some years ago among Wellington students) and hophead for a person who drinks regularly. The term hophead is (or was) used in convivial greetings, `Hello, hophead', the implication that the person addressed was a persistent drinker being equivalent to calling him a decent joker.

There was little
sign of panic and in
one nearby building
a group of elderly
people continued
their Christmas bash
for several hours
before police
quietly removed
them.

The resultant "bash"
was a beauty.

What he spent on
beer week-nights
would total no more
than what most
jokers spent on
their Saturday
bashes.
Notes: [OED2 1948 LF II 111 chk ref and cit](Ballantyne)

Quote:
`Hell, he has had a
bash,' said Cliff.
`Spent the whole
night on the tiles,
eh? ...'
An informal PARTY.

Author: MANTELL
Quote:
They tell me Breck
held his liquor
pretty well. Had to
be really tanked up
to show any signs.
That sounds like a
bash.
Bash: Wild uncontrolled blow by a shearer.

I've bashed about
the land some.

`Push', `bash',
`crash' occur pretty
frequently in
describing progress
in accounts of
tramping trips, and
tell a tale of scrub
and tangled bush.
We would stream bash or plod our way up the ridges. Ibid. 90 We dropped into the Arahura River valley and bashed over some of the biggest boulders I ever want to see.

At the first bluff
he sidled up the
spur but he got off
the discs and had to
bash through the
lawyers and
windfalls.

We put on full
wetsuits and
booties, with
freezing-workers'
gumboots and bash
hats fitted with
lights...

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
Take P.O.W. for
example. Everyone
had bashed up a duff
for himself at one
stage or another.

`... he was in my
class at school.'
`Sure, Rupert. You
remember. I used to
bash you up. Give
you the old Chinese
burn. You used to
enjoy it too.'

Kids getting "the
bash' from Mum and
Dad - these things
were the norm for a
significant number
of people around me.

...a five-year-old
talks of seeing
blood on the walls
and dragging his
brother to safety as
his mum "gets the
bash"...

Mr Harawira, who
earlier told Prime
Minister Helen
Cklark and her
ministers they had
got the "bash" at
Waitangi's Ti Marae,
might be loud and in
your face, but his
mum is the power
behind the show.

The incident also
sparked an emotional
response from
Associate Maori
Affairs Minister
John Tamihere, who
said there were
elements who had
already indicated
"that it's good for
the prime minister
to get the bash".

He was given a
chance. And blew it
- this time giving
his missus the bash
and threatening to
kill her.

It's fine to have a
fanatical bash-crash
merchant in midfield
but with all the
talent New Zealand
can field we need
rather more than
that in the middle.

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
BASHER. A shearer
who uses the above
type of blows.
[BASH. A wild
uncontrolled blow by
a shearer.]

Advt.] V.O.B. Basic
Slag is cheaper this
year. The value of
Slag Top-Dressing
need not be
stressed.

The relative merits
of superphosphate
and basic slag for
pasture top-dressing
are much discussed
in certain
districts,
particularly North
Taranaki and North
Auckland. Many
experienced farmers
are firmly of the
opinion that slagged
pastures have better
milk production and
fattening capacities
than ones treated
with superphosphate.
How much this may be
due to a greater
effect from slag,
how much to some
effect on the
mineral content of
the herbage, and how
much due to
management it is
impossible to say.

Mr E. M. Smith
stated before the
members of the Iron
and Steel Institute,
London, that the
slag from the
ironsand smelting
was worth 15s per
ton as a manure, and
it was quite equal
to the basic slag
from the furnaces at
Home.

SCOTIA BASIC SLAG is
absolutely the
cheapest Phosphoric
Acid available to
the farmers.

WE ARE NOW BOOKING
ORDERS FOR BASIC
SLAG, MADE IN
ENGLAND, IN LOTS TO
SUIT FARMERS TO BE
DELIVERED ABOUT JUNE
NEXT.

It is not correct
that import licenses
for basic slag for
the coming season
have been reduced.

The Court of
Arbitration... also
found that an adult
female worker should
have a basic wage of
GBP1 16s.

The fixing of the
basic wage by the
Court of Arbitration
at GBP3/16/- for men
at 21 years old and
GBP1/16/- for women
has provoked much
adverse comment.

The wage level will
remain below what it
ought to be, and
this is particularly
true of those on or
near the basic wage.

The Labour
Government.. decreed
that a [farm] cadet
be paid the basic
wage.

No good purpose
would be served by
attacking the basic
wage.

Everywhere they met
the same reply -
that they were not
learned in any trade
and therefore not
worth the basic
wage.

Author: GISBORNE
Quote:
... basils (tanned
sheep)
Basil: Tanned sheepskin used for the manufacture of light leather.

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
Reaching the end of
the walk, and things
just going fair, he
returned and again
said to the tall
Moree Myall, `You
are still cutting
too often - go
easy,' but the light
limbed Australian
continued to strip
the `Basil' from the
unfortunate stud ewe
he was shearing.
Standing by, the
Moree native engaged
in taking off the
trimmings around the
udder, then
deliberately swept
the glistening steel
of his razor shears
across the teats of
the stud ewe, and
deliberately shore
them off level with
the belly line.

The weight of the
irons is therefore
borne by the waist.
Leather `basils' are
worn by the
prisoners round the
ankle, to keep the
iron from chafing
the skin.
Notes: c1875 Otago Guardian in 1980 Tonkin Dunedin Gaol 27

Author: CROWE
Quote:
Basket fungus starts
off growing rather
like a puffball 3-4
cm wide, but later,
when the ball
bursts, a white
basket-like shape
breaks out... The
Maori ate the thick
gelatinous volva or
outer shell when
young and before it
burst.

Clathrus cibarius, THE `BIRD-CAGE FUNGUS'. ... This fungus, known variously as `basket fungus,'`lattice fungus,', `Devil's purse,' `tutae whetu,' `tutae kehua,' belongs to the Phallaceae, a family included in the Basidiomycetes. It is found commonly throughout New Zealand during the late autumn and early spring. [Distribution.- Australia; Chile; ... New Zealand]

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Matakupenga ... 3. Clathrus cibarium, net or basket fungus. = pukurau.

The Maori treated
unexpanded plants of
the basket fungus as
a great luxury.

Author: MARTIN
Quote: ... the Phalloids to which belong such conspicuous fungi as the SCARLET STINKHORN (Aseroe rubra) and the BASKET FUNGUS (Clathrus cibarius). [40]The BASKET FUNGUS or LATTICE FUNGUS spreads its globular latticed network a conspicuous white, slimy structure with an unpleasant odour, that never fails to amaze its beholders. Its miraculous and sudden appearance caused the ancient Maori to term it `thunder dirt'.

Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Quote: Clathrus cibarius, basket fungus.

[photo captions] (1)
Honey mushroom (2)
Red tobacco pouch
fungus (3) Violet
tobacco pouch fungi
... (5) Basket or
lattice fungus.

In the home garden,
a fairly common
fungus found in
potting mix, compost
and bark mulch is
the Ileodictyon
cibarius white
basket fungus. It
has an eerie,
skeletal appearance
and is fascinating
to watch grow.

At one stage of its
growth, the
open-look
basket-fungus,
Clathrus cibarius,
is edible.

A well attended
basket social was
held at the
residence of Mr. and
Mrs. P. Maclean,
Kelvin Road, Waimumu
on Friday evening,
...
Notes: in 1966 Barry In the Lee of the Hokonuis 363

Quote:
Basket social: a1949
North Auckland. As I
understood it a
function for making
money. People bring
a `basket' (in the
sense `Ladies, a
basket') of food
which is auctioned
and often
re-auctioned.

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
(Joe Gasparich,
Northland kauri
country), The way in
which the bush
people - the bushmen
and their wives -
stuck to one another
is shown by the way
they rallied round
in the case of a
family that was in
need. A common
method of raising
money was called a
`basket social'. A
hall would be used
for the function,
and the people of
the district would
be invited to bring
along baskets. Now
these baskets were
made of any material
at all at hand, and
it was remarkable
the ingenuity and
workmanship shown in
making them. ... In
the basket its maker
put a supper, the
food cooked at home
... [151] Now on the
night of the basket
social, all the
baskets would be
handed in ... They
would then be
auctioned, and the
purchaser of the
basket would have
the pleasure and the
honour of having
supper with the
provider of the
basket. ... Now I've
seen them pay twelve
... pounds in those
days for a basket,
just to make sure
that the girl of the
boy's choice saw
that he really meant
business. ... Every
penny of that would
go to the family in
need ...

Author: BATISTICH
Quote:
Basket socials were
always a stir [in
Northland c1920s].
... Basket socials
were the nearest we
got to bacchanalia -
tipsy cake in large
doses could have
strangely affecting
results. The baskets
were put up for
auction just before
the supper waltz;
highest bidder got
basket and girl -
the girl, sometimes
it turned out, for
life.

Author: BOSWEL
Quote: And then the mill workers organized a big basket social for us, and with the money they arranged a grand picnic. Ibid. 153 [pre WW1, Northland bush], A basket social took the form of a dance, with an auction of supper baskets. Each girl would make a pretty basket and fill it with good things for supper. When supper-time came, the baskets were auctioned from the stage and keen was the rivalry and competition for some of the baskets, young blades emptying their pockets and often dipping into their bank accounts in trying to out-bid their rivals.

A basket social and
dance.. for Maori
soldiers.. turned
out an unqualified
success.

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
A common method of
raising money was
called a 'basket
social'... The
people of the
district would be
invited to bring
along baskets. Now
these baskets were
made of any material
at all to hand... In
the baskets, the
maker put a
supper... Nobody
knew who was the
owner of the basket.
They would then be
auctioned.
basket-fence n.-basket-fence n. a stake hedge interwoven with pliant branches.
... even in the primers we were marched along the corridor to assembly ... The standards would parade around the upper basketball courts to the tune of Colonel Bogey, ...

For this race, they
made their bets on
"basketing night",
the previous
Thursday, when they
gathered to place
race rings on the
birds' legs and put
them into boxes for
Friday's truck
journey to Levin.

The basking shark is
very large, its
length ranging from
thirty to
thirty-five feet,
and it usually gives
from five to seven
barrels of oil,
sometimes much more.

The Sea-Serpent
..There are almost
as many and diverse
modes of explaining
him away and turning
him into a specimen
of a known marine
species - squid,
ribbon-fish, whale,
basking shark, etc.,
just as the
gradually awaking
senses of litle
Alice turned the
monstrous Red Queen
of Looking-glass
Land into a harmless
black domestic
kitten.

Notice of the Occurrence of the Basking Shark (Selache maxima, L.) in New Zealand.

The basking-shark, Cetorhinus maximus, is among the largest of living fishes. It is ... known from all oceans and all temperate zones. The name has been applied because of its peculiar habit of lying motionless in the sunshine on the surface.

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote:
BASS (v) Swindle.
British racecourse
slang. Late 19th
century.

The fishermen who go
out to the
100-150-fathom water
off [Otago]
frequently catch ...
a huge groper, which
they call `bass
groper', and which
seems to be
specifically
distinct from the
ordinary hapuka.
They say it is
common off
Wellington, and is
there known as
`black bass'. [216]
... I ... made
inquiries of local
[Wellington]
fish-merchants, and
learned that ...
from Kaikoura a
large groper was
occasionally
received, and was
called a `bass' ...

Polyprion americanus Bloch and Schneider. This deep-water representative of the genus is now identified by Waite ... with the wreck-fish of the Atlantic. It is occasionally taken outside Otago Heads, and is known by the local fishermen as `bass groper' or `black bass'.

Author: PARROTT
Quote:
Until 1911 the New
Zealand Bass was
considered to be a
deepwater form of
the common Groper or
Hapuka.

Author: BINNEY
Quote:
`Sea-bass; caught
the bugger out at
Awatuna Mouth on
Sunday,' said Les.

country was

The birch timber -
commonly known as
'bastard' birch -

bastard birch [=] kamahi [s]

Quote: Podocarpus ferruginea, Don. Miro, Bastard Black-pine of Otago, ornamental and useful tree; attains a height of 40-60 feet, trunk 2-3 feet in diameter. A useful wood, but not so durable as the matai or true black-pine wood
Miro (bastard black pine) .. Podocarpus ferruginea .. Wood hard, elastic, strong, and grain prettily figured; ... Ibid. 408 Miro (bastard black pine) slab.

DoZ.ry (d&omacr.Z.r&ybreve.), n. The fish. [Add.] Bastard dory (Zoo.l.), The Australian and Tasmanian name for the New Zealand boarfish (Cyttus Australis).

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
He's the real nigger
in the woodpile ...
Some of you jokers
ought to get off the
Head's back and have
a go at the real
bastard of the bush,
the self-appointed
headmaster.

The Peninsula
vocabulary was
notorious. ... [16]
Reminiscences of
panders' slang were
used with the
quaintest
inappositeness. But
pre-eminently the
word `bastard'
passed into common
use.

Source: For the Rest of Our Lives
Author: DAVIN
Quote:
You're an
extravagant bastard,
Tony.

Author: WILSON
Quote:
Dan Freel's
conversation was
plentifully
interlarded with
oaths and
obscenities that are
- or would have been
in the 80's - quite
unprintable. At
first it seemed an
arresting, if not an
interesting
idiosyncracy, but
one soon sickened of
it. For instance he
used the word
bastard as the
Americans use guy,
and as we were then
beginning to use
bloke, to mean
anyone about whom he
was speaking ...

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote:
When used by one
friend to another,
is a routine
expression in wry
good humour. .in
4;`Why doesn't one
of you lazy bastards
take a turn at
boiling the billy,
why does the hardest
worker (i.e. the
speaker) have to do
the extra little
jobs?'
bastard n. fellow, term of affection, e.g. he's a good old bastard.

Author: LELAND
Quote:
(A) It means what
you think it does,
but it can also be a
term of ENDEARMENT
and ADMIRATION. You
are a right bastard,
aren't you? (see:
hard shot, false
friends) (B) a
common variety of
coarse metal FILE.

Two witnesses in the
two-up cases at
Wellington mentioned
that `bastard' was a
common expression
among the habitue's
of the `school'. The
word is usually
preceded by the
great colonial
adjective, which
flourishes in the
vocabulary of
assorted sizes and
degrees of luridity.

Author: LEE
Quote:
`He's a bastard'.
Guy used the term
not for its
dictionary meaning,
but because among
New Zealanders, no
term expressed
greater contempt.

Author: FULLARTON
Quote: A Padre ... muttering `The bastards!' ... in accents that gave to that common Anzac expletive a new and searing potency. Ibid. 112 It's a bastard of a country.

Author: BALLANTYNE
Quote:
I thought it was a
bastard of a place.

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote:
A man offensive to
the extreme degree.
.in 4;`You'd hit me,
you bastard, would
you?'

Author: DUCKWORTH
Quote:
[as an intensifier],
It's raining like a
bastard, and we
didn't put any
[milk] bottles out.
I'll have to go to
the dairy.

Author: HARGREAVES
Quote: When we got to Queen Charlotte it was pissing with rain and blowing like a bastard and I thought, ahhh, this is more like home. Ibid. 44 The next morning I heard the forecast: it was blowing like a bastard, south-west.

Author: HUNT
Quote:
We'd make dumplings,
too, fried up in the
camp oven. Buggers
afloat we called
them [c1916] ... And
what did we call the
poached eggs? A pair
of bastards on a
raft, and we'd have
tits on toast -
belly pickled pork
on toast. I still
use those old names;
everyone laughs at
me.
Pseudophycis breviusculus Richardson. Bastard red cod.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: BASTARD RED COD Physiculus (Pseudophycis) breviusculus (Richardson) The vernacular name of this fish was first given to it by commercial fishmen who, when one was hooked and brought to the surface, would exclaim: ` - another bastard Red Cod!' meaning to say it was not a true Red Cod; the name stuck to this fish and was used by line fishermen of Otago.
The bastard red cod (Pseudophycis breviusculus) is stouter, a deeper red in colour, and has a rounded tail fin.

Author: AYLING
Quote: NORTHERN BASTARD RED COD Pseudophycis breviuscula (Physiculus breviusculus) ... The bastard red cod is similar in shape to the red cod but is much smaller ... Ibid. 144 SOUTHERN BASTARD RED COD (Bearded rock cod) Pseudophycis barbata ... The southern bastard red cod, known as the bearded rock cod in Australia, is similar to the red cod but does not reach such a large size.

Author: PAUL
Quote: Bastard red cods There are two species related and rather similar to the red cod ... they are not easily separated from each other. Pseudophycis barbata occurs round the South Island ... and P. breviuscula around the northern North Island.

Source: Royal Commission on the Fisheries of Tasmania
Quote: nf W3

Author: HURSTHOUSE
Quote:
... the best [sea
fish] are the Hapuka
... the Moki, the
Wharehou[ao-acute],
the Patiki (a small
plaice), the Kawai
(a coarse common
fish rising at the
fly in tidal waters
and sometimes dubbed
salmon) a sort of
mackerel, and some
mullet, rock-cod,
bastard-skate, and
snapper.

The ill-treatment
they endured was
called
"bastardisation",
and there are
repeated references
to it in a book
published six years
ago to mark the 50th
anniversary of the
Regular Force Cadet
School at Waiouru,
where,from 1948 to
1991, about 4000
teenage cadets were
inducted and trained
to be soldiers...
But from his
research -
questionnaires
returned by former
cadets and key
figures - he says
"bastardisation"
took many forms.

Bastion Point became
the fire lighter for
the first
substantial Treaty
examination, first
by Aucklanders and
then by the rest of
the nation.

The occupation at
Bastion Point was
followed by the
arrest of seventeen
protestors in
February 1978 at the
Raglan Golf Course.

Quote:

tuberculatus. G.

Quote: New Zealand possesses only ... the bat (Pekapeka, two species) and a small indigenous rat (Kiore).

Quote: Pekapeka, n. 1 bat.

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author: FORSTER
Quote: In the morning I described the new Shag & a new lark, & George drew the Shag and a new Bat, which we got. [ed. fn Vespertilio tuberculatus of Descr. Anim. p. 62 ...

Author: FORSTER
Quote:
We had already
discovered a small
species of bats in
the woods ...
... we have two species, which are familiarly known by the names of the short-eared [220] bat (Chalinolobus tuberculatus), and the long-eared bat (Mystacina tuberculata).

South Canterbury is one of the few places where the long-tailed bat or pekapeka still survives in a rural landscape. Ibid. 29 Long-tailed bats may use fragments close to larger tracts of forests during their nightly forays that can take thgem up to 20 kilometres from their roost sites.
... we have two species, which are familiarly known by the names of the short-eared [220] bat (Chalinolobus tuberculatus), and the long-eared bat (Mystacina tuberculata).

The big brown pan
that held the `bat'/
Was trembling like a
leaf.

Even the metallic
ring of the coins
could be heard,
followed by the
suppressed sights of
`heads' bettors as
`tails' were cried
while `two ones',
`barred,' `heads a
dollar', `tails'
ditto, `pass the
bat', and other
equally quaint and
even classic chants,
were wafted on the
midnight breezes.
... Much to
`Truth's' deep
regret, for it
detests having to
give the show away,
lately, at Miramar,
when some
road-making or
mountain-razing work
has been going on,
some of them have
engaged in the
simple yet sinful
process of tossing
two bright copper
pennies, with a bit
of wood, popularly
known as `the bat'
or `the kip' and,
therefore, in the
eye of the law are
hardened criminals.
There are terms for money: bat for a hundred-dollar note, a brick and bluebird chips for a ten-dollar note, lettuce for a twenty and tomato for a hundred-dollar note.

A colony of rare
native bats has been
discovered at
Walton.

The native New
Zealand bat is
believed to be
almost extinct.

[Hdg] Marooned
Tararua bats battle
on. Take off your
hats to the
tenacious Tararua
Forest Park bats,
still battling on
after being marooned
in the area by
glaciation and
volcanic activity
more than 90,000
years ago.

Sometimes the
details work to
evoke deeper
emotions, such as
when the girl stows
her Bata Bullets and
singlets neatly away
in a holiday cabin,
while unspoken
tensions wait.

Neither of us had
tracksuits, just an
old pair of grey
slacks, a jersey and
a pair of Bata
Bullets.

I rolled in with my
weedy 'mo, Swannie,
brown cords and Bata
bullets, cool as I
thought.

Author: CADEY
Quote:
He probably wouldn't
have a wife, in
which case he'd
batch with me.

Author: SCOTT
Quote:
My wife, having as
usual forgotten the
date and remembered
only at the eleventh
hour, did what she
calls "slapping up a
batch of scones"
half an hour before
she was due to
start.

Author: MANSFIELD
Quote:
Missus knocked him
up a batch of scones
last week.

Author: ANTHONY
Quote:
... kids will come
dropping in at all
hours with basins of
soup, and batches of
scones and so on.

Author: ANTHONY
Quote:
I never went to the
Watson's house but
what I had a cake or
a batch of scones,
or something edible
to take home with
me.

Author: SUMMERS
Quote:
Anna, there's a
batch of scones
under that
tea-towel.

Author: KEENE
Quote:
It was my scones
that won him back.
By now I was
becoming a very
capable cook, and
could produce a
mouth-watering batch
of scones in no time
at all.

Author: ANTHONY
Quote:
I never went to
visit the Watsons
but what I had a
cake, or a batch of
scones, or something
edible to take home
with me.

Author: MULGREW
Quote:
That, too, was the
day Victor went mad
and baked his batch
of scones.

I made a batch of
scones and put them
in the oven just
before I left.

Author: MANSFIELD
Quote:
Missus knocked him
up a batch of scones
last week.

Author: PARK
Quote:
No, I won't, I'll
bake a batch of
scones instead.

Those boys who
"batch" and grow
fretful when their
turn at the frying
pan comes around can
comfort themselves
by remembering that
they are qualifying
themselves for a
happy married life.

Author: BLAKE
Quote:
I batched up next to
a mountain
ribbonwood, close to
the headwaters,
because this was the
only tree I was able
to find to which I
could anchor my
galley-side.

Quote:
Glossary. batch up -
to take up residence

Morere is one of the
most picturesque of
all New Zealand's
hot springs areas.

was badly damaged in
- yes - a flood.

bur, Bathurst [s] Xanthium spinosum L.

`Biddybids detract
very materially from
the value of the

Author: HILGENDORF [& CALDER]
Quote: BATHURST BURR (Xanthium spinosum) `is not uncommon in warm and rich soils from the North Cape to the Waikato, rarer southwards to Wellington,' but occurs only on waste lands and corners of cultivated fields. It is a shrubby annual from 9 inches to 3 ft. in height; ... This plant was introduced about 1890, and caused a considerable scare, owing to the fact that in Australia, and one may suppose particularly at Bathurst, it caused depreciation in the wool estimated at 3d. per pound. It has, however, never caused any trouble here, and is hardly recognised by sheep farmers, even where it is most common ...

batten: Used to keep the wires on a fence at equal distances apart. It also gives the fence strength. Can be made of wood, steel, wire, chains or plastic strip. Same as dropper. the load.

batten ... NZ
upright member in
fence not fixed in
the ground, used to
keep wires an equal
distance apart
(batten staples ...
$56.90 a case).

The typical new ...

When all the wires

[Hdg] Fence battens

The `battening up'

The stamping battery

The battery has

The next objects of

Kurunui Battery ...

The most important

the system differs
little from

ore ... when brought
to the surface, is
committed to
`batteries' or
crushing-mills,
where the stone is
stamped or ground
into powder.

Author: WILSON & FRASER

First the sheep went

- that was warm
water out of a hose.

I want to say,

Author: McGILL
Quote: battle make pregnant, merely make love. Vince Boyle of Winton was researching a history of Mossburn when he came across a fellow recalling his wagoning days in 1914 in Northern Southland, and spoke of how he `battled a woman'. He was going to marry her, but a few days before the wedding she had a dentist remove her teeth and sent him the bill. They did not get married. Farmer and Henley describe a battler as one given up to debauchery, which leaves an outside chance that the wagoner merely seduced and failed to fertilise.

In a battle of a
different kind - in
Wellington on April
3, 1943 - the
"Battle of Manners
St" erupted when US
servicemen refused
to let Maori
servicemen into the
Wellington Allied
Services Club. In
New Zealand's worst
riot, 1000 American
and Kiwi troops and
several hundred
civilians fought for
four hours. At least
two Americans were
killed.

There were other
Sources of conflict,
the best known being
the "battle of
Manners St", which
started when some
southern Americans
argued with Maori,
which led to an
all-out street
brawl.
The Battle of Manners Street, inflated by folklore and An Encyclopedia of New Zealand is properly reduced, citing an official report in National Archives...

The first sign of
the tougher police
attitude came days
later in Molesworth
St, Wellington...
The Battle of
Molesworth St, as it
came to be known,
lasted only moments.
But it had a
traumatic effect on
a country accustomed
to thinking of the
police as an
essentially benign
law enforcement
agency.

Every time we play
them it's like the
Battle of the
Bridge, when
Auckland play North
Harbour, or Otago
play Canterbury,
we're neighbours so
it's all on.

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The

Inches long,

Author: TURNER
Quote: The battler seems [in Australia] to have been the poorest itinerant. In this sense, the word is not current in New Zealand where battler is used for a person who puts up a hard fight against adverse conditions without giving in, and is thus a general terms of praise.

A battler all his
life ... but now

... It would be a

he is thrown on the
scrapheap.

Author: McGILL
Quote: battler conscientous worker approved of by peers; reflects antipodean recognition of life's strugglers, the word also meaning a swagman; a petty punter living on winnings; a prostitute independent of ponce or brothel; eg `Bob has no flair, but he's a battler.' ANZ.

AFTER decades of sterotyping ourselves as wee battlers, a nation who can fashion anything out of number eight wire and as generally tough old boots..it was depressing to watch Lisa Chappell whinging and moaning her way around Malaysia on Intrepid Journeys

Mary
Collins...battler

Author: HARPER
Quote:
Our camp has not yet
been described, and
... it is the
simplest and best
form of shelter for
a party of two, ...
It is an invention
of Douglas's, and we
call it a `batwing'.
In the ordinary
course of camp life,
survey parties can
have their loads
packed on horseback,
and carry tent and
fly, with a second
smaller fly to pitch
at the end of the
tent to shelter the
fire. We ... [51]
could not afford to
take such a weighty
camp. We therefore
pitch an ordinary 6
ft. by 8 ft. canvas
tent, on a ridge
pole, with an 8 ft.
by 10 ft. fly six
inches above it; and
cut the tent in half
along the ridge, and
taking away one
half, leave the
other half standing.
This is just large
enough to allow two
men to lie `heads
and tails'. [The
side left open, and
one side of fly
raised 4 ft. in
middle, and under
this the fire burns
so have shelter in
wet weather.]

The Golden Bauble
Award. Winston
Peters wins this one
from United Future
leader Peter Dunne
by a country mile,
not only because he
was cynical enough
to grab the baubles
of ministerial
office with both
hands even after
telling his
supporters he had no
interest in the said
perks, but because
of his brashness in
claiming it was all
a media beat-up.

Before Winston said
he "would not accept
the baubles of
office", the word
referred to showy
trinkets or trifles.
Now it has been
redefined to mean
large powerful
positions much
greater than either
warranted or
deserved and the
trinkets now refers
to junkets of the
first class
travelling variety.

[Rod Donald]'ll be
up there, with his
sunflower braces on
over his angel's
nightie, roaring
with laughter at
Winston's baubles,
along with the rest
of us.

[Caption] I have not
been seduced by the
baubles of office
... As minister of
Foreign Affairs
outside of
Government I have
all the baubles but
no office.

If attending the All
Blacks' grand-slam
winning match last
weekend wasn't a
bauble of office,
what is?

Is it for enjoying
the baubles of
office when he
wasn't even elected
in Tauranga, or is
it simply because
he's sold his soul
to the Prime
Minister Helen Clark
to win a ministerial
salary?

Peters knew he was
on trial, and
defendants shouldn't
grin. A smile might
suggest he was
enjoying the baubles
of office.

The next election is
still a long way
off, but the latest
3 News poll suggests
NZ First is being
punished for leader
Winston Peters'
going back on his
"baubles of office"
promise.

[index to common

It refers

villa type with a
bay window on the
front facade (and,
in larger versions,

one hears often (in
fact I devoted a
section to the `bay
villa' in an
architectural thesis
I recently
completed). The
`bay' refers to the
bay window
(naturally enough);
and also, some say,
to San Francisco
Bay. It was (and is)
a house form common
in that city; and it
may well have spread
to New Zealand from
there.

By the later decades

Mostly the bay
whalers operated

which saved the cost

Author: STRAUBEL
Quote: The pursuit in coastal waters of black whales was known as `bay whaling',and the procedure followed was for the ships to lie at anchor in a convenient harbour or bay, sending out their boats to cruise in nearby waters for `fish'. Ibid. xviii [dating on NZ coast from about 1829 at Cloudy Bay, and 1835 in Banks Peninsula]

Author: McLINTOCK

A more positive step

Bay whaling in New
Zealand was based on
the regular
migrations of the
right whales as they
came into sheltered
waters to calve.

Author: HUNT
Quote:
The old bay whaling
parties have long

Author: BAUCKE
Quote:
An old-time bay
whaling station
consisted ... of at
least two boats,
with their crew of
six men each. The
headsman, or mate,
four ordinary
oarsmen, and the
harpooner, or
`boat-steerer,' who
pulled the bow-oar,
and drove in the
harpoon, and who,
when the whale had
been struck and
`fastened on,' went
aft and steered the
boat, while the mate
took his place, and
by repeated
lance-thrusts killed
it.

The first specimen
was ... killed by
whalers at Port
Mahia, at the north
head of the Bay.

... if possession of

consumes this trophy
the better. The Bay
owed its win
principally to the

forwards.

Author: LINDSAY
Quote: The larger species [of Aciphylla ] are familiar to the settlers as `Spear-grass', or `Bayonette-grass', `Wild' or `Bloody-Spaniard', [bloody =?] in allusion to their very rigid, strong, poniard-like, sharp-pointed leaves ... Hence a `Spear-grass Scrub' on the hill ranges is frequently most formidable ... to men and horses, though it forms one of the favourite hunting grounds of the Wild Pig. In the Matukituki Valley, `Bayonette-grass' forms an undergrowth in a dense scrub of prickly thorn ...

The plains are
covered with
grasses, the roots
of which are
gathered into tufts
or tussocks,
intermixed with the
Bayonet grass or
`Wild Spaniard'

The remarkable genus Aciphylla comprises the `spear-grass' and `bayonet-grass' of the colonists, so called from their rigid pungent leaves, which occasionally inflict uncomfortable wounds on incautious travellers.

Source: Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
Author: HAAST
Quote: They formed with the gigantic Aciphylla Colensoi, the Spaniard or Bayonet grass, ... which ... most severely punished man and horse.

Author: KIRK

taramea, a plant (Aciphylla squarrosa and other sp.), spear-grass, bayonet-grass, spaniard: a hill and mountain plant from whose spiny blades the Maori by heat and torsion extracted a valued scent.

Bayonet Kings [sc.

Author: FRAME
Quote: We stopped at Hampden.. walking higgledy-piggledy carrying kits and rugs down to the picnic ground by the beach with its beach 'dunny', the dark stained wooden seat split down the middle, the concrete floor puddled muddy and salt-smelling. Ibid. 51 Along the path from the lean-to, the 'dunny' beside the cypress tree and soon known as 'the cypress', was covered with the small fragrant roses known to us as 'dunny roses', and was without a door, while the dunny seat, long and wide like a beach dunny, was set over a deep hole half-filled with old 'kiki' (our word for faeces) in varying shades of brown, topped with faded pieces of newspaper, the Oamaru Mail and the Otago Daily Times.

Source: Bay, The : A History of Community at Titahi Bay
Author: FORDYCE & MACLEHN
Quote: In 1933 the progressive association organised Titahi Bay's first beach carnival, at Easter. Yacht races, speed boat races, treaure hunts, children's races, sideshows, a merry-go-round, golf, swimming, tennis and dancing kept visitors entertained.Ibid. 106 [Caption] The Plunket Beach Carnival was opened by the Minister of Health, Jack Marshall.

The former were on
the sandy margins of
the river, and were
often extended by
means of `wing-dams'
and other ingenious
devices far into the
rushing waters. In
these claims the
gold was found
lodged in `pockets'
or fissures formed
by the slate bars
...

Author: MAY
Quote: Collet's quicksilver plates rapidly became common on the beach-claims although they did not completely supplant the simpler cradle and sluice-box. Ibid. 244 It was a matter of nice judgement. The digger recognized four classes of payable ground: `tucker ground' kept him in food with nothing to spare; a `wages claim' gave him a pound or two above living expenses; a `riser' was a rich claim; and a `piler' or `homeward bounder' the richest of all. Probably most of the `pilers' were beach-claims, where the leads were shallow and rich, the outlay small and provisions cheap because of easy access.

Source: Bay, The : A History of Community at Titahi Bay
Author: FORDYCE & MACLEHN
Quote:
Charlie Hasse helped
Adam Wright as a
beach custodian each
season between
Labour Weekend and
Easter. They
directed traffic,
collected rubbish
and glass bottles,
maintained and
cleaned public
facilities, and were
responsible for
general beach
maintenance.

Author: MUELLER
Quote:
The greatest
drawback with beach
diggins is, they are
so quickly washed
out. Unless they
find gold in the
Ranges, and have
deep sinking, there
is very little
prospect of the
diggers now at the
Coast remaining
long.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
From the `Fire-mill'
... and other beach
diggings in the
neighbourhood [of
Okarito] tons of
gold were won; and a
little is still
obtained by
industrious
beach-miners.

[The beach
(Wellington)], A
person calling
himself Captain
Richards, of the
schooner Cheerful,
has beguiled and
smuggled from the
[Wellington] beach,
four to five young
females to carry
with him to the
Chatham Islands, to
locate them ...
amongst the reckless
set who form the
members of a whaling
gang ...
Notes: 1841 Mar 6 NZ Gazette and Spectator (Wellington) 3 quoted in 1982 Richards Whaling and Sealing in the Chatham Islands 22

Author: GODLEY
Quote:
What is called `the
Beach'; that is the
long [Wellington]
street (about a mile
and a half) if
street it can be
called, that has
houses only on one
side and runs along
by the sea.

Author: MACDONALD
Quote:
All the classes of
men ... congregated
[c1840s] on Thorndon
and Te Aro flats,
and along what we
knew for years as
`the Beach', but is
now known as Lambton
Quay ...

Author: COAD
Quote:
Truth to tell, he
had been a nuisance
to his relatives and
they had shipped
[42] him to New
Zealand with orders
to make his fortune.
This he evidently
thought could be
done by strolling
about the beach [at
Wellington] with his
hands in his
pockets, grumbling.

The anniversary of
the landing of the
first settlers was
celebrated from the
very first year,
usually with aquatic
sports off the
Queen's wharf, which
was much nearer to
`The Beach,' as
Lambton quay was
then called, than it
is today. Climbing
the greasy pole was
always one of the
events on
Anniversary Day ...
[l.c. in above sic]

Author: SARAH MATHEW
Quote:
[not shore etc -
from ship - first
experience of
Kororarika], The
situation of this
place [Bay of
Islands] is very
beautiful at the
head of a fine cove,
... Immediately on
the beach stands an
extensive well-built
store, with wharfs
and such buildings
as boat houses,
etc., ...
Notes: 1840 Mar 19 Sarah Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 94

Author: LANCASTER
Quote:
[(?hist)
Kororareka], Since
Hobson had landed on
the Beach this
morning, reading
England's
Proclamation of
Annexation in the
little wooden church
..., the Beach's
principal business
had been to get
drunk.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
`The Beach', as
Kororareka was
called, was not that
fabled `Beach' which
the explorers had
sought: the
dissolute men known
as `the
beachcombers' found
no gold nuggets;
they made a living
by preying on seamen
in one way or
another.

Wilson's Beach
[Wakamarina,
Marlborough]

Source: Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson
Author: HAAST
Quote:
We camped on the
sandy beach of the
river ...

Author: MONEY
Quote: ... a creek flowed through the valley, winding over a small beach of shingle. Ibid. 30 The river ... became wider and deeper, so that we were compelled to seek for fording places, which we learnt ... to choose at the bars or beaches above the falls, where the current was not so strong ... and the footing was therefore far better.

Author: PYKE
Quote:
As a result, the
adjacent ground was
left untouched; so
that the Co. were
enabled to work
claim after claim of
a really rich beach.

The best [gold] was
found on the beaches
and shallow bars of
the stream ...

Author: DOBSON
Quote:
A number of
gold-diggers were
working in the
neighbourhood, some
on the beaches and
some on the
adjoining terraces.

All `beaches'
obliterated and
boulder-hopping a
necessity.

Author: NOLAN
Quote: Beach: flattish gravel deposit at a riverside.

Author: BARRINGTON
Quote:
I believe there is
plenty of gold on
this river, but I
also believe that
there must be pumps
to work the ground,
as they are all
heavy beaches.
Notes: 1864 Apr 19 Barrington Diary in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 407

Source: Bay, The : A History of Community at Titahi Bay
Author: FORDYCE & MACLEHN
Quote:
Others associated
with beachfront
places at this time
included Charlie
Hayward and the two
auctioneers from
Wellington -
Clifford Dunbar
Sloane and Eric
Johnston, keen
fishermen out most
weekends on their
boats.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
`Beach gold!' I once
heard an old-timer
remark with heavy
scorn, `it's like
feathers. ...'

Author: MAY
Quote:
The sinking was
shallow, the ground
dry, and the gold
coarser than usual
for beach-gold.

Author: NEAVE
Quote:
... on one occasion,
a team of beach
horses, especially
fine animals that
served the surf
boats [on the South
Canterbury coast],
were stuck in the
creek at Severn
Street ...
Notes: 1980 W.Gard Reminiscences of 1860s in Neave The Land of Munros 83

Quote:
We originally
travelled to the Bay
for weekends while
the McCormick clan
built what was to be
a family beach
house.

Author: DOBSON
Quote:
Very rich
gold-bearing ground
was found at
Charleston, and in
the terraces on the
adjoining hills, old
beach leads were
worked up to 500
feet above sea
level, ...

Even for a beach
potato like myself,
Don Grady certainly
makes the prospect
of Queen Charlotte
Sound excessively
inviting.

Source: Narrative of a Nine Months Residence in NZ
Author: EARLE
Quote:
But there is another
class of Europeans
here [in the Bay of
Islands], who are
both useless and
dangerous ... These
men are called
`Beach Rangers;'
most of whom have
deserted from, or
have been turned out
of whalers for
crimes, for which,
had they been taken
home and tried, they
would have been
hanged; some few
among them ... had
deserted from their
ships, and were then
leading a mean and
miserable life
amongst the natives.

Author: BAKER
Quote: An even earlier form, beach ranger, apparently formed on the Australian bushranger ... is recorded by A. Earle ... in 1827.

Source: Bay, The : A History of Community at Titahi Bay
Author: FORDYCE & MACLEHN
Quote:
The benefits of the
Wellington-Manawatu
Railway line were
already being felt
and the recent
subdivision at the
beach resort of
Plimmerton was a
topic of local
conversation.

The families turn
the beach into a
feudal society and
mark out the
fiefdoms with beach
umbrellas.

Author: MAY
Quote: The beach-workings, which began so promisingly on the Watsons' South Beach claim, extended in spectacular fashion during the last three months of the year. Ibid. 186 The beach-workings of south Westland, stretched along sixty miles of coastline with the diggers perched on the sand between bush and high-water, were in sharp contrast to the Ross gold-field

Author: PYKE
Quote:
When the river is
`up' the beach
workings are covered
and the occupants
cease from their
labours.
Bluff oyster-catcher, avocet,/ And tripping beach-birds, seldom met/ Elsewhere - ...

Author: COWAN
Quote:
From the `Fire-mill'
... and other beach
diggings in the
neighbourhood [of
Okarito] tons of
gold were won; and a
little is still
obtained by
industrious
beach-miners.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
Although at the
outset the Maori got
rid of his coins ...
by purchasing
`anything and
everything' from
beach-traders, he
later found that his
visible riches were
an embarrassment.

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
I remember when I
was beachcombing up
in the Bay of
Islands ... What,
just living off the
beach, Son? ...
Yeah. Bit of fishing
and mussel-picking,
sheep-stealing and
garden-raiding when
a man felt energetic
or hungry.

Author: PFAFF
Quote:
[West Coast mining],
For a considerable
time [in 1860s] I
was coasting and
beach combing until
Wakamarina rush took
place.

A strong smell seems
to be considered a
necessary attribute
of ambergris by the
average
beach-comber.

Author: BATEMAN
Quote:
The small quantity
of gold under the
boulders, which lie
on the sandy beach
[on the West Coast,
South Island] is
generally supposed
by gold prospectors,
otherwise termed
`beach-combers', to
be due to the
lifting action of
the surf.

The beaches ... have
now been worked for
many years, but the
yields are not so
good. ... still, the
`beach-combers' make
fair wages.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
Idle, drunken
vagabond ... he
wanders about
without any fixed
object, cannot get
employed by the
whaler or anyone
else, as it is out
of his power to do a
day's work; and he
is universally known
as the
`beach-comber'.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
Even the corrupt
beachcombers and
whalers of Kapiti
would go out of
their way to say a
good word ... for
Mr. Hadfield.

Author: POWER
Quote:
... a few
half-drunken loafers
(beach-combers, as
they are called here
[in Auckland])
hanging about the
numerous pot-houses.

Funds are running
out and the evil
consequences of
employing
beach-combers,
escaped convicts and
sailors [in
pre-settlement
Canterbury] are
becoming every day
more apparent.

... Lyttelton ....
by all accounts is
the receptacle of
loose beachcombers
and escaped lags and
convicts, who have
been employed in
preference to honest
and able men from
the settlements.

Author: THOMSON
Quote: It was impossible that a community [Kororareka in 1838] composed of sailors ..., convicts, traders, beach-combers, sawyers, and New Zealanders could live together ... Ibid. 297The Pakeha Maori must not be confounded with the idlers and beachcombers who loitered about Kororareka.

Author: LEE
Quote:
It is a series of
three islands with a
climate varying from
temperate to
subtropical, a land
of industry with no
place for the
beachcomber; ...

Author: BUICK
Quote:
During the remainder
of the day [February
1840] a strong
effort was made by
the beachcombers and
whisky sellers of
Kororareka to spread
dissension among the
chiefs ...

Author: SOLJAK
Quote: New Zealanders have coined or adapted many expressions to meet local requirements, as illustrated by the following: ... beachcomber: first applied to deserting seamen and escaped convicts from Australia. Recorded before 1840

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
Several sealers
lived permanently on
the Chathams because
there was no law
there as the group
only nominally
belonged to England
and was not yet a
part of New Zealand.
It was the home of
escaped convicts,
ne'er-do-wells and
beachcombers from
Australia chiefly,
but those with the
worst reputation
came from Callao in
Peru.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
`The Beach', as
Kororareka was
called, was not that
fabled `Beach' which
the explorers had
sought: the
dissolute men known
as `the
beachcombers' found
no gold nuggets;
they made a living
by preying on seamen
in one way or
another.
beachcomber n. man, often an outcast, making a precarious living on beach or remote place [N.Z. origin, first recorded in 1844. An earlier form was beachranger].

Quote: ... a few half-drunken loafers (beach-combers, as they are called here [in Auckland]) hanging about the numerous pot-houses. Quote:
It is a series of

climate varying from

many expressions to

beachcomber: first

there as the group

belonged to England
and was not yet a

It was the home of

Quote:
`The Beach', as
Kororareka was
called, was not that
fabled `Beach' which
the explorers had
sought: the
dissolute men known
as `the
beachcombers' found
no gold nuggets;
they made a living
by preying on seamen
in one way or

beachcomber n. man,
often an outcast,
making a precarious
living on beach or
remote place [N.Z.
origin, first
recorded in 1844. An
earlier form was
beachranger].

Author: BUICK
Quote:
During the remainder
of the day [February
1840] a strong
effort was made by
the beachcombers and
whisky sellers of
Kororareka to spread
dissension among the
chiefs ...

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
The Pakeha Maori
must not be
confounded with the
idlers and
beach-combers who
loitered about
Kororareka.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
Most of the
beachcombers are
there for this
treat, plus what
looks to be most of
the inhabitants of
the pa.
Notes: Jim Cameron writes : Beachcomber may have a wider meaning than is given in DNZE sense 2 (a person who searches beaches for interesting or valuable objects) and be applied to a person who simply frequents or lives at the beach.

Quote:
While putting up a
printing office [in
Port Nicholson] I
picked up two
wanderers, who I
engaged to saw ... I
adopted them because
they were shaved and
clean. ... They
appeared to me to
contrast to great
advantage [?with]
the regular `beach
comber'. I write the
phrase large because
I think it is
[???new] to you. It
is appropriate to
the class. Its
meaning I assume is
evident. The `beach
combing' class is
large. The fellows
are daring, dirty,
requiring much
excitement,
accustomed to work
on shore and on
board, generally
about the beach, and
take what they find
without any very
strong sense of
doing that which is
improper.
Notes: 1840 May 15 S. Revans to H. Chapman [TS] Letters 42

Source: New Zealand and Its Six Colonies
Quote:
Except among the old
whalers and the
`beachcombing
population'
marriages with
native women seldom
take place.
... such political beachcombing vituperation as has been indulged in [by the Petone Chronicle].
Notes: [The reference here may be partly and snidely to the fact that Petone is a beachfront town.]

Author: GASKELL
Quote:
It's too cold for
beach-combing down
our way.
Notes: [nf W3] (A transferred and weakened use, perhaps a coinage, formed rather from beach-comber n1 than from a verb.) ?Lazing on the beach.

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
He was ... a rolling
stone who moved
about the country
... beachcombing
with Maoris in
Northland ...

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
I remember when I
was beachcombing up
in the Bay of
Islands ... What,
just living off the
beach, Son? ...
Yeah. Bit of fishing
and mussel-picking,
sheep-stealing and
garden-raiding when
a man felt energetic
or hungry.

Author: VON HAAST
Quote:
Generally the
greater portion of
the sand is removed,
but in favourable
spots, sheltered
either by a slight
indentation in the
coast-line, or by
some large pieces of
drifted timber, its
heavier particles
remain; these
consist [529] of
black iron-sand
(both magnetic and
titaniferous oxide
of iron) associated
with small garnets
and with gold. These
black layers are
often one or two
inches thick, and
repose upon coarse
quartzose sands. As
soon as a storm has
subsided, the
`beachers' or
`surfers' as they
are called, examine
the coastline near
their houses. When
they come upon one
of the rich spots,
the fine particles
of gold being often
visible to the naked
eye, they at once
remove the black
layer of sand out of
the reach of the
tide, and wash it
when convenient.

While putting up a
printing office [in
Port Nicholson] I
picked up two
wanderers, who I
engaged to saw ... I
adopted them because
they were shaved and
clean. ... They
appeared to me to
contrast to great
advantage [?with]
the regular `beach
comber'. I write the
phrase large because
I think it is
[???new] to you. It
is appropriate to
the class. Its
meaning I assume is
evident. The `beach
combing' class is
large. The fellows
are daring, dirty,
requiring much
excitement,
accustomed to work
on shore and on
board, generally
about the beach, and
take what they find
without any very
strong sense of
doing that which is
improper.
Notes: 1840 May 15 S. Revans to H. Chapman [TS] Letters 42

Quote:
... such political
beachcombing
vituperation as has
been indulged in [by
the Petone
Chronicle]. -->[The
reference here may
be partly and
snidely to the fact
that Petone is a
beachfront town.]

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
He was ... a rolling
stone who moved
about the country
... beachcombing
with Maoris in
Northland ...

It's too cold for
beach-combing down
our way.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote: Idle, drunken vagabond ... he wanders about without any fixed object, cannot get employed by the whaler or anyone else, as it is out of his power to do a day's work; and he is universally known as the `beach-comber'. Ibid. 2/4 Even the corrupt beachcombers and whalers of Kapiti would go out of their way to say a good word ... for Mr. Hadfield.

Source: New Zealand and Its Six Colonies
Quote:
Except among the old
whalers, and the
'beachcombing
population,"
marriages with
native women seldom
took place.

Source: Woman Who Loved Plants & Other Stories, The
Author: HASMAN-JUDD
Quote:
So when he drops off
I go for a wander
along the beach,
just beachcombing
really.

Source: Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ
Author: HARPER
Quote:
A few diggers live
here [Gillespies
Beach, West Coast],
working for gold on
the beach ... This
`beach combing' is
sometimes
profitable, as a
great deal of
`surfacing', or
black gold-bearing
sand, is now and
then deposited after
a storm, ...

[At Hokitika] the
gold of the
black-sand deposits
is very fine, and
... the recovery of
a high percentage
presents some
difficulty. The
various methods of
recovery known as
`beach-combing',
have already been
described.

... while along the
beach north of the
river
`beach-combing' is
sometimes resorted
to after heavy
weather, to extract
the precious metal
from the leads of
`black sand' with
which [gold] is
associated.

Author: PFAFF
Quote:
[West Coast mining],
For a considerable
time [in 1860s] I
was coasting and
beach combing until
Wakamarina rush took
place.

Author: MAY
Quote:
When they come upon
one of the rich
spots, the fine
particles of gold
being often visible
to the naked eye,
they at once remove
the black layer of
sand out of reach of
the tide, and wash
it when convenient.*
... [fn] This method
of working the
beaches was also
called `haymaking'
or `beachcombing'.
These terms were not
applied to
beach-workings above
high-water mark.
Notes: 1868 Haast in 1967 May West Coast Gold Rushes (1962) 222

Quote:
The first clue comes
in a chapter headed
" Beachcrossers
1769-1839": "Unlike
Tasman, James Cook
actually crossed New
Zealand beaches,
literally and
metaphorically."

There are few
Belich-type
catchphrases (though
"beachcrossers" may
enter the
lexicon)...

Author: TUCKETT
Quote:
At each place which
I have visited, I
have been assured
that the Maories are
dying rapidly -
`perishing like
rotten sheep,' these
people often say;
thus at Kurreroo or
Molineux, where
there are now
half-a-dozen
natives, they say
that formerly, and
at no remote period,
about two
generations previous
to the present,
there were above a
thousand; and in
many other places
within the last
sixteen years, which
is about the extent
of the experience of
the older beachers,
there has been, in
many places, a
corresponding
diminution of
numbers. If this is
an unexaggerated
statement, it is a
very distressing one
to reflect on. Since
Dr. -- visited this
settlement, one of
the residents, Mr.
--, an educated man,
has opened a school
for half-bred or any
other children, and
the progress which
the children have
already made is very
encouraging.
Notes: 1844 May 22 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 223

Source: Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
Author: VON HAAST
Quote: As soon as a storm has subsided, the `beachers' or `surfacers,' as they are called, examine the coast-line near their houses. When they come upon one of the rich spots, the fine particles of gold being often visible to the naked eye, they at once remove the black layer of sand out of the reach of the tide, and wash it when convenient. Ibid. 364-365 In the descriptive part of this publication I have already alluded to the black-sand beachers, who watch the coast principally ... where small indentations favour the preservation of magnetic ... iron-sands

Author: ELDER
Quote:
On this ... beach he
found ... a number
of miners who worked
... amid the
black-iron [check]
sands to be found on
the beaches. In the
early days of the
gold-rush many of
these `beachers' or
`surfacers' had
prospected the whole
southern part [of
the West Coast].

Author: MAY
Quote:
BEACHER: a miner
working a sea-beach
claim.

Source: Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland

Quote:

Author: MIDDLETON
Quote:
Sure that's it. All
the beachies at
Northend are talking
about it.

Author: GROVER
Quote:
The chief-headsman,
or beachmaster, as
he was often known,
did not keep order
[among a shore party
in the 1830s] ...by
knocking down any
man who argued with
him.

Source: Bay, The : A History of Community at Titahi Bay
Author: FORDYCE & MACLEHN
Quote:
[Hdg] Beachscape and
boat changes

Author: McCAULEY
Quote:
For almost two weeks
in the January of my
fourteenth summer my
sister and I stayed
with our Aunt Elly
and Uncle Roy in a
beachside cabin.

Source: Bay, The : A History of Community at Titahi Bay
Author: FORDYCE & MACLEHN
Quote: Beach side development of Tireti Rd was a mix of weekend baches and a few more substantial places.Ibid. Her regular clinics were run from an old bach behind the northern boatsheds where some of her patients' beachside injuries included jellyfish stings, cuts and lacerations caused by fish hooks, box thorn prickles and the barbed wire which had been placed around the beach during the war.

Author: WAITE
Quote:
The most deadly gun
(or a battery of
them) fired from the
Olive Groves away
inland from Gaba
Tepe. As this gun
enfiladed the beach,
it became widely
known as `Beachy
Bill'.

The "Beacon",
probably the best
known name in
Antarctic geology,
is now being
defined; limits are
being set, and its
whole nature is
becoming known. [5]
This highlights the
necessity for
workers in areas
other than the
Trans-Antarctic
Mountains to
endeavour to see the
type Beacon, and
conversely those
workers familiar
with the type Beacon
should try to see
what is regarded as
the Beacon in other
areas, particularly
the Antarctic
Peninsula.

Miss R. Askin:
Palaeobotanical
Studies of Beacon
Supergroup,
Antarctica.

...already parents
report one of the
reasons they are
desperate to get
into so-called
beacon schools is
that, with a
shortage of quality
teachers, it's the
big popular schools
that are less likely
to have problems
attracting
well-qualified
staff... When the
child completes its
education - paid for
by the taxpayers of
New Zealand who
cannot get their own
children into those
beacon schools - the
family will leave.

Mr Cosgrove was a
key member of the
infamous "Beagle
Boys Brigade" that
surrounded Mr Moore
when he was ousted
as Labour leader by
Helen Clarke in
1993.

He praised the
"Beagle boys" - a
group of young men
who'd helped
organise Labour's
1993 election
campaign.

The campaign team
earned the name
"Beagle Boys" for
their black eyes,
caused by working 18
to 20 hours a day
trying to get Labour
into government.

We don't want
confrontation - the
moment it gets that
way we have to use
the beagle boys and
the Maori wardens
and that's where it
gets ugly.

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author: HOARE
Quote:
Lest we slip,
however,
irrevocably, into
the Beagleholean
slough of Forster
despond - that
imaginary Tolkienish
world of Teutonic
druids and fantasies
in which the New
Zealand editor of
Cook delighted for
his anti-Forster
excursions - we do
well to recall ...
that not all of
Forster's
relationships were
... disastrous.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Some of the [slang]
expressions listed
by children in two
schools are: `Up the
shoot, going eyes
out, bullswool, go
jump in the lake,
... shivery dick,
shiver me timbers,
... you're telling
I, got it on the
brain, like smoke in
a wheelbarrow'
(Kaitaia), `Sheila,
crow, bud, frig it,
grub, holy moses,
blast it, mole,
balls to you, shut
your face, ... nerts
to you, go bite your
back, have a roll,
fluff off, scram,
ants in your pants,
rag bag, ... you're
bats, dronk, drongo,
dill, dip, dippy, ya
big lug, greetings
gruesome, who dented
your beak. (South
Wellington). 2.
(ejaculation) [nf
W3] Mind your own
business! Get your
nose out of my
business!

[The runaway] saw me
ride up to the house
and thought I was a
beak.

A rare Gray's beaked
whale that died in a
stranding at
Pencarrow Head was
pregnant... It is
only the 15th known
stranding of the
species in the
Wellington region
since 1874.

The rarest "find"
ever recorded in New
Zealand is the
beaked whale,
Tasmacetus
shepherdi, which was
washed ashore near
Hawera in 1933.

Beaked Whales Not
Uncommon.

"The animal is one
of the so-called
beaked whales, and
is known as the
strap-toothed whale,
on account of the
two peculiar teeth
which grow from the
lower jaw and curve
over the upper jaw,
so that the mouth is
almost prevented
from opening. .."

Beaked Whales Not
Uncommon.

The New Zealand beaked whale (Mesoplodon hectori) is known only from a skull in the British Museum and a skeleton in the United States National Museum, Washington, but of the latter no description has been published.
The southern beaked whale (Mesoplodon grayi) is distinguished by its pair of triangular flat teeth being situated just in front of the hinder end of the symphysis of the mandible.

Author: WILSON
Quote: BEAKIE: another term for Garfish/Piper

Michael Cullen said
"I'm going to stick
my beako in here".

Author: CARR
Quote:
... there is only
one job that the
most fastidious
could refuse, and
that is `picking
pie'. Tuis [?=This]
consist [sic] in
pulling the wool off
the trimmings that
have been taken off
by the `wool
pullers' at the
beam. These
trimmings are ...
allowed to rot until
the wool comes away
easily. [Pie
pickers] live and
eat by themselves.

Author: HOWARD
Quote:
Incoming skins are
sorted to arbitrary
standards - wigs
(old males),
clap-matches
(females), bulls,
yearlings, grey or
silver pups (under
one year), black
pups. If the cargo
is intended for the
European or American
market, the skins
are removed from the
animal with an inch
of blubber adhering,
and in the final
simple treatment are
washed, heavily
slated, and then
folded or `booked'
into rectangular
shape for packing.
Skins destined for
China, however, are
treated with more
preliminary care.
They are taken as
cleanly as possible,
and after careful
washing are sent to
the `beamer' to be
thoroughly scraped
free of the last
remaining particles
of flesh and
blubber.

A relic of the past
was discovered in a
ploughed field at
Taumarere, one day
last week. It was in
the shape of a
George III. penny,
dated 1797, ... If
that `bean' could
speak, what wouldn't
it say on the land
policy of New
Zealand's early
days.

Beans, bread,
buckaroos, cash,
coin, dough, loot,
green stuff, lucre,
mazuma, moolah, want
some?

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
BEANS (n) e.g., get
one's - . Be beaten
up. British army
slang quoted by
Kipling in 1890.
[this from
Partridge]

One guy said if I
touched his car,
he'd give me my
beans,' Hunt said.

Author: COLIN GORDON
Quote: When jokers cut themselves there is a nurse [employed by the Works] to do up cuts, etc.; so others try to make out they have cut their cocks, and the terms [associated with] this are to cut your dong-wollop, kidney-puncher, bean-tosser, hawk-sword, family maker.

Author: AYLING
Quote: 150 BEARDED COD (Eucla cod) Euclichthys polynemus ... The bearded cod is a small deepwater species with a large head and a long tapering body ...

Author: FEATON
Quote: MYOSURUA ARISTATUS (Benth.) The Bearded Mousetail. ... This minute plant is a native of the Northern Island; ...

LOST at Pelorus
Bridge, Brown Beardy
dog, last seen at
Bridge. Would anyone
knowing the
whereabouts please
ring 670 Spring
Creek collect.

Author: MARSHALL
Quote:
Hammond's got ther
best dogs. Beardies.
Run all day; gutsy
and clever with it.
I never seen better
holding dogs than
his.
Beardie. A variety of sheep dog with very long hair, something like a Skye terrier's. (C.)

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
For his breed - that
is for a cross
between bull
terrier, blue merle,
beardie, ... - Flynn
was a tractable dog.

Out on the flanks
might be ... two
young beardies whose
main job was
heading, and
shepherding the
stragglers would be
Charlie's
strong-eyes, Bean
and Belle.

Author: McLEOD
Quote: Beardy: Shaggy, with hair drooping over the eyes and almost sweeping the ground.

Author: McNAUGHTON
Quote:
Tat was delighted to
be free. He frisked
around the yard and
made friends with
the old beardie tied
under [34] the dray.

Author: NEWTON
Quote: Beardie: A woolly curly-coated dog. Broadly speaking we have three types of sheepdog - beardie, long or rough-coated and short or smooth-coated.

Author: WILSON
Quote:
... he didn't even
bawl at Franz, his
yellow Beardie pup,
...

Beardie :A type of
dog - very hairy.
Usually used as a
huntaway.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
`Don't mind Taipo',
she said as she
ushered me in. I
froze. ...`What the
devil is it?' She
chuckled. `A
Beardie'. `Does it
bite?'

Author: McGILL
Quote:
`Don't mind Taipo',
she said as she
ushered me in. I
froze. ...`What the
devil is it?' She
chuckled. `A
Beardie'. `Does it
bite?'

Author: WILSON
Quote: BEARDIE: another name for Red Cod
beardie n. NZ & Austral. (also beardy) long-haired variety of sheep-dog.

Author: SALMOND
Quote:
bearer the lowest
member in the house
frame, sitting
directly on the
foundations

.. there have been
serious losses among
ewes owing to
bearing trouble.

Among the older ewes
in particular, from
now, on, there is
likely to be a
certain amount of
trouble through the
protrusion of
bearings.

The bearing is seen
protruding. If seen
early, the bearing
can be successfully
returned.

The incidence of
'bearing' trouble is
considered often to
be connected with
the type of feed.

It is certainly the
short, blocky ewe
with the wide pelvis
which is the most
liable to put out
her bearing.

They [the new breed
ewes] will also be
able to be fed well
without the bug bear
of bearings or
getting cast.

Nearly all breeding
sheep flocks in New
Zealand are affected
by vaginal prolapse
or bearings, at a
cost of between $30
million and $200
million. [bearing
trouble]

A high incidence of
bearings (prolapsed
uterus) was common,
while abortion
problems randomly
affected properties.

Another reason for
the losses was a
rise in bearings -
prolapsed vaginas -
in ewes that were
carrying more than
one lamb. As the ewe
died so did the
lambs. "Bearings are
a mystery to us, we
don't know why they
vary from farm to
farm and from year
to year, but
whatever it is that
sets those up,
they're set up this
year over quite a
big area"....

Things that stood
out were checking
ewes prior to
lambing, assisting
when cast, dealing
with 'bearing
problems' and at
times acting as
midwife.

The number of
bearing ewes
salvaged from death
on any farm is very
low.

Author: MRS WILLIAMS
Quote:
For the first week
the cow's milk,
called `beastie',
should be reserved
entirely for the
calf.

Author: CAIRD
Quote:
When a considerable
stretch of country
had to be mustered
each man got his
separate beat.

Author: STRONACH
Quote:
Boy.. hunted them
all on the next
man's beat.

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
In those days, when
men were glad of
jobs, shearers used
to write asking for
a 'pen', just as the
musterers did to ask
for a 'beat' on the
station of their
choice.

beat: (i) that area
which a musterer is
detailed off to
clear. An easy beat
is one of the easy
walking, usually the
bottom or top beat,
though the latter
may entail a long
initial climb. A
hard beat is usually
one of the middle
beats and very often
includes bluffs and
also much need to
run dogs on the
blind.

Author: STACEY
Quote:
There was no chance
of getting mustering
because many men in
their fifties were
still mustering and
you had to wait for
someone to die
before a beat became
available.

Source: High Times in the High Country
Author: KERR
Quote:
On higher beats
there may be no
water for thirsty
dogs, who dehydrate
and die quickly, so
prudent musterers
carry an emergency
bottle of water.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
beat: (ii) area of
ground allotted to a
rabbiter for
poisoning. [see also
bottom beat, double
beat, high beat,
lambing beat, low
beat, middle beat,
mustering beat,
outside beat, second
beat, shepherd's
beat, top beat and
walking beat.]

Author: SCOTT
Quote:
When you didn't turn
up with the grub, we
turned out and beat
the track, finding
the tucker and your
camping place.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
... and in New
Zealand among
criminals for `to
run away' (Nelson
Baylis, letter of
1932).

Source: Avondale College Slang Words in Use
Quote: beat the feet: walk
Beat the feet: run, especially on some errand

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote:
BEAT THE FEET (v)
Run away, escape.

Everyone who is
anyone in the
underworld ... when
needing to sell a
radio, hide out some
place if `beating
the fleet' or just
wanting a few jugs.

All hands walked
centry [sic] [over
the cattle] all
night in this order.
... 40 yards [on]
was another fire.
Here ended my beat.
Draper's began, and
went to another fire
and to the sea.

Author: MOORE
Quote:
On one occasion I
had the top beat and
had to wait for the
men below me.
beat ... NZ area traversed by musterer of sheep (a lambing beat).

Author: TINNE
Quote:
It is customary to
invite all the
neighbours to your
`muster,' as they
can then pick out
their missing sheep
which have strayed
from the adjoining
runs. As they
complete each flock,
it is turned over to
a shepherd, who
would drive it off
with the aid of his
dogs to a beat,
possibly ten or
twenty miles distant
...

Author: CAIRD
Quote:
When a considerable
stretch of country
had to be mustered
each man got his
separate beat.

That awful Wilson
did not muster his
beat at all, fiend
of a fellow.

Beat.-A musterer's b. is the ground off which he has to clear the sheep each day; often top b., bottom b., middle b., etc., also hard and easy bs. The word is also applied to the ground on which a rabbit poisoner has to lay his poison.

Author: BURDON
Quote:
Each man has his
beat, for which he
is responsible.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
The men were out on
their beat by
daylight, sometimes
well before. The
beats were about
half a mile apart,
or more if the
country was open; on
broken ground we had
to keep pretty close
together.

Author: NEWTON
Quote: The following [1924] muster I was entrusted with a `beat' on the hill... Ibid. glossary, Beat: the strip of country each man musters.

Author: ACLAND
Quote: Beat. A musterer's beat is the ground off which he has to clear the sheep each day, often top beat, bottom beat, middle beat, etc., also hard and easy beats. The word is also applied to the ground on which a rabbit poisoner has to lay his poison.

Author: STRONACH
Quote: Boy was certainly the fastest sheep dog I have ever seen. He put in a splendid hunt, which would have been a bad head if the sheep had not been so fast, and hunted them all on to the next man's beat. Ibid. 18 I was two beats from the top, and there was shingle all the way. It slid continuously, and all the time I had to bear up hill, to keep a level track. However, we got off `the hill' quite early, put the sheep across Cat Creek at Tarndale, and raced for the homestead.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
Before dawn next
morning, the
musterers, as per
custom, in order to
be on their beats
before sun up,
started into action.

Author: NEWTON
Quote: beat: The strip or area of country each musterer has to cover or muster. Six men, say, will each have own beat to muster when `doing' a block of country.

Author: JOHNSTON
Quote:
Mr Parkins and Stan
were to leave a 3
a.m. for the range,
the former working
his two dogs and the
latter his faithful
Pat. `Stan, you know
your beat,'
announced Mr Parkins
...
beat n. land patrolled by a shepherd.

Author: DAVIES
Quote:
... the Boss was
adamant that the two
boys couldn't miss
their lambing beat.

Author: AYSON
Quote:
They got a good
muster of cattle,
took them to the
yards, put them
through, kept those
that were to be
tamed in the
paddock, and let the
rest out in a mob,
each to find its way
to its own beat.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
I don't think she
was ever yarded,
though many attempts
were made to get her
in; finally she had
to be shot on her
beat in the bush at
the Upper Hook.

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
He has crossed the
Straits, then. Times
must be bad among
the stations when
Davie [Dunlop the
Sundowner] has come
so far out of his
beat.

Well, I took to the
track. I came up
north [from
Southland] and
swagged with a
character that was
well known on the
track at that time
[the mid 1920s]. ...
They were fellows
that were on the
track permanently,
and they all had
their beats.

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote:
BEAT IT (v) Win an
acquittal

Quote:
... the axe was used
to beat off the
depths of the scores
[sc the guide marks
cut in the log]

[cartoon:
after-match
function] He's a

ruck - I'll say that

shark, Beaumaris 158

by Rush, however,

the hang of things

ackers.' `Did you

Quote:
What a beaut! What a
beaut try!

beaut.'
~ n.(slang) anything excellent. superfine, especially in phrases, its a beaut, what a beaut
beaut Sl., chiefly Austral. & N.Z. ~n. 1. an outstanding person or thing. ~adj., interj. 2. good or excellent.

Quote:
In constant use by
youngsters ...
hummer, corker
[etc.]

was beaut and hummer
[sc. drunk]

...the party was at
that stage which old
soldiers of the
Middle East would
describe as `beaut
and hummer' -

could not be better.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
What a beaut! What a

beauter.

gossips.

Look, Hori, at the

`Aw, that's a kid's

Quote: beaut:; BEAUTIFUL in the sense of `that was a beautiful dive into the swimming bath ', or she's a beaut horse or sheila, etc. ... Note that unfamiliar words in New Zealand are likely to be contractions offamiliar ones, as beaut for beautiful, or speedo for speedometer, or park for parking place (see: park).
beaut Sl., chiefly Austral. & N.Z. ~n. 1. an outstanding person or thing. ~adj., interj. 2. good or excellent.

Once when she
couldn't have me Dad
let me go to the
flicks by myself. He
gave me some extra
money, so I went to
the milkbar and
bought a gobstopper
and some other
lollies. I stuffed
my face, and felt
crook all the way
home. He bought new
footy boots for my
eldest brother too,
and an Art Union

must have had a
beaut time up the
RSA that day, I
reckon.

aint a bute.

Author: SANDYS

`She's a wee beaut,

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: GREATER CONVOLVULUS [BINDWEED] (Calystegia sepium) has the same popular names as the last species, [i.e. convolvulus] and in addition, beautiful white devil, and its native name of pohue. It is much like convolvulus [bindweed], but is larger in all its parts. The leaves are 3 to 5 inches in length and the flower 2 inches across, more usually white than pink.

This `river-bed' is

Author: KIRK
Quote: With the view of obviating the confusion caused by the misuse of the common names hitherto applied to the New Zealand beeches, I would suggest the adoption of new names based on the obvious characteristics of their foliage:- For Fagus fusca, tooth-leaved beech; for Fagus solandri, entire-leaved beech; and for Fagus menziesii, round-leaved beech.

Beech (b&emacr.ch), n. [Add.] ... The ordinary native beech of commerce in New South Wales is Gmelina Leichhardtii. The New Zealand beeches are Fagus Solandri, F. Blairii, F. Menziesii, F. fusca, F. Cliffortioides, and F. apiculata. The word beech, however, is rarely used in New Zealand, the trees being called birch by settlers and bushmen, and tawai by the Maoris. See under BIRCH,n

Birch. Various species of Nothofagus. There are various kinds (white, red, black etc.) of trees in New Zealand called birches. They are all really beeches and the newspapers and forestry people are trying to get them so called, but up country they are still always called birches. Birch (creeks, hill, etc.) is one of the commonest components of local names in the South Island. ([1898 Morris Austral-English], and an unpublished letter to Hunter Brown from Dr Hodkinson, August 9, 1854.)

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote: English names of animals and plants are sometimes mistakenly applied. The native beech, Nothofagus, has been called birch since the early days and is still often so called by bushmen; ...

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote: Beech .. tawai, tawhai Nothofagus

Author: DAWSON
Quote: Five species of Nothofagus were formerly recognised in New Zealand, but more recently two of these have been combined as varieties of one species. Nothofagus menziesii: silver beech (the bark is white and silvery particularly in young trees). Nothofagus fusca: red beech (the timber is reddish in colour). Nothofagus truncata: hard beech (the wood has a high silica content making it hard). Nothofagus solandri var. solandri: black beech (the bark is very dark partly due to the growth of a sooty mould). Nothofagus solandri var. cliffortioides: mountain beech (grows mainly at higher altitudes than other beeches).

Quote: ...silver beech is the only species attacked by a fungus, Cytaria, whose orangey, golf-ball-like fruiting bodies may be abundant on the branches of some trees; ...
Trilepetala (Tripetala?)adamsii - unseen since 1954 - is presumed extinct. The three beech mistletoes and Tupeia antarctica are all in gradual decline nationally.

Beech mistletoes are

Author: MARTIN
Quote: The most counspicuous of these [pouch fungi which develop underground] is the violet-tinted BEECH POTATO (Hysterangium scerodermum), a tuberous-looking fungus resembling a small Derwent potato.

Author: MARTIN
Quote: Finally, there are those curious, yellow, spherical `fruit' of the so-called beech strawberry (Cyttaria gunnii), a fungus which attacks the silver beech. These strawberry-like fruits form clusters on the twigs at the end of the branches, their honey-combed surface making recognition easy and certain.

A universal animal

The player won who

Even in New

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
Bell-wether. To this
day tame wethers are
used to lead others
to their doom in the
freezing works. They
carry no bell but
still retain a broad
leather collar. This
will protect them,
and would
effectively blunt
the knife of a
sticker who might
absent mindedly seek
to slit the wrong
throat.

Author: MCLAUCHLAN
Quote:
In pioneering days,
dogs were used more
to contain sheep in
the absence of
fences than to drove
them. The shepherd
often led his flock
with a bell-wether.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: In a few tagging games the players joined hands with the He when they were caught and helped him catch the other players. These games were known as The Bellahonie (E-21) (Wellington, 1910), Kick Post One (Hampden, Otago, 1880), and Ballyhooley (Wellington, 1920). More popular were those games in which the players helped one another to fight the He, and of these the most widespread was the game known as Kick the Tin (e-3), Kick the Boot, Kick the Block, or Homiacky. In this game the He was put on guard of a jam tin placed inside a small circle marked on the ground. [Other players hid: those He could see he named and tapped the tin three times and `captured': other hiders waited till they had chance to kick tin out of circle: then all were free again.]

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: There are games recorded in this period for which there is no record before 1900 though they may well have existed under other names. West Coast: Dunk and Davey, Spang Weazling; Wellington: Who Goes Round My Stone Wall, Beg o' My Neighbor, Bellahonie, Run a Mile, On and Off the Bridge, Here Come Two Nuns, Colours, Isaac and Rebecca. Scrag, Diabolo, Bumble Puppy, Homai, Fives;

Quote: ANTHORNIS MELANURA. (BELL-BIRD.) ... Native names. Mako, Makomako, Komako, Kokomako, Korimako, Kohimako, Kokorimako, Titimako, and Kopara. Of the above names, Korimako is most generally used by northern and Makomako by southern tribes. Author: MORRIS
Quote: Bell-bird ... name given to several birds, from their note, like the tinkling of a bell. In Australia, a Honey-eater, Myzantha melanophrys, Gould (`Birds of Australia,' vol. iv. pl. 80), the `Australian Bell-Bird' (the same bird as Myszantha flavirostris, V. and H.), chiefly found in New South Wales; also Oreoica gutturalis, Gould (Vol. ii. pl. 81), the `Bell-bird' of Western Australia; and Oreoica cristata, Lewin. In New Zealand, Anthornis melanura, Sparrm., chief Maori names, Korimako in North, and Makomako in South. Buller gives ten Maori names. The settlers call it moko (q.v.). There is also a Bell-Bird in Brazil.
12. Anthornis melanura, Sparrm. Bell bird, Korimako, Makomako, which last name settlers often render into mockymock.

Bellbirds have been

and Hamilton starts

sanctuary-bred birds
at four sites.

[Kookaakoo, macrons]

Bell-Bird, is of a
purple colour, with

breast, shaped like

bird with a bright

like a saddle, these

are green
parroquets, large
hawks, and several
kinds of wild ducks,
besides Emus,
greenbirds and
woodhens, which are
birds of excellent
flavour. [ed. fn:
The linnet, brown

Botanic Garden in
Wellington.. means
[sic] that
bellbirds, last seen
in 1902, are again
calling in the
forest.
(Wallace Shearing Glossary) bellied sheep: A sheep that has had the belly wool shorn off it prior to the main shearing.

People were now
flocking in pretty

...

Amongst its [a
capsized ferry's]

of the bellmen who
plied their trade,
and often made a
hideous noise in the
city streets. This

to announce the

What'll I do? I've

`Wring your

bystander.

Bell-men pervade the

Centriscops Humerosus ... Bellows Fish.
