Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
One of the last of
the bellringers to
parade the streets
of Maoriland could
often be heard [at
Reefton c1900],
ringing out his sad
or glad, or
indifferent tidings,
..

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: Next in order of importance [to Egg Cap] in the pitching games was Bells (K-23). This was based on the game of Pitch and Toss ..., but had a more innocuous character. The coins for this game, that is the `bells', were the round, flat tops of the cylindrical Bell [Company] Wax Vesta matchboxes. The head was the blue end with the red flowers in the middle. The `sugaries' at the other end of the box (the spot on which the match was struck) were not often used, although there is one report in which they were said to represent half the value of the bell. ...

The life-nominees
shall wear
long-faced
bell-toppers,/

Author: THATCHER
Quote:
His volunteer cap's
on whenever I meet
him,/ He wears it to
save a belltopper no
doubt;/

Source: Pirate Chief and the Mummy's Complaint..., The
Author: SKEY
Quote:
Now this your stiff
belltoppers won't
do,/ One kick and
their day is done;/
So the billycock
soft my looks shall
renew,/ And let off
my innocent fun.
Belĺ.toṕ.per (b&ebreve.ĺ.t&obreve.ṕ.-p&etilde.r), n. A tall silk hat. [Colloq.]

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Bell-topper. The ordinary Australian name for the tall silk-hat.

Author: THATCHER
Quote:
And the firm of
Mills Brothers/ Was
there in a
belltopper;/

Author: THATCHER
Quote:
One new chum had got
an umbrella,/ And in
a beltopper [sic]
was rigged;/

Quote:
`A very fine man in
appearance, stature
and spirit' he
[Francis Hicks]

... he was observed
walking briskly to
his 8am appointment
with his work,
dressed in the
invariable
belltopper frock
coat, check trousers
...
bell-topper ... n. Australian name for tall silk hat.
~ n. Australian name for the tall silk hat.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
When on his rounds
he rode an old horse
and always wore a
bell-topper hat. It
was not unusual to
come onto the
doctor's horse and
bell-topper on the
side of the road or
track, and the
doctor lying down a
band or somewhere
nearby fast asleep.
[pre-1910]

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Bell-topper. Current in New Zealand as early as 1853 (B., 1941).

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
Father had brought
out a belltopper
with him [in 1840]
...

Quote:
No sooner had he
left the store than
the diggers caught
sight of his
bell-topper and
began [31] greeting
him with cries of
`Joe, Joe.' The
township was soon
ringing with the
cry. The minister
was puzzled to
understand why he
was being barracked
so freely and asked
Thomas the reason.

Author: SCANLAN
Quote:
Did you go to school
in a belltopper hat?
Mike says the boys
do at Eton. He says
it would be a bosker
game kicking them
round the yard.
bell n.- bell-apple n. a large soft-skinned passion fruit.- bell-topper n. a silk hat.

Author: MANSFIELD
Quote:
He had a good voice;
he liked to sing in
public, he liked to
dance and attend
pic-nics - to put on
his `bell topper'
and walk out of
Church if he
disapproved of
anything said in the
sermon - and he had
a passion for
inventing highly
unpracticable
things, like
collapsible
umbrellas or folding
lamps. He had one
saying with which he
met all
difficulties.
`Depend upon it, it
will all come right
after the Maori
war.'

Author: FERGUSON
Quote:
And when his `bell
topper' he puts on,
his looks there's no
withstanding.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
BELL-TOPPER: High
hard hat with wide
flat crown.
Notes: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 185

Quote:
Auckland swell. `I
wonder you new chums
wear those
disgusting
bell-toppers'.

Author: TINNE
Quote:
... no tall black
hats
(`bell-toppers,' a
[a-acute] la
coloniale) ...

Quote:
An unfortunate
publican was once
weak enough to
return from a
commercial visit to
Dunedin with a
regular black hat -
popularly known as a
`bell-topper' - ...
and his friends
kindly kicked the
offending hat into
the river.

... a bell-topper
...

Larrikinism [title] ... I was coming up Rattray St. today, wearing a bell-topper, and found about thirty boys preparing to pelt all comers. ... Nobody supposes that the masters are unaware of this larrikinism; ...
Notes: 1878 Evening Star (Dunedin) quoted in 1974 Wood Victorian New Zealanders 31

Author: GREY

In the fall, my
bell-topper and its
wearer parted
company.

Author: INNES
Quote:
An individual was
seen swimming [to]
the ship, with his
`belltopper' fixed
firmly on his head.

[Of the mistaken
idea new emigrant
has of Colonial
costume] The
outlandish gear [sc
wide-awake hat] is

`bell-topper' is

Notes: 1884 Aug 30 `Daily News' in 1886 Clayden Handbook NZ 209

Author: BARLOW
Quote:
In the meantime the
only `bell-topper'
to be [209] found
among the head-gear
... had been called
into requisition ...

.. last year my
clip, including
pieces, bellies and
locks, averaged
gross in Timaru ...

Put up two temporary
wool bins in the
woolshed for the
bellies and pieces,
then started to
plane boards to go
round the bottom of
the wooltable.

belly - the wool off
a sheep's belly,
pressed and sold as
'bellies.'

A bale of bulk ewe

stains have not been

Bellies are stored
in two fadges.

Author: LOUGHNAN

belly: (ii) (n)
belly wool.

Pizzle stain:
Unscourable urine
staining in wether
and ram bellies, and
ewe crutchings.

Bulky skirtings,
second shear bellies
and pieces and first
crutching were
unchanged on Nov 8.

Summer days were
spent on
flutterboards and
hastily constructed
wooden
"belly-boards".

In the South Island
when shearing
full-wool ewes with
winter combs plus
lifters, a belly
crutch is often done
six to eight weeks
beforehand.

It [shearing twice a
year] also does away
with the ewe belly
crutching.

Belly... The thick
part of the lash of
a stock whip ...

.. The belly, or
thickest part of the
thong, was filled
out with pieces of
leather laid
lengthwise ...

Quote:
belly: (i)(n) thick
part of a stockwhip,
about the middle of

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
It [the whip] has a
taper and belly to
make it lash easily
...

Watch out for big
boulders 'cause even
with 4 wheel drive
you can get bellied.

He told them how
he'd bellied on a
hummock within five
minutes of starting
and then realised
he'd neglected to
bring a wire rope
and shovel.

He and his married
man crutched and
bellied the hoggets
themselves in July
...

When we had cut out
the ewes he looked
forward to crutching
the smaller and
lighter hoggets.
They should have
been much faster as
we would not have to
belly them.

Then the way is
clear for the elite
mob to come in; when
they are bellied and
crutched, bladeshorn
and put back on the
hill.
Belly. (1) The thick part of the lash of a stock whip, toward the middle. (C.)

The big stations may
make classing a very

and may even divide

different classes,
besides keeping the
bellies, locks, and
stained wool
separate.

Quote:
The skirtings of the
neck and shoulder
can be called first

britch ends made
into second pieces.
The `bellies' can be
placed in a pack
hung on the
shearing-board, and
when two of these
are filled they can
be pressed.

Author: SMITH
Quote: There are also baskets for the bellies and locks ... The `picker up' is the name given to the young man or boy whose duty it is to [75] carry the wool from the shearer to the skirting table ... Ibid. 88 The bellies that have been collected by the pickers-up are sorted into two classes: FIRST BELLIES ... BELLIES ...

Regarding the
respective values of
the clips, it is
hardly necessary to
state that fleeces
from March-shorn
sheep were not able
to be rolled. From
them only stained
wool and bellies
were sorted out ...
A star bale sold at
a crutching sale
made 101/4d., while
a fadge of the same
wool pooled later
made 121/4 pence ...
Belly. (1) The thick part of the lash of a stock whip, toward the middle. (C.) (2) the wool off a sheep's belly, pressed and sold as `bellies'.(C.)

`Bellies' form the
bulk of the
skirtings and are
seldom classed
except for type or
condition.

I take the next
[bale of wool] and
weigh it. `Bellies
and pieces,' they
say.

It's not bellies in

Author: GASKELL
Quote:
I take the next
[bale] and they
weigh it. `Bellies

wall can be very

Bellies often

They also swept up
the bellies and
pieces, and so kept

An "improved Romney
ram" was credited
with 31 lb of wool,
without the "belly".

We crutch and belly
shear in late April
or May ...

Quote:

I was allowed to

Quote:

Quote: Belly wool. The wool shorn off the sheep's belly. It is often twiggy and stained, and is pressed separately and sold as belly wool, a lower grade of wool.
belly, belly wool: The wool shorn form the sheep's belly.

Juvenile
delinquency. What
about us? ... [10]
... Climbing over

heaving the stand
planks into the
water when we tired

side and

Quote:
John Thompson and
Tony Prestage
belly-crutching
ewes.

Quote:
`It hurt,' she added
... `So I didn't do

He trotted down into

What a lousy dive
for a man going to
the rescue, ...

Quote:
How white his father
looked ... poised
for a bellyflopper.

powerful strokes ...

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
The rope lashed to
the willow above
Larsen's Hole that
swung him in a
glorious sprawling
bellyflopper into

... the latter is

Author: ELWELL
Quote: The animal was at length brought with its head close up to the corner of the post [of the stockyard], the end of a small rope fastened to one of the rails ... was now passed rapidly round its body, and handed to the men outside to put round another rail and hold ... Almost at the same time that this `belly-rope', as it was called, was being fastened to keep the body of the animal upright, Harold would be putting a rope round one of the hind legs.

Author: KENWAY
Quote:
He will
`belly-scarf' and
`back-scarf' the
lot, that is to say,
he will cut about a
third through on
both the lower and
higher sides.

Author: KENWAY
Quote:
selecting a certain
group of trees he
will `belly-scarf'
and `back-scarf' the
lot.

The stereotyped cry
`Below in the
gully!' is sent
forth, echoing from
tree to tree. This
is a timely warning
for those working
below to betake
themselves a spot of
safety from flying
limbs ....
Notes: [1914 Auckland Weekly News] quoted in 1953 Reed Story of Kauri 160

Author: Swainson
Quote:
These belts and
clumps consist of a
rich variety of
wood; the graceful
tree-fern, and the
deep-green,
glittering-leaved
karaka, clustering,
in unusual
profusion, around
the tall stems of
the statelier forest
trees.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote: It is to be hoped, that as they [the wooded Tinakore heights] are included in the Belt of land reserved all round the Town for public purposes, strict precautions may be taken to preserve the timber from depredation. Ibid. 175 ... necessary reserves for public purposes, including a broad Belt of land round the Town for the recreation of the inhabitants; ...

Author: HAAST
Quote:
If the citizen [of
Christchurch c1866]
went out to the
Belts, the
boulevards of the
City, he found ...
the trees that had
been planted in the
East [Belt] had been
neglected, ... the
iron enclosures were
rusted, the
plantations infested
with weeds, ... the
footpaths covered
with grass. ... The
North Belt towards
the East was a
narrow foot-track
...
(P. heterophylla) was more abundant on the Belt than it is now.

Author: ADAMS
Quote:
Their way lay along
`the Belt' that
broad band of Native
bush which encircles
Dunedin.
The wax-eye (Zosterops lateralis), too, used to build in the bush on the Belt, and even in suburban gardens, and was decidedly more abundant than is the case now. ...

On the suburban side
of the Belt all to
the eye was uniform
and conforming, the
latest tar-seal
serving the affluent
middle-class and
their housing : new
cars breaking the
speed limit ...

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
On the suburban side
of the Belt all to
the eye was uniform
and conforming, the
latest tar-seal
serving the
prosperous
middle-class and
their housing; ...

Quote:
We shot with bows
and arrows; bows of
cherry, arrows of
bamboo or of hine
hine (we pronounced
it [in Dunedin]
henny-henny), the
whitey wood that
grew in the Belt
just outside the
back gate ...
belt ... Town Belt green area.
Notes: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; nf. 1986 NZPOD],

Quote:
[HOLD THE BELT, win
the prize; (transf)
take the cake], It
is reported from
across the Tasman
that when a sheep
was being shorn at a
station near
Penhurst, a
starling's nest with
one egg in it was
found in the wool.
To hold the belt,
Zealandia will
require to produce a
duck that has
hatched a sitting of
eggs in a collection
plate.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
Mrs. Roland Reed was
nearly as good with
the rifle as was her
husband. On two
occasions she won
the belt at the

Author: PASCOE

The treacherous

delightful walking.

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
benched out [of a

Author: DENNIS
Quote:
Beyond Top Hut the
track is benched for
maybe 20 minutes
before large poles
take over to mark
the easy, well-worn
path across the

One of my
correspondents,
tramping with her
husband, referred to
the `benched-out'
track they were
following up the
hillside, to be met
by an
uncomprehending
stare.... She, on
the other hand, knew
of no other name for
the kind of farm
track that at one
time was dug and is
now more commonly
bulldozed along and
up a hillside.
`Benched-out' roads,
she assures me,
climbed all over
Banks Peninsula
where she was
brought up and it
had not occurred to
her that the phrase
was in any way
unusual.

At Smith Creek
Shelter a
well-benched track
ascends gently to
the head of Smith
Creek...

Some of his

A capacity yarding

The sale attracted a

and many of the

Wairarapa.

On inland northerly

breaks develop
successively in

problem is very real
in holding-paddocks
and on hillsides
that are frequently
used as access

sheep aggravate the
position by camping
on these terracettes
...
bench ... 6. N.Z. a hollow formed by sheep on a hillside.

Author: CARR
Quote:
When the flax
arrives at the mill
it is weighed and
credited to the
cutter. The `bench
loader' then takes
two or three bundles
and puts them in a
barrel (heavy end
down). He then takes
the longest leaves
and places them on a
bench convenient to
the `feeder'.
...[44] The `feeder'
takes each blade
separately and
places the butt end
into the `stripper'
which takes the
green outer covering
off. ... The fibre
as it leaves the
stripper is caught
by the `fly boy',
who collects enough
to make into a hank,
which he places
convenient for the
`shaker'. The
latter, with a
motion like cracking
a whip, gets rid of
as much rubbish as
possible, after
which he places the
hank handy for the
`washer'. This man
places the fibre in
a vat, through which
... clean water is
running.

When he returned to

...the likes of

Sixpence [:] tanner,

For the shilling bob was the most common nickname in use, but also recorded is deener. This latter name was used more widely in New Zealand and Australia than in Britain. The sixpence attracted many slang terms - tizzy, tanner, sprat, bender, and a kick.

Quote:
The blanket tailings
or blanketings, as
they are otherwise
called, consist
mostly of iron
pyrites and other
sulphides, cobines
with quartz, and
contain a fair
proportion of gold
...that had escaped
over the silver
tables. These
tailings are treated
in berdans with
extra quicksilver
and ground up. The
berdans now in use
at the Thames ...
are generally five
feet in diameter ...
At one time a couple
of rotating balls
were considered
sufficient for the
amount of crushing
required; now, the
general practice is
to have a loose ball
as well as a
stationary one
attached to a chain,
and it is called a
drag ball; this drag
does more work than
a loose ball ... for
the drag grinds the
bowl as much as the
tailings.

mercury is added to

It's usually used
for testing the ore.

Author: McARA

Lag is a general term used to refer to a sentence or to an inmate. Examples are big lag (life sentence or preventive detention), a wicked lag (any sentence over seven years, life or preventive detention), and a bed-and-breakfast lag (a very short sentence). To knock your lag out is to serve your time in prison.

[I] concluded that what I'd found was the species Gymnopilus spectabilis, commonly known as big laughing gym. Eating this mushroom gives whole new meaning to the expression, " I nearly died laughing". That is literally what can happen. The victim goes into fits of uncontrollable laughter (perhaps because of the mushroom's psilocybin content), but also experiences nausea, abdominal pain, convulsions or death.

Quote: Bigeye tuna Thunnus obesus Widespread in topical and subtropical seas.

Theirs are the only
scales I believe,
since Mum and I
calibrated them,
using a full bag of
sugar, a number of
cans of vegetables
and a
bigger-block-of-cheese.

Author: POWER
Quote:
... an artillery
officer is
Biggy-bung; one
wearing spectacles
is Four-eyes or
No-eyes ...
Notes: [Maoris' nicknames for the whites in the party]

Quote: (And)

A team of
enthusiasts has
painstakingly dug
out a 500-metre
gentle uphill track
that will give
beginners and
families access to
what is becoming one
of New Zealand's
most popular bike
parks. About 35,000
cyclists have
visited the Makara
Peak mountain bike
park on the edge of
Karori this year.

Bike happy -
condition of some
dogs who, whenever
you start a bike,
won't shut up and
spend most of the
time in the paddock
yodelling at the
two-wheeler and not
the sheep.

I don't kill things
with a bike-spanner.

Long summers spent
in New Zealand
getting the cash
together to set off
in search of his
mountainbiking
fortune. There were
the cheese rolls,
sold at a local
race, the bikeathon
in the Octagon where
people guessed how
far he would go in
an hour (all the
time sitting in one
spot), more raffles
than he would care
to remember...

Author: MARRINER
Quote:
Lefty had contrived
to elevate himself
to first-name terms
with the bikies...

During 1976 bikie
gangs were again in
the news.

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
It was a snake and
his leg was pinned
under his bike. ...
We ... got his bike
off him. That was
the last time that
snake gave a Queen
Street bikie a
ticket ...

[a (youthful)
motor-bike devotee,
particularly one who
belongs to the cult
and whose behaviour
may be anti-social],
... no-one could
pretend that
commerce has any
more right than
`bikies' to run
noisy vehicles'

He called me a
`dirty bikie
bastard' ...

Special police
mobile task forces
similar to one set
up to deal with New
Plymouth's `bikie'
invasion last
week-end, may be
widely used. The
police
officer-in-charge of
the Wellington
division,
Superintendent E.J.
Trappitt, said
yesterday that the
concept of task
forces was being
developed to meet
the mobility of
`bikies'. He said
that the movement of
`bikies' was a
recent development.

Two children
suffered injuries at
Waihi Beach on
Saturday morning
when a speeding
bikie swept up a Kon
Tiki line which
dragged them into
the tide. The
children both
suffered burns from
the nylon line. The
motor-cyclist,
reported to be a
member of a gang,
was riding illegally
...

Author: JUSTIN
Quote:
We were ordered to
our cells, ... and
it was found that an
ex-bikie was
missing. ... The
bikie was an overfat
... and universally
hated prisoner.

Author: BELL
Quote:
Well he knew it not
just Maori, cause
they all left
Hawaiki,/ And he
knew he must warn
other tribes and
wished he was a
bikie./ But of
course there wasn't
any roads, only
little tracks,/ Just
wide enough for
little sleds and
Maori wild dog
packs.

Author: CLEARY
Quote:
... but what can one
old woman do with
night coming down
and nobody to
protect her from
these larrikins. ...
In two minutes each
of these bikies has
a heavy hand on his
neck. ...

There are a number
of MOTOR-CYCLE gangs
in New Zealand whose
young MEMBERS model
themselves largely
on the `Hells
Angels' although the
all Maori `Mongrel
Mob' might not like
that description.

Source: Avondale College Slang Words in Use
Quote: bikies: motorbike gang
bikie n. Austral. sl. one who is dedicated to riding a motorcycle, often in a gang.

Author: DUCKWORTH
Quote:
Punks, bikies,
trainee civil
servants, inner-city
fringe people, clad
in Opportunity Shop
garments.

Author: REILLY
Quote:
He was little better
than a bikie, the
only difference
being he wasn't
Maori and he didn't
belong to a gang as
such.

Author: McGILL
Quote: bikie member of motorbike gang. NZA.

Where else are they
so big on
hypocorisms? ...
They're those dinky
little words we make
up, like these:
kiddies (children),
cardies (cardigans),
boatie (person who
sails boats),
yachtie (person who
sails yachts),
drinkies (drinks),
bikies (people who
get together to ride
motorbikes),
wrinklies (old
people), rellies
(relations), wellies
(Wellingtons, as in
gumboots), wallies
(variation on
wankers), littlies
(children).

When they got back
to the farm Chris
had arrived. He
heard them ... and
saw, bullocking in
through the gate,
two 650s, red, and
orange, on one a
Maori ... riding out
of any bikie saga
...

Author: Grace
Quote:
Some like the mural.
Others think it
modern and hideous
and say that
ancestress Ngarua
has been made to
look like a gang
member or a bikie.

Author: MANTELL
Quote:
`Kind of totem
thing. Bikie gangs
in Auckland - all
the rage. Sort of
paramilitary thing.'

An estimated 5,000
motorcyclists have
joined today's
"bikoi" protesting
ACC levy rises,
according to
organisers.

Up to 3000
motorcyclists are
expected to roll
into the capital on
November 17 for a
"bikoi", over
proposed rises in
ACC levies.

Christchurch is a
very biky place, and
it was not
surprising to find
that the next claim
was in respect of a
machine also.

BIL left New Zealand
three years ago,
when it moved its
head office to
Singapore...

Perhaps that is why
Brierley Investments
Ltd, which has done
so much to change
the face of pushier
cities, is holding
its annual meeting
here today... "The
BIL annual meeting
turned into a
love-in yesterday."

Author: POLACK
Quote:
... the casks [of
whale oil] ... are

being upwards, and
the body of the
casks kept apart
from touching each
other, bedded and
quoined with small

Author: HYDE
Quote:
And the strike was
no baby. 1913
brought Prime
Minister Bill
Massey's Cockits
riding into town -
strikebreakers armed
with pick-handles
and ready to smash
any head that came
in their way.

It is only in what
the homely settlers
speak of as "Bill
Massey's district"
that the character
of the soil is
revealed by the
plough.

So "Bill Massey's
stew," as it is
called, has
out-lived its former
position as the
stock camp joke.

Author: BURTON
Quote:
Great days for "Bill
Massey's tourists" -
the most glorious
picnic they had ever
had.

Author: MILLER
Quote:
(Preface), The story
of my adventures as
one of `Bill
Massey's Tourists'
...

Cyprus would be nice
to see, just the
thing for `Bill
Massey's tourists',
but I would rather
be going to France
..

Author: PUGSLEY
Quote:
All the action was
in France and `Bill
Massey's Tourists'
were stuck among the
desert sands;
letters home were
now full of
complaints.

Author: BOYACK
Quote:
We have boots which
weight [sic] about a
stone, regular Bill
Massey's farm yard
brand with nails in
the soles very handy
for fighting.

Author: GORDON
Quote:
These [mustering]
gangs were made up
of men who'd taken
up the "burnt
chops", ate "hockey
sticks", wore "Bill
Masseys" slept in a
"scratcher" and rode
pigskin .. hockey
sticks are chops,
Bill Masseys, boots.

For many years, Dad
kept an old Army
overcoat... He
affectionately
called it his 'Bill
Massey', as William
Massey was Prime
Minister of New
Zealand at the time
that these coats
were issued during
the First World War.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
As one squad clumped
along in their
newly-acquired "Bill
Masseys", the
instructor gave the
command, "Right
turn!"

Many of our party
had already..
provided themselves
with more or less
comfortable boots of
the type known
amongst the Diggers
as "Bill Masseys".

They are New
Zealanders; and they
wear Bill Massey's
boots.

Just now "Bill
Massey's boots" are
in high favor.

The long march was
made even more
unbearable by the
ill-fitting "Bill
Massey" boots the
soldiers wore.

[Slang of the NZEF]
Issue boots were
`Bill Masseys.'

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Bill Massey's. NZ army-boots: New Zealand soldiers': in GW Ex the late Wm. Massey, who was the NZ War Minister.

Author: BAKER
Quote: Among numerous terms originated in the first Great War we may note Bill Masseys for army boots issued in this country.
Bill Masseys n. army boots in World War 1 [From name of N.Z. Prime Minister].

Having rolled my
swag up in
regulation style,
and having provided
myself with bill-can
and nosebag, I made
a start from
Woodville on June 22
for fresh fields and
pastures new.

The latter [sc.
Maori] were armed
only with bill
hooks, but no
dangerous wounds
were inflicted.

Source: From New Plymouth to New Plymouth
Author: WOOD

The fern is fired;

ready after

...

House and opened our

Ibid. 129 The line of survey has to be taken across a certain country ...; though it should be ... thick tangled and heavy bush and undergrowth, the party with their bill-hooks and fern slashers must cut their way.

an appointment, a

he couldn't get a

[a (? Government)

I was a fairly

That was the reason

Billet. In the 'nineties station hands spoke of `a permanent b.', where they now [1933] speak of a `job'. In those days a man's job was his allotted task, and his billet was his appointment. (C.)

I sat on a log and

night.

The water swirled

Biĺ.ly (b&ibreve.ĺ.l&ybreve.), n. [Add.] 3. A bushman's kettle; a cylindrical tin vessel with detached lid and arched wire handle; - sometimes called billy-can.

Author: HYDE
Quote:
There was no one
with whom to argue;
at three o'clock,
beef tea came up in
billies.

billy: Tin can used

Quote:
billy: tin with lid

camping in

Primus.

dispensed into

Author: KENNAWAY
Quote:

are stuck against
the quickly-dying

Each swagman carries

Quote:

wood to boil a small
billy

Author: BATHGATE
Quote: It is true that there were large tins of boeuf bouilli containing not very palatable boiled beef, with a good deal of liquid, which were obtainable and used for ships stores. The contents were commonly called soup and bully, and the cannisters bully cans, from which the popular name of `billy' for a tin pitcher is undoubtedly derived. [Bathgate is possibly following Morris's Austral English surmise.]

Author: SIMPSON
Quote:
This billy is an
article much like an
outsize in
preserved-peach
cans; indeed its
real name is
billy-can. It has a
wire handle on it as
a bucket has, and a
lid as a saucepan
has. ... The billy
is found in almost
every home
throughout Australia
and New Zealand.
Where milk is not
delivered in
bottles, the billy
is `put out' at
night to receive the
morning supply.

Author: WALKER
Quote:
Monday, got in
stores at the
following rates and

9d. tea 4/6 a good
handful ... Pick
15/6 Shovel 10/- Tin
dish 6/- Billy 3/6
small swing pot for
boiling

..., panikins, and

Notes: 1863 Lauper in 1960 Pascoe (ed) Over the Whitcombe Pass 25

Author: BUTLER
Quote: On to other D's, with which his saddle was amply provided, he strapped his Erewhonian boots, a tin pannikin, and a billy that would hold about a quart. I should, perhaps, explain to English readers that a billy is a tin can, the name for which (doubtless of French-Canadian origin) is derived from the words `faire bouillir.' frying pan to cook his flapjacks.

Author: MANSFIELD
Quote: I'll send the kid down with the things and a billy of milk. Shall I knock up a few extry scones to take with you ter-morrow? c1920s Eliza McKenzie in Outlook in 1975 Knight Poyntzfield 20 [reference Wellington 1850s] Meantime the Mothers had again boiled the `tin can', (the word billy was not used then[sc Wellington, 1850s]) which did duty for a kettle as well, as a tea pot, ... .

course very silly,/
... We're told lost
the run of his
billy,/

... the billey (a

[A boatman of
Waitaroa, West Coast
of Fiordland] says
he heaved the eggs
away `because they
would not go in the
billy.'

Author: WOOD
Quote:
Well ... the chief
thing in my
recollection is the
billy - a large,
black, strong one it
was - that gave us
tea when we were
thirsty, and food
when we were hungry;
...

Author: ROCHFORT
Quote:
On awaking in the
morning we were
disappointed to find
a light head wind
blowing, and a
number of ships of
all sorts and sizes,
from the noble `East
Indiaman' to the
clumsy `Billy boy,'
wind-bound like
ourselves; ...

Starting as a
billy-boy, he worked
at just about every
job in the next 3
and a half years -
on the skids,
loading timber;
breaking down logs
in the sawmill;
driving logging
trucks, a TD18 dozer
and chainsaw felling
of native trees.

The only point I
want to make is that
my experience of
mountains is lengthy
although it may not
be deep - billy boy
to the botanists of
the `twenties',
mountaineering and
field collecting for
geologists in the
`thirties'.
Notes: 1960 Report of Ninth Science Congress May 12-17: Proceedings of Royal Soc. of NZ 144

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
As the "billy boy,"
it was my job to get
to camp before dark,
light the fire and
start the dinner.

Here you find boys
of scarce fourteen
eager to take on a
job as billy-boy, a
by no means enviable
task.

Author: COULSON
Quote:
Cutting grass seed
was dry work, and
there was a regular
break for a drink.
It fell to the lot
of the Billy Boy to
provide this. 2.

Source: Farm on the Wanganui River, A
Author: ALLEN
Quote:
I was fleeco,
billy-boy and
rouseabout.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
As the billy-boy, it
was my job to get
back to camp before
dark, get the water,
light the fire and
start the dinner.
[billy boy]

Author: McKAY
Quote: BROWN BILLY BREAD wheatmeal ... baking powder ... salt ... treacle ... cream and milk ... Let the mixture rise in billy ten minutes (on the rack) before baking.
BILLY BREAD ... flour ... wheatmeal ... salt ... B.P. ... golden syrup ... milk. Mix ... into a wet dough, grease and flour the billy, bake for 2 hours with lid on.

Regarding the usage
... `billy bread or
loaf' you can use
either, some say
`billy bread'. I
have made it for
years past.

Brian occasionally
made a billy brew
but mostly there was
thermos tea and a
loaf of white bread,
so soft.
BILLY CAKE ... flour ... sugar ... butter ... sultanas or currants ... baking powder ... milk ... egg ... place in billy, and bake ... until cooked.

Author: SCANLAN
Quote:
`Pooh! I'd rather
have billy cake with
raspberry jam.
Scones aren't very
special; we often
have them.'

Author: KOEBEL
Quote:
A request for water
to fill his
billy-can.

Author: DARE
Quote:
... I had to carry
down to the woolshed
an enormous billy
can of tea ...

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
Or even back in
Forli in the billet
drinking plonk from
chipped mugs with
Mick pouring it out
from the section
[93] billycan.

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
Quite a few were
present ... and Jim,
with Mollie, ...
sauntered off
together, armed with
billy cans and
baskets [to gather
blackberries].

Author: HOGAN
Quote:
Days of Billy-can
and Pikau,/ Horse
and Buggy, sleet and
snow,/ Railway camp
and crowded
`Boozer',/

Author: CHARLES
Quote:
Wherever men worked
or played ... they
brewed tea. And why
call it a billycan?
I have never found a
satisfactory answer
to that one.

Author: TRAIL
Quote:
`Where is the
billy-can and the
gooseberries?' our
mother asked.

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
The shrapnel could
be pretty thick ...
once we got a shower
of it just when we
were brewing up tea.
It riddled our
billy-can and we
lost all our tea.

Author: HUDSON
Quote:
... watching the
billycan boil.

Author: MASON
Quote:
Here, in the summer,
we would go with our
billies and pull the
soft, reluctant
fruit off the bushes
putting one in the
can for every three
we ate. ... One
afternoon ... four
of us ... took our
billycans to the
mudflats and began
to fill them.

Author: SIMPSON
Quote:
This billy is an
article much like an
outsize in
preserved-peach
cans; indeed, its
real name is
billy-can.

In many suburbs
billy cans are still
used for deliveries,
the milk being
ladled out of a
container that is
open to germs and
dust.

Author: PFAFF
Quote:
Mr.McParland sent to
Dunedin for 100
billy cans, but ...
abbreviated by
writing 100 billies,
first boat. The boat
duly arrived with
the 100 billies, but
... they turned out
to be goats.

Oh you
[bush-felling]
contractors in black
singlets and
bowyangs, fuelled on
spuds and mutton and
pumpkin and rice and
spotted dog or
deadman's arm and
black billy tea:
perfect toast
sopping with butter
and Cocky's Joy
(treacle): come into
our art galleries,
onto our stamps,
wrap within songs,
...

Heavily swagged
diggers and laden
horses whose swags
consist of all the
household goods of a
mining party, from
the black billy
which boils the tea,
to the tom cat which
kills the rats and
mice.
Notes: 1864 Apr 16 Otago Witness in 1976 Veitch Clyde on the Dunstan 29-30

Author: CRUMPTON
Quote:
He awoke about
midday and called
loudly for a crack
o' the whip, but
when told he had
made short work of
it the night before,
demanded a quart of
black billy tea, ...

Author: CHARLES
Quote:
Black billy tea,
boy,/ Black as it
can be,/

Author: SEVERINSEN
Quote:
Our evening meal was
a sparse affair
consisting of
copious supplies of
strong black billy
tea and little else.

... its buttressed
roots offer a
too-convenient place
for the
road-contractor to
`sling his billy,'
...

Author: FERGUSON
Quote:
The billy he would
sling afresh./ That
they might have .../
`A snack before they
went to bed'.

Author: PEACHE
Quote:
There was plenty of
scrub about so we
soon had a fire
going and boiled our
`billy'.
Notes: 1875 Dec 26 Peache Jnl in 1970 Gray Quiet with the Hills 38

Author: GUTHRIE
Quote:
He gathered sticks
and boiled the
billy, while
Elizabeth Mary
unpacked the
luncheon.

Author: WALKER
Quote:
We got in rather
late, ... it was as
much as Bill could
do to bake some
bread, cook some
bacon and boil the
billy while I dug a
trench around the
tent ...

Author: WHITWORTH
Quote:
We boiled the billy,
and had breakfast.

Author: MONEY
Quote:
We ... set to work
to boil the billy as
quickly as possible.

Author: STUD
Quote:
... one of them
should knock off ten
minutes before time
to boil the billy.

Author: PFAFF
Quote:
There was no
firewood to be had,
so we boiled our
billy on a long
stick we carried
with us.

Author: MANDER
Quote:
He moved on till he
found a safe place
to make a fire to
boil the billy for
tea.

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
[Speargrass] was of
no use as a rule,
but when dead its
stalks were useful
to boil the billy.

Author: HISLOP
Quote:
There are now
several bonnie burns
coming down the
mountain sides to
the river, the
largest of which are
the famous Roaring
Meg and Gentle
Annie; and a visitor
... may wash his
colours of gold from
almost anywhere
while his wee wife
boils the billy.
billy ... 3. boil the billy. Austral. inf. to make tea.

Author: ROGERS
Quote: [express billy's boiling, it's smoko time, time for a cup of tea] `Looks like the billy's boiling,' Broker said, nodding toward the kitchen ... `Come on mate. Put your knittin' away.'

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
Chaffey came over
one day to Les
Waghorn's dad
saying: `I've
brought you over a
bit of young billy.'

It may be pointed
out that in the
matter of
billy-boiling along
roadsides, drovers
are a class apart
and there is little
prospect of
suppressing what has
been a universal
custom, since the
earliest days of
settlement ...
Permission to light
billy-fires should
be granted.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
... a cluster of
stones by a bushland
river still charred
by a billyfire of
long ago, ...

Author: WAITE
Quote:
You could not do
better than bring
the cattle and some
rabbits, another
billy goat, etc.
Notes: 1840 July 6 T.W. Bessant in 1940 Waite Port Molyneux 12

Author: PICKERING
Quote:
Fires would have
been substantial and
built with a
dry-walling
technique that
wouldn't have
disgraced a
craftsman. Strong
Y-supports were set
in the ground either
side of the fire and
from the cross bar
would hang
billy-hooks, which
everyone carried.
There are many examples of rhyming slang in use at Paparua:..Billy Lid for a kid (child).

Oh, the days of
Hughey's tribute and
the doings that they
did! You had to
drink your grog
those times from out
a billy lid.
Notes: c1890-1900 Edwin Edwards `Waitekauri Every Time' in 1985 Penguin Book of NZ Verse 93

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
Often I was driven
to frying myself a
steak in the
billy-lid.

Author: MUELLER
Quote:
We have no plates -
only pannikins, so I
ate my stew out of
one, while Price had
a billy lid for a
plate, ...

Author: WOOD
Quote:
... some other
facetious person had
crowned him with a
billy lid.
BILLY CURRANT LOAF ... flour ... sugar ... Edmonds' Baking Powder ... 1 egg ... butter ... milk ... salt ... Bake 1 hour not removing the lid till cooked.
BILLY LOAF ... flour ... wheatmeal ... goldem syrup ... salt ... baking powder ... Bake in No. 3 billy with lid on.
WHEATMEAL BILLY LOAF ... wheatmeal ... salt ... golden syrup ... `Silverdust' flour ... baking powder ... milk ... Can be baked in baking powder tins, well greased, and with lids on.

Regarding the usage
... `billy bread or
loaf' you can use
either, some say
`billy bread'. I
have made it for
years past.

In New Zealand about
85 per cent. of all
town milk sold in
urban areas is
pasteurised. ... Too
much `billy' milk is
still sold.

Author: McCREDIE
Quote:
BILLY SPONGE CAKE
... Have ready a
3-quart billy with
buttered paper; cook
with lid on 1 1/2
hours. Do not have
fire too fierce and
do not take lid off
till the cake comes
out.

Author: THOMSON
Quote: BILLY SPONGE. Four eggs, 1/2 lb. sugar, 3/4 lb. flour, 1/2 teaspoon baking powder, few drops of rosewater. ... Bake in a bread tin.

Author: FINLAY
Quote:
BILLY SPONGE.
Ingredients:- 4ozs.
Flour 8ozs.Sugar 4
Eggs No.2 Billy.
Time, about
3/4-hour.
BILLY SPONGE ... eggs ... sugar ... flour ... put in a greased billy sprinkled with sugar, bake ... not removing the lid of the billy.

Author: CHERRILL
Quote:
And in true New
Zealand style, I
suppose I had better
send her the recipe
of a billy-sponge.

Author: R MASON
Quote:
A sponge cake of a
particular shape and
type. Not made with
the usual
sponge-cake
mixture'.

Billy Sponge. 4
eggs, 8 oz. sugar, 4
oz. flour, pinch of
salt. Whisk the
eggs. Gradually beat
in the sugar. Pour
into a greased and
floured billy or
loaf tin. Sprinkle
with castor sugar.
Bake at 325[degree
sign] for 3/4-1
hour.

Author: HYDE
Quote: Starkie ... was off again - not entirely discouraged, for he had eggs, bacon, and billy tea in his stomach and [pounds]26 in his pocket. Ibid. 70 Rannock fed his prison labour on honest bush food: fresh meat, billy tea, enormous flat damper scones cooked on the three-legged camp oven.

Author: BACON
Quote:
The workmen were
having a spell ...
The foreman nodded
as we came near,
squinting up at us
from where he sat
nursing a mug of
black tea. `Goodday,
mates. Like a mug of
brew?' ... `Yeah,
there's plenty in
the billy.'

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
But after a good
strong brew of
billy-tea I was able
to carry on, ...

Author: HALEY
Quote:
Red tea it used to
be called
...[sic]somewhere.
Billy tea.

Author: SLIGO
Quote:
The fire was going
... The black billy
tea stewed.

Author: PICKERING
Quote:
Of billy tea.
Waiting until the
billy boils,
throwing in half a
handful of tea,
trying to hook the
billy off the fire
before it boils
over, and tapping
the side with a
spoon to settle the
leaves. Then
demonstrating a
touch of skill by
pouring the tea over
the billy handle and
into your chipped
enamel cup and
swallowing the brew
in hot blowy gulps.

Nowadays, musters
are completed in
days using
helicopters and
4WDs. Hob-nailed
boots, billy tea and
camp ovens have been
replaced by GPS
locators, energy
drinks and Vibram
rubber soles.

With a cushion to
our backs and a
generous plate of
good things on our
knees and a cup of
steaming hot "billy
tea" we feel it is
indeed a happy and
restful Christmas
Day... Again the
billy is boiled and
after tea we set our
faces homeward.

Author: MORELAND
Quote:
In a few minutes we
were grouped about,
sitting and
standing, lunching
off girdle scones,
current cakes,
pineapple, and
'billy tea'.

Source: Tetaka Kai: A Book of Well Tried Recipes
Quote: BILLY TEA A clean billy, good water that has percolated through pumice ... Have ready a white linen rag in which is placed 1/4 oz of tea, loosely tied ... Let the water simmer ... take out the bag. Drink without milk ...

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Tea ... Billy-tea, or Bush-tea. Tea made in a billy (q.v.) There is a belief that in order to bring out the full flavour it should be stirred with a gum-stick. New Zealand tea. Tea made of the leaves of the manuka (q.v.). See Tea-tree.

Author: WRIGHT
Quote:
The spuds and meat
were nicely done,/
The billy tea was
made.

Pigeon and kaka
stew, ... and ...
several large
pannikins each of
choice billy tea.

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
The billy tea was
soon ready.

Author: MULGAN
Quote:
She thought Hugh's
boyish enthusiasm
for billy tea
delicious ...

Author: LEE
Quote:
Pannikin after
pannikin of `billy
tea.'

Author: MYERS
Quote:
`Come down ... where
we'll be clearing
the gorse this
afternoon, Tara.'
`All right! and I'll
bring `Billy' tea.
...'

Author: WHITWORTH
Quote:
Again we drank our
billy tea and talked
of books.

Author: CHERRILL
Quote:
Is that what you
call `billy tea'?
She had watched him
throwing in tea by
the fistful.

Author: LYON
Quote:
We had been in the
habit of getting
water for the billy
tea at a little
waterfall above a
mountain pool, in
which there swam a
lordly and and
outsize kokopu, a
little more than a
foot long.

Author: JOSEPH
Quote:
We baked our own
bread in a
camp-oven, and lived
mainly on that and
fish and billy-tea.

He built a fire and
showed us how to
make `billy tea', so
the thermos flasks
were left untouched.

Author: SEVERINSEN
Quote:
Our evening meal was
a sparse affair
consisting of
copious supplies of
strong black billy
tea and little else.

Author: MACNICOL
Quote:
... we sat ...
outside the hut and
enjoyed our
billy-tea and thick
sandwiches.

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
`Years since what?'
Hubert repeated.
`Since I had a mug
of billy tea. Just
smell it, will you?
Nothing to beat it.
Billy tea boiled
over manuka.'

Author: KEENE
Quote: Porridge was eaten with treacle and the billy tea was well sweetened with sugar - ... Ibid. 108 Fill [a treacle tin] with water, punch a hole in the lid, hang it on a pot hook in the chimney or on a stick over a fire in the paddock, drop in the tea when boiling ... This is `Billy Tea'.(?)
billy-tea, tea made in a billy [Fr. bouiller, to boil].

Author: THOMAS
Quote:
His technique for
making billy tea was
correct. He waited
for the water to
boil, then dropped
into it a little
less tea than would
be used in a teapot
and allowed it to
boil just briefly
before taking the
billy off the fire.

Author: ROWAN
Quote:
We boiled the kettle
[and] made some
`Billy' tea.

Author: GRACE
Quote:
They drank their
`billy' tea.

Source: Life in the Hinterland of the South Island
Author: BRUCE
Quote:
After a breakfast of
chops, bread and
billy tea, we
drafted up our
different lots of
sheep.

Author: KEENE
Quote:
We supplemented this
fare with all manner
of pies and cakes,
`washed down with
billy tea' to quote
the boys.

Author: HOLCROFT
Quote:
No tea ... tasted
like billy tea, the
water boiled over a
fire of manuka cut
from the scrub with
dew still on the
branches.

Author: COULSON
Quote:
When the boss called
'Billy time' the boy
would have to trudge
down the hill to
where the billy had
been left in the
shade, carry it up
again, and go along
the line of reapers.

Author: MYERS
Quote:
... she was on her
way across the
paddocks, carrying
[35] the `Billy'-tin
and the basket of
good things for tea.
Notes: [Mrs Myers spells always with a cap B., probably mistakenly thinking thinking it derived from the proper noun, Billy.]

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
A cook once said to
the manager, `I wish
you would speak to
that there bullocky.
He walks about with
as much sangfroid as
billy-be-damned.

Source: Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand
Author: HOCKEN
Quote:
The sole comforts of
this miserable night
were boiled ducks
and billy-boiled
tea, unless one
might add that the
soaking clothes ...
were dried ... by
frost.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
Grateful were the
spells for rest and
smoke and the midday
billy-boiling
half-hour; more
grateful still the
sundown halt for
rest ...

It may be pointed
out that in the
matter of
billy-boiling along
roadsides, drovers
are a class apart
and there is little
prospect of
suppressing what has
been a universal
custom, since the
earliest days of
settlement ...
Permission to light
billy-fires should
be granted.

Author: HAY
Quote:
And so remembers all
a lively store/ Of
billy-boilings to
the evening star;/
outdoor tea-making

Author: MALCOLM
Quote:
The 1939-40 era of
the numerous small
dairy farms, some
being little more
than Billy-can
farms, is also gone.

Author: SCOTT
Quote:
Ned Ryan and Pat
McPhee.. Sat down to
Christmas dinner of
pork, doughboys and
billy-made tea.

Author: HUNT
Quote:
One night our house
burned right down,
way to billio up
there.

Author: JOHNSTON
Quote:
He's typical of the
modern generation.
I'm all right Jack
and to Billy-oh with
responsibility.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Billy carts were
absolutely essential
for a boy.
Originally this was
a box - butterbox or
slightly larger -
set on an axle and
with, preferably, a
pair of high wheels
off a discarded
pram, about an
18-to-20-inch
diameter, and having
long shafts.

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
And then we had
[c1913] a little
`billy-cart' - a box
with a couple of
wheels on it and a
shaft -

Author: GIBBONS
Quote: Then we had to catch the billy cart... Ibid. 21We had several billy carts in our time, all made from benzine boxes.

[Caption] We had a
little 'billy-cart'
- a box with a
couple of wheels on
it and a shaft - and
we used to go down
to the wharf when
the coal boats were
coming in, and take
a length of
four-by-two with us

Author: McGILL
Quote: billycart trolley home-made from cannibalised prams and leftover bits of lumber, possibly once associated with carts pulled by billy goats.

Author: FARJEON
Quote:
All are alike
attired in rough
jackets, moleskin
trousers, and
billy-cock hats.

Author: HUNT
Quote:
I levied
contribution on a
publican for a
billy-cock-hat.

Author: PYKE
Quote:
Only cherubs don't
wear `billy-cock'
hats, nor carry
`swags', as a
general rule.

Source: Pirate Chief and the Mummy's Complaint..., The
Author: SKEY
Quote:
So my head-gear I'll
have a billycock
hat. ... Now this
your stiff
belltoppers won't
do,/ One kick and
their day is done;/
So the billycock
soft my looks shall
renew,/ And let off
my innocent fun.

Author: COTTLE
Quote: ... billy-cock hat

She saw a man
standing at the foot
of the bed, dressed
in a check coat and
a billycock (or
bowler) hat.

Author: PHARAZYN
Quote:
Hunting goats. Robin
shot a Billy.

I myself put away
nearly a whole
`billy' full of new
potatoes.

Source: Holiday Trip to the Catlins District, A
Author: HOCKEN & FENWICK
Quote:
We had a hurried
lunch and a billyful
of tea.

Author: MARSH
Quote:
`Here you are, old
fellow,' said my
father coming
through the stunted
manuka scrub with a
billy-ful of spring
water.

Source: Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson
Author: HAAST
Quote:
... Mr. Burnett went
down for a
billy-full of water
...

Nothing but one loaf
of bread left, could
hardly get firewood
enough to boil one
billy full of tea.
Met some mourays who
told us of the new
digins.

Author: MUELLER
Quote:
I also turned out
Bob and ordered him
to boil a billy-full
of tea.

Author: WILLIAMSON
Quote:
Gathered a billyful
of mussels, which we
had for supper.
[chk]
Notes: 1866 Williamson Diary in 1870 Whitworth Martin's Bay Settlement 23

Author: MONEY
Quote:
Here was a grand
field for our
sharpened appetites,
and billy-ful after
billy-ful did we
consume of the raw
fish with great
gusto.

Source: A to Z Glossary of Wool Terms
Author: SQUIRE
Quote:
bin bale - a bale of
wool of mixed
contents from a
grower.

Author: WOOLPRO
Quote:
Bin bale - a
woolgrower's mixed
bale from which each
type of wool will be
taken and placed in
the brokers' bins
with similar types
from other bin bales
received from other
woolgrowers.

A series of
unskilled, low-paid
jobs followed [for
her] ... as bin boy
in a woolstore, ...

Doggedly, the
shearers went back
to the boards ...

Author: HAMILTON
Quote:
The shed had
accommodation for
twenty-five
shearers, but at a
pinch room could be
found for
twenty-seven on the
board.

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
All along the
'board' are doors
into the sheep pens
- catching pens they
call them - and
opposite them are
other doors called
portholes, leading
out of the shed into
counting-out pens.

A mellow finishing
touch inside has
resulted from using
varnished taraire on
the wall and gates
facing the board.

Author: CAIRD
Quote:
Immediately behind
the [wool] tables
come the bins
labelled for the
different sorts of
wool.

Source: In the Land of the Tui
Author: WILSON
Quote:
At the main entrance
of the shearing shed
.. stands a
wool-press and
behind this are the
bins ...

Author: MOWAT
Quote:
Put up two temporary
wool bins in the
woolshed for the
bellies and pieces,
then started to
plane boards to go
round the bottom of
the wooltable.

Author: MEEK
Quote:
We picked the locks
and stains, we
filled the tins and
swished the bins ...

Author: RIDDOLLS
Quote:
Bins for holding
wool after it has
been skirted and
classed are of two
types, fixed and
movable ...

Author: DOMINY
Quote:
Fleeces are expertly
folded and tossed
into 'bins'. In
addition to the main
line of fleece,
there are bins and
bales for belly
wool, topknots ...

Author: ASPINALL
Quote:
Landing strips and
top-dressing bins
were built in all
sorts of unusual
places in the hills
and on the downs and
terraces.

Source: Country Bloke and Other Verse, The
Author: MCMILLAN
Quote:
There's an airstrip
and bin where we
rode long ago.

Hill country unit
auction .. concrete
killing house, sheep
and cattle yards and
airstrip with 49
tonne fertiliser
bin. [fertiliser
bin]
Bins: Ore hoppers.

The security man at
the gate inspected
the bin and took
away their grog. I
can understand their
stopping young men
toting a couple of
dozen coldies on
their back, but two
respectable women?
What could they
possibly do? As they
were able to buy two
cans inside the Park
at inflated prices,
I wonder where
avarice comes in and
commonsense goes out
the window?

As the skinny joker
from/ the centre
curses the thing/
into gear and
collects/ a dump bin
on his way/ to
temporary safety

The T wing of the
shed, where the wool
press and bins are
located.. has a
large cellar
underneath, into
which the daggs and
such of the wool as

is passed through

Author: BATHGATE
Quote:
Meanwhile the
`pickers up' were
busy gathering up
the fleeces as they
fell from the bereft
sheep and carrying
them to the sorting
table, where they
[173] were stripped
of the `pieces',
which were thrown
aside, while the
best of the fleece
was quickly
classified, rolled
together, and
deposited in a kind
of bin, according to
its quality, whether
`clothing' or
`combing.'

Source: In the Land of the Tui
Author: WILSON
Quote: At the main entrance of the shearing-shed, which is a long building with pens down the centre, and an outlet at each end, stands a wool-press, and behind this are the bins into which the fleeces, after having been classed, are placed preparatory to being pressed. Ibid. 244 Meanwhile the shorn fleeces are carried to a large table in the wool-shed by a man appropriately named `Fleecy', and are spread out by four wool-pickers, who tear away the bad parts and fold the fleeces square, passing them to the classer, who, in turn, after a rapid examination hands them on to his attendant, and he places them in their respective bins according to their quality.

Author: WRIGHT
Quote:
No more mighty
fleeces crown the
bins like drifted
snow,/

Author: CARR
Quote:
Dag Cutting. - The

off the dirty
portion of the

cutter ... with a

into another bin. It
is then called
`second pieces'.

Bin: Receptacle for holding loose wool prior to pressing in either a shearing shed or woolstore.
bin ... NZ & Austral. receptacle for wool in wool-shed.

Author: BEARDSLEY
Quote: I like a little kip after my crib, but there's no time for that, not even forty winks, and I tell you there's times my tucker burns in my bingy all afternoon. Ibid. 242 bingy stomach

The wool removed by crutching is of low value and the amount per clip is usually small. For these reasons `crutchings' are seldom if ever classed except by the wool brokers when the wool is sent to them for binning. Ibid. 711 In `Binning,' the bales are broken up and classed into lines. This method of building up saleable lines is generally used in the case of small parcels of fleece wool and bales of oddments which cannot be included in the main lines without destroying their evenness. As each vendor's wool [712] is classed in the binning-room, the wool in each class is weighed and credited to the owner before being placed in its appropriate bin.
Binning: Broker service for the disposal of small or mixed lots of wool. Each grower's wool is classed and weighed to bins with similar types from other.

Binning [sc

Author: ANDERSON
Quote: On the Hollyford job the road went through beech-forest, but this was locally called birch. Woe betide us if we referred to birch trees in our correspondence with Head Office: we were reminded that it was beech and given all sorts of advice telling us that the botanical name was something like Fagus fagusti, and so on. Some people are allergic to beech trees and the local name for this allergic condition was birch itch. On one occasion a compensatory claim was sent to Wellington advising that the condition suffered was birch itch. Back came a reprimand about this use of the term birch - it should be beech, Head Office pointed out. Nothing was done about this until one day it came to the notice of our chief. He was quick to reply and acknowledge that the trees were beech, not birch, but the itch suffered by the men was birch itch not beech itch. It was locally named by them, and as far as his staff were concerned they used the term birch itch to describe the allergy caused by beech trees. There was no further comment from the Moguls in Head Office.

1. A tree with a
silvery bark. The
name of `birch' was
applied in error by
early New Zealand
settlers to
different kinds of
beech and is still
often so used by
bushmen. ...

Birch (b&etilde.rch), n. 1. [Add.] In New Zealand the name birch is applied to all the native beeches (see under BEECH) and to all small-leaved forest trees; it is, however, qualified by various adjectives, - white, black, brown, red, silver, etc.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: In New Zealand, the trees called birches are really beeches (q.v.), but the term birch is used very vaguely; see quotation 1889. In Tasmania, the name is applied to Dodonoea ericifolia, Don., N.O. Sapindaceae.

As is well known, the Fagus family occupy one of the most important positions among the forest trees of the Middle Island ... Four species are recognized by botanists; these are known to settlers [of Otago and Canterbury] by the names of Black, White or Red Birch, not Beech, which would be their more correct designation.

[Ferns] contrasting

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL

Author: GUTHRIE
Quote:
[caption facing]
`BUSH' SHOWING BIRCH
TREES AND FERNS

Birch. Various species of Nothofagus. There are various kinds (white, red, black etc.) of trees in New Zealand called birches. They are all really beeches and the newspapers and forestry people are trying to get them so called, but up country they are still always called birches. Birch (creeks, hill, etc.) is one of the commonest components of local names in the South Island. ([1898 Morris Austral-English], and an unpublished letter to Hunter Brown from Dr Hodgkinson, August 9, 1854.)

Fagus Solandri. - The most common name of this tree is `black-birch,' but it has several other names. In the Wellington and Marlborough districts it is called `black-birch'; in Canterbury it is called `black-birch,' `white-birch,' `red-birch,' and `brown-birch'; in Otago it is known as `white-birch,' `black-birch,' or black-heart birch.' Young specimens of this tree that have no dark heart-wood are often called `white-birch.' This tree is a beech, and it would do away with confusion if it was called `black-beech'. Fagus Menziesii. - The commonest name of this tree is `silver-birch,' but it is often called `brown-birch,' `red-birch,' and `white-birch' [308] in different localities. It would be best to call it `silver-beech,'though it is gaining an Australasian reputation as `Southland beech.' Fagus fusca. - In Auckland this tree is called `black-birch'; in Wellington `red-birch'; in Nelson, Marlborough and Westland it is called `brown-birch'; and in Otago it is called both `red-birch' and `bull-birch.' The most suitable name is `red-beech.'

The utmost confusion
prevails among the
common names of the
birches. There are
scarcely two
districts, a few
miles apart, in
which the same name
is applied to the
same tree, and a
similar result may
be obtained by
consulting two
bushmen in the same
bush. With a view to
obviating this
difficulty Mr Kirk
suggests `the
adoption of new
names based of the
obvious
characteristics of
foliage [e.g.] for
Fagus fusca
`tooth-leaved beech'
...

[this cit. not spec.
repeated in
individual entries]
[In Oxford Forest] I
learned that the
tree [F. solandri,
entire-leaved beech
] was termed [red,
brown, white, black,
and yellow] birch at
different stages of
its growth, but the
application of these
terms differed
greatly; perhaps
Black Birch was most
generally applied to
the mature condition
before decay
commenced, and White
birch to the young
state; but there
were too many
exceptions to allow
the names to be
anything but
misleading.

The perversity with
which the true
`beeches' have
become popularly
known as `birches,'
and different kinds
of `mapau' as
`maples - a popular
name which includes
small trees of
widely distinct
Natural Order, is
enough to fill with
despair any botanist
who desires to
foster a system of
popular names that
will be free from
misleading and
inaccurate
suggestions.

'... the term birch
may be regarded as a
generic name applied
by bushmen to any
small-leaved tree,
and qualified by the
prefixes `black',
`white' or `red' at
the caprice of the
individual or as may
be suggested by the
colour of its
foliage, bark or
timber.' So the term
`black birch' was in
many districts
applied to
Pittosporum
tenuifolium [ ] and
to Weinmannia
racemosa [Kamahi] in
Otago - the latter
tree being also
known as `brown
birch' or `red
birch.' Myrsine
Urvillei [ ] was
known as `red
birch', and
Carpodetus serratus
[ ] and Quintinia
serrata [ ] as
`white birch.' It
was principally to
the trees of the
species Nothofagus
(then known a
Fagus), that the
term `birch' was
applied, and a
distinguishing of
the various kinds by
the prefixing of a
descriptive word was
a step in the right
direction; but in
this instance the
step was on a path
that led to a
quagmire. To take
only the instance of
N. Solandri
(formerly Fagus
Solandri). [v. 1885
Kirk] ... The
confusion created
has been endless ;
it has at times even
resulted in
commercial loss ;
[v. (Morris) 1889
Kirk `Forest Flora
of NZ p.91] yet so
strong is habit that
confusion was
preferred before a
change of name. And,
indeed, the bushmen
might well ask what
name they should
adopt ; for the
scientists came and
added to the
confusion by
pointing out that
the trees usually
called `birch' were
not birch at all,
but `beech' - when a
fresh crop of names
resulted.: `black
beech', `red beech',
`dusky beech', etc.
The scientists
themselves, however,
in calling the
species Nothofagus,
`beech', took care -
that is, usually
took care - to make
the distinguishing
prefix one that
would not lead to a
repetition of the
old confusion. N.
Solanderi was
accordingly called
`entire-leaved
beech' ; N.
Cliffortioides,
`mountain beech' ;
N. Menziesii,
`round-leaved beech'
; N. fusca
`tooth-leaved
beech'. It was some
time before even
these names were
agreed upon ; and
`silver beech'
finally took the
place of
`round-leaved beech'
for N. Menziesii. A
note may here be
made of the fact
that, whilst the
entire-leaved beech
was Fagus Solandri,
on Fagus being
changed to
Nothofagus, Solandri
was altered to
Solanderi ; but this
has been altered
back again to
Solandri ; for that
was the original and
not incorrect
spelling of the
word.
Notes: Andersen Popular Names ff Kirk in 1875 [Reports on the Durability of N.Z. Timber 16]

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: ... it is perhaps futile to hope that the more exact name [beech] will become popular ; but we might at least expect some consistent nomenclature to be adopted through the islands. At present the various species are designated almost indifferently, white, red, black, silver birch etc. What is white birch in one part of the country may be black in another ... The use of the name birch in place of beech is inexcusable, though ... N. Menziesii ... [shows] some external resemblance to the English birch.

Colour Coding
[heading] ... St
Patrick's Day sports
organiser, Mr Lyn
Thompson yesterday
inquired about the
difference between
red, black and brown
birch. It was

of the red birch is
silver, but the
timber is pink when
it's green. Brown
birch often has
black bark, but the
green timber is red.
Sometimes the bark
of the black birch
is white, but the
timber is yellow and
sometimes it's brown
when it's green.

The birch forests
(Fagus), which are
so important in the
South, are absent
from the North...

Author: ANDERSON
Quote: On the Hollyford job the road went through beech-forest, but this was locally called birch. Woe betide us if we referred to birch trees in our correspondence with Head Office: we were reminded that it was beech and given all sorts of advice telling us that the botanical name was something like Fagus fagusti, and so on. Some people are allergic to beech trees and the local name for this allergic condition was birch itch. On one occasion a compensatory claim was sent to Wellington advising that the condition suffered was birch itch. Back came a reprimand about this use of the term birch - it should be beech, Head Office pointed out. Nothing was done about this until one day it came to the notice of our chief. He was quick to reply and acknowledge that the trees were beech, not birch, but the itch suffered by the men was birch itch not beech itch. It was locally named by them, and as far as his staff were concerned they used the term birch itch to describe the allergy caused by beech trees.

It is Rogernomics,
Ruthenasia,
Jennycide and
Birchitis on a
regional scale.

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote: as common in NZ in a variety of senses and uses as it is in gen. Eng. - esp. bit of a, pronounced [ ] and often spelt bituva, used adjectively for `small, little', and also ironically in understatement as `large' (e.g. 1944 `I must 'er made a bituva mistake, and opened up yer nose'): also used (esp. by children) adverbially as `rather': e.g. `It's bituva hot in here'. These and other uses are attested in OED(S) and EDD; cf hang of a; collocations (A) BIT OF (A) [to go to file 3BI5 BIT 1.]. The expression is in constant use. It has different meanings, but each is clear from the circumstances of the conversation. For example: A bit of luck, A bit of a break The event is praised, its quality is genuine. A bit of a lark, A bit of fun There is no intense quality in the event. A bit of an ass, aren't you? The quality of the topic is weakened so that the remark will not sting as much. A bit of a hold-up (i.e. check to progress) The delay is brief. A bit of risk attached to it The proportion of risk is not great, possibly slight. A bit of a muddler, A bit of a no-hoper, A bit of a poor show The quality referred to is present in full force.

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote: Exaggeration is not an Australian characteristic and appears mainly in slang ...; understatement shows in style and unemphatic intonation rather than in vocabulary, except for the ubiquitous a bit. Ibid. 126 [qoting a Queensland survey] The word bit is common because it occurs in a bit (169) ..., a bit of (142) ... The word bit (1,241) is thus very frequent; compare two (1,253)..

With two guys you can bomb the other into drag by turning into `bitch' i.e. reversing the roles. see Bomb Someone Out

Bitch.-(1) Spoil or botch; (2) pour out tea. I thought these were colonial expressions, if ever there were any; but an erudite friend points out that (1) is used by Surtees in chapter XLII of `Handley Cross,' perhaps the most English book ever written, and that (2) is an old Cambridge University expression quoted in Gradus ad Cantabrigiam - a dictionary of Cambridge expressions, published in 1824. Let us hope that Samuel Butler introduced it to Canterbury.

~ Slang. To spoil or
make a mess of,
e.g., `You've
bitched the whole
thing.' (C.)

Nothofagus fusca, Hook. Tawhai Tawhairaunui, Black-birch of Auckland and Otago (from colour of bark), Red-birch of Wellington and Nelson (from colour of timber). --This is a noble tree 60-90 feet high the trunk 5-8 feet in diameter. The timber is excessively tough and hard to cut. It is highly valued in Nelson and Wellington.
Fagus cliffortioides Hook. f. .. Mountain beech or birch. [Fagus] fusca Hook. f. .. Tawhai, black-birch. [Fagus] Menziesii Hook. f. .. Silver or red birch. [Fagus] Solandri Hook. f. .. White-birch.

Author: HAAST
Quote: Fagus fusca, the black birch of the colonists, soon makes its appearance together with the two conifers Podocarpus Totara and Libocedrus Doniana, the Kawhaka of the natives ...

[Notho]fagus fusca, Hook. f. ... Tooth-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Auckland and in part of Otago and Southland. Black or Bull Birch of Lake Wakatipu. Red Birch of Wellington, Nelson, and in part of Otago and Southland. It is not so easy to see why any difficulty should have occured in the identification of this fine timber-tree apart from the misleading tendency of the common names generally applied. The thin yet firm texture of the leaf, the prominent veins, the sharply-toothed margins, are characters that can only be confused with those afforded by a careless observer. Yet merely owing to the use of common names based upon colour, and applied or rather misapplied to the leaves, bark, or wood at the fancy of the bushman, no species has been more misunderstood.

Author: HAY
Quote: The Tawairaunui (Fagus fusca) is a species of the former, known as `black birch'. ... [It] is not so plentiful in the North.

[Notho]fagus solandri, Hook. f. ... Myrtilloides cinerascens, Banks & Sol., MS. Cliffortiordes oblongata, Dryander. Entire-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Wellington, Canterbury, and in part of Otago and Southland. White Birch of Nelson, and in part Otago. Black-heart Birch of Otago. White, Black, Red, and Brown Birch of Oxford and Alford Forests. A fine tree, sometimes attaining the height of 100 feet, but usually 60-80 feet, with a trunk from 2 to 4 feet or more in diameter.

Quote: 9. Tawai, (Leiospermum racemosum.) This tree has a rough, dark-brown bark, and a small round leaf, in shape like that of an elm. June 26 [1958].
Minister of Finance

Black Budget, it was

The 1958 budget was

and union leader

1958 [heading] In

reduce demand for

local manufacturing

Author: LEVY
Quote: It was not so difficult to replace the forest with grass where the climate made intense white-ash burns possible after the felling of the forest. ... But in higher rain-fall belts, when poor burns (black burns) only occur, much forest litter remained unconsumed ... Ibid. 241 A steady, hot fire was desired in order to burn all fallen timber and leaf mould, seeds, and fern spores lying dormant on the forest floor. A white ash, called a white burn, was the objective; a black burn resulted from a less intense fire where the heat was not sufficient to burn the timber, leaf mould, seeds, and spores on the forest floor.

Murray was in a car

when they saw four
schoolboys walking
along the footpath.
Murray is reported
to have said: `I'm
going to get a black
tonight.' He then
asked for the radio
from one of the boys
who, in fear of his
safety, gave it to
Murray. Returning to
the car, Murray
said: `Look what
I've got - I didn't
even have to beat
him up for it.'

Source: Early Journals of Henry Williams, The
Author: WILLIAMS
Quote:
Mr. Marsden entered
with much apparent
interest, upon the
idea of a New
Zealand settlement
in Port Jackson;
that is to say,
within the Colony.
... [We think] that
it should not be
within one hundred
miles of Sydney;
that the natives
should not be
subject to visits
from the curious
intruders, ... [May
5 54] The natives
have had much
conversation,
relative to the
projected settlement
in New Holland; ...
They wish to be
distinct from the
whites or blacks, to
retain their own
teachers ...

`We want you! ... we can understand you!' `No, I am going to the islands [sc Melanesia as Missionary, later Bishop] to the blacks there.' (N.B. The Maoris speak of the Blacks with a little touch of contempt.) `You are wanted here! Never mind the blacks.'
Notes: 1855 J.C. Patteson in 1874 Yonge Life of John Coleridge Patteson 1/234 [Picton Maoris to J.C. Patteson]

Author: POTTS
Quote: Usually the black fantail, Rhipidura fuliginosa, called by the Natives tiwaikawaka, breeds under conditions ...
36. Rhipidura fuliginosa, Sparrm. Black Fantail, Black Flycatcher, Ti-waka-waka.
Rhipidura fuliginosa Sparr. Black Fantail. Remaining plentiful and widespread in the South Island, this species still occurs fairly frequently in the North Island.

pi[i]wakawaka, a bird (Rhipidura flabellifera), pied fantail: the so-called black fantail, which is chocolate-colour (R. fuliginosa) is ti[i]wakawaka. The former is common throughout Newzealand; the latter is common in the South Island but rather rare in the North and is thought to be a mutant of the former. Both names were applied to both birds by the Maori, but for distinction pi[i]wakawaka for the pied and ti[i]wakawaka for the black have been adopted by the Pakeha. The bird is noted for the disaster it caused to Maui in his struggle with the mother of night, Hine-nui-te-po, Death personified.

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: FANTAIL Rhipidura fuliginosa Maori name: Piwakawaka. ... Birds of normal colour pattern (`Pied Fantail') make up most of the population in North Island, but the `Black Fantail' (i.e. dark phase) accounts for perhaps a quarter of the population of the South Island subpecies; ...

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Fantail Rhipidura fuliginosa (SPARRMAN, 1787) North Island Fantail R.f. placabilis BANGS, 1921. South Island Fantail R.f. fulginosa (SPARRMAN, 1787). Chatham Island Fantail R.f. penitus BANGS, 1911. OTHER NAMES: Piwakawaka, pied fantail, black fantail.

Goaded in Parliament
by Associate Maori
Affairs Minister
John Tamihere, who
called Mr Brownlee a
"big fella", Mr
Brownlee asked the
Acting Speaker if he
could call Mr
Tamihere a "black
fella", a "black
man".

The
Tamihere/-Brownlee
big fella/black
fella exchange
threatened to tip
the House into a
cesspit of its own
making. Happily, the
round of apologies
that quickly
followed saved us
from suggesting our
parliamentarians
might like to stand
on their heads to
remind themselves of
the muck they're
making of our race
relations.

Quote:
The Anglo-Saxon

Englishman was a
match for several
"black fellows," the
term frequently
applied to the
natives, was now
universal.

MAMAKU (Cyathea medullaris). This is the black fern- tree of the settlers.

Our women's rugby
team the Black
Ferns, retained the
Canada Cup and their
unbeaten record,
while the Kiwi Ferns
league team were
unbeaten on its way
to winning the world
championship.

Annaleah is the
goalkicking centre
in the Black ferns
who are playing the
curtain-raiser at
next weekend's
Bledisloe Cup test
at the Sydney
Football Stadium.

New Zealand's only
successful national
rugby team this
year, the triumphant
women's World Cup
winners, will now be
known as the Black
Ferns.

She plays on the
wing for the Black
Ferns, as the New
Zealand women's
rugby team is now
called after
rejecting labels
like Gal Blacks,
Elle Blacks and She
Bs.

Better or not the
officially
sanctioned
substitute was
announced early in
August and the Gal
Blacks of brief
notoriety (along
with other canvassed
names such as Elle
Blacks and She Bs -
after ABs) were
finally history. The
team was henceforth
to be known as the
Black Ferns. Here
the colour adjective
fittingly remains,
and the noun echoes
the name sported
(since the early
1990s) by another
black-clad
international New
Zealand women's
team, the netballers
or Silver Ferns.
Since that title
itself derives from
the famous
fernleaf-cum-national
symbol of the All
Black jersey (to
wear the silver fern
is a common variant
of to be an All
Black), there is an
obvious
appropriateness in
reapplying the fern
to the rugby union
context. Black Ferns
is further
legitimised bv the
presence in the
natural world of a
black (tree-) fern,
in Maori the mamaku.

An off-duty police
commander in his
Jandals and a Black
Fern helped chase a
man who led police
on a 40km pursuit
through rush-hour
motorway traffic in
Auckland yesterday.

New Zealand's Black
Ferns lifted the
World cup for
remarkable fourth
successive time in
what is being hailed
as the greatest game
of women's rugby
ever . . the Black
Ferns' only try came
from Carla Hohepa
...
So, too, is the edible pith of the black ferntree (Cyathea medullaris); it is applied raw.

Author: WAITE
Quote: Black Flounder - Patiki - Rhombosolea retiaria.
Rhombosolea retiaria Hutton. I am not aware whether the black flounder is met with in the Otago Harbour ... but it is found in brackish water ...

RHOMBOSOLEA RETIARIA Hutton. Black Flounder; Patiki-mohoao. This species, known generally as `river-flounder,' is occasionally taken in the sea. Common in the estuaries of most large rivers, and often taken many miles inland.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Author: SPEIGHT
Quote: The four species of Rhombosolea are distinguished by form and colour. The best known is the Sand flounder, or simply Flounder, (R. plebeia) (Plate II. fig. 2) wider across than the other, while the Greenback (R. tapirina) with white undersurface, the Yellowbelly (R. leporina) and the Black flounder (R. retiaria) have their distinguishing colours recorded in their common names.
Notes: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 201

Author: WILSON
Quote:
FLOUNDER, BLACK More
sole-like in shape
than his cousin
flounders this
fellow also has
small, brick-red
spots on his back
and has the ability
- unlike the other
flatfish - of being
able to live in
pure, fresh water.
Other names are
`River Flounder' and
`Mud or Freshwater
Flounder'.

Another rare species
is the black
flounder, which may
be available in the
lower North Island
because a few are
netted at Lake Onoke
in the Wairarapa and
sold locally. It has
a dark green back
with darker mottling
and is dotted with
beautiful brick-red
spots.

Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery

It is known to fishermen and those in the fishing industry as the River Flounder as it is caught mostly inside or near the mouths of rivers and enters lakes where it lives chiefly among weeds. To some it is known as the Maori Flounder. I have helped to catch these fish in various rivers in New Zealand, Both in the North and South Islands, from the Bay of Islands, Bay of Plenty, Canterbury and Otago.

MAIRE.- (Olea cunninghamii and O. lanceolata.) ... BLACK MAIRE.- (Olea apetala.) ... MAIRE.- (Santalum cunninghamii.) These afford fine-grained timber of great density ... All are commonly called `Maire' alike by settlers and Natives. Black maire usually attains the largest dimensions, and is sometimes 40 feet high or more. Santalum is the least of the group, but even stems of this ... make durable fencing rails. ... All the kinds are confined to the North Island ... Eugenia maire black maire

NESTEGIS CUNNINGHAMII, black maire. A tall, stout-trunked tree of North Island mixed forests, recorded also from Nelson and marlborough but now common in only a few districts. The young sapling has longer and narrower leaves as has its nearest relative, the white maire (N. lanceolata).

Author: FORSTER
Quote: We saw a great Variety of bird this day viz. A white & sooty Albatross (Diomedea exulans & palpebrata). The black & sooty Petrel, (Procellaria aequinoctialis & fuliginosa) the black banded Petrel (Procellaria vittata); the small white rumped Petrel (Proc. pelagica) & we saw likewise three times a Port Egmont Hen, which is commonly thought a mark of the vicinity of Land. [ed. fn] The birds listed here are, respectively, the Wandering Albatross; Light-mantled Sooty Albatross; White-chinned Petrel; Great-winged Petrel; Pachyptila spp; Wilson's Storm Petrel and Antarctic Skua.

Author: BULLER
Quote: Majaqueus parkinsoni, Gray. (Black petrel.) ... I am quite satisfied that this bird is the `Night Demon' of our diggers. I had a live one ... from Collingwood ... No wood is to be
seen elsewhere than

(red pine), totara,

RAILWAY SLEEPERS
Wellington. November
11. Guthrie and
Larnach's tender,
for totara or black
pine sleepers,
delivered at
Lyttelton, Timaru,
or Oamaru,was
accepted by
Government at 2s 10d
each.

Hotel-keepers look
pleased and jingle
the loose silver in
their pockets in a
manner irritating to
one's feelings.
Firewood has risen;
black pine, 27s per
cord, in great
demand.

In an economic point of view, the chief trees of the Middle Island, are the Red and White Pine, respectively called by the Maoris: the former Mai or Matai (Podicarpus spicata),[fn] the latter the Kahikatea (Podocarpus dacrydioides). [ed. fn] Black Rue of Otago, Hook., f.; Miro, Black Rue or Black Pine in Otago, Hector; Miro, often confounded with Black Pine, Balfour; Matai, Colenso, - Mai or Matai (Taylor).
The most valuable for sawn timber are Black Pine, or Miro (Podocarpus ferruginea), having red, hard, durable wood. Ibid. 48 Black Pine. Podocarpus ferruginea, Don.

Author: KIRK
Quote: MIRO, also called BLACK PINE in Otago.- (Podocarpus ferrugineus.)
matai, a tree (Podocarpus spicatus), black-pine: often shortened to ma[a]i.
The miro or black pine (Podocarpus ferruginea) yields a gum used for the same complaints.

pine towers above
