Author: TORLESSE
Quote:
Kaikatea, (white
pine), mahi, black
pine, remu, (red
pine).

Here [at Taeri] was
the tall and
graceful black pine;
the manukau, a shrub
like the [Victorian]
tea-tree scrub, only
more greenly leaved;
a few broad leaved
grass-trees; the
mappo, the kolu, the
red pine, and others
too numerous for me
to remember; but
their leaves were
... delightful to
one accustomed to
the dingy foliage of
Victorian forests.

The black punga
stumps which dotted
the clearing
appeared suddenly to
have sprung to life.

Black punga and
brown tree ferns,
40ft high, with
lofty Nekau [sic]
palms, rise above
the thick
undergrowth that
lines this beautiful
work of Nature.
black punga [=] mamaku [s]

Author: MARRINER
Quote: I mean how many people've got the balls to whack even one Black Power member?

Black Power, says
Cathro, "are
verbalising a real
dissatisfaction
about something."

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote:
The predominant gang
denominations in the
jail varied. The
Mongrel Mob was
strong. After the
Moerewa affair a lot
of Black Power
members came into
the jail, anbd later
the Stormtroopers
arrived. But the
other groups, like
the Head Hunters,
Sinn Fein, the
Filthy Few, and
Highway 61, were all
present in smaller
numbers from time to
time.

In a dark corner..
about 10 youths two
patched Black Power
members in their
twenties are
drinking a slab of
beer, whisky and on
assortment of other
spirits.

At one end members
of the Black Power
gang stood about in
bandanas and black
T-shirts and tattoos
and attitudes of
lethal ease.

Author: BAKER
Quote:
'Saves me the
trouble,' says Puru,
a young Black Power
prospect, abused and
bullied at home,
expelled from school
and, at only
seventeen, already
locked into a
depressing cycle of
crime, court and
jail.

When he was Prime
Minister, Muldoon
took a personal
interest in Black
Power by helping
their work trusts to
plug into the
government lifeline
of the PEP schemes.

Robin once said to
me: 'My life is
Black Power, Harley
Davidson, then you
and the kids - in
that order.'

He had Helen Wong
from his office
working quietly with
Black Power in
Wellington finding
them scrub-cutting
contracts.

There will be a
hangi lunch
organised by Black
Power (so no
troublemakers) and
live music featuring
local bands the
Pauas and Six Volts.

Author: KOEA
Quote:
She glimpses,
briefly, a large red
truck, a Porsche and
four members of
Black Power on
motorbikes following
a bus full of old
ladies.

Author: FRASER
Quote:
Walsh, known as 'The
Black Prince', was a
highly intelligent,
iron-willed man.

Although of medium
height and stocky,
with dark hair and
features - he was
dubbed 'The Black
Prince' - Walsh was
a physically
dominating presence.

Within 12 [years], [Walsh] was expelling opponents and a communist publication announced, "The Black Prince has emerged." ... Oh, Walsh wasn't just a Black Prince, he was The Prince, sitting up there in his Seamen's Union perch, watching the sun setting over Wellington, holding up Marx's Wages, Prices and Profits and declaring "This is my Bible."

At times, even "The
Black Prince" (union
leader Fintan
Patrick Walsh) sat
up and took notice
of Doug Morton.

The "Black Prince",
as he was dubbed by
his one-time
communist fellow
travellers, famously
managed to
antagonise captains
of industry and
other Establishment
types.

The Black Prince, The Biography of Fintan Patrick Walsh is due to be published on Tuesday. It was the first successful biography of the union strongman, who ruled by fear, power and manipulation, Hunt said.

Not once in all
these years have I
happened upon that
dear little friend
of former days, the
black robin
(sometimes called
"the bushman's
friend") of the
southern bush ...

The land birds were
a species of pigeon,
which Mr. Travers
then wrongly
believed to be the
same as the New-
Zealand pigeon, the
black robin (Miro
Traversii) [sic] ...

Too many species
have been lost
despite the amazing
success stories such
as black robins and
takahe.

The black robin,
whose fight back
from the brink
became legend in
international
wildlife lore, is
now positively
populous beside the
black stilt.

Who better placed to
comment than Don
Merton, the man
credited with saving
the Chatham Islands
black robin and,
thus far, the
kakapo?

The black robin
population, which
was famously plucked
from the brink of
extinction in the
1980s, now numbers
about 150

Author: SHEPHERD

This day returned to

Duck a black bird

Island are

have excited the
conservation world.

Black robin Budget

latter-day greenie.

Quote:
Black rue Pine, or
Matai

There were about
forty men
black-sanding, and
they make a bare
livelihood.

Te Maika has rich
blacksand beaches,
and is within
walking distance of
the very extensive
blacksand deposit at
Taharoa.

Author: VON HAAST
Quote:
Generally the
greater portion of
the sand is removed,
but in favourable
spots, sheltered
either by a slight
indentation in the
coast-line, or by
some large pieces of
drifted timber, its
heavier particles
remain; these
consist [529] of
black iron-sand
(both magnetic and
titaniferous oxide
of iron) associated
with small garnets
and with gold. These
black layers are
often one or two
inches thick, and
repose upon coarse
quartzose sands. As
soon as a storm has
subsided, the
`beachers' or
`surfers' as they
are called, examine
the coastline near
their houses. When
they come upon one
of the rich spots,
the fine particles
of gold being often
visible to the naked
eye, they at once
remove the black
layer of sand out of
the reach of the
tide, and wash it
when convenient.
Notes: 1868 Von Haast in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 528-529

Quote:
Nearly the whole of
the west coast of
the Middle Island
... is auriferous
... a ship's boat
disembarked you on
the black sand of
the sea shore ...
Ten thousand diggers
... were delving in
the sand of a long
strip of beach sixty
miles south of
Hokitika.
Notes: 1885 A Forbes `Souvenirs of Some Continents' in 1895 NZ Reader 259

Author: HEINZ
Quote:
They give me a
shovel and with it
nearly full of sand,
direct me to shake
it gently in the
water till all the
sand has gone, then
round its rim is a
thin line of gold,
fine as dust, enough
to cover a
threepenny bit. This
is the easiest way
of getting gold, so
easy it is called
`haymaking', but it
will not last long,
as the black sand
brought down by the
rivers, with its
gold from the
mountains and cast
up on the beach
where it has lain
for centuries, is of
limited extent.
Notes: 18-- Harper Letters from NZ (1914) in 1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 10

Author: SAMWELL
Quote:
[with reference to
the Aleutian
Islands] ... we came
to an anchor in
about 30 fathms
Water with bottom of
black sand and
shells.
Notes: 1778 D. Samwell Journal 27 June in Cook Journals (1967) 3/2/1120

Quote:
The gold is very
fine, and
accompanied by a
great quantity of
black sand, from
which it is
difficult to
separate it.
[goldfields] Sunk paddock ... Saturday 24th. Washed hard from very early to very late and brought home the blacksand.
Notes: 1863 June 23 Diary of an Unsuccessful Digger in 1931 Aug 27 Star (Christchurch) in 1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 96

Author: HARPER
Quote:
... after heavy surf
[on the West Coast]
much black sand,
with traces of gold,
is thrown up on the
beach, ...

Mr. Skey found the
new mineral ... in a
sample of heavy
black sand, reported
as saved by alluvial
miners in Barn Bay
...

Author: KITTO
Quote:
It is most useful
for the final
process [of gold
recovery] when the
black sand has
travelled over the
ordinary tables.
The common associate of alluvial gold is the black sand of the miner, principally composed of magnetite ... which from its great weight is left behind with the gold.

... the auriferous
black sands ... The
rich black-sands of
Donoghue [sea] Beach
have already been
mentioned.

Author: BLYTH
Quote: Black Sand: These deposits occur all along the West Coast of the South Island and are composed of black iron and other metals sometimes carrying gold in alluvials also.

Such material in
this [Shotover]
district could
hardly be anything
else than the `black
sand' derived from a
dark rock containing
magnetite ... which
owing to its
density, is commonly
associated with gold
in fluvial wash.

Author: HOWARD
Quote:
Other seekers ...
moved down ... to
Codfish Bay, where
payable gold was
found in company
with black sand
occurring in
wash-dirt three feet
deep.

Author: HEINZ
Quote:
... all we got for
our trouble with the
tin dish were a few
colours and black
sand, which is
always an indication
that you are in
gold-bearing wash.

He shovels the black
sand into the gold
box, washes it
through with water
pumped from the
lagoon on the other
side of the sand
hills. The gold
falls on to the
plush (`I just use
an ordinary towel')
which is then shaken
into a baby's bath.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
Luring, encouraging,
enticing, odd
nuggets up to the
size of a small
fingernail bare
their beauty in
black sand in pan or
sluicebox.

Author: NOLAN
Quote: Blacksand: a dark, heavy sand composed chiefly of metallic minerals instead of quartz.
black sand black iron sand on some west coast beaches in NZ.

Source: Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
Author: VON HAAST
Quote:
In the descriptive
part of this
publication I have
already alluded to

Black-sand beaches on the West Coast. [heading] Ibid. 136 Apart from other mining pursuits ... is the black-sand industry.

Black sand, with its

tends to be

..the same
dismal-looking
vegetation - dry,
withered looking
tussock,
intermingled with
black scrub which
always in its
natural condition of
living growth looks
to the inexperienced
eye quite withered
and dead at a little
distance.

These spots, more
correctly termed a
"black scurf" are
the resting stage of
the fungus
Rhizoctonia, known
also as Corticium
during another stage
of its life. In the
black scurf stage it
is never a serious
blemish...

Black shag and eels
have also played,
and are playing,
havoc in many rivers
where trout used to
be plentiful.

About the same time,
the narrator of
these facts was told
by Maoris that a net
of worms was always
found in the upper
stomach of the black
shag, though the
bird never seemed to
be inconvenienced by
the fact.

Graculus carbo, cormorant or black shag; Graculus varius, pied shag; Graculus brevirostris, white throated shag; also another species of shag, locally called the `blue shag' ... pretty highly esteemed by the sailors as an article of food;

Author: HAAST
Quote: Of birds still belonging to the Avifauna of New Zealand, the following species were represented :- Graculus punctatus, spotted shag; Eudyptula undina, small blue penguin; Anas superciliosa, grey duck; Graculus carbo, black shag; Graculus varius, pied shag; Graculus brevirostris, white throated shag; Ossifraga gigantea, nelly; Apteryx australis, large kiwi, Nestor meridionalis, kaka; Stringops habroptilus, kakapo, and some other undetermined species.

There are thirteen species [of shag] in New Zealand Phalacrocorax novae-hollandiae (Black shag), P. melanoleucus (Frilled Shag), P. brevirostris (White-throated Shag), P. varius Pied shag, and P. punctatus (Spotted Shag), which I have often found in the inland bays, rivers, and lakes.

Kiwi as any black

Thus the men's
softball team has
become the Black
Sox, which plays
antonymously on the

White Sox baseball
team which name has

applied in full

associations!).

Our men's softball
team, the Black Sox,
created history by
being the first
country to have won

series.

The boys are members

trend
[speed-stacking]

America [hdg]
Ashhurst's Michael
Sadlier heads to

[hdg] New Zealand
has a new national
team - the Black
Stacks.

"Black Sticks" is
not the generic name
for all New Zealand
hockey teams. The
Black Sticks are the
New Zealand women's
hockey team.

And even the All
Whites is OK ,
because they were
the first to rip off
the All Blacks. But
then every man and
his dog was doing
it, and with each
stupid title our
sports team gave
themselves, we sank
deeper into the
murky abyss, with
the Tall Blacks,
Tall Ferns, Black
Caps and Black
Sticks dragging us
down at double
speed. When I heard
that one of our
teams had actually
named themselves
"Wheel Blacks", I
wondered whether we
had finally settled
in the sludge at the
bottom.

My dream is to play
for the Black Sticks
and eventually win a
gold medal at an
Olympic Games.

Hockey officials
entered uncharted
territory yesterday
by opting to call
their nameless men's
team the same as the
women - the Black
Sticks.

In Pied, a tight target-like knot of 50 black stilt heads is surrounded by a "widespread" (3nm in diameter) flock of pied stilts. This is a direct reference to the fact that in 1980 there were only 50 black stilts left in the world. One of the threats to the species was that it had begun inter-breeding with pied stilts.

New Zealand boasts
four endemic waders
not found elsewhere
in the world. These
are the black stilt,
now limited to a few

high ground in the

Island; the shore
plover, confined
entirely to a small
island off the
Chathams, where its
numbers are fairly
strong; and the New
Zealand dotterel,
red-breasted in
summer, rather
curiously nesting in
two discrete groups,
one in the Hauraki
Gulf, the other far
away at and around
Stewart Island -

Quote: `There are eleven species of Native Ducks belonging to nine genera, all found elsewhere, except two--the little Flightless Duck of the Auckland Islands (genus Nesonetta) and the Blue Mountain Duck (Hymenolamus). seldom affects more
than a few ewes.

Author: BALLANTYNE
Quote: `I'd like a nice piece of black velvet,' Clive said. `One of those quarter-castes, boy. They give you a good go for your money, they reckon.' Ibid. 263 I'd like a nice piece of black velvet. One of those quarter-castes, boy.

Author: FRANCES
Quote:
All they want is to
get you in the dark
and then go off and
boast they've had a
bit of black velvet.
That's what they
call us, [Maori
girls] Johnny. Black
velvet!
And ... the Rhipogonum scandens, or Black vine,with its numerous smooth black stalks ... is also a very striking plant. Ibid. 1/III/50 Black vine. Rhipogonum scandens, Forst.

R. scandens or Black
Vine, with its
numerous smooth
black stalks, dark
green shining leaves
and bright scarlet
berries.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Weka pango, black weka, a South Island variety.
O. fuscus. - Black Weka. West Coast of South Island.
Ocydromus fuscus (Black Weka)

An addition to the
aviary has been
received of 14
kakapos, 10 kiwis,
and six black wekas.

In the Sanatorium
grounds, and in the
pond adjoining,
there are a number
of weka (including
some black weka from
the West Coast
Sounds), kiwi, roa,
wild ducks, paradise
ducks
(putangitangi), and
a variety of other
birds.

The black weka is
undoubtedly becoming
more plentiful in
the Fiord County
Forest.

The baleen from our
Southern "right
whale," commonly
known as the "black
whale," is not so
valuable as that
procured from the
northern animal.

A black whale was
stranded yesterday
morning on the beach
about ten miles
south of New
Plymouth.

A black whale,
measuring between
forty and fifty feet
in length, has been
washed up on the
beach a few miles
north of Timaru.

The southern whale
fishery consists of
three distinct
branches .. second,
that of the common
black whale of the
southern seas

Author: BELL
Quote:
The black whale
fishery was tried in
New Zealand some
years ago, but it
was abandoned until
last year, when it
was renewed by one
vessel and two shore
parties from Sydney,
and one vessel from
Hobart Town.
Notes: 1831 Nov Bell Letter in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 3

Author: McDONNELL
Quote:
The black-whale
fishery may be
carried on to any
extent in the bays
...

Author: YATE
Quote:
... in Cloudy Bay
are several large
whaling
establishments; as,
in calving time,
that large sheet of
water is visited by
immense numbers of
the black whale,

The Island of
Victoria is peopled

(balaena

Author: WALTON
Quote:
From May to
December, the bays
of New Zealand are

or Right Whale; ...

Author: POLACK
Quote: Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called para[as-acute] paraua[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, mungu nui (black physeter); right whale, tohora (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, mango (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber);

Source: Narrative of Eight Months Sojourn in NZ, A
Author: HODGSKIN
Quote:
It had been for some
time the principal
rendezvous of the
South Sea whale
ships ... in search

whale'.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote: The black whales of the southern hemisphere appear to be considerably inferior in size to those of the northern. IBid. 1/162 It is called the `black whale, or right whale' (Balaena Australis, or Antarctica). Sometimes chase is given to the finback and humpback whale, which, with the black whale, belong to the great division of the cetacea known by the sieve-like or screening apparatus (baleen) with which they are provided; ...

Author: MONRO
Quote:
It [the finback] is
distinguished from
the black or right
whale by the fin on
its back, as well as
several other
peculiarities of
structure.
Notes: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 248

Author: MAJORIBANKS
Quote:
The black whales
have no teeth,
consuming their food
by suction. The
sperm whales ...
have teeth, ...

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote: [=right whale] They [shore-stations] are fitted out for the capture of the black or `right' whale, [fn Balaena Antipodum] ...; but occasionally sperm [fn Physeter macrocephalus] or hump-back [fn Balaena Gibbosa] also near the land sufficiently to be taken by the shore-parties. Ibid. 153 Of Whales, there are the Sperm (Physeter Macrocephalus), the Humpback (Balaena gibbosa), the Fin-back (Balaena physalus), the Pike-headed (Balaena Boops), the Large-lipped (Balaenopterus musculus), and the Black or Right whale (Balaena Antipodum).
He was authorised, should the prospects of black whaling not prove to be good to ... engage in sperm whaling. Ibid. xv/xvi Right whales, usually called black whales because of their colour ...

Author: RHODES
Quote:
... he plainly saw
[the crew] were too
lazy for black
whaling, and advised
me to go after
sperm.

Author: EVANS
Quote:
Then [after the
early non-galvanised
triangular wire] the

`black wire' as it
was more often
referred to. It was
almost the
equivalent of
quarter-inch iron
...

I look upon a wire
fence as worse than
useless,
particularly one of
No 8 black wire ...

May of the sheep
stations of the
present day are
still bound with
black wire fences
erected in the
1860s.

Author: EVANS
Quote:
.. the first round
wire or 'black wire'

Quote: Miro Traversi ... Found now only on Little Mangere Island ... Black Wood Robin. TOU-TOU-WAI, MIRO.

Author: BULLER
Quote: OCYDROMUS FUSCUS. (BLACK WOODHEN.) ... Native name.- Weka-pango. ... referred to by Captain Cook ... `They are a sort of Rail, about the size and a good deal like a [175] dunghill hen.'
(Reischek) OCYDROMUS FUSCUS, Dubus. - Black Wood-hen (Weka).
Ocydromus brachypterus, Lafr. (Black Woodhen.)

Gallirallus brachypterus Lafres. Black Woodhen. Philpott (1919, 222) gives an illuminating account of the ups and downs of this species. In the mining days `many were killed for food, and many more were destroyed needlessly by the miners' dogs.'

NO. A.89. - OCYDROMUS FUSCUS, Du Bus. Kelp-hen, Blackwood hen. It abounds in the many inlets and sounds of the south-west coast of this island. The only place where we noticed that it seemed shy was in Milford Sound. As soon as the tide begins to recede these dusky Rails come out on the shore to feed amongst the kelp.

The black woodhen..
is found in the
secluded forests of
the west coast of
Otago.

A solitary specimen
of the
black-and-white
oyster-catcher was
observed, an
occurrence that is
not common so far
north.

LARUS DOMINICANUS,
Licht. Kororo. Grey
Gull, Black-backed
Gull, Large Gull.

Quote: Black-backed gull .. karoro Larus dominicanus

Author: NATUSCH
Quote: Family LARIDAE (gulls). Of the three species here, the common red-billed gull (Larus novaehollandiae scopulinus ... ) breeds on islets in harbours and off shore; the black-billed (L. bulleri, ... ) nests commonly on the wide shingly river flats of Canterbury; and the much larger black-backed (L. dominicanus, ... ) breeds along coasts, river banks and on outlying islands [and is] our biggest and commonest seagull.

Source: Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ
Quote: 193. Larus dominicanus Lichtenstein, 1823 thern Black-backed Gull (Karoro [Dominican Gull]circumpolar ...

Quote: Dominican Gull Larus dominicanus LICHTENSTEIN, 1823 ...The New Zealand population has increased this century. ... OTHER NAMES: Karoro, southern black-backed gull, kelp gull.

Author: BROWN
Quote:
A lone black-backed
gull ... came to
investigate, but
Leaping Lena's back
tray contained only
a kerosine tin and a
broken fishing
grapnel.

She wanted to
commemorate what she
considered ":the
murder and genocide"
of black-backed
gulls in the area...
Over the years in
Island Bay she's fed
bits of bread and
meat fat to the
black-backed gulls,
and can pick out the
young ones before
they mature at three
years.

Author: Crowe
Quote:
Black-backed gulls
can live to 28 years

sometimes called the
Dominican gull from
the colours worn by
Dominican friars.

Gull breeds on the
main river-bed ...

Author: BULLER
Quote: LARUS BULLERI. (BLACK-BILLED GULL.) ... [Native name.- Tarapunga.]
Bruchigavia melanorhyncha Buller. Black-billed Gull. This species bred in 1907 in a South Island river-bed.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote: The birds breeding on [Bird Island, Nelson] were Caspian Tern (Hydroprogne caspia), Sea Swallows (Sterna frontalis) and Blackbilled Gulls (Larus bulleri), these in amity and friendship closely packed together; lastly ... half a dozen wicked pair of Blackbacked Gulls (Larus dominicanus).

The black-billed
gulls had already
departed.

Less plentiful is
the endemic
black-billed gull,
which is mainly a

Island.

Author: Moon
Quote:
The endemic
black-billed gull is
mainly an inland
bird, frequenting
South Island
riverbeds and lakes.

The black-billed
gull breeds mostly
in Canterbury, Otago
and Southland on
shingle islands and
on the shores of
lakes and rivers.

Immediately on
arrival at
Southland's capital,
we went to Mr.
McKenzie's Museum ..
He had three New
Zealand birds I had
not before seen.
They were a small
yellow parroquet, a
larger greenish blue
one, and a
black-crested
penguin.

Author: BULLER
Quote: DIOMEDEA MELANOPHRYS. (BLACK-EYEBROWED ALBATROSS.) ... Native name.- Toroa. ... This species of Albatross is far more common in our seas than Diomedea exulans, ...

The black-eyed gecko
was first discovered
on the Seaward
Kaikoura Range in
the 1970s, though
not formally
described until
1984. It is New
Zealand's only
alpine lizard,
inhabiting bluffs
and outcrops between
1250 and 2200 metres
above sea level.

Source: FMC - (Federated Mountain Clubs of NZ) Bulletin
Quote:
Insects and lizards
are particularly
diverse in the new
park, and include
three species of
giant weta and New
Zealand's only
alpine lizard - the
black-eyed gecko -
which has its
stronghold in the
area.

"Three species of
giant weta live in
the park and it is a
stronghold for New
Zealand's only
alpine lizard, the
black-eyed gecko."

Author: Jenny Jones
Quote:
The black-eyed gecko
was named after an
inland region of
Kaikoura called the
Kahutara Saddle, in
1985.

Black-eyed geckos
have been recorded
at 2200 metres above
sea level, and
Cascade geckos were
discovered in the
Sinbad Gully in
fiordland clinging
to rock ledges at
1600 metres above
sea level, suffering
from frost damage to
their bodies.

The black-fronted
terns are unlike
most terns in that
they live and breed
inland, only
visiting the coast
to feed in autumn
and winter.

Author: MYERS
Quote: Chlidonias ablistriata Gray. Black-fronted Tern. Oliver in 1907 found this beautiful tern breeding in at least two of the South Island river-beds.

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: BLACK-FRONTED TERN Chlidonias albostriatus Other namesra, Sea Martin, Ploughboy, Inland Tern, Riverbed Tern.

Author: NATUSCH
Quote: The somewhat stumpier black-fronted tern (Chlidonias hybrida albostriatus, ... ) is common on South Island shingle flats .

Source: Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ
Quote: 9.1 Sterna albostriata y, 1845)] Black-fronted Tern New Zealand; breeding on riverbeds throughout the South Island east of the ranges .

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Black-fronted Tern Sterna albostriata (GRAY, 1845) ... OTHER NAME: Tara.

Its vernacular name
is black-fronted
tern, and it closely
resembles the
white-fronted
species, but lacks
the white forehead
and black bill.

Its remarkable name,
however, is applied
on account of a
white band
separating the black
crown from the bill,
whereas in the
black-fronted tern
there are no white
feathers over the
bill.

BLACK-HEART A
heartwood
discoloration in
tawa and other
timbers.

The utmost confusion
prevails among the
common names of the
birches. There are
scarcely two
districts, a few
miles apart, in
which the same name
is applied to the
same tree, and a
similar result may
be obtained by
consulting two
bushmen in the same
bush. With a view to
obviating this
difficulty Mr Kirk
suggests `the
adoption of new
names based of the
obvious
characteristics of
foliage [e.g.] for
Fagus fusca
`tooth-leaved
beech'; for Fagus
solandri
`entire-leaved
beech' etc. [This is
unsuitable as
foliage varies] I
would suggest the
retention of the
common Otago names
Fagus fusca - Red
birch ; F. solandri
- Black-heart birch
; F Menziesii -
Silver birch.
Nothofagus Solanderi

Author: HECTOR
Quote: Nothofagus solandri, Hook. White-birch of Nelson and Otago (from colour of bark), Black-heart Birch of Wellington.--A lofty, beautiful evergreen tree 100 feet high; trunk 4-5 feet in diameter.

[Notho]fagus solandri, Hook. f. ... Myrtilloides cinerascens, Banks & Sol., MS. Cliffortiordes oblongata, Dryander. Entire-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Wellington, Canterbury, and in part of Otago and Southland. White Birch of Nelson, and in part Otago. Black-heart Birch of Otago. White, Black, Red, and Brown Birch of Oxford and Alford Forests. A fine tree, sometimes attaining the height of 100 feet, but usually 60-80 feet, with a trunk from 2 to 4 feet or more in diameter.

Author: KIRK
Quote: Nothofagus solandri, BLACK-BIRCH

35 Hand specimen,
entire leaved beech
(black heart birch).

Notes: (E. Phillips Turner) [Otago] see cit. 1 b. above.

Quote:
BLACK-JACK, OR
BLENDE.- Sulphide of
zinc.

Author: SANSOM
Quote:
He stepped off, but
with no confidence,
in another
direction; we
scrabbled around and
there it was, an old
`black-jack' or
`square-face' which
had held gin in the
early days.

.. for in those
years when
Marlborough is not
the balmy summer
suntrap enthused
about on
black-labels ...

Then - a teaspoonful
of gold dust, for
the two brothers
were black-sanders,
taking gold from the
beach, but only
occasionally.

Two or three
isolated settlers,
together with one or
two `black-sanders'
along the sea-beach
and a few bushmen
complete the
population of the
area. ... [25] On
the sea-beaches the
`black-sanders'
often have to wait
many weeks or months
before a payable
patch of black-sand
makes.

Author: MAY
Quote:
Eighteen weeks had
been time enough for
the black-sanders to
extract the
accumulated wealth
of centuries.

Ken ... is a
`blacksander', one
of the few left on
the Coast. His mine
is the beach where
the high tides wash
away the top layers
of white sand to
reveal the
gold-bearing black
stuff.

The `blacksanders'
reaped their
harvest.

The latest boorish
boss that deserves
pillorying is one
Francis, who is held
[to be] of what are
called the
`black-trackers' who
clean lines or
something of that
sort. [re: Tramway
Dept]

[Hdg] Zorbing not
for the
pink-knuckled... New
Zealand has
contributed the
terms zorbing and
black-water rafting.
Zorbing is an
entertainment where
those taking part
are suspended inside
giant plastic balls
and rolled down
steep slopes.
Black-water rafting
is the pastime of
floating along
pitch-black
underground streams
in inflated inner
tubes.

Making a splash is
what black-water
rafting is all about
- for rafters and
the new owners of
the original Black
Water Rafting
Company. Tourism
Holdings this month
takes control of the
10-year old business
which pioneered
trips for tourists
in inflatable rubber
tubes along cold
underwater caves of
Waitomo.

"We represent a
company called
Blackwater Rafting,
who are involved in
cave tubing," Mr
Bassett said.
"Unfortunately, they
lost exclusive
rights to their name
when a judge ruled
that Blackwater
rafting had become a
generic name for
cave tubing and
others in the
industry could use
it... For example,
Blackwater Rafting
was involved in cave
tubing, but the
media continued to
describe the
activity as
blackwater rafting.
The company should
have corrected this
the first time, as
by not doing so the
term eventually
became generic."

Source: Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ
Quote: [45. Pterodroma nigripennis] (Rothschild, 1893) Black-winged Petrel

Paper Plus offers a
little shrine to
Toddy,
Blackadderville's
favourite son.

The North Canterbury
town today
farewelled
"Blackadderville"
and rebranded the
place "Refreshing
Rangiora".
She let the Sunday Star-Times join her, husband Des and friends to watch the game in the living room of her Rangiora (also known as Blackadderville in honour of you-know-who) home.

Author: ELLISON
Quote:
At least she's a
Jersey, not like
those blackamoors.
For some reason Dad
had been persuaded
to go in for
Friesians a few
seasons before.

[Caption] Jhai
Henham-Croft, 11,
top, out
blackbaiting ..
Blackbait are
whitebait that are

as they feed in the

Author: McGILL
Quote: blackbait fish found in the brown creeks of the West Coast.

But Mum had
foresight. She stood
at the finishing
line with a
blackball, a popular
lolly [c1880] which
was Johnny's
favourite.

Author: SUMMERS
Quote: She said so to her father once, in a rather prickly mood because an old friend of his ... would produce a bag of blackballs and offer them round.

I always found my
stocking bulging
with presents of the

Usually an orange,
... a bag of
blackballs, ...

The eyes of the
young guests
sparkled when they

She brought a bag of
blackballs for him.
When he accepts them
... she coos and
pats him ...

As a schoolboy I had

given one boiled

- from an old,
curiously ornamented
tin ...

Author: HULME
Quote:
She brought a bag of
blackballs for him.
blackball ... 2. n. NZ black and white mint-flavoured sweet.

Quote:
I usually chose a

enjoyed rolling it

...

Suck that black-ball
at your peril, my
friend.

Author: VIRTUE
Quote:
"She used to share
lollies with me. I
think they were
blackballs."

Source: English as it is spoken in NZ
Author: BENNETT

Author: MANDER
Quote:
That night he added
[to the store's
stock] ju-jubes,
liquorice,
blackballs,
butterscotch and
sugar-candy sticks
to his next order.

Author: GRIEVE

... our latest
`stunt' is to reward
the tidiest with

...

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
And one morning ...
I went up to her and
said I wanted to buy
some blackballs. I
always did like the
taste of blackballs,
he said.

Author: PARK
Quote:
And Mrs Bedding, the
lolly-shop lady,
poured out all the
wonders she had
stored ... in the
back of the shop.
Black gelatinous
bears ..., the
blackballs, aniseed
balls, ... Hundreds
and thousands, musk
lollies hard as
bullets ... green,
white, yellow
conversation lollies
with inscriptions of
`Oh, you kid!' and
`Is that so?' and
sometimes,
blushingly, `You're
the cat's pyjamas.'

Author: BLAKISTON
Quote:
At the end of a day,
when I sometimes
gave him a hand, he
would fish a
blackball from his
pocket, and offer it
to me, saying: `I
always pay my
debts.' His
unfailing supply of
blackballs made him
very popular with
children during his
many years at the
Gorge.

Author: FRAME
Quote:
... a sixpenny shout
from her pay for
blackballs or acid
drops or ?.us; New
Zealand where really
woody Solanum spp.
are common.

Author: BATISTICH
Quote:
She called us 'kids'
collectively and
never came without a
brown paper poke of
blackballs doled out
to us from the
bulging pocket of
her check shirt.

He had bought forty
acres of blackberry
and gorse.

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: BLACKBERRY (Rubus fruticosus and [R.laciniatus]), occasionally called bramble, is commonest in the middle and south of the North Island, and on the West Coast of Nelson.
blackberry [=] blackberry: cut-leaved blackberry [s](?) ... blackberry [s] Rubus fruticosus agg.

Author: WADE
Quote:
Tataramoa: the
Bramble or
Blackberry of New
Zealand.

There was a
full-time
'blackberry man'

station hands

bushes.

Author: WOODHOUSE

Blackberries
maintained the
footing they had
gained, not only on

throughout the
district, and these
he poisoned
relentlessly with
'blackberry snow.'

Why, nowadays, there
is not a squatter
who does not know
that blue stone is

of ammonia, that

sheep drench carbon

Falla speaks]

Up Auckland way the
crusade in favour of
cheap domestic labor
[sic] has resulted
in a scheme for the
importation of a
number of black
`boys' from the
islands, said `boys'
being men who are
sent to the Dominion
under contract by
their relatives or
owners with whom a
regular slave or
`blackbird' traffic
will be initiated.

Captain Thomas,
Wills and party
arrived at Riccarton
... having bushed it
last night at the
edge of the big
swamp, and leaving
their blackbirds
behind, who would
not move on Sunday.

shoals of that kind
of porpoise called

`black fish'; ...

A whole shoal of

Author: PAUL
Quote: Rudderfish Centrolophus niger Widespread in temperate seas of the world. In some areas known as blackfish. Mid to dark brown on the head ...

GIRELLA TRICUSPIDATA. Mangrove-fish, or Blackfish. Common in Auckland throughout the year. Sold as `blackfish.' ... In December and January this species is often seen on the surface associated with school snapper, among which it appears to spawn.
Notes: Phillipps and Hodgkinson Further Notes on Edible Fishes

Maoris are early

Raki.

blackfish - pai|ka

In this bay [in

They portend bad

Grampuses, of black
fish as they are

GLOBIOCEPHALUS

Blackfish.

Quote:
... the Rongomoana,
or black-fish, and
other kinds of whale
...
The blackfish (Globicephala melaena) possesses 9 to 12 pairs of teeth, not nearly so large as those of the killer.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Tukuperu, n. 1. Ibid.452 Tukuperu ... Gobiocephala melaena, blackfish. Ibid. 549 Upokohue, n. Globicephalus melas, blackfi, and Cephalorhynchus hectori, porpoise.
The blackfish (Globicephalus melaena) is usually found in schools ...

One yet other flesh food [of the Moriori] was ... [that] classed under the generic term rongo-moa n' (whales) which might include every sea [365] mammal known to those meridians, but more exactly that commonly called `black-fish'.

The paraoa or sperm

relative of the
dolphin and the
common porpoise)

Source: In the Grip of an Island
Author: SANSOM
Quote:
Wonderful days those
were, when we might
be amongst the
dolphins (cow-fish
we called them) or a
school of pilot
whales (black fish
to us), or to see a
single thresher
shark whacking the
water with a tail as
long as its body.

[Caption] Nobody
knows why these
blackfish came to be
lying dead on
Ruakaka Beach near
Whangarei.

The blackfish
(Globicephalus
melas) is a
gregarious and timid
species of whale
which feeds on
cuttle fish.

Recently a school of
blackfish drove
ashore at Maori
Beach, Stewart
Island, and were
stranded.

The most common paua
species, blackfoot,
needed three years
to grow to sexual
maturity.

It is said that
Maori traditionally
would not take
yellowfoots,
believing them to be
female blackfoots,
hence their being
named queen paua by
Europeans.

Source: Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Quote: [species name] paua .. [scientific name] Haliotis iris .. [other name(s)] blackfoot. See also Haliotis australis

Author: WILKES
Quote:
Kororarika is still
the principal
settlement, and
contains about [296]
twenty houses, ...
and many shanties,
besides tents. It is
chiefly inhabited by
the lowest order of
vagabonds, mostly
runaway sailors and
convicts, and is
appropriately named
`Blackguard Beach'.
Notes: 1840 Mar in 1852 Wilkes U.S. Exploring Expedition 1/295-296

Author: FINLAYSON
Quote:
There are five of
them in the
calf-pen, two brown
ones, a blackie, and
two that Jake calls
the `map calves'
because they are
like white oceans
covered with reddish
continents and
islands.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
That's right, said
the Major. Mine [sc
an imitation steel
helmet made of
papier-mache] blew
away in a gust of
wind and the platoon
commander nearly
flipped a blackie
with shock. What
happened to Bluey?
Went into the bag at
Sidi Resegh.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
There were two old
Irishmen, Vaizey and
Paddy Brick, who
were favourites with
the children. `Would
you like some bread
and blackman?' Paddy
would ask the kids,
meaning bread and
treacle.

Author: McGILL
Quote: blackman treacle, in bread and blackman, favourite with children early this century; ref. Fred Smith, Southland, in author's Ghost Towns of New Zealand.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
In the version [of
Mother Mother the
Pot Boils Over]
played at Waikari,
Dunedin, in 1920, a
blackman comes to
the door and says:
`I want a match.'
`Spit on the floor
and take one,' says
the maid. The
blackman takes one
of the children,
whereupon the maid
shouts, `Mother,
Mother, the pot's
boiling over.'

Source: Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success
Quote:
This left dad with
very little
practical use from
[his arm], although
he made a lot of
progress and
eventually was able
to use it for simple
things like holding
eating utensils and
later was also able
to do some
shovelling when he
went black
sanding...

There were about
forty men
black-sanding, and
they make a bare
livelihood.

Source: Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success
Quote:
We used to go down
there and go black
sanding, a process
where you scooped a
thin layer of black
sand from the beach
and put it through a
gold mining box
which separted the
sand from the
heavier gold.

At present there are
small parties who
earn a good average
living by what is
known as
`blacksanding' ...
between Jackson's
Bay and Karamea.

The operation of
working the beach
sands on a small
scale is known as
`black-sanding',
because the gold is
associated with
ironsand (magnetite)

Ken Nolan started
his blacksanding
more than 25 years
ago.

Author: BAKER
Quote:
Among other terms ..
blacksmith, an
incompetent cook.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
If he is a bad cook
he can also, and
more safely, be
termed a blacksmith.

Author: GORDON
Quote:
A bad cook was a
"blacksmith" and the
regular mutton stew
was a
"hash-me-gandy."

They called a crook
cook a 'blacksmith',
perhaps because he
used his stove like
a forge and welded
all the food to the
pot. Though those
whose noses scented
out the menu, while
clumping up the
path, won't forget
those days ..
providing their cook
wasn't a
'blacksmith' - on
sabbatical from the
local forge.

Author: REED
Quote:
On reaching Paieri
we were met by Mr
Dewe, who drove us
to his pretty home
amongst the hills,
where we were
delighted to hear
the bellbirds or, as
they called them,
`blacksmith birds',
ringing out their
sweet notes.
Notes: c1861 Mrs J.W.Stack in 1973 Reed Annals of Early Dunedin 15

Quote:
A sheep that is
difficult to shear:
a blacksmith.
Blacksmith.-A term of contempt for a bad cook.

Author: BAKER
Quote:
Among other terms we
have derived from
farm life and and
sheep stations are
...blacksmith, an
incompetent station
cook.

Quote: Blacksmith. `An incompetent station cook' (B1941): New Zealand and Australian rural: late 19-20C.

Author: ACLAND
Quote: Blacksmith.- A term of contempt for a bad cook.
blacksmith n. incompetent cook on a N.Z. sheep station.

Author: McGILL
Quote: blacksmith contemptuous term for bad station cook. [Acland]

The 2005 British and
Irish Lions tour
officially ended
with South African
referee Jonathan
Kaplan's final
whistle on Saturday
night. The result:
38-19 to the All
Blacks, the final
onslaught in what is
becoming known as
the 3-0 series
Blackwash.

[Caption] Good show,
old boy ... Yeah
Right: Sir Clive
Woodward
congratulates Graham
Henry on the series
Blackwash last night
... sort of.

If you were disposed
to be optimistic,
you might remember
that after the Lions
were "blackwashed"
in 1966, they
returned to New
Zealand in 1971 and
won the series.

The Australian media
was reverberating
with the awful
prospect of a
blackwash weekend.
Two-zip to the Shaky
Isles on top of the
netball.

It's for that reason
that, although 12
members of the WElsh
side were involved
in this winter's
losing British and
Irish Lions tour of
New Zealand, Jones
insists the Six
Nations champion
will carry no scars
from the 3-0
blackwash.

IF YOU were disposed
to be optimistic,
you might remember
that after the Lions
were "blackwashed"
in 1966, they
returned to New
Zealand in 1971 and
won the series.

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: PONDWEED (Elodea canadensis), called also Canadian pondweed or black weed in Auckland and Canterbury.

Only the alpine shield fern (Polystichum cystostegia), bladder fern (Cystopteris tasmanica), mountain kiokio (Blechnum montanum), thousand-leaved fern (Hypolepis millefolium), finger ferns (Grammitis poeppigiana and G. givenii), one filmy fern (Hymenophyllum villosum) and two clubmosses (Huperzia australiana and Lycopodium fastigiatum) are found primarily in this habitat

Author: POTTS
Quote: The bladder fern, which, broadly speaking, has a home under every flag ...such, for instance, are some of the conditions under which the bladder fern Cystopteris fragilis is usually discovered here.

There are underwater
forests of bladder
kelp up to 15 m
tall, and penguins
nest under the
floorboards, their
morning calls an
infallible alarm
clock.

...my first success
in an underwater
photography
competition was a
grainy
black-and-white
photo of bladder
kelp off the Otago
coast.

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote: Blade: (n) Knife. Recorded as British criminal slang in 1929, but probably in use long before that.

[Blue is a Mongrel
Mob gang member]
When he joined gang
members used blades
but today's weapon
was the gun and
14-year-olds were
not mature enough
for this. `You do
not want a
14-year-old boy with
a gun in his hand.
That is not the
buzz,' he said. ...
Blue said he thought
the mobs' `buzz' was
the best it had been
for 20 years. `We
have our own little
buzz. You cannot
describe it. It's
living life to the
hilt.'

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
With only two blade
crutchers.. we had a
fairly easy time.

Author: MILLS
Quote:
Well, the calm,
peaceful atmosphere
of a blade shed is
much more to my
liking than the
constant din of
handpieces and
machinery.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
He first went to the
Muller [station] in
the old blade days,
... got a stand
again the next
season and shore
there for the next
seventeen years.

Author: PERRY
Quote:
In some parts there
is a reaction in
favour of blade
shearing.

Until June 30, the
Council's staff
looked after the
street name
"blades", while
other road signs
were contracted to
AA Signs. But when
the contract was
retendered, the name
blades were included
in the package won
by Horizon Holdings.

We bulldozed tracks
and bladed the
country that was
safe to blade into
windrows and let
them rot down and
put a match to them.

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
Had to take the
scarfs out in
sections and blade
them out of the way
with a dozer.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
My last association
with blade gangs was
at Mt White in the
'50s.

Author: DOMINY
Quote:
The sequence of
shearing in the
valley is determined
by the order of
lambing, and yearly
the same blade
'gang' moves from
property to
property.

Blade gangs are
conscious of the
quality of their
job, and there are
fewer shearing cuts
and fewer locks.

To hear a human
gurgle is contagious
enough, but coming
from a
semi-bare-bellied
sheep proved too
much for the
blademan and soon he
was staggering
around the boards
convulsed with
laughter himself.

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
Some great stories
can be told by blade
men ...

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
Machine men only
stop a few times a
run to change
cutters, compared
with blade men
giving their shears
several wipes in a
run.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Like Charlie Obery
I'm a blade man -
for all their big
tallies those
characters who have
to use machinery
take second place
with me .. I've run
into most of the top
blade men of my time
in these parts.

Source: Big Country of the South Island
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
A top blade-man in
his day

Source: High Times in the High Country
Author: KERR
Quote:
Hector Munro, a
blade shearer
himself, was one man
down on his board
and brought in his
son Walter, a blade
man, to help shear a
mob. [blade-man]

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Ivan blade-shore the
whole wether
flock...

.. it takes a
reasonably adept
shearer about five
minutes to blade
shear a sheep ...

Author: BARDSLEY
Quote:
Six shearers would
come to blade-shear
and my job was
mustering,
penning-up and
working on the
board.

Author: PETER
Quote:
.. we muster for the
stragglers and
blade-shear bellies
and under neck so
they can walk out.

We pre-lamb blade
shear our 6000
Polwarths and Merino
ewes in July over 12
days. We blade shear
our 2000 replacement
hoggets in
September. We've
been blade shearing
our Merinos since I
can remember.
[blade-shear]

Author: MACINTOSH
Quote:
He was an
exceptionally good
blade shearer ...

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote:
Boardwalkers have
become unnecessary
as the general
standard of shearing
among blade shearers
has improved.

Source: High Times in the High Country
Author: KERR
Quote:
Hector Munro, a
blade shearer
himself was down on
his board ...

Woolpro, it seems to
me, doesn't
recognise the
existence of blade
shearers and wish
they would all just
go away (or become
machine shearers).

Bryce is a blade
shearer; a fencer
and territorial
soldier in the
off-season.

Author: GIBBONS
Quote:
They were both blade
shearers.

Wanted, good blade
shearer (one used to
woolly sheep),
willing to do
mustering; must have
dogs. Apply at once
for position of
barber to the Flying
Corps.
Blades.- Hand shears as opposed to shearing machines. Hence also blade shearer. (C, since about 1897)

Until the outbreak
of the Second World
War all shearing at
Glenaray was done
with blades, but
owing to the acute
shortage of blade
shearers ... the
owners were forced
to change to machine
shearing.

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
Most of our good
blade shearers today
are veterans, and
one foresees that
this age-old art of
blade shearing may
die out.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
Come shearing time,
Donald, having no
machines in the
shed, engaged a
couple of blade
shearers.

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
`Teviot' had a
magnificent stone
and steel woolshed
[built 1880] ...
with two complete
drafting races, much
wool storage room,
two ancient screw
presses, and stands
for 26 blade
shearers, for this
was the era before
the Ferrier
Woolpress, ...

Author: SHARPE
Quote: As blade shearing is slow, and the merino sheep ... are very difficult to shear, the back-country station is usually last on any shearer's itinerary. Ibid. 40 ... when one blade shearer starts on five thousand sheep the end is a long way ahead.

Author: HARPER
Quote:
Twelve
blade-shearers were
required for
shearing, besides
anothe ten or so men
in the shed.

Ivory Poi Rutene,
aged 35, a blade
shearer, ... was
remanded to
September 6.

Author: PERRY
Quote:
Nowadays shearing is
mostly done with
machines, although
in some parts there
is a reaction in
favour of blade
shearing.

Author: SHARPE
Quote:
As blade shearing is
slow .. the
back-country station
is usually last on
any shearer's
itinerary.

Author: GORDON
Quote:
Despite the
popularity of the
faster machines
blade shearing is
still taught at
special wool board
shearing courses ...

Author: THORNTON
Quote:
Many high country
runs preferred to
retain blade
shearing for their
Merino fleeces.

Author: NEWPORT
Quote:
Machine shearing
required a totally
different style and
some sheep suffered
injury by men who
only knew blade
shearing.

Not concerned with
pin-drive or
spline-drive
shearing gear is
Grant Anderson, one
of the blade
shearing gang
operating at the
Acland's Mount Peel
woolshed ...

We would like to
look at whether
blade shearing gives
the same effect.

Author: MACINTOSH
Quote:
We did this with
blade shears then
...

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
Jingling Johnnies :
blade shears.

Author: PEAT
Quote:
The predominant
sound, a very old
sound, is the
'whisk-whisk,
whisk-whisk' of four
sets of blade
shears.

A blade shed is
strangely quiet
after a machine one.

Here's an example of
her hard-nosed
interrogation
technique, from her
interview with a guy
who won a "blade
swooping"
competition in
Australia... Blade
swooping is like a
cross between
paragliding and
parachuting, except
you do it close to
the ground.

Source: Land of the Mountain and the Flood
Author: CHANDLER
Quote:
The rate of pay for
shearing in those
days was one pound
per hundred sheep on
blade work, plus
keep and housing.

Source: Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock
Author: MILLS ET AL
Quote:
Some months after
his engagement, the
blade-crutching
started.

In shape, [the
family
Trachypteridae] are
usually long, deep,
and very much
compressed and
flattened on the
sides, so much so
that their local
appellations always
embody some idea of
these peculiarities
- such as
ribband-fish, lath
or deal fish, band
fish or blade fish,
and also oar-fish.

Author: PAUL et al.
Quote:
[index to common
names 283-293]
bladefish 1633

Many high-country
farmers favour the
old blade-shearing
methods because more
wool is left on the
sheep.

The annual round of
the blade shearing
gangs.. still
features on the
calendars of high
country stations.

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
[attrib] ..., and
yet over the years
it has developed
into a competitive
sport and for past
years, right back in
early blade-shearing
history, it was
always a race, and
an honour to shear
for the `ringer's'
stand.

Author: CHARLES
Quote:
Sure I'll sing you a
song/ Of the
blade-shearing
days,/

Author: WHEELER
Quote:
[attrib] In
blade-shearing days
it catered for 24
shearers who once
clipped 120,000
Merinos.

Mr Solomon abandoned
his youthful stints
at the freezing
works, blade
shearing, and paua
diving, and settled
for the metals
industry where he
spent the next 25
years.

It reminds me of
blade shearing in
the middle of
winter, with a frost
outside and the gang
of men scrunched up
shoulder to shoulder
around the kitchen
table.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Although late March
was late enough,
blade-shorn lambs
could come to little
harm.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
A top blade-man in
his day he claims
that his 164 ewes,
at Molesworth, is
the blade record for
that shed.

Author: McLEOD
Quote:
... lean Australian
blademen from `the
other side' across
the Tasman [and]
tough old Merino
shearers ...

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
Some great stories
can be told by blade
men: ... . A good
blade shearer is
pretty to watch.

Although machine
shearing prevails on
the flat, the blades
are making their way
down country after
lessons tragically
learnt in the snows
of last year... The
calming effect of
the blades as
compared to machines
makes quite a
difference.

Generally speaking,
machines are used on
the plains and
blades in the back
country.

Hand blades clip the
fleeces.

Author: WOODHOUSE
Quote:
I grabbed the blades
/ And flattened the
wool aside.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
Old shearers with
their blades honed
and ground.

His visual sense
records the black
singlets, the
stretched cords and
arms of the shearing
blades, the scramble
of the crewcut
hogget to get back
upright.

Each shearer had on
the wall his pot of
oil and turkey
oilstone for the
constant sharpening
of his blades ...

The majority of the
larger sheep-owners
.. have come to
recognise the
advantages of
'machines' over
'blades.'

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
So most of us stick
to 'the blades', the
big shining steel
shears 8 and a half
inches long, with a
double spring 'bow'
on the end ...

Source: A to Z Glossary of Wool Terms
Author: SQUIRES
Quote:
Blades - hand
operated shears for
blade shearing.

Author: McGILL
Quote: blades of meat feet; rhyming slang variant of English `plates of meat'.
bladesman: Handshearer.

Another blahboard
spotted on a
Festherston St
footpath "Life is
short. Eat more
pancakes and fewer
rice crackers."

Blah-boards No. 1,
spotted outside a
florist in Mercer
St: "Every blade of
grass has an angel
bending over it
whispering, 'Grow,
grow'."

Author: KIRK
Quote: Nothofagus Blairii

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Beech ... In New Zealand, there are six species of true beeches, which according to Kirk are as follows - ... -->BLAIR'S B. Fagus blairi, T. Kirk ... All these, however, are commonly called Birches.

386 Lithograph of
`Blair's beech'
foliage.

Heard about the
latest overseas
management theory
that's making
inroads into the
Capital's psyche?
After a project
mishap, a team
leader summons his
group for a meeting
where the
participants
"blamestorm",. You
guessed it, there
ain't no hugs or
strokes in a
blamestorming
session. It's all
about working out
who's innocent and
who takes the rap.

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote:
BLADE (v) Mode of
assault, using a
blanket to blind or
confuse the victim.

The battery has
three stampers in
each box, double
cams, quickslver
placed in battery
boxes, grating
perpendicular, with
round holes. The
copper-plate tables
are about 12ft. long
by 5ft. wide, and
raised about 14in.
above the blanket
boards; ... [The
blankets] appear to
be ordinary grey
blankets of a very
inferior
description.

The blanket strakes
below the silver
tables are about 20
feet long; they are
so arranged that any
part of them may be
washed from time to
time ... Instead of
blanket, baize and
coarse plush have
been used with
advantage.

In dry rocky habitats away from the sea, especially on the eastern side of the South Island, another characteristic assemblage of ferns can be found. This includes the rock fern ()Cheilanthes sicheri), woolly cloak fern (C. distans), blanket fern (Pleurosorus rutifolius), and Pellaea callidirupium.

Courtney [sic] place
is also a good place
to meet blanket man,
who is Wellington's
favourite transient
even though he
smells like an ass.

"Every year the
costumes just get
better as people go
that little bit
further," he said,
pointing to a group
of revellers dressed
as Wellington street
vagrant Blanket Man.

On reading that very
religious
Anglican['s] (H
Westfold) invective
on the blanket man
and his friends, I
was reminded of
"There, but for the
grace of God, goes H
Westfold."

Author: POLACK
Quote:
[The whale] is then
raised as high as
the mast head, and
another tackle is
applied to a fresh
piece of blubber,
technically called
blanket pieces,
during which the
preceding piece is
lowered into an
inclosed place below
the deck, called the
blubber room.

The constant outflow
of crushed quartz
and water from the
stamp boxes is
received on a table,
having on it grooves
or ripples,
containing
quicksilver and a
large extent of
amalgamated copper
plates smoothly
nailed on. This may
be called the silver
table; ... The flow
then passes over
blanket tables,
which arrest
mechanically all the
heavier particles.

Author: MALONE
Quote: About four miles from Pokatutu's pah, we stopped, opened our blacket-bags, and took a hearty lunch.
Notes: [refers to Maoris' packing everything in blanket-rolls and slinging them]

Source: Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ
Author: HARPER
Quote:
... on turning in we
lie `heads and
tails' in our
blanket bags.

Author: DON
Quote:
I donned the
gumboots, hat, and
blanket-shirt of a
bedfellow.

We see this liquid
[sc. puddled ore]
sent over `beds',
and `floors', and
`ladders', and
`blanketings', and
washed again and
again.

While on an official
visit to the Thames
Goldfield I
...[observed] the
... effect of
Cyanide of
Potassium, in
preventing the
flouring of mercury
used in working the
blanketings. These
blanketings I found
have ... a decidedly
acid reaction, due
... to the presence
of ferric and
ferrous salts ...,
and it is to the
former ... that what
is commonly known as
[335] `flouring,' is
mainly due, in the
process cited above;
such ferric salts
being able to either
oxidize or
chloridize the
surface of any
mercury ..., thus
enfilming it with a
compound, which
being practically
insoluble in water
... prevents that
metallic contact
taking place between
detached mercurial
globules, which is
necessary to
amalgamation.

The blanket tailings
or blanketings, as
they are otherwise
called, consist
mostly of iron
pyrites and other
sulphides, cobines
with quartz, and
contain a fair
proportion of gold
...that had escaped
over the silver
tables. These
tailings are treated
in berdans with
extra quicksilver
and ground up. The
berdans now in use
at the Thames ...
are generally five
feet in diameter ...
At one time a couple
of rotating balls
were considered
sufficient for the
amount of crushing
required; now, the
general practice is
to have a loose ball
as well as a
stationary one
attached to a chain,
and it is called a
drag ball; this drag
does more work than
a loose ball ... for
the drag grinds the
bowl as much as the
tailings.

Author: GRADY
Quote: When the Orca finally refound their `lost whale' it had blasted (blown up like a balloon) to twice its normal size owing to decomposition gases.

Author: BARNS-GRAHAM
Quote:
[Hawkes Bay
musterer] `Come
behind, Don, blast
and tut your stupid
soul.'

He would fill the
sink with cold water
and put his feet in
it to keep him awake
when the coffee,
coke and blast caps
had worn off.

They prefer to smoke
or 'blast' the
product
intravenously and
often spend several
days under its
continued influence.

Author: GRADY
Quote: Blasted - Swollen whale advanced in decomposition after death.

Black Tuesday
continued on the
roads of the
Northern Suburbs
when a psychiatric
patient from
Wellington Hospital
allegedly stole a
car from Wellington
Railway Station and
took it for a blat
in the Newlands
area.

I enjoy having a
blat in the
powerboat and it has
got me involved in
designing one.

A couple of blats
during the week on
his nameless jetboat
on the nearby
Waimakariri river is
his favourite way of
unwinding.

Phillips has
delivered on his
promise of a blat
around the harbour,
a fast,lumpy ride
that left me
sporting bruises in
the most unusual
places for weeks.

We blat down the
hill, wind swiping
at our faces.

David Gunn had run a
blaze from the top
of the Kaipo slip
... south along a
ridge for `three
hours.'

In the morning we managed to find a ford, ... and set off down the Olivine Gorge. About a mile the blaze started to head vertically [36] upwards and continued to do so until we were above the bushline ... Ibid. 69 ... after a few hundred steep feet of the Dorset Ridge had been covered, an indifferent blaze was picked up which led through bush and scrub to the tussock line at the end of Dorset Ridge, ...

Source: In the Lee of the Hokonuis
Author: BARRY
Quote:
The flax fibre
produced from the
mill was hung in the
bleaching paddock,
the flat area
belonging to
Tresidders.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
[caption] Fibre is
being carted from
the mill to the
bleaching paddocks,
...

Soft sunlight bathed
moss, liverwort and
blechnum ferns
lining the walls
near the entrance.

Author: REED
Quote:
Having regard to the
high and increasing

... [sic] it may
well be conceived
that the real value
of the kauri tree
... lies in the
periodic crop of gum
which may be taken

Notes: 1916 Kauri Gum Industry Report in 1972 Reed Gumdiggers 31

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
The third period of
the history of Rugby
games between New
Zealand and
Australia began with
the first test match
played for the
Beldisloe Cup and
this took place at
Eden Park on
September 12, 1931.

2ZB commentator,
John McBeth has
called all of the
last 15 All Black
tests as well as
this year's Hong
Kong and Australian
seven-a-sides, the
World Cup, the
Bledisloe Cup and
all of this season's
Wellington games.

People talk about
watching "the
Bledisloe". It
doesn't get the word
Cup half the time.

The All Blacks
didn't lose
Bledisloe II - the
sequel which nearly
lived up to its
classic original -
because the referee
added a few lost
minutes...
Unfortunately, as
much as they are
taken on board, they
will not bring back
the Bledisloe.

His Excellency, the
Governor-General,
Lord Bledisloe, has
presented a cup for
competition between
New Zealand and
Australian Rugby
teams, and the first
match will be the
Test at Auckland
today... The
"Bledisloe Cup" will
be the first trophy
presented for
matches between
Australia and New
Zealand.

One ram was tooted
and we had to bleed
him freely.

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
Often in that
Autumn, belated
lambs that failed to
fatten in the
earlier drafts,
waxed fat. The seed
ripened on the
ryegrass, and with
it came the legacy
of `ergot'.
Practical sheep men
found that this
complaint produced
`staggers'. Too much
blood obtained,
although the patient
was in splendid
condition, used to
keep spinning round,
and the remedy was
the ancient panacea
of most diseases in
England, centuries
ago, and ere science
interrupted their
outlook, viz. `to
bleed' and take from
the patient the
overflow of red
corpuscles.

Author: TOMLINSON
Quote:
After camping the
night there, we had
to cross Kerr's Hill
which was covered
with tutu, a
poisonous plant for
sheep, and the curse
of drovers. ... Odd
sheep started to get
`tooted' and instead
of pushing on the
men started bleeding
the sheep. This was
done by cutting a
vein under the eye.
It was supposed to
help the sheep,
although I never
thought it did any
good.

Gum climbers and
bleeders scaled
kauri using a
weighted line and
rope, and later,
taking advantage of
kauri's soft outer
layer of bark and
sapwood, hand
spikes, climbing
hooks, and boots
equipped with toe
spikes.

It was found that if
slashes were made in
the trunk of the
tree, it would
bleed, and the resin
could be harvested
later. Initially, it
was thought that
bleeding did not
harm the tree.

Like in the old television show, The Brady Bunch, a blended family is formed when parents get divorced or widowed (when one parent dies) and then remarry. The parents bring their children together and create a new family.

Dr Fryor says
despite the growing
"normality" of
blended families,
not enough is known
about what makes
them tick and why
some work better
than others.

Amongst the
varieties most
suitable for London
are the following:
Sturmer Pippin..
Blenheim Orange..
Wellington Pippin. .
Cox's Orange Pippin.

Quote:
The Blenheimer was
cooling my throat.

So the Blenheimites
browbeat the poor
farmers quite, -

Quote: CRESTED BLENNY Parablennius laticlavius (Blennius laticlavius ) ... The crested blenny is a small fish ... that like most blennies has a smooth scaleless skin and a blunt head. It has a long tapering body and the distinctive crest, made i of a large forked cirrus above each eye, that suggested the name crested blenny.

After Tankbusters came Blerta, a combination of a band, a theatre group and a film company, which was started by Lawrence.

According to the
afficionados of New
Zealand's musical
history, Blerta
stands for Bruno
Lawrence's Electric
Revelation and
Travelling
Apparition. For most
New Zealanders over
50, however, Blerta
is best remembered
as a colourful
troupe of artists,
anarchists and
musicians who
travelled the
highways and byways
of New Zealand in a
vivdly decorated
omnibus of
indeterminate age
and intermittent
reliability. ...
Religious allusions
aside, Blerta's
over-riding message
was fun.

The ultimate road
trip lasted for a
good part of the
1970s when the
Blerta (Bruno
Lawrence's Electric
Travelling
Apparition) bus led
a convoy of
performers and
hangers-on across
the back blocks of
Australia and New
Zealand.

During its five-year run in the 1970s, Blerta attracted such an extraordinary collection of movers, shakers and far-out characters, Bruno was just one wild man among many... "It's possible to trace the beginings of the New Zealand film industry from Blerta," says Murphy, whose documentary Blerta Revisited, features in the naton's film festivbals this month... Blerta began in October, 1971, when Bruno was 30 years old and restless as a bear stung by a swarm of bees... Blerta was an acronym for Bruno Lawrence's Electric Revelation and Travelling Apparition... "Blurter" was also a rude term for genitals in '70s slang.

Dropping out was in
then, and so was
Bruno Lawrence's
Electric Revelation
and Travelling
Apparition. The
family hooked up
with the heady
Blerta roadshow for
a while, and
seven-year-old Karl
was one of many kids
with happy memories
of racing on stage
during performances.
ZOSTEROPS LATERALIS, Lath. - White-eye, Blight Bird.

Quote:

little bird called
the Blight bird ...

Quote:
The birds I noticed
were the bell-bird,
the blight-bird, the

Quote:
In and around the
garden [in
Canterbury in the
1870s] we had robins
(rare) waxeyes
(blight birds),
tomtits,. ...

tauhou, a wandering bird (Zosterops halmaturina), blight-bird; twinkie; button-eye; wax-eye; ring-eye. Tauhou means stranger and this name was given by the Maori when the bird appeared, in 1856, in the central part of Newzealand, gradually spreading north and south till the islands were occupied. It is an Australian bird, and was blown across the Tasman sea in the year mentioned.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Kanohi-mowhiti, Zosterops lateralis, silver-eye or blight-bird (mod.).

Author: RICHARDS
Quote: Zosterops (ring eye) cerulescens ... The white-eye feeds on insects and fruit besides honey. ... [74] White-eye, Blight Bird. POTEREKAI.

[Caption]
Silver-eyes are also
known as "Blight
Birds", being
particularly
valuable in removing
aphids from orchards
and rose bushes.

The blightie is a
very tame little
bird.

The silver-eye or
`blight bird'
frequented the
gardens in the

[of the South
Island].

Author: BULLER
Quote: The history of the little Zosterops, or Blight-bird, is a case in point. Ibid. 1/82 By the settlers it [sc Zosterops] has been variously designated as Ring-eye, Wax-eye, White-eye, or Silver-eye, in allusion to the beautiful circlet of satiny-white feathers which surrounds the eyes; and quite as commonly as the `Blight-bird', or `Winter Migrant'.

To-day my son was dissecting a common bittern (Botaurus poecilopilus) ... We found the `bill of fare' for that day to have been a silver-eye (Zosterops caerulescens), ... It is well known that the bittern varies its feeding ... adding still another enemy to our useful little migrant blight-bird.

Author: FIRTH
Quote: blight bird

Blight́.bird́. (bl&imacr.t́.b&etilde.rd́.), n. (Zoo.l.) The New Zealand name for the white-eye (Zosterops coerulescens), whichclears trees of insect blight; - called also ring-eye, silver-eye, and wax-eye. See WHITE-EYE in Dictionary. The bird was originally confined to eastern Australia and Tasmania, but it settled in flocks in New Zealand in 1851, making its escape from the great bush fire of Black Thursday (Feb. 6, 1851).

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Blight-bird ... a bird-name in New Zealand for the Zosterops (q.v.). .us; Called also Silver-eye (q.v.), Wax-eye, and White-eye (q.v.). It is called Blight-bird because it eats the blight on trees.

Author: POTTS
Quote:
The white-eye or
blight-bird, with
cheerful note, in
crowded flocks,
sweeps over the face
of the country, and
in its progress
clears away
multitudes of small
insect pests.'

A notable exception
is the silver-eye,
white-eye or
blight-bird
(zosterops) which
was blown across the
Tasman Sea by a
storm some fifty or
sixty years ago.
[Zosterops] subsists almost entirely [in Wellington orchards and gardens] on the destructive little Aphis known as `American Blight'.

and quite as

Notes: check yearA. Hamilton, `Native Birds of Petane, Hawke's Bay'

Quote:
The little green
white-eyes, or
blight birds, are
moving from place to
place ...

Author: WHITE
Quote:
The little `Silver
Eye' or `Blight
Bird,' so called
from its very useful
propensity of eating
various blights, has
a silvery circle
round its eyes,
composed of tiny
white feathers which
are sweetly
becoming.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: pihipihi, n. 1. Zosterops caerulescens, wax-eye, blight-bird.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: Kanohimowhiti, or Tauhau, white eye or blight bird (Zosterops lateralis) was first observed July 1856 in the South, and about Auckland.

The little 'wax-eye'
or as it is commonly
known, the
'blight-bird' is
reported to be doing
good work in the
orchards and gardens
this year.

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: SILVEREYE Zosterops lateralis Other names: Tauhou, Waxeye, White-eye, Blightbird, Blightie.

mainly Auckland or
North Island

Author: McGILL
Quote: blighty blight bird, now better known as waxeye, white-eye or silver-eye.

Author: GREY
Quote:
The trees were full
of the little yellow
blighties, named
from their very good
habit of eating the
insect blight.

Author: BAKER
Quote: Need to find some outlet for pent-up feelings resulted in the concoction of blimey charley! (why charley?); by Christchurch.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Blimey Charley! A c.p. used to blow off pent-up emotions: New Zealand and Australian: 20C. B1941. In Australian, also blimey Teddy!

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote: Some expressions that have been claimed for New Zealand are at the rate of knots `very fast', hook your mutton `clear out', have the wood on `have an advantage over' and the oaths Blimey Charlie and (By) Christchurch (obviously a neat save suggested by the place name).

Author: McGILL
Quote: blimey, Charlie! indicating friendly relief; obs.; derived from mostly Cockney `blimey' abbreviation of `Gorblimey', abbreviation of `God blind me'. NZA.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
blind: i. Ground
easily overlooked
unintentionally even
when quietly
'looking' sheep. ii.
A feature - a gully
or spur which ends
abruptly and so
denies access
beyond.

Poor and mediocre
benefits have
resulted from the
failure to clear all
roots and stumps, to
give the surface of
fields some
preliminary grading,
to avoid drawing the
mole across
depressions and
blind creeks.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
..soft spots,
localities mined
with under-runners,
blind oozy creeks,
cliffs and so forth
are avoided.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
.. the ground became
terribly broken and
cut up by swamps,
quicksands, blind
creeks, and all
sorts of snares and
pitfalls.

Source: History of the Early Gold Discoveries  in Otago
Author: PYKE
Quote:
When matters had
settled down a bit
the miners spread
themselves along the
river, getting gold
almost everywhere on
the beaches, and
following it in
until they stood up
to their thighs in
the stream `blind
dipping'.

The plan of what, we
believe, was called
at the Nelson
diggings "blind
dipping" has, we
learn, been
successfully
practised at the
Dunstan. this is
done by the miner
standing in the
water and taking up
shovelfuls of stuff
from the bottom.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: kanakana, ... 3. Blind eel or lamprey. [so 1957/93 Geotria australis, lamprey. = korokoro.] Ibid. 324 Pia ... 2. Blind eel. = napia.
Eptatretus cirrhatus Forster. Blind-eel or Hag.

Author: MORELAND
Quote: HAGFISH [Eptatretus cirrhatus] ... Hagfish and blind eel are widely used alternative names, while the Maori tuere and napia are still in use.

The above list of

puhaiwhakarua
(red-jacket), koiro
(conger eel), tuere
(blind eel), whai

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: HAGFISH (TUERE) Eptatretus cirrhatus (Bloch and Schneider) The Hagfish, or Blind-eel as the fishermen call it, is one of the most unpleasant-looking creatures of the sea.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Pia ... Heptatretus cirratus, hagfish or blind eel.

Author: NATUSCH
Quote: the common hag fish or `blind eel', Eptatretus cirrhatus ... Eptatretus exudes quantities of thick slime.

Author: DOOGUE & MORELAND
Quote: HAGFISH ... Other names: Heptatretus cirrhatus; blind eel; tuere, napia (Maori).

Author: WILSON
Quote: BLIND EEL: see Hagfish

Author: PAUL
Quote: Hagfish Eptatretus cirratus also known as blind eel; it is eel-like, but not a true eel. Hagfishes occur in cool waters throughout the world, but this species is restricted to New Zealand.

Source: Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Quote: [species name] hagfish .. [scientific name] Eptatretus cirrhatus .. [other name(s)] blind eel

Teddy and W. to
lambs to drive them

Author: HAAST
Quote:
... we descended as
fast as we could,
but soon discovered

a so-called blind
spur, which fell
abruptly into a
steep [OED2 deep:
check] gully, ...

The principal workings here are blind gullies and streams. Ibid. 24 With an immense number of blind gullies, all more or less auriferous, and a creek that paid and is promising to pay for a considerable distance yet ... who can predict the future of the Woolshed ...

Author: BARKER
Quote:
He's in one of them
blind gullies.

Author: McLEOD
Quote: A clearing completely surrounded by bush will be called a `blind Parkee'. Ibid. 255 Pakihi: A clearing in the bush, perhaps only a bay. If totally enclosed, a `blind' pakihi.
Blind.- (1) Unseen, hard to see (creek, gully, etc.) (2) Leading nowhere (spur, creek, gully, etc.) I think (1) is the commoner usage. (C.)

Author: McLEOD
Quote:
Gradually the [dog's
command] distance is
lengthened until you
hunt him as far as
you can see. Then he
must be taught to
run `on the blind' -
that is, to go up or
down hill as
directed, looking
for sheep he hasn't
seen.

Author: BULLER
Quote: BOTAURUS POECILOPTILUS. (BLACK-BACKED BITTERN.) ... Native name.- Matuku-hurepo. ... [142] The Common Bittern is very generally distributed ... in places suited to its habits of life, such as raupo swamps, sedgy lagoons, and those `blind creeks', covered over with a growth of reeds ands tangle, which are so numerous in all the low districts.

At present the diggings are believed to be confined to Tuapeka ... where Gabriel's Gully ... and a few blind leaders have been opened. Ibid. 45 Some of the many prospecting parties who are now ransacking the mountains are meeting with temporary success, but it is only in small ravines or blind leaders.

Author: HAY
Quote:
Eventually it was
proved that the find
was but a `blind
reef', a `pocket', a
mere isolated
dribble from the
main continuous vein
we had at first
supposed we had
struck.

These particular
veins are `blind',
or feather out in
the enclosing
dacites.

Author: PHARAZYN
Quote:
Teddy and W to lambs
to drive them to

Author: BARKER
Quote:
.. taking short cuts
across the lake to

or explore a blind

Author: BARKER
Quote:
'He's in one of them
blind gullies.'

About two miles from
the river, on the
Lammerlaw Creek, in
a blind gully,
christened by

miners, Johnson's
gully, who was the
first to prospect
the place ...

A party of Maories
from Jacob's River
are doing well
[mining] in a blind
gully leading into
Victoria Gully. The
day I was there they
found a nugget over
an ounce in weight.

Author: DAVIS
Quote:
After I come home at
night the jargon
runs round and round
my head. ... On meat
- bit of a jockey
here, boys ; give us
legs, legs; bring
out your burton;
blind her off; we'll
need rollers and
staging; turn off
the blowers, mister
mate, or we don't go
in the freezer.

Author: PRESHAW
Quote:
A few of us landed
in one of the ship's
boats; not a safe
thing to do as a
rule on the Coast,
what are known as
`blind rollers'
often rising and
swamping a boat.

The man who enters a
boarding or
`temperance' house
is immediately
accused of having
rolled a beer barrel
through the maze of
the Licensing Act.
He is suspected of
designs of all
descriptions. He is
dubbed `a dropper',
or `a blind tiger.'

And every beginning

scoop and blind-drag
as many [whitebait]
as possible out of
sanctuary.

Quote:

Author: R GILBERD

`Nothing between us

Author: CLEVELAND
Quote: blind-stabbing: Used by Jack Sweeney, prospector, to describe traditional method of getting gold-bearing wash out of glacial rivers. The prospector is anchored by a rope which is controlled by a mate on the bank. He wheels a wheelbarrow as far into the torrent as is possible, shovels the alluvial wash into it blindly, because the water contains glacial silts and is milky white, and returns to the bank with as much as he can shift. This is processed at leisure for gold

Quote: Blinded with science. A c.p. applied to brawn defeated by brains: Australian and New Zealand: C20.

... `blinded with
science' comes from
boxing, as does

Anti-waste campaign
[against] ... Tyre
and tool loser,
clothing waster,

...

The biggest problems

Author: WILSON
Quote: Montia fontana Blinks ... Fresh green, low patches ...Flowers tiny, white. ... Fairly common low altitude, wet open ground ...
blister v. charge exhorbitantly for goods;n. exhorbitant charge for such.

Author: McARA
Quote: Blister: A small charge of gelignite placed on a large stone to break it into pieces small enough to handle. The charge was laid on the stone and covered with damp clay to make it airtight. Frequently used by truckers when the ore passes or chutes became blocked with large boulders.

Note how the Labour
Department always
like to get your
`goat.' When you
refuse the overtime
... how they chase
you round with
`blisters'.

Author: GRIEVE
Quote:
[a reprimand] ... I

to believe that a
,us; parental
application of hot
water and soap,
administered with
the added impetus of
an official
`blister' delivered
in an envelope
bearing the
awe-inspiring legend
`On His Majesty's
Service', might have
the desired effect.
blister ... 3. a. N.Z. sl. a rebuke. b. N.Z. & Austral. sl. a summons to court.
Notes: [nf. 1986 NZPOD but cf. 74 (as verb); 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 51]

Fuller is enjoyable

...bloat oil...

He'd found Missee

Quote: [species name] pilchard .. [scientific name] Sardinops neopilchardus .. [other name(s)] sardine, bloater

Author: PAUL
Quote: Pilchard Sardinops neopilchardus ... Sometimes called the sardine. Also occurs around southern Australia. ... In the 1880s a fishery in the Marlborough Sounds produced salted and smoked `Picton Herring', and small fisheries have developed briefly elsewhere. ... Pilchard are caught for groper bait (`bloater'), and have been used also for tuna.

Author: KING

... Native Land
Court sittings were

Most of the family

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
There are many

Block: an area of land, e.g.: Development block - an area being developed from bush or scrub to farmland. Settlement block - an area made (settled) into farms.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
Large areas of land
were purchased in
the North Island.
Almost the entire
South Island was
bought in a few huge
`blocks'.

1. in forest management, a major subdivision of a forest, generally bounded by natural features and bearing a local name. In some of the first established exotic forests, BLOCK was used in place of Compartment. 2. in land-subdivision, a major subdivision of a Survey District. ... A BLOCK is usually 1/16 of a Survey District and is square, with sides 250 chains long. Block numbers are indicated by roman numerals 3. in land-subdivision, a term relating to a defined area of Maori land and bearing the original Maori tribal name.

Author: CAREY
Quote: The word block is used in New Zealand to designate a portion of land purchased at a particular time, and opened to settlement; thus the Omata block, the Bell block, the Grey block etc.
To enforce this tapu they have constructed a pa on Rawiri's section on the Bell Block ...
Notes: 1854 Sep 20 Taranaki Herald in 1856 Fitton NZ 153

capitalists arrived

"She (the
