Author: G T ARCUS
Quote:
A few years ago I
travelled to Britain
via Australia and on
the boat an
Englishman was
telling me that
while in Australia
he bought a block of
land and built his
own house. To me the
word block suggested
a large piece of
land, so with
visions of Sid
Kidman I asked him
how big. He replied,
`Oh, just fifth of
an acre,' I said
that in NZ we would
call that a section.
An American put in
that in his country
a section was a
square mile and the
word was used with
that meaning in
parts of Australia,
but in the States
they used the word
`lot' to describe a
building block. I
replied that in NZ
building blocks were
the piles that a
house stood on and
the Englishman said
that in Australia
they called them
stumps.

You may have noticed
that we have dropped

Unfortunately, new

The Pickers' lair is

"low-key Kiwi-proud

popular with

Until recently, the
good old New Zealand

held up as an

Seventeenth Doll is offensive in its attitudes towards women and its rampant "blokeism".

Author: BAKER

betray two

...

Blokes in sheds
listen to Radio
Sport.

Zealand's image of

Professor Fraser

solving problems by

And so I chose

...it is also an

But the obviously
out-of-the-office
blokes and

jackets over their

they are a visiting
delegation from
Invercargill?

And then there's the
part where the
average bloke, or

band.

"The thing that I
always said about
Pakekura is that

The Terrace
[Wellington's main

Moore says.

He took

power, the better to
do all that he did
for his ordinary
blokes (and, near
the end, because
even he could not be
entirely untouched
by linguistic
fashion,
"blokesses".)

The ordinary blokess
seemed genuinely
shaken.

The bloke is afraid
to climb into the
blokess's trap, on
account of his
horse.

The ordinary blokess

In the yard, the

numerous blokesy

Source: FMC - (Federated Mountain Clubs of NZ) Bulletin
Quote:
We discovered this
[the use of female
knickers] in a rare,

discussion after I

my sweaty crutch ...
Tell Them I've Gone Pig-Hunting .. is a catalogue of shot, stabbed, clubbed tuskers described with blokey energy, plus endearingly prose for "Nature's orchestra".

I was out in the
blokey shed doing a
little bit of lathe
work and the song
about 'rugby,
racing, and beer'

while the toy I was

When a blokey icon

Breweries takes an

"sustainable

are edging into the

The hosties now have

and trousers, school

mysteriously called

After just four
hours in this
country, he feels
Kiwi blokiness
falter.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. Ibid. 176 [Waitara, Taranaki, 1899] A `taw' was usually an `alley' or `blood alley' made of agate. We used to take them home and burn them in a fire to convert them into `blood alleys'.

Author: KEITH & MAIN
Quote:
Marbles were the
currency of
childhood and there
were an astonishing
number of names for
them, some referring
to the material or
colour, others to
value or function in
the game. There were
agates, aggies,
American alleys,
blood alleys,
bomb-squashers,
bonies, bonsers,
bottlies, bull's
eyes, bum-squashers,
cats-eye, [sic]
chinkies, connies,
duckies, eggies,
glassies, Greeks,
milkies, mollies,
peelies, peewees,
pisswees, pretties,
Scotties, smokies,
stinkies, stonies,
stripies,
tom-bobblers and
whities. The march
of technology added
ball bearings -
ballies or steelies
- which were
unbeatable when it
came to smashing an
opponent's miserable
glassie. World War
II[roman] brought
`clayeys' often
imperfectly
spherical they were
pathetic terracotta
substitutes for real
marbles.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: blood alley. A white, or whitish, marble streaked with red: Aus. and NZ children's: latye C.19-20. Adopted ex. common English dialect.

Quote:
His Majesty's

despatch to Mr

I have such a dread

Notes: (Jane Maria Atkinson) [reference Austro-Prussian War, and manoeuvrings of France under Louis Napoleon]

Author: LINDSAY
Quote: The larger species [of Aciphylla] are familiar to the settlers as `Spear-grass', or `Bayonette-grass', `Wild' or `Bloody-Spaniard', [bloody =?] in allusion to their very rigid, strong, poniard-like, sharp-pointed leaves ... Hence a `Spear-grass Scrub' on the hill ranges is frequently most formidable ... to men and horses, though it forms one of the favourite hunting grounds of the Wild Pig. In the Matukituki Valley, `Bayonette-grass' forms an undergrowth in a dense scrub of prickly thorn ... [50] Familiar to the shepherds of Canterbury as `Bloody Spaniard'.

That unpleasant kind
of spear-grass which
grows on the ranges
in Taranaki and
which is popularly
known by the
sobriquet of Wild
Irishman, seems to
be in bad repute
wherever it is
found. Dr. Von Haast
says that in the
South Island it is
called Bloody
Spaniard.

When first walking
along steep mountain
sides, catching hold
of friendly tussocks
for support,
sometimes by mistake
you catch a young
Spaniard, and then
you know why our
"rude forefathers,"
the pioneers, often
called it the
"bloody Spaniard";
it really and truly
was; I have proved
it.

Dan Freel's

- or would have been

At first it seemed

... The sanguinary

After the first few

much loss in time. I
noticed that the
Irishmen, though

flattery of
imitation in this
respect.

Yeh. Bloodywell need
them.

Author: BARRY
Quote:
I came to the
conclusion that the
lode was not a
permanent one, but
only what is called
a `blow' of quartz.

The molybdenite
deposits ... are
described ... as
roughly circular or
oval-shaped outcrops
of [24] quartz, or
`blows' carry
wolfram and native
bismuth. The `blows'
when followed down
develop into
irregular
pipe-shaped masses
...

So far as one could
judge from a surface
examination, the
outcrops appear to
be isolated blocks
of quartz or `blows'
that follow the
foliation planes of
the schist.

In places
[scheelite] occurs
as blows in the
quartz in sufficient
quantity to be
sorted by
hand-picking.

An immense `blow' of
quartz 150ft by
100ft on the
surface, and
standing 30ft above
the surrounding
ground was located
in 1872 on the Rainy
Creek property.

Author: NOLAN
Quote: Blow: a large outcropping reef, usually of barren quartz.

This great "blow" of
quartz, as the
miners term it,
strikes to the

therefore crosses
the auriferous belt
nearly at
right-angles.

The great "blow" or
"buck-reef" of the
Tokatea is found in
the slates at the
western end of the
lower or No. 7 adit.

because the trees

Author: BATHGATE
Quote: [Bank clerk] `By the time I had cleaned, or `blown' the gold, it was too late to think of returning. Ibid. 220 The gold is placed on a flat pear-shaped metal dish, with a perpendicular rim or edge except at the point of the pear, where there is no rim. This is moved in such a manner that the gold is tossed up, and all the finer particles and dirt are worked forward towards the opening, out by which the operator blows the sand.

Author: D'AVIGDOR
Quote: [Colonialisms] To `blow' is, in the colonies, to brag or boast; this is graphic if not elegant; but one of the most curious expressions, based on an entirely errroneous derivation, is `an old identity', used for a person long `identified with a place' - in fact an old inhabitant, or one whose interests have long been bound up in it. This expression is unfortunately now universal even in newspapers.

I don't care about
blowin' about it.

Author: SOLJAK
Quote: The following New Zealand expressions derive from British dialects, ... blow: to boast
blow v. boast.

Author: NIXON
Quote: blow to boast. Seems to be replacing skite.
blow ... NZ & Austral. colloq. boast.
They'll give that cruising Russian lot,/ Some real Colonial `blow';/
Notes: 1885 May 4 Lyttelton Times in 1967 Bailey and Roth Shanties 74

Author: FIRTH
Quote:
His merry laughter
at our `blow.'
blow: (1) Any stroke the shearer takes; e.g. `a blow over the tail'. (2) `To strike a blow' means to begin work.

Author: BURDON
Quote:
The sheep they shore
were not so well
woolled on the belly
and carried less
wool on the points
than they do now, so
that fewer short
blows were required
to take off the
trimmings; but the
shears they used
were one inch and a
half shorter in the
blade and, being
joined by a single
instead of a double
bow, required a
wrist of iron to
drive them
continuously
throughout a
summer's day. A
piece of raw hide
known as a knocker
is now used to
prevent the shears
clashing when
closed, but before
this was introduced
the clack and snap
of steel meeting
steel was a noise
inseparable from any
busy shearing shed.
Blow.- The stroke of the shearer in handshearing. He drives the shears forward and makes a cut.
blow n. in shearing, a single cut with the shears.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
With a few deft
`blows' the ringer
had cleaned out the
crutch.

A minimum of blows applied on the sheep should be aimed at. ... On good average-shearing crossbred sheep anything from fifty to sixty blows is satisfactory. Ibid. 65 The best way of working when crutching is to go at a good smart pace for half an hour and then have a five minutes' blow.
Blow: A shearing stroke with the handpiece of shears.

BLOW: A shearing
stroke with a
handpiece, or
shears.

Author: FERNANDEZ
Quote:
On the board the
noise changed. There
was the high whirr
of the shearing
hand-pieces. Ten
stands, ten bodies
bent over the sheep,
bring off the
fleeces with deft,
sweeping blows.

A shearing stroke
with a handpiece or
shears.
blow ... 6. Austral & N.Z. a stroke of the shears in sheep-shearing.

A system of sluicing in which strips of ground about 3 yards wide, on each side of a gutter, are sluiced into a gutter which runs down the slope. The work begins at the top of the slope and works down to a tail-race already constructed at the bottom ... The Blowing-Down System of Sluicing. This is a novel system of sluicing that has been successfully used for the working of wide stretches of poor alluvial ground in Central Otage. Its greatest application has been in the Cromwell District where it has been in use for over thirty years. It was first introduced by a Russian miner, and, although long in use, is almost unknown outside of Central Otago.

The sheep rub

Shift the mob one

for the best. Every

in the past both

the Pay Office ...
`The working class
can kiss my arse,
I've got a bludger's
job at last', sang
Smithy to the tune
of the Red Flag. ...
`All the boys sing
it whenever they
pass Bludger's Hill.
... Makes the
base-wallahs mad.'

Author: BRUNO
Quote:
... before Bludgers'
Hill was officially
condemned as a title
in Routine Orders by
sensitive base
wallahs.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
This chap finally
admitted he had
never come down from
Bludgers' Hill and
then asked what
outfit he had been
in.

Maadi, once known to
thousands of New
Zealanders as
`Bludger's Hill' the
site of Freyberg's
headquarters, the
training camp and
the main camp for
those on leave from
the front - is
unrecognisable.

Author: McGILL
Quote: Bludger's Hill nickname for admin. quarters on rise of Maadi base camp near Cairo, WWII. [Jim Henderson]

Author: KIPPENBERGER
Quote:
The Fourth Brigade
Headquarters was
established on the
Hill, so on
[1940-1941] to be
derisively and
unfairly known as
`Bludgers' Hill.'

They sent ole Bill
to Bludgers' Hill,
and jacked him up a
stripe.

"What do they all do
up there on
'Bludgers' Hill'?"
(the name given to
that hill in Maadi
Camp where
Headquarters 2
N.Z.E.F. and other
odds and sods
resided.

Hot for the foe,
Noel "Wig" Gardiner
has a year at
Bludgers Hill near
the Nile, while the
bloody defeats of
Greece, Crete, Sidi
Rezegh and Ruweizat
scar into our island
history.

Source: For the Rest of Our Lives
Author: DAVIN
Quote:
Well, how do you
like the idea of a
bit of bludging at
Div HQ, Curly?

Back at base, they
set the pace, when
bludgin' was an art

What is undeniable,
however, is that a
large number of New
Zealanders have come
to believe that
universal welfare
does breed state
dependency, that
bludging is a
national way of life
for too many and
that a "selfish"
older generation
would see their
descendants reduced
to penury so long as
their divine right
to the pension
survives as long as
they do.

Author: CASEY
Quote:
We came on a
bludging trip. Can
you let John have
Padre to ride for a
day or two?

His airmanship and
leadership saw him
return home with the
ribbons of the DSO,
DFC and bar on the
left breast of his
uniform. He
exchanged the blue
for working clothes
again.

The andesites occur
in bars, varying
from 20ft. to 300
ft. in width, and
are termed by the
miners "hard
country" or "blue
bars".

Amongst birds he has obtained [at the Chathams] are ...a Dotterel, differing from the common Dotterel of this country ...; a sea-bird, called by the whalers the `Blue Billy', the beak of which is singularly shaped, and of a blue colour, hence its trivial name; the Nelly Ossifraga gigantea) ...

The Mollymawks we had till we reached the South Tropic. ... In the Pacific I saw ... large flocks of `whale-birds' as the sailors called them - which were the Blue Billy (Prion turtur); but, in the South Atlantic, we met flocks of another but larger-sized grey bird, which they also called `whale-birds.' These were evidently Procellaria glacialoides.

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: BROAD-BILLED PRION Pachyptila vittata Other names: Parara, Blue Billy (Chathams).

Author: RICHARDS
Quote: Prion ... vittatus ... These tiny birds are light grey above; ... The blue bill is very wide and edges of the upper mandible turn upwards. ... They breed on the Chathams. There are three sorts of blue billies as they are locally called. ... Whalebirds, Blue Billies.

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Broad-billed Prion Pachyptila vittata vittata (FORSTER, 1777) ... OTHER NAMES: Whalebird, scooper, blue-billy, parara. ... Body blue-grey with conspicuous black open-M pattern across upper wings.

Author: BRERETON
Quote:
The blue bird, swamp
hen or pukeko was
very plentiful [at
Ngatimoti, Nelson
c1860s-1870s]

Author: LORD
Quote:
We say a man is .../
I nearly forgot to
mention `blue
blind', `bunkered',
and `brimful'

Author: WILSON
Quote:
We got no ready
money as pay [for
shearing] but a
`blue blister',
i.e., a cheque on
Johnny Jones.

But now we can smell
it. No, not the cow
dung, kids, but the
clear mountain air
and the faint scent
of blue borage
wafting down the
valley.
blue borage [=] viper's bugloss [s] Ibid. 7 borage blue [=] viper's bugloss [s]

The main source of nectar in this wild and remote area, flanked by the high mountains of the Seaward and Inland Kaikouras, is viper's bugloss (echium vulgare). Mountain-honey was the first company in New Zealand to market this kind of honey as blue borage, which is the local common name for the plant.

The Karori
restaurant, which
offered a Born to Be
Wild Salad (blue
borage honey-glazed
smoked eel and
watercress, lime
pepper salad with
karengo crostini)
matched with
Monteith's Black,
and Pheasantly
Phruity Purple Haze
(pheasant on crushed
urenika potatoes
with port and
blackcurrent sauce,
wild mushrooms and
parsnip crisps)
matched with
Monteith's Celtic
Red.

The clays and sandstones are called the `Blue Bottom' ... [Ibid. 86] The Blue Bottom is so called because it forms the basement formation of the extensive unconsolidated later Tertiary and more recent deposits of the coastal plain, and consists chiefly of blue clay.

Like the `blue
bottom' of North
Westland, the clays
[at Parapara,
Nelson] frequently
contain calcareous
concretions,
spheroidal or
lensoid in shape.

... and it is here
assumed to be the
marine sandstone of
the Blue Bottom.
Blue Bottom Formation ... It is locally called Brighton Bottom at Rimu.

An Educational
scheme is under way
for the benefit of
:- (1) the Blue
Boys.

Author: MACDONALD
Quote:
I learned that my
number of charges
had increased to
seven pairs of
'blues".

(Gloss) blue boys:
wounded,
convalescents.
[check]

An Educational
scheme is under way
for the benefit of
:- (1) The Blue
Boys. (2) Lead
Swingers.

Author: INGRAM
Quote:
Our host was one of
the many kindly
Londoners who call
at Hospitals on
Sundays and take out
`Blue-boys' for an
airing.

The patients you
meet at every
corner, landmarks of
blue - those
well-fitting
faultlessly tailored
blues! How the
tailors of England
escaped "a fit of
the blues" when they
came face to face
with them for the
first time I do not
know.]

A Blue Boy appeared,
then another, still
a third, all ready
for some fun.

It was infinitely
touching to see some
of the Blue Boys
making the beds and
helping to prepare
things for their
wounded comrades.

The New Contingent
Association is
opening shortly a
fine big recreation
room in the hospital
building for the
Blue Boys... It is
to be known as the
Kapai Club.

Roughly 75,000 of
the "red boy" and
112,000 of the "blue
boy" were sold.

Author: Owen Marshall
Quote:
'We should try for a
fishing trip soon.
Blue cod in the
Sounds - what do you
reckon?'

Blue cod are pierced
with rods and
spitted
(Black Stewart Island) It was no unusual event ...to land ... Moki, Latris ciliaris; Trumpeter, Latris hecateia; Blue cod or Rock cod, Percis colias; and Red cod, Lotella bacchus.

There are
restrictions on
taking the tasty
blue cod here but we
bring up a terakihi
that is perfect for
the pot.

Author: HECTOR
Quote: 38. ROCK COD. ... This (Percis colias) is the Coal Fish of Captain Cook and Blue Cod of the settlers in the South, and the Pakirikiri of the Maoris ...

Author: SHERRIN
Quote: ROCK COD (Percis Colias). ... This is the coal-fish of Captain Cook, and blue-cod of the settlers in the South, and the pakirikiri of the Maoris, and is the most commonly-caught fish among rocks on the coast.
Blue cod (Percis colias)

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Blue cod... name given to a New Zealand fish Percis colias... Called also in New Zealand Rock cod (q.v.).
Blue-cod (Parapercis colias, Forster).
PARAPERCIS COLIAS (Forster) Blue Cod; Rawaru. A highly esteemed food fish; secured in water up to 100 fathoms.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Quote: 42. Parapercis colias Forster. Blue Cod. Maori: Pakirikiri
Parapercis colias (Forster). Blue cod. Rawaru.

Author: POWELL
Quote: BLUE COD (Parapercis colias ) Rawaru of the Maoris, is our most esteemed food fish.
Blue Cod Parapercichthys colias (Bloch and Schn.)
Notes: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 409

Author: MORELAND
Quote: [=MARBLEFISH] BLUE COD [Parapercis colias ] ... A very old name from Cook's time, coalfish, is still in use. A variety of Maori names are now little used.

Author: JOHNSON
Quote:
I hauled in a blue
cod ... large enough
for the whole
family.

Author: AYLING
Quote: BLUE COD (Blue weever, rawaru) Parapercis colias

Author: PAUL
Quote: Blue cod Parapercis colias ... Found only in New Zealand. Known almost exclusively by this common name, the occasionally listed coal-fish being a name used only by Captain Cook and some early writers, and derived from an unrelated European fish.

Police officers who
forced prisoners to
pose for degrading
photographs and
dealt out excessive
punishment were not
reported because of
a so-called "blue
code of silence"
that exists within
the police.

Author: "H"
Quote:
He told of the hard
long weeks of
"driving" through
"tight blue country"
to pick up a reef.

Author: AYSON
Quote:
Their larder was
also enlarged by the
eggs of cranes,
shags and gulls
which nested in
thousands on trees
overhanging the
river below the
swamp paddock.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote:
The Matukutuku, or
Crane, of this there
are several kinds in
New Zealand; the
blue crane or that
which inhabits the
seashore is common
to every one ...

Author: DOMETT
Quote: ('Twas that blue crane with bristly crown -/ You recollect?) ... Ibid. 2/338 Blue crane .... Ardeidae; Herodias Matuku?

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
THE BLUE HERON
[title] In the
neighbourhood of
Takaka ... we
watched the nesting
customs of the Blue
Crane.

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: BLUE REEF HERON Egretta sacra Other names: Blue Crane, Matuku-moana.

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: White-faced Heron Ardea novaehollandiae novaehollandiae LATHAM, 1790 ... OTHER NAME: Blue crane. ... Throughout New Zealand in wetland habitats; ... Still expanding north anReef Heron Egretta sacra sacra (GMELIN, 1789) ... OTHER NAMES: Blue reef heron, stern reef heron, blue crane, blue heron, matuku-moana. ... Reef herons in New Zealand are at the southeastern limit of their mostly tropical range, and for that reason alone may never be common. d east from Australia. Ibid. 132

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... blue duck, a rumour, esp. a baseless one;

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Blue duck. A rumour, esp. if baseless: New Zealand soldiers': in G.W. Semantics: quack! quack!

[Slang of the NZEF]
A `blue duck' was a
rumour; but a `bird'
was a prisoner in a
cage.

Author: BAKER
Quote: Among numerous terms originated in the first Great War we may note ... blue duck, a rumour.
blue duck n. (Sl.) rumour (World War 1 slang).

Author: McGILL
Quote: blue duck rumour, especially a baseless one or a dud; chiefly Kiwi army WWI, developed from Australian for anything not coming up to expectations.

Irene and I scramble
down to the Lambert
and immediately
spook a pair of blue
ducks.

My first sight, in
1993, of your
spectaular and very
rare blue duck
swimming with young
against rushing
white waters felt as
though I had been
given one of life's
privileged moments.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
We could talk
learnedly of wash,
blue ducks, seepage
races, benching,
californian riffles,
and all the terms
that go with
prospecting.

Easter, 1933, was
disastrous with evil
storms. Len Boot ...
made a blue duck's
trip down the
Whitcombe.

THE endangered blue
duck may not know
it, but the chances
of its survival have
received a boost to
the tune of $1.5
million over 15
years. The blue duck
can only live in its
habitat of
fast-flowing
mountain streams.

The wildlife pond
was created by
building a dam in
1976, doing
extensive planting
and encouraging
scaup, grey teal,
shoveler, black and
white swans,
mallards, Carolina
wood ducks and a
breeding pair of the
endangered Whio
(blue duck).

Further down the
path I flush a pair
of endangered blue
duck from their
trackside cover.

The Taieri Gorge was
full of blue duck.

[Dusky Sound] We shot several curious Birds among which was a Duck of Blue grey Plumage with the end of its Bill as soft as the lips of any other animal, as it is altogether unknown I shall endeavour to preserve the Whole in spirits. [fn] the Blue Duck or whio, Hymenolaimus malacorhyncus (Gm.).]

Author: HEAPHY
Quote:
Great quantities of
blue ducks,
apparently a species
of shoveller, are to
be met with on this
stream.
Notes: 1846 Heaphy Exped South-West Nelson in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 198

Quote:
Shot a wihu, or blue
duck ...

Source: Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson
Author: HAAST
Quote: Our provisions here began to fail, but catching some eels and whios (blue ducks), they made a good addition to our scanty commissariat. Ibid. 136 The most abundant member of the family Anatidae... is the whio, the blue duck of the settlers. (Anas malacorhyncus).

I shot four blue
duck, 4 pigeons and
a caw-caw and a
wecka.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
I don't think a
minute passed
without a brace of
wild ducks flying
past, - grey, blue,
and Paradise.

... the light-eyed Teal slunk silently from view; or ... the little Grebe with rosy breast, dived and sported with restless activity; close by a group of sober Grey Ducks; whilst the watchful Paradise Drake basked on the sunny bank above ... Ibid. 48 ... from the swift stream below ... arose the plaintive whistle of the Blue Duck ... Ibid. 72 ANAS SUPERCILIOSA, Gml. Parera. Grey Duck. Ibid. 73 HYMENOLAIMUS MALACORHYNCHUS, Gml. Whio. Blue Duck, Mountain Duck.

101. HYMENOLAIMUS

Duck. Whio.

Quote: HYMENOLAEMUS MALACORHYNCUS. (BLUE DUCK.) ... Native name.- Wio

Quote:
[A] few Paradise and
blue ducks ...
uttered their
well-known notes.

Quote:
At the mouth of the

Hymenolaimus malacorhynchus. - Whio, Blue Duck. Both Islands.

Source: Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ

Quote: Blue or mountain ducks (Nestor rotabilis [sic - Harper is shaky on scientific names], are not now found in any numbers except in the upper parts of hitherto unvisited rivers, ...

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Whio ... 2. n. Hymenolaemus malacorhynchus, blue duck; sometimes called whistling duck.

Hymenolaimus malacorhynchus Gm. Blue Duck; Mountain Duck. This beautiful and characteristic species maintains itself wherever the mountain-creeks which form its home are undisturbed by the too near approach of settlement.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote: ... the same peculiarity may be seen in the neck of the Blue Duck (Hymenolaemus malacorynchus).

Author: McLEOD
Quote:
Another expression
for a hopeless day
when rain or fog
prevents any chance
of mustering is `a
blue duck,' and I
don't know the
origin of this
either.

Author: BLAKISTON
Quote:
With pork, young
rabbits and an
occasional blue duck
we were never short
of meat. Tamer than
other wild duck, the
blue mountain
variety have now
been killed out in
this district, ...

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: [so 1957 Hymenolaimus]
blue duck n : a New Zealand duck (Hymenolaimus malacorhynchus) with mostly lead-blue plumage

Quote: Blue duck .. .. whio .. .. Hymenolaimus malacorhynchus
blue duck NZ = WHIO

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The

... the third sort
is the blue grey
duck before
mentioned or the
whistling duck as
some called them
from the whistling
noise they made.
[ed. fn] The Blue
Duck, Hymenolaimus
malacorhynchus. It
is sometimes called
the Whistling Duck,
and the Maori name,
Whio, is also
derived from its

Author: FORSTER
Quote:
The third sort was a
bluish grey
whistling duck,
about the size of a
wigeon; its bill had
a remarkable
membranaceous
substance at the
extremity on both
sides ... Its breast
was sprinkled with
ferruginous
feathers, and on the
wings it had a large
white spot.

Author: MONEY
Quote:
There was a species
of grey duck [near
the Grey river] with
white bills, often
described as the
whistling duck.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Whio ... 2. n. Hymenolaemus malacorhynchus, blue duck ; sometimes called whistling duck. [so 1957/496 Hymenolaimus ]

whio , a water-bird (Hymenolaimus malacorhynchus), blue-duck, mountain-duck, whistling duck; name echoic, like English whew-duck having a similar name for the same reason. The place-name Whiorau, means blue-ducks a-plenty.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Whio 1. v.i. Whistle ...2. n. Hymenolaimus malacorhynchus, blue duck ; sometimes called whistling duck .

A few kiwis, blue
ducks and hens were
got on the flats..
and caw-caws were
fairly plentiful.

Arrived Wataroa
safely. Plenty of
blue ducks.

Author: WOODHOUSE
Quote:
Blue Duck Pool.. was
so named because for
several seasons my
father and I saw a
blue duck swimming
about with her brood
of ducklings.

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
Another expression
for a hopeless day
when rain or fog
prevent any chance
of mustering is a
'blue duck' ...

blue duck - fog-in
or wet weather.

She's away for a
blue duck.

[Answers to
correspondents]
`Blue Duck': your
mss. is synonymous
with your non de
plume

Source: For the Rest of Our Lives
Author: DAVIN
Quote:
`Having a good time
[on leave]?' `She's
a blue duck. ... Had
a bit of a run-in
with a pongo MP down
the Berka.'

Author: MUNDY
Quote:
I said to Mack `she
looks like a blue
duck.' [i.e., an
unprofitable
(gold-mining)
venture or claim]

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
Would Mabel last
out, and with 30
love and Mabel
serving [her too
often repeated
`double fault'], the
result looked like a
`blue duck'.

A petition to force
a by-election for
two new trustees for
the Terawhiti
Licensing Trust
never got off the
ground. Organiser
Norm Thomas says the
petition is a `blue
duck'.

It's a case of "blue
duck" with my
Deception money.

Author: OWENS & PERKINS
Quote:
We finished the
drain, and as they
used to say on the
creek, she was a
blue duck - there
was nothing there
[sc. no gold].

Apparently, I had
made a meet at the
Johnny Horner for
that afternoon and
when I didn't front
she blued. to
blue....to abuse
someone

He is still a
conductor in the
tram service, and
was shown the
blister when Bailey
was served with a
bit-o'-blue.

For a man on the
Collar, every blue
he gets in means
maybe another two
years.

Author: HAMILTON
Quote:
Bluey had lost his
seaman's ticket over
his jail blues, and
I don't suppose
he'll ever get it
back.
blue, n. a bill, a summons. Also a fight or row.

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote:
BLUE (n) Criminal
charge

The group was issued
with `blues',
banning them from
the hotel for two
years after they
began fighting among
themselves about
9pm.

Author: JACKSON
Quote:
Early in the month
of September, 1941,
the whole battalion
moved `up the blue'
(a term used to
indicate any portion
of the sterile
Western Desert) to a
place called
Baguish.

We were striking out
into the blue... In
the desert the
unknown is always
"the blue", whether
it be Egypt,
Cyrenaica,
Tripolitania or
Tunisia.

When we had settled
down and knew that
the Western Desert
was ALWAYS "up the
blue", I inquired..
where could I learn
the language?

You'd be talking,
you'd take somebody
shopping or go out
for lunch or dinner
today. Tomorrow
they'd be up the
blue and walk on a
landmine and you'd
never see them
again.

Author: BARBER
Quote:
... the whole
brigade [the Camel
Corps] could, on an
hour's notice, go
off into the `blue'
for five days
without any
communication or
assistance from
base.
Notes: 1938 John Robertson The Cameliers in Palestine 27 in 1984 Barber Red Coat to Jungle Green 93

Quote: Out in the blue!

In the desert the
unknown is always
`the blue', whether
it be Egypt,
Cyrenaica or ...
[etc]

Source: For the Rest of Our Lives
Author: DAVIN
Quote:
Had a bit of a
run-in with a pongo
MP down the Berka
last night. ...
Those bastards are
too bloody fond of
poking the borax at
a bloke just back
from the blue.

Author: STEWART
Quote:
[IN THE BLUE : ?away
from base : ?in the
wrong] In the dense
smoke and dust the
Otago left had lost
touch with the
sorely reduced
companies on the
right [in the
advance by Eaucourt,
September 1916] ...
the companies ...
reported their
location ... by
runner to Battalion
Headquarters. ... It
was with some
consternation that
General Braithwaite
... found his troops
in a position so
much `in the blue'
as to invite
disaster.
Notes: ?In trouble; ? too far away from base in the (unknown) desert.

Quote:
After they were far
beyond their guns
they led their men
on "into the blue".

Author: LANCASTER
Quote:
If I blue twenty
cheques they'll
never come back.

It appears that
Humby's pa
obligingly wheeled
his barrow over the
border last January
and Humby started to
blew the sum of
260[pounds] the old
man had left behind
him.

Author: LANCASTER
Quote:
You must give a man
one chance in a year
to blue his cheque.

Author: 'ANZAC'
Quote:
The boys had fixed
to give us a boncer
welcome, but ... in
the words of our
informant `they
blued their cheques,
got shikkared, and
the show bust up.'

... those who blued
a tanner.

Author: MEEK
Quote:
BLUED THEIR CHEQUES:
Spent their money
mostly on liquor.

Blues are farmed
prolifically along
the coast of
Galicia, Spain's
Atlantic seaboard
...That region
produces 240,000
tonnes ... worth
$150 million, les
than half the value
of greenlips.

Andrew James (Blue)
Kennedy (1925 -
......) ... Never
one to dodge a
`blue' with
employers ..., he
was in fact
nicknamed for his
wiry crop of ginger
hair.

Author: THATCHER

Author: GIBBS
Quote: Incidentally, it was Johannes Anderson (1924) writing in the New Zealand School Journal about a specimen of this butterfly which had been caught in Westland, who gave it our common name, saying `I have called it the `blue moon butterfly' because it is so rare; it is found only `once in a blue moon'. Besides it carries the blue moon on its wings, and it is like other blue moons - it is there all the time, but it is only when you are in certain positions that you see it.' The name has stuck and is certainly appropriate. The butterfly is known as the `common eggfly' in Australia.

shirts' and

cabbage-tree hats

"Blue Smoke goes
drifting by / Into
the deep blue
sky..." Those word,
instantly memorable
to anyone older than

1940s, signal the
opening of one of
the few truly New

to become a

The Blue Streak
railcar is being
replaced not by one
bus, but by three
each way daily.

Author: LEITCH
Quote:
A through
Auckland-Wellington
express service
known as the 'Blue
Streak' has been
tremendously
popular.

Author: LEITCH
Quote:
While the 'Silver
Star' overnight
sleeper will be the
most comfortable,
the 'Blue Streak'
railcar is the only
way to see this
vital transport
artery during the
daylight hours.

A sample of Blue
Stufff analysed at
harness racing's
drug laboratory in
Auckland had been
found to contain a
broncho-dilator not
previously detected
here.... Rennell
said HRNZ was
already conducting
its own probe into
Blue Stuff, when it
became apparent
their investigations
were crossing the
paths of local
police.

While Harness Racing
NZ chases round the
country looking for
the ridiculously
named Blue Stuff,
four trainers named
have been tarnished
with the unsaid
"druggie" label...
The substance is not
illegal under New
Zealand law but is
believed to be
performance-enhancing
in horses and
therefore banned in
racing.... So armed
with all this, some
bright spark in
Australia has
decided to call it
Blue Stuff - not
HorsePower or Super
Horse, or even
methoxyxchlororidepanoprophren.You
can imagine the
confusion when
there's a pre-dawn
bang on the door and
the coppers are
yelling through the
letterbox: "We're
looking for illegal
Blue Stuff."

Author: ANZAC
Quote:
I am fed up with
hospitals.. fed up
and surfeited with
the old blue suit!

Author: MACDONALD
Quote:
The neat blue bundle
was placed beside
each patient and
contained pyjamas,
towel, face-cloth
and the famous white
shirt, blue pants
and scarlet tie
which were to be
worn when the
patient was
officially allowed
up. How they longed
to be well enough to
wear those "blues".

It is becoming very common in the country from Wairoa to Gisborne [and is also called recorded from Christchurch].

Author: CONNELL & HADFIELD
Quote: Blue tussock (Poa colensoi and Poa intermedia) grow about 8 inches high with bluish narrow leaves. The only palatable tussocks are, (1) the blue tussocks which are easily killed by continuous burning and by continuous close grazing..

Quote:
blue tussock: small,
now also rather
rare, native tussock
(poa colensoi) which
is sometimes
incorrectly called
silver tussock.

I think that
taxation should
occur in proportion
to the amount of
unimproved land a
man possesses - thus
5s per acre is not
too great a tax on
the property which
carries blue tussock
and wild Irishman,
while 6d per acre is
sufficient for the
paddock carrying
four sheep to the
acre per annum, laid
down with Poverty
Bay rye grass.

The configuration of
the land is
undulating, and all
ploughable, save two
or three hundred
acres of nicely
grassed spurs; in
fact, the property
is said to be one of
good blue tussock in
its maiden state.

From the Gorge Creek
to Gow's Creek,
right back to the
main range, the
alpine country will
in summer time carry
a sheep to the acre,
and this upon the
best fattening
native grasses and
herbs, blue tussock,
soft speargrass,
aniseed, and cotton
plant.

There was a fair
area of yellow
tussock on the
northern end of the
run ... Blue tussock
was not plentiful
except on some of
the spurs running
down to the Waihao
...

danthonia and other

Author: WHEELER
Quote:
Unless you walk over
this country
[Central Otago]
you'll miss the
native grasses, like
danthonia and the
blue tussock. To a
Merino, one mouthful
of this hard feed
[13] is worth 10 of
soft greenfeed.

Author: DAWSON
Quote: Short tussock grassland ... is characterised by the light brown tufts ... of hard tussock (Festuca novae-zelandiae) together with silver ussock (Poa cita = P. caespitosa), blue tussock (Poa colensoi) and blue wheat grass (Elymus rectisetus).
Blue tussock (P. colensoi) is a favoured food plant for many insects but has been much reduced in abundance by grazing animals, which also seek it out.

One of the effects
of the disappearance
of the rabbit in the
far back is the
increase spread of
the blue tussock.

Less grand and altogether less fortunate are the short tussocks. Growing up to half a metre in height, they include such hardy species as blue tussock (Poa colensoi), silver tussock (P. cita) and hard, or fescue, tussock (Festuca novaezelandiae.).

Ferndale Dairies, of
Eltham, have been
producing blue
cheese since 1951.
That first classic,
simply labelled Blue
Vein, is still a big
seller for the
company.

Of established
blues, the best in
the class was
Mainland's Galaxy
Blue Vein, which is
the archetypical New
Zealand cow milk
blue, with a
powerful salty taste
and moist body.

Most astounding of
all is the belated
recognition of
Galaxy Blue Vein.,
which has been made
to the same recipe
since 1951, and is
one of the
strongest-tasting
blue cheeses in the
world.

Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Quote:
Blue vein belongs to
that family of
cheeses which in
England is called
stilton, in France
roquefort, in Italy
gorgonzola, and in
Denmark Danish blue.
New Zealand blue
vein is recognised
as a blue cheese in
its own right and
can be distinguished
from its Continental
counterparts by the
deeper yellow colour
of its curd. This
arises from a
difference in milk
colour.
blue vein cheese containing blue mould.
Notes: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; nf. 1986 NZPOD]

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote:
The main kind of
cheese produced is
`cheddar', with one
factory at Eltham
producing `blue
vein' cheese.

One large blue whale
will yield 200 tons
of meat, which, when
reduced to 5000lbs
of extract, will
make 500,000 pints
of soup.

The monster was
identified as a blue
whale (Balaenoptera
sibbaldi) one of the
largest species
known.

The blue whale was
known as the
"cosmopolitan of the
seas," and had been
found almost
everywhere where
there was sea.
The blue whale (Balaenoptera musculus) is the first of the four species or rorquals, or finners, to be mentioned. It is the largest species of whale, and, indeed, of all animals, living and extinct.

Author: WELD

Woodhens and blue
whistling and
paradise ducks

Of the moa, to my
surprise, I saw
neither bones nor
relics of any kind

Canterbury.

him generously with

Author: MEADE
Quote:
The custom of
tattooing is now
falling out of
fashion amongst the
rising generation of
both sexes, and it
is to be hoped that
before many years
have passed, the
nickname of
`Blue-lips' will no
longer be applicable
to the native girls
of New Zealand.
Where the tattooing
is confined to the
slender lyre-shaped
line on the fair
one's chin, the
effect is really not
unpleasing; but the
tattooed lip is an
abomination.
Notes: 1864 Dec 27 Meade Ride through Disturbed Districts in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 441

Author: LYSNAR
Quote:
For the young women
this ornamentation
[moko] was limited
to the lips, and the
name `blue-lips' was
given to them by the
English. Red lips
were looked upon as
a reproach or
disfigurement.

Quote: BLUE-NOSE WAREHOU Hyperoglyphe antarctica (Blue-nose grouper, griffins silverfish, bonita, deepsea trevalla) ... [302] They are caught regularly on hapuku long lines along with hapuku and bass and are sold as hapuku.

Grant's audiences
have not been large,
but, for some
inexplicable reason,
on July 11 a vast
throng assembled to
hear `the word', and
as the police had
been prodded
unkindly for some
time about these
meetings Sergt.
Burrows had a little
quiet conversation
with Grant as a
result of what that
individual was
blue-papered to
appear in the S.M.
court on a charge
...

A rouseabout - also
variously known as a
rousie, woolhandler,
shedhand, fleeco,
the person `picking
up' or a blue tongue
- is responsible for
the passage of wool
after being shorn
from the sheep's
back to the wool
press where it is
baled.

Blue water title may
be another term that
is not used, or
little used, outside
New Zealand. NSOD
does not record it.
nor does DNZE.
Perhaps a popular
rather than a
lawyers' term, it
refers to a piece of
privately owned land
that extends below
high water mark, an
unusual but not
unknown occurrence.

The kokako, or blue
wattle crow, is a
threatened species
and is bred in
captivity at Mt
Bruce.

Sir James Hector, in
drawing attention..
to a very fine
specimen of the New
Zealand crow or jay.
as it should more
properly be called,
made interesting
references to the
complete isolation
of the orange wattle
crow, in the South
Island, and the blue
wattle crow in the
North Island.

The blue-wattled
crow is of a dark
bluish-grey colour,
with the lower part
of the back and
abdomen tinged with
rufous-brown.

WILSONI. Bp.
Blue-wattled Crow.

Author: BULLER
Quote: GLAUCOPIS WILSONI. (BLUE-WATTLED CROW.) ... Native name.- Kokako
Glaucopis wilsoni. - Kokako, Blue-wattled Crow. North Island. Very irregular in distribution.

I have paid special attention to the nests of three birds- the Native Canary (Orthonyx ochrocephala), the Robin (Myiomoira albifrons), and the Tomtit (Myiomoira macropcephala). Sir Walter Buller says ... that the Blue Crow (Glaucopis cinerea) lays a single egg, and ... leaves the care of the chick to the to the Popokatea, or Canary (Orthonyx albicilla).

Author: MYERS
Quote: Callaeas wilsoni Bonaparte. Blue-wattled Crow. This beautiful species supplies one of the greatest surprises of the investigation.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote: Thus I learnt that the Blue Wattled Crow (Glaucopis Wilsoni), ... was at one time common also on Tutira.

ko[o]kako, two birds (Callaeas wilsoni - North Island, and C. cinereous[sic] - South Island), blue-wattled crow and orange-wattled crow, the colour of the wattles being the only difference; nearly if not quite extinct: this is the bird to which the echoic name bell-bird was first applied.

Author: POWELL
Quote: BLUE-WATTLED CROW (Callaeas wilsoni). A moderately large dark bluish grey bird with a stout black bill, ... and conspicuous wattles of bright blue. The South Island species, C. cinerea, is almost identical except for the wattles, which are orange ... The Orange-wattled crow is still plentiful ... The Maori name for both species is Kokako.
blue-wattled crow n : a passerine bird (Callaeas wilsoni) of New Zealand that resembles a starling

(c) Other common names: (i) Skipjack; Striped Bonito (ii) Bluefin Tuna; Southern Bluefin; Southern Tuna (iii) Yellowfin All sometimes referred to as Tunny. (d) Principal localities where taken: (i) A summewr visitor to New Zealand ... (ii) Southern Bluefin Tuna is a large species of temperate Australasian seas and migrates south to Foveaux Strait in summer months. (iii) A widely distributed tropical species which ranges into northern waters ... in summer months.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: korokoropounamu ... Girella cyanea, blue fish.

From Cape Maria van
Diemen a number of
fish termed
`blue-fish' are
recorded. The same
returns also record
rock-cod. I am quite
unable to suggest
what fish is meant
by `blue-fish,'
unless, indeed, the
observer has used
the names
indiscriminately.
These fish were very
numerous, were taken
during every month
of the year, and fed
chiefly on mussel,
but occasionally on
small fish. They
weighed from 1lb to
2lb each.

Author: BEATTIE

I do not know Tommy
Roundhead's Maori

small and good to
eat and were
numerous there. The
old chief at
Blueskin Bay was
very blue in his
tattoo; ...

Perhaps most truly

buildings (Knox,
Bishopscourt),
coarsely
hammer-dressed
because it was too
hard for fine
dressing.
Notes: See also Knight & Wales : Buildings of Dunedin 1988

You can fancy, old
mate, now I'm
longing .../ To flee

Therefore,
Woollcombe, get thee
hence; go home thou
wowser on the
wallaby; hump bluey,
carry Matilda, pad

parsonical howler,
thou Wowseristic
whaler Woollcombe.

Myself with a
`bluey' hung on a
broom.

He could roll his
"bluey" and reach
the spot where the
work was thickest.

Bluey.- Swag. A nickname for a swag common in the 'nineties. In those days most station blankets were blue (earlier still, I believe, they were red). Hence bluey up-- carrying a swag. ([1898 Morris Austral-English])

Author: VAILE

Author: NEWTON

blue ... -blu'ey n. a blue blanket in which the bushman wraps his belongings; a smock-shirt made of coarse material. -to hump one's bluey v.i. to go on the tramp carrying a pack on one's back.
bluey ...n. orig. a blue blanket commonly used by swagmen for wrapping their possessions, now the swag (q.v) itself; a summons (N.Z.)
~ n. originally a blue blanket commonly used by swagmen for wrapping their possessions, now the swag (q.v) itself.

bluey n. Austral. inf. 1. a blanket. 2. a swagman's bundle. 3. hump one's bluey. to carry one's bundle; tramp. 4. a variant of blue (sense 9). 5. a cattle dog. [(for senses 1, 2, 4) C19: < BLUE (on account of their colour) + -Y]

down to a very light
bedroll.

After half a
century, the era of
the `bluey' is over.
From now on, thanks
to Dataprint, the
Police Department's
new [dollars]66,000
computerised traffic
summons system,
offending motorists
will receive
`whiteys.' The blue
summons paper has
been replaced by
white computer
paper.
`Bluey' ban for pests in bar-rooms ... Hotel patrons who misbehave in Christchurch hotels will soon be served with a `bluey' - a legal notice warning them to stay off the premises.

The sort of
behaviour that had
taken place was not
and would not be
tolerated,
especially with the
advent of `Blueys',
the recently
introduced banning
notices for
misbehaviour.

Blué.y (bl&umacr.&ybreve.), n. 1. A bushman's blanket; - so called from its color. 2. A bushman's bundle; a swag; - so called because a blamket is sometimes used as the outside covering. To hump bluey, to carry a swag; hence, to travel about in the bush, esp. in search of work. [Colloq.]

Someone asked me the

each other - like
sheep - over the
edge. .h;.us; [cf.

`Presenting a bold
and almost
perpendicular front,

1658.]

On the top the

I can only dream of
the exquisite taste
of the champagne
bluff oysters.

By the time we'd
reached our
destination,
Ohawini, bluff
oyster of the north,
it was my considered
opinion that there
was and is a
desperate need in
our stressful
society for the
hiring of billboard
space to accommodate
the names of
offending wimps and
nerds.

The Bluff oyster, we
believe, is our most
noble heritage. It
is the big band of
oysters, insistently
pounding its message
to the senses. It is
closely rivalled by
the Nelson oyster
which, you will
understand if you
know Nelson, is an

Bluff oysters are identified as ostrea angasi, first cousin to the highly prized French belon oyster from Brittany. Ostrea angasi are also found in Tasmania and around the NSW coast, where they are known as Jervis Bay oysters, native oysters, mud oysters or flat oysters.

Author: BACON
Quote: Board, Education-New Zealand State Schools are administered by one or other of ten Education Boards, who make teaching appointments for all schools in their respective areas. Teachers are graded following inspection visits, and according to the Inspector's assessment, are given `grading marks'. In applying for a position, a teacher quotes his mark, the vacancy being filled by the highest graded applicant. Local parents elect School Committees bi-annually. Committee has no say in curriculum, etc., but is, in effect, a caretaking body.

Source: In the Land of the Tui

Author: GORDON
Quote: The department-boss is in charge of the board-walkers often promoted from the ranks, who are in charge of the chain etc.; they vary the speed the speed of the drive on the chain, which is done by a chain hanging down, giving rise to cries `Give it a pull' (i.e., speed it up) or `Pull it back' (slow down). If some are tired and he speeds it up, there are cries of `Get out you whip!' or `Bring your whip tomorrow!'. If the men are very tired to the point of mutton-staggers there will be cries of `Give him a drink of water.', and responses `But he had water yesterday'.

Author: TURNER
Quote: Calves not kept for the herd become bobby calves, a truly standard word since it was defined in the Bobby Calf Marketing Regulations in the New Zealand Statutory Regulations, 1938: `Bobby calf' means a calf which is intended for slaughter for human consumption as boneless veal.' The origin and dating of the word are doubtful. There is a similar word poddy calf for a hand-fed calf, recorded in Australia from last century. The present New Zealand meaning seems to have arisen about 1929. The Christchurch Times, 17 August 1929, reported: `During the last year or so quite a trade has grown up in young, or `bobby' calves, which are taken in by the freezing works, killed and exported.' The term vealer is also used.

all morning. Must
have a hangover, I
reckon.'

Local publican Bruce
Ford said the two
youngsters had
`kicked up bobsie
die' on the boat
during the journey
from Bluff to
Stewart Island.
sy-die n. N.Z. infss; confusion (esp. in kick up bobsy-die. [< C19 Bob's a-dying]

Author: BEARDSLEY
Quote:
kick up bobsy-die
make a fuss

Author: McGILL
Quote:
Another time she
went to the outhouse
and sat on a
hedgehog and kicked
up bobsy-die, ...

Author: McGILL
Quote: bobsy-die fuss or fun; common phr. `kicking up bobsy-die'; ironic C18 English nautical almost rhyming `bob's-a-dying/idling' underwent sea change to NZ C19, possibly picking up `bobbery' or shindy, from Hindi `bapre'. Ngaio Marsh used original in Surfeit of Lampreys: `If she's right ... it plays Bobs-a-dying with the whole blooming case.' NZA.

Author: McLEAN
Quote:
By generally kicking
up bobsy-die.

They had paper down
- but me mother

about that place.

Die" in deafening

Heard of poor
Daniels (bob-tail

Beauty-on-demand
(nicknamed "bod") is
aimed at busy

like Kenny, juggle
children, a business
and a life, "but
still want to look
good."

Kenny said she has
25 experienced
beauty therapists on
her books who want
to be "bod girls"...

By definition a
boddler is a
smallish person who
is not really a baby
but not quite a
full-blown toddler.
The expression,
boddler boy, was
copied after a
mother from
Waimahaka, in
Southland, was
savagely attacked by
her 14-month-old son
with a sawn-off
rattle.

Author: GEE
Quote:
This was.. because
the badminton
association

opposite her home
was staffed by
"bodgies and
widgies." "So bad is
their behaviour that
recently I have had
to erect a six-foot
fence costing sixty
pounds along the
side of my house to
stop them making
love under my pine
trees".

This is partly his
nature: the natural
bodgie keeps
colliding with the
responsibilities of
office.

Author: ELDRED-GRIGG
Quote:
Gangs of boys roamed
about in jeans and
leather jackets.
They were called
bodgies and I
thought they might
beat me up.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
I suppose a bloke
who becomes a bodgie
is somebody who's
not interested in
what they're doing.

The bodgies and
widgies (who did not
drive motorbikes)
were here! They
drank fearsome
mind-altering
concoctions like
Bodgies Blood - a
mixture of raspberry
syrup and soda water
...

Author: VIRTUE
Quote:
Her mum had probably
been shot by some
thoughtless local
bodgie.

Mr Mallard is
enjoyed in the House
as that rare thing,
a superbly
well-organised
bodgie.

Author: MANNING
Quote:
The terms "Bodgie"
and "Widgie" are
peculiar to the
middle 20th Century,
but the
characteristics are
not... In the
under-privileged
masses the
counterparts of
Bodgies were
variously styled as
'yahoos',
'larrikins',
'hooligans' and
'yobs'. The
'playboy' of upper
class society is the
"Bodgie" of the
poor.

One of the first
things that emerged
in Mr Manning's
study was that
neither bodgies nor
widgies lack
intelligence but
there was widespread
resentment at the
lack of freedom in
school and
education.

Young New Zealand
servicemen decided
last evening to
clean Queen Street
of the "teddy boy"
and "bodgie"
element.

On Labour weekend
the island was
overrun with
hundreds of boozing,
cursing,
bottle-smashing
bodgies and
widgies... The
bodgies favour blue
jeans, the widgies
black sweaters and
tight black shorts

[Hdg] S.M. Refers to
Waiheke Bodgie-
Widgie Trouble.

"I refuse to speak
to widgies, sir"...
"Widgie? Widgie? I
am a widgie?"...
"Well, what do they
call a boy widgie?"
"A - a bodgie is
what you mean."

Some of those "Teddy
boys" and "bodgies"
carry knives and
once someone started
cutting their hair
anything could have
happened.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
Another thing I
don't like about
coming to town, and
that's these bodgie
jokers you see
around the place.

There will be
niggles - the
arbitrating
advantage of
high-income
individuals now
forming themselves
into bodgie
companies...

The bodgies and
widgies.. drank
fearsome
mind-altering
concoctions like
Bodgies Blood - a
mixture of raspberry
syrup and soda water
...

Bodgie kid, farm
trainee,
hairdressing
apprentice,
horse-riding move
extra, then - BANG1
- writer of a truly
trashy phenomenon
involving teenie
virgins, a kinky,
fish-netted
scientist and his
coterie of misfits
with raging libidos.

It did stage too
many bodgey and
bogan gigs.

[The car] natched my
brother's Bodgie
haircut and
winklepicker shoes.

He was more bodgie
than Ted. He got
around in a
flat-top.

Anyway, if Parker is
a criminal so is
anyone who has
bodgied up a receipt
for the tax man,
ratcheted up an
insurance claim, or
even contributed to
the black economy...

That he has just
spent time in Sydney
as an official guest
at the Olympics made
this [insulting]
observation daringly
bodgie-esque.

He and Sharon have
settled into the
comfortable
bodgiedom of late
middle-age; he
drives a black
Holden, she a new
four-wheel drive.

The freelance writer
insists that the
booklet ... is a
souvenir to mark
Rotorua's first
league
international. Angry
officials claim it
is a bodgy
programme.

Build up production
with Bodmin.

In its ability to
milk cows, then, the
Bodmin system cannot
be seriously
faulted. The wrangle
between satisfied
users of Bodmin
milking clusters and
the Ministry of
Agriculture's Dairy
Division is healing
up. ..This means
that a Bodmin plant
is considerably
cheaper to install
than a conventional
plant. One farmer
told me that two
things suggested to
him that his Bodmin
clusters were
gentler in action
than conventional
types.

This is my second
season using the
Bodmin units.

The Bodmin system.
As a Waikato farmer,
Syd Bodmin the
designer was
concerned at the
damage inflicted on
cows by milking
machines ... [Bodmin
cluster; Bodmin
plant; Bodmin unit ]

The Bodmin can also
save you up to a
third in electricity
costs.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
In breaking in a
young bullock to the
team [c1900] the
first step was to
couple the young
beast to a steady
near-side bullock
used to working in
the body (centre) of
the team.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
`Fences near the
rivers went body and
sleeves'
Notes: [From a letter written by Jock Anderson, 11 May 1897]; 1959 L. Masters Tales of the Mails 100

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
In the small river
Ashburton ... we had
a little
misunderstanding
[105] with the
bullocks; the
leaders ... slewed
sharply round, and
tied themselves into
an inextricable knot
with the polars
[sic], while the
body bullocks, by a
manoeuvre not
unfrequent, shifted,
or as it is
technically termed,
slipped, the yoke
under their necks,
and the bows over;
...

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
A beast yoked up in
the central part of
a bullock team.

Irresponsible body
corporates could
leave complacent
apartment owners
facing ruinous
repair and
maintenance bills, a
property management
expert warns... A
body corporate is
made up of all
owners of a
unit-titled
property. There is
no opting out. The
main player is the
body corporate
secretary, usually a
professional... The
body corporate:
Comprises all owners
of a unit-titled
property...

Body corporate
chairman Joe Dowrick
said residents found
out about the
development only a
few days before its
launch.

Author: STEVENS
Quote:
There are several
species of lice
found on sheep, but
those which occur in
New Zealand are: 1)
the red louse or
body louse, or wool
louse (Damalinia
ovis) .. The wool or
body louse is widely
distributed and more
difficult to deal
with.

Dry humour runs
thick through this
collection; for
example .. -
body-snatcher - a
stock buyer.

Person who selects
stock for sale - a
body snatcher.

We have heard a good
deal about Seagulls
and Body-snatchers,
yet there are few
people who know the
origin of the phrase
or the appellation.
The words have been
coined and used by
the disgruntled
section of the
Watersiders' Union.
... Now it is
generally known that
a Body-snatcher is a
man who rushes in on
another man's job
when the going is
good and slips back
to his own work when
things get slack.

Author: MOORE
Quote:
I wanted a `Boeing
seat' (an electorate
with an airport
serviced by Boeing
aircraft - a
big-city seat) and
preferably one with
radio and television
studios.

[The bush nurse] has
to use roads that
would as these
bushmen put it "bog
a duck."

Quote:
Angelica
trifoliatabog-anise
(And)
Puakarimu (Lycopodium deuterodensum) is largely confined to kauri forest, and the bog clubmoss (L. serpentinum) to a few swamps in the far north, where it is now a very rare plant.
(And) BOG CLUB-MOSS Lycopodium laterale

Gorse has always
been a problem on

stage it was found
necessary to bog
disc ...

Quote:

`shot': before

...

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
There are two grave
errors in tension
adjustment. One is
to start the
handpiece with too
light a tension, so
the when the first
blow goes in the
gear bogs and chews,
and small balls of
wool collect under
the cutter.
bog: If a shearer attempts to cut too much wool at once the shears get `bogged' in the wool.

Source: Avondale College Slang Words in Use
Quote: to bog: to fibreglass, to fill

Author: LELAND
Quote: bog in: BEGIN to engage enthusiastically in an ACTIVITY usually eating.

Author: COCKAYNE

(And) [an error =
swamp-lily]
bog lily [=] Maori onion [s]

Quote: Bulbinella gibbsii var. gibbsii BOG LILY ...Maori onion ... Native to: St[ewart Island] (var. balanifera occurs in N. and S.) Chrysobactron Hookeri var. angustifolium

The stream banks were covered with the brilliant yellow tapering flower stems of the bog lily Chrysobactron Hookeri.

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: The bog-moss (species of Sphagnum) is nearly always present in the former ...

The time is fast
approaching when the
entries for the
potato competition
close, and all who
are interested in
the cultivation of
the 'bog orange'
should try for the
munificent prizes
which are offered.

We observe many fine
specimens of
gooseberries,
tomatoes and that
excellent if not
melting fruit the
'bog orange' which
is at present
retailing at
twopence per pound.

Author: PUGSLEY
Quote:
The diet [on
troopship] was :
Breakfast -
porridge, coffee,
bread and butter.
Dinner - tough roast
beef and potatoes or
`bog oranges', beans
and cold tea or a
mug of soap.[sic]

Old high country
slang for .. swedes,
bog oranges.

The river was
running over
boulders, some of
them as big as a
house, and then
between walls of
rock, the banks were
being of the same
boulders, covered
with the worst scrub
I ever saw - a kind
of manuka, grass,
trees and bog pine
all twined together.

The river was
running over
boulders, some of
them as big as a
house, and then
between walls of
rock, the banks
being of the same
boulders, covered
with the worst scrub
I ever saw - a kind
of manuka, grass,
trees and bog pine
all twined together.

A few hundred feet
up the bush gave
place to a belt of
stunted bog pine,
above which sparsely
scattered tussock
tufts obtained a
grudging existence,
and then came peaks
of bare granite.

Author: DENNIS
Quote: To the west of this valley southern rata is found ... joined on the ridges by yellow silver pine and bog pine (Dacrydium bidwillii) ...

A remnant bog pine
and mountain toatoa
community of great
scientific interest
is part of the 396ha
set aside under the
Ben Dhu [Station
tenure] review. The
property is in the
Upper Waitaki Basin,
west of Omarama.

Author: WILSON
Quote: Bog pine (Dacrydium bidwillii) has been reported many times on Stewart Island, but plants so called appear to be only forms of pink pine ...

Woody scrub,
including bog pine
and mountain toatoa,
grows around the
edge of the
clearing.

Author: KIRK
Quote: Dacrydium Bidwillii bog pine Dacrydium Colensoi bog pine
Dacrydium Colensoi bog pine
... the track leads on to low peaty land ... which has recently been covered by a young forest of bog-pine (Dacrydium Bidwillii).

Author: DAWSON
Quote: ...a group of conifers formerly included in Dacrydium; silver pine (Lagarostrobos colensoi), yellow silver pine (Lepidothamnus intermedius), bog pine (Halocarpus bidwilli), H.biformis and manoao (H. kirkii).
bog-rush [s] Schoenus pauciflorus Hook. Schoenus pauciflorus

shearer's handpiece
- bog-iron, boggi or
boggle-eye.

Author: HAAST
Quote:
On the highest point
between the Maruia
and Grey [rivers]
lies the most
extensive tract of
this swamp ground.
Five miles from this
bog-saddle ...

Author: JOURNET
Quote:
Your horse always
turns out to be
tender-hoofed on dry
days and a
bog-wallower on wet
ones.

This writer, who has
spent her entire
adult life breathing
the rational,
liberal Wellington
air, and has
traditionally
sneered at law and
order hardliners,
caught herself
uttering the phrase
"bogan scum" when
her aged car turned
up stripped and
smashed on the banks
of the Hutt River.

Although Dunedin is
perceived as the
label's [sc. Flying
Nun] spiritual home,
the whole shebang
started as a cottage
industry in the
bogan-infested
flatlands of
Christchurch.

If you believe the
hype, it would seem
we will never escape
the pioneering,
bogan spirit that
has seen generations
of Kiwis get
hammered, fondle the
chicks, puke on the
lawn, and then drive
home.

Don't be misled,
mate, by the bogan
image [The Mad
Butcher] puts on
during his frequent
appearances on the
radio.

The prize was the
best bogan party the
world has ever seen
- a pool table, a
spa pool, a hulking
great stereo, all
the beer and
sausages and lamb
chops you and your
friends could gobble
and the Radio
Hauraki band, live
at your place on a
Saturday night,
playing all the
AC/DC you could
handle.

Larkin thought he
had died and gone to
bogan heaven.

The bar gets its
fair share of Goths
who drink cider
(it's cheap) and
bogan chicks who
stay ever faithful
to bourbon and Coke.

...the momentary
appeal of bogan
retro is part of the
film's spirit...

West Auckland is the
legendary "bogan
country".

Three weeks ago they
wrote his retirement
tributes. Today
Bogan Fella is back
on track for another
tilt at the New
Zealand Cup.

"I certainly
wouldn't call anyone
bogan to their face.
If I did, I'd
probably get knocked
out especially if it
was in Upper Hutt on
a dark night."

Fellow bogans of
Upper Hutt, let us
arise, especially we
fat and sloppily
dressed ones.

Petrol heads,
bogans, and gruffs -
these names mean one
thing to west
Auckland comedian
Ewen Gilmour :
"westies". Gilmour
believes westies
live all over the
country. No matter
where they live they
share a love of
tight black jeans,
the smell of burning
rubber and the feel
of a leather jacket.
Being a westie is
about lifestyle, not
location.

A stereotypical
bogan or "westie" is
a male clad in black
jeans and black
T-shirt embellished
with the name of a
heavy metal band.
Females of this
genus are normally
found wearing
ill-fitting jeans
and lace blouses or
velvet dresses and
an optional speckled
leather jacket. The
bogan car of choice
is Holden and the
more grunt the
better. Fluffy dice
are mandatory and
not optional. The
bogan drink of
choice is Lion Red
and preferably from
a crate. Bogan
pastimes usually
involve their car
and ranged from drag
racing down
residential streets
to peel-out sessions
in vacant lots.

Most of us make
random forays into
the world of bijoux,
be it something
functional from
Pascoes, an
anonymous antique,
or a bogan's delight
from a fleamarket.

Rugby bogans? I
thought bogans hated
sport and loved
black home-knit
jerseys and Escorts.

Sometimes a boy and
girl who can only
describe each other
as "sort of all
right", " a real
dog". "stink" or "a
bogan" are obliged
to go further than
they want just to
keep up with the
group.

No one will ever
know just how many
bogans - "Wellington
westies" - lie on
the ocean floor
stretching out
beyond Paraparaumu
beach (having failed
in their intoxicated
attempts to swim out
to Kapiti wearing
upward of two pairs
of black jeans).

So what exactly is a
Westie? "I think you
call us Bogans down
in Wellington.

At a time that was
already stressed
enough, my
grandmother became
the target of a
mindless, violent
act of some boguns.

Reformed Otorohanga
bogan Rohan Max, now
of Hamilton, says "a
bogan is working
class, talks about
loud music, fights,
dogs, women they've
never met, drinking
and cars."

Certainly he felt
like a bogan in a
china store at the
flash Auckland do
where they announced
the three finalists
last month.

Dumb guitar rock
made a surprise
return in 2002, and
the Datsuns were in
the right place at
precisely the right
time, with the kind
of music that bogans
in the New Zealand
backblocks have been
banging their heads
to for decades.

It did stage too
many bodgey and
bogan gigs.

BOGAN An unhip
fellow from an
unfashionable
suburb. Derived,
some claim, from
"Bougainville", in a
back-of-beyond
sense.

Bogans as fashion
icons? It sounds
unlikely, but Massey
University design
student Genevieve
Packer's
bogan-inspired
fashion collection
is ultra-cool...
"Bogans are one of
New Zealand's last
bastions of
anti-cool - I wanted
to take that and
re-interpret it in a
fashion context as
cool... I think
bogans are something
we all identify with
- they are part of
our national
identity and we
should appreciate
them."... Packer's
fringed leather
cuffs anbd collars
are inspired by
bogan chicks'
tasselled boots. Her
line of T-shirts
feature popular
bogan names like
Shazza, Mussa, Gazza
and Bazza as well as
bogan vehicles like
Holdens, Cortinas
and Toranas.

It is unacceptable
for a bogan in
boatshoes to abuse
and insult staff..
if said bogan is
unable to keep track
of its personal
possessions.
"Westie" comedian Ewen Gilmour, whose show, Full Leather Jacket was part of the Laugh Festival, also embrace his boganhood.

Usually I'd consider
a rugby league
jersey to be a sure
sign of, well,
boganism.

"Bogans are part of
our cultural
identity - a lot of
people will deny it,
but so many things
are attributed to
boganism," Packer
says.

Bogans are my
favourite people. I
return to my
essential boganism
from time to time. I
get in the car and
rev it up and down
the road a bit. Then
- not at the same
time, of course, I
swig a few beers in
quick succession and
take myself back to
a simpler life.

And while they've
thrown off the
shackles of boganity
(notably the three
feet of hair that
once encircled his
head and torso)
there's still a bit
of the Metallica
about Shihad.

Is it possible to
transform
Bogansville into
Babeville, or are
its residents
destined to spend
the rest of their
lives being reviled
by right-thinking
folk for wearing
skull T-shirts,
absurd hair styles
and jeans with ankle
zips?

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
BOGGI (pronounced
bog-eye) A shearer's
handpiece. This term
originated in
Australia, the early
models being shaped
like the Boggi
lizard. To me it
also suggests
another meaning,
i.e. to keep the
handpiece bogged up
cutting wool.

Author: McARA
Quote:
The routine of
shovelling, or
bogging as it was
called, followed by
drilling and
blasting, was
continued until
under normal
conditions the shaft
had been sunk about
fifty feet below the
timbers, ...

At the bins, the
tubs having been
emptied into
enormous containers,
the coal is screened
(sifted) ... and
loaded into hoppers
... [which] are
fitted into a
four-wheeled frame
called a bogie.

BOGEY: A framework
consisting of a
carriage and 4
wheels used for
carrying logs on
bush tramways

Source: Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The
Author: MAHONEY
Quote:
A new type of lokey
appeared that was
distinctive to
trams: the bogie
lokey. This
specialist type was
first developed in
the United States
timber industry. A
boiler and engine
were mounted on a
chassis riding on
two or more bogies.
All bogie wheels
were driven by
driveshafts and
gears.

Author: FARRELL
Quote:
Mary Agnes's older
brother Leo played
the jovial Irishman,
yarning and cracking
with the men in the
bar, while in
private despising
them for the
bogtrotters they
were, the feckless
idle Paddies of the
jokes and the skits,
content to root a
bare living from the
sour coastal pakihi,
exactly as they
might have done at
home.

Author: HODDER
Quote:
`Bohea struggles',
or tea parties are
common [in Nelson].

Crossed the Whytangi
in two streams, they
meet 200 yards below
in a boil where we
nearly lost one dod
[sic, dog].

Source: Five Years' Residence in New Zealand
Author: FULLER
Quote:
.. it may be
required to boil
down other than very
old sheep for tallow
...

.. they [graziers]
would elect to boil
down their stock
which are now fat
rather than to keep
them till March or
April.

The parts retained
will boil down to an
average 15 lb to 20
lb of tallow.

Old done ewes will,
I think, be almost
unsaleable ... the
sooner they are
boiled down the
better.

Author: CONNELL & HADFIELD
Quote:
The only way surplus
sheep could be
properly disposed of
was to boil them
down for tallow.

Author: LAMBERT
Quote:
Then came the
outbreak of scab,
and thousands of
sheep had to be
slaughtered to boil
down for tallow.

Author: McCASKILL
Quote:
The first sheep
shorn at Tarndale
were from the
straggle muster of
the autumn of 1881
and their wool was
taken ... for
shipment from
Lyttelton. Five
thousand sheep were
boiled down soon
after, ...

... as yet the
sheep-owners have
not been driven to
`boil down' but
expect to do so as
their stock
increases, ...
Notes: (1850) 1971 Speeches and Documents 27 quoting July 8 Godley letter

Author: RIVES
Quote:
I loafed about the
station and had a
look at the 12,000
wethers they had got
in from which they
were to draught
7,000 to boil down.
After lunch I walked
down with W. to look
at the boiling down
house. ... The
boiling down house
is about two miles
from the homestead
to avoid the stench.
It is built of
galvanised iron.

If a squatter ...
should proceed to
boil down the whole
flock ... he would
be denounced as a
lunatic ...

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
Practically all the
stock [sc sheep] on
the runs in New
Zealand is fat; and,
as there is an
over-supply for
consumption,
squatters are forced
to turn their fat
stock [96] into
money by boiling
them down for their
tallow. There is a
boiling-down works
at Featherston, ...
where thousands of
these large fat
sheep ... are boiled
down.

Author: GILKISON
Quote:
But the best part of
the tramp on the
home hills is the
mid-day `boil.' ...
True, on other
expeditions we boil
the billy ...

Author: STRONACH
Quote: We halted at the Saxon for a `boil'. Each filled his small mustering billy and held it over the fire on the end of the mustering stick, ... Ibid 26 We had a boil and then started the ascent.
boil ... 2. ... NZ & Austral. colloq. (also boil-up) ct of making tea. 3. ... boil the billy, boil up NZ & Austral. colloq. make tea.

Author: CAPT JOY
Quote:
.. began to boil at
7 our boats returned
[445] June 5 cut in
our whale and began
to boil this is a
Monstrous whale 10
feet bone
Notes: 1836 May 31 Capt. Joy Mary Mitchell log in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 444

Quote:
`She boild! Mugs up.
Here's the cow;
who's got some
grit.'

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
By the time we
arrived at Anna it
was well past
mid-day, and Des and
I decided that we
would stop for a
boil and give the
horses half an
hour's spell.

Author: STRONACH
Quote:
We had a boil and
then started the
ascent.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
.. we left our
horses grazing in
the creek and called
in for a 'boil.'

Author: RHODES
Quote: ... began to boil out. Ibid 20 Two strange sail in sight boiling out. Ibid 22 At 10 began to boil out. Ibid 23 Employed clearing the decks and boiling out

Author: SIMPSON
Quote:
No break for a
smoke, no boil the
billy, only your
cold tea to drink at
mid-day.

Author: WRIGHT
Quote:
We ... boiled the
billy and feasted on
damper and tea,/

Source: Life on a Five Pound Note
Author: HOSKEN
Quote:
One day, a resident
of the Mackenzie
Country, when
travelling in a dray
on the Braemar Road,
overtook a young
swagger. `Throw your
swag up, and get
in,' he remarked,
`and we'll boil the
billy soon.' But
this young
Englishman, a
stranger to New
Zealand and its
ways, not knowing
what `boiling the
billy' meant and
mistrustful of his
friend's rather wild
and unshaven
appearance, refused
the kind offer and
decided to push on.

Author: HEBERLEY
Quote:
[We] boiled the
Billy and made some
Tea out of tawa
bark.

Author: GOLDIE
Quote:
No wood - not as
much as would boil
the billy.
Notes: 1861 Dec 22 John Goldie's Diary in 1947 Beattie Pioneers Explore Otago 87

Author: CAIRD
Quote:
... boiling the
`Billy.'

boil ... 2. ... NZ &
Austral. colloq.
(also boil-up) act
of making tea. 3.
... boil the billy,
boil up NZ &
Austral. colloq.
make tea.

Author: MOFFAT
Quote:
... I went up the
left-hand branch,
boiled the billy,
...

Author: MANSFIELD
Quote:
We stop - boil the
billy and have tea
and herings - [?sic]

Source: Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ
Author: HARPER
Quote:
With the usual
colonial freedom, we
boiled the billy and
had a meal in one of
the huts before
shouldering our
loads.

At 2,200 ft the
billy is boiled.

We boiled the billy,
and after a
sumptuous lunch set
out for the
waterfall.

Author: KOEBEL
Quote:
`Boiling the billy'
... when you boil
the `billy', you
make tea, voila
[a-grave] tout.

Author: SCANLAN
Quote:
... they boiled the
billy for supper,
which they had on
the banks of the
stream, ...

... stop to boil the
billy.

Author: MULGAN
Quote:
They had ridden
together ..., and
she had taken him to
a picnic ... in a
favourite little
river-bed, where
they boiled a billy
near a rare clump of
trees ...

Author: AYSON
Quote:
His first task each
morning was to boil
the billy and
prepare breakfast.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
The next halt was at
Waipatiki stream,
where the horses
were unloaded again
and allowed to fend

packman boiled the
billy and had lunch.

Author: DEMPSEY
Quote:
... we lingered
there and boiled the
billy for our tea.

Author: TOMLINSON
Quote:
The only thing I had
forgotten [in my
musterer's
equipment] was a
walking stick, which
was used for
crossing creeks and
also for boiling the
billy.

Author: NEAVE
Quote:
At the top [of the
path at Wanaka], the
billy was boiled for
the tea break, and
... somebody tapped
the billy to induce
the tea leaves to
sink.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
I was the `new chum'
so it was my job to
boil the billy [for
the bush gang]

Author: TUI FLOWERS
Quote: On back-country trips, it's customary to boil the billy (heat water in a small can over a campfire for tea).
Notes: 1986 a U.S. food-writer's written remarks: p.c.Tui Flower NZ Woman's Weekly (14 Jan 1987)

Author: SHERRIN
Quote:
We boiled the billy
...

`She boild! Mugs up.
Here's the cow;
who's got some
grit.'

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
`Not as much
firewood left as
would boil the
billy,' Maurice said
afterwards, with
much exaggeration.
boil the billy, stop for a meal;

Source: Life in the Hinterland of the South Island
Author: BRUCE
Quote:
A little after
mid-day they arrived
at a stream where
the silent man threw
down his swag and
boiled his billy.

Source: History of the Early Gold Discoveries  in Otago
Author: PYKE
Quote:
This boundary was
always debatable
ground - it was
always imperatively
necessary that
claims should be
`pegged out', and
this rule was of
necessity `more
honoured in the
breach than in the
observance.' Pegs
were not to be had,
unless imported, and
when introduced
stood a great chance
of helping to boil
the neighbour's
`billy'.'

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
It was midday when
he roused himself,
opened his
tucker-bag, and made
a fair meal of what
he found there. He
did not boil his
billy, ... but
contented himself
with a drink from a
small stream that
ran in a gully near
by.

Author: SIMPSON
Quote:
Before the real
Australian guides
you out of the bush,
he will probably
halt at some place
where there is water
and say, `How about
boiling the billy?'
In saying that he is
not asking you for a
cigarette, a pipe of
tobacco, a chew of
gum. ... He is
simply extending to
you the original and
(I hope) the
everlasting
hospitality of all
Australia; he is
suggesting that he
make a brew of tea.

Author: CAIRD
Quote:
.. I rose from my
incumbent position,
and began to assist
in the preparations
for lighting the
fire, and boiling
the 'Billy.'

It was a most
uncomfortable
situation - not a
stick to boil the
billy and nothing
but big snow
tussocks for the
horses to eat.

Author: KOEBEL
Quote:
When you boil the
billy, you make tea.

Author: DREAVER
Quote:
My favourite
memories were of how
pleasant it was to
boil the billy in a
sheltered gully at
the top tailing pens
at Shingly Creek,
and after a day's
tailing to sit back
and relax for a
while.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
In some back-country
districts in
Canterbury, it is
the practice for
musterers .. to boil
up .. when
cirumstances
permitted during
their beat.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
.. if ever I saw the
practice of boiling
up on the hill
carried to the
extreme, it was that
day.

Author: MILLS
Quote:
Apparently satisfied
that here at least
was one motorist who
knew how to go
through stock he
disappeared from
view again. Coming
to the end of the
mob, the reason
became obvious. He
was "boiling up"
over the bank.

Author: JANES & ROWE
Quote:
When we reached a
point overlooking
the basin where the
Trent plunges into
the bush we boiled
up and ate our lunch
...

Author: CURTIS
Quote:
We were lucky enough
to find a dry
overhang under which
we could shelter and
boil-up.

Author: CURTIS
Quote:
.. we did not linger
there, but hurried
away to find a
sheltered spot where
we could boil up.

Author: WATERSON
Quote:
It must be about kai
time. We'd better
boil up. [boil-up]

They cooed out, and
while he skinned the
spiker they found a
possie in a bit of a
trog and boiled up.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote:
VI Shooters halt for
a 'boil-up' after
travelling several
hours up a creek
bed.

Author: SHARPE
Quote:
Our first comments
about a miserable
old sod, who would
knock off for a
boil-up while the
hired help ...

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
While the shepherds
had a boil-up, the
sheep would string
well up the face and
were ready for the
final lift up to the
top, and through the
rimrock to the easy
country above the
station buildings.

Author: WATERS
Quote:
I can still see that

with the necessary

boil-up and a bite

Author: CURTIS
Quote:
About mid-morning we
had our first
boil-up and, as
