an idyllic spot.

Author: HINDMARSH
Quote:
A good rest at the
water and several
boil-ups and they
were as ready again
as they would ever
be.

...the days of a
boil up on the marae
are being reinvented
by keen chefs and
entrepreneurs.

Meal. It would
definitely be a
boil-up. You take a
big hunk of meat,
some spuds and a
couple of other
veges, throw them in
a pot and you're
away.

When Karen, who
cooked for 13 people
a day on $150 a
week, served Rick a
boil-up in the first
episode, I'm sure
middle (course) New
Zealand sniffed.

Author: BAKER
Quote:
Sean could smell
roast meat,
watercress and puha
boil-ups, smoked
fish...

There is also an
"eye of the cat"
(karupoti) and an
"egg of the seagull"
(huakaroro), a hard
yellow waxy variety
which is a favourite
for boil-ups of meat
and vegetables.

Neophytes will
receive an authentic
introduction to pork
bones and puha (only
the correct term is
kai tutura or
"boil-up", bros) and
who knows, they
might even venture
to order their first
kina.

He was so calm and
more concerned about
the fish boil-up he
missed on the way
back from being out
fishing after my
emergency call.

The idea was that
he'd be a role model
for Maori, showing
them the good
effects of being a
"good old Maori boy
who likes a boil
up".

Surviving on their
father's labourer's
wage, the staple
dish was "boil-up" -
meat and vegetables
boiled together in
one cauldron-sized
pot.

He's cut down the
"boil-ups" to once a
week. "But I eat
more Weet-Bix, for
example, for
breakfast."

The idea of eating
anything else green
took some getting
used to, as did
giving up a lifetime
of greasy food,
which started with
boil-ups, brisket
and mutton.

On patrols, he [the
NZ Mounted Rifleman]
is characterised by
a fine capacity for
busines [sic] and a
passion for
innumerable
`boil-ups' for the
ever welcome mug of
tea that helps so
much to relieve the
tedium of dull,
weary hours.

We had a welcome
boil up.

Author: ROBERTSON
Quote:
No opportunity was
lost of having a
`boil up.'

Author: ORBELL
Quote:
At the midday stop,
some people always
insist on a boilup.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote: [caption] Shooters halt for a `boil-up' after travelling several hours up a creek bed ... Ibid. 125 ... having had our proverbial `boil-up' ...
The billy brings to our mind the inevitable boil-up, the boiling of the billy for a cup of tea. No one seems to have collected this expression. It may be pure New Zealand.

Midday boil-up was
at the end of the
first long flat,
after which our
route lay over river
boulders to a small
flat ...

Author: McGILL
Quote: boil-up tea-break, mostly among thirsty trampers boiling the billy.

Author: JOHNSTON
Quote:
... first `boil up',
Rangitoto, 18th
October, 1925.

So long as there are
babies ..., there is
washing to be done
daily, ... Once a
week or once a
fortnight there's a
copper boil-up.

Finally, he was as
boiled as an owl.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: boiled dog. `Side'; New Zealanders': from ca. 1910. Perhaps on boiled shirt. [Supp. Also Australians' ca. 1918: put on dog.]

Author: BAKER
Quote: Other twentieth century New Zealand expressions ... include ...boiled dog, `side' or affectation.

Then come the bloody
boiled lollies.

Author: HOLCROFT
Quote:
As a schoolboy I had
to go off early to
bed ... Early
evening ... I was
given one boiled
lolly - a blackball
- from an old,
curiously ornamented
tin ...

Author: GIBBONS
Quote:
Pencil cases,
pencils, boiled
lollies and small
bars of chocolate
were the normal sort
of birthday gifts.

It reminds me of an
evening around the
brazier: dried
hedge-wood, tobacco
and medicinal herbs
predominate, then
comes a sweet
vanilla layer
combined with cassis
like yummy boiled
lollies, with a
final whiff of lamb
chops.

Author: DUFF
Quote:
A neighbour whose
bull I had arranged
to hire told me a
few days ago that
`the old fool had
knocked himself out'
and was now
`finished - a
boiler'.

At the Rangiora
sheep market
recently for the
first time for many
years, 'boilers'
were sold, the
prices being 1/- to
3/6 each. In
addition to the fat
sheep coming
forward, a few large
lines of boilers are
waiting their turn.

Although large lines
have been booked for
boiling-down
purposes, boilers
have not yet been
handled in any
quantity as yet.

There was to be no
solo tries this time
but he went about
his work in the
boiler room
efficiently.

Author: DUGGAN
Quote:
[Riley's Handbook]
... the afternoons
my own [in the pub]
until five ... when
the railwaymen come
in for their
boilermakers, whisky
and a beer chaser.

The fine grassy land
bordered on the
overstocked district
of Sydney - the
`boiling-down'
system was then
unknown - the soil
overstocked, Pat
Philip undiscovered.
Notes: 1852 Saunders' Monthly Magazine Vol I in 1976 Canterbury Colony 10

Quote:
It is said there are
thousands of fat
wethers ... ready
for the pot, and as
no market can be
found for them a
`boiling down'
company has been
established.
Notes: 1867 Timaru Herald in 1938 Burdon High Country 112

Author: CRAWFORD
Quote:
The Boiling Down
works ... provides a
great service to the
runs in freeing them
of their surplus
stock,...

Author: JACKSON
Quote:
I believe [the kea]
acquired his liking
for fat in the old
`boiling down' days.

Author: SEWELL
Quote:
After which time,
assuming favourable
circumstances, ...
and surplus stock
worth something
above boiling down
rate, they will give
a large return for
the capital laid
out;

Author: HURSTHOUSE
Quote: `Boiling-down' was formerly practised to a considerable extent in Australia; the mere fat or tallow of the animal for export to England being worth far more than the meat for colonial consumption. `Boiling-down establishments' were formed in the pastoral districts, and the process became a regular business. The sheep or cattle were killed and skinned, the carcass thrown into the boiling vat, the fat skimmed off for export tallow, and the meat thrown away. `Boiling down' will probably remain a permanent feature of Australian grazing in the districts remote from large towns.

Author: BENMORE
Quote:
On 25 may, B.D.
started on benmore;
boiling down, like
other unpleasant
things, was usually
known by its
initials.
Notes: >[1870 May 25 Benmore diary] in 1981 Pinney Early Northern Otago Runs 24

Author: BURDON
Quote:
Boiling down did not
begin in New Zealand
until later [than
the Australian
1850], as there was
no need for it; ...

Author: WILSON
Quote:
... some run-holders
set up boiling-downs
[specific reference
to 1880 slump]
boiling down n. process of rendering tallow from sheep's carcases.

I brought in a lot
of boiling downs.

Boiling-down appears
likely to become an
important industry
in the province of
Wellington.

.. low-priced meat
and boiling down are
synonymous terms.

Author: KAY
Quote:
One farming practice
long gone is
remembered by the
name, Boiling Down
paddock. The
boiling-down of
mutton carcasses for
tallow was the end
use of sheep until

[boiling-down]

Author: GUTHRIE
Quote:
The lapping of the
sea mingled with the
bell notes of the
moko moko and tui
and ... that of the
burning bush wood in
the boiling of the
`billy'.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
So that `Mother'
would know he was
nearing home,
Chaffey habitually
hung a piece of
white calico on a
tree stump, a
boiling-the-billy
distance away from
the whare, ...

Author: RIVES
Quote:
I loafed about the
station and had a
look at the 12,000
wethers they had got
in from which they
were to draught
7,000 to boil down.
After lunch I walked
down with W. to look
at the boiling down
house. ... The
boiling down house
is about two miles
from the homestead
to avoid the stench.
It is built of
galvanised iron.

Author: D'AVIGDOR
Quote:
... the latter [sc.
offal] are taken to
the boiling-down
house, on the
opposite side of the
road, where tallow
is made, ...

Author: THORNTON
Quote:
In the huge
Molesworth block at
the head of the

was a small
boiling-down plant
erected at the
Tarndale run in
1880...

Author: KAY
Quote:
The boiling-down
plant was on the
neighbouring
Huangarua land.
[boiling-down works]

Author: McCASKILL
Quote:
There [at Tarndale
station] he built a
shearing shed for
fifteen men, fenced
a holding paddock of
2,000 acres and
ordered a
boiling-down plant
from Andersons in
Christchurch.

Author: MARSHMAN
Quote:
The ultimate value
when the
boiling-down point
has been reached,
will be ... the
worth of the wool
and tallow.

Source: Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand
Author: WELD
Quote: in prudence a man should not calculate on a higher than the minimum, or boiling-down price of about 5 s. a-head [sic] for male (wedder) [sic] stock; ...

Source: Five Years' Residence in New Zealand
Author: FULLER
Quote:
... a boiling-down
price for wethers
would be reached in
a few years.

Source: Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand
Author: WELD
Quote:
I think that in
prudence a man
should not calculate
on higher than the
minimum, or
boiling-down price
of about 5s a head
...

Store pigs were
hardly saleable
which is easily
accounted for by the
almost entire
stoppage of the
boiling down
establishments in
this district -
sheep ruling much
above boiling-down
rates.

.. every spring it
[spring mutton]
appears scarce and
dearer than the
previous one, from
15s to 17s per head
being a substantial
difference to the
boiling-down price
of a few years ago.

Old ewes that had
fallen in condition
were parted with at
less than
boiling-down rates.
[boiling-down rate]

We ate our campoven
bread and fat chops,
and dream 'd of
great flocks to be
drafted off every
year to boiling-down
works.

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
Practically all the
stock [sc sheep] on
the runs in New
Zealand is fat; and,
as there is an
over-supply for
consumption,
squatters are forced
to turn their fat
stock [96] into
money by boiling
them down for their
tallow. There is a
boiling-down works
at Featherston, ...
where thousands of
these large fat
sheep ... are boiled
down.

Drive with W.Beetham
to his boiling down
works and meat
preserving factory
[at Masterton]

Author: AYSON
Quote:
Boiling down works
had also been
started at Green
Island. Merinos were
boiled down for
their fat and pelts
: and as the hind
legs of merinos
contained no fat
they were given
away. Jock Graham
did a roaring trade
in Dunedin by
purchasing carrots
in the Taieri and
tying three of them
to a hind leg of a
sheep. This was
known as a fiddle
and he would hawk
them through the
streets and dispose
of them for
sixpence.

Author: BURDON
Quote:
Two years later [sc.
1869] boiling down
works were started
at Washdyke in South
Canterbury.

Author: WILSON
Quote:
... I do not want to
leave station life
without mentioning
one feature that was
beginning to appear
on most stations in
the 'seventies.
These were the
boiling-down works.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
Mr. Nairn had a
boiling down works
and large wool dump
and storage shed at
Pourere, and wool
and tallow used to
be shipped direct
from Pourere.
[1880's]

In the succeeding
two years the
ex-coke-shoveller,
boundary-rider,
stockman,
boiling-down works
labourer, shearer,
rouseabout, ...
examined a mining
boom ...

Another [photograph]
shows the
boiling-down works,
another the Richmond
stockyards.

Author: PARK
Quote:
Day after day we saw
mobs of dusty sheep
cramming the road,
kept in order by
busybody little
dogs. They were en
route to the
boiling-down works.

Author: WILSON & FRASER
Quote:
.. after the
boiling-down works
opened at Woodlands,
large drafts were
sent there every
year.

Source: Big Country of the North Island
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
In 1887 the station
established its own
boiling-down works.

Author: THORNTON
Quote:
.. excess sheep had
been a real problem
as they either had
to be disposed of in
boiling-down works
or simply destroyed.

The students caused
a boil-over in
Wairarapa senior
club limited over
cricket on Saturday
defeating previously
unbeaten Landsdowne.

Oliver.. had no
hesitation in
describing the
boilover the
gutsiest win he had
had in the blue and
gold jersey.

Bok Choy:... Karanda
says the leafy
vegetable which
tastes a little like
cauliflower, is used
a lot in everyday
meals in China and
has found a
widespread
popularity among
Europeans.

Statistically, I'm
not going to find a
bok choy nibbling,
shiraz drinking,
male model with a
penchant for picking
up my dry-cleaning
and spontaneous
Pacific Island
holidays who wants
to hang out for no
more than 24 hours
at a time.

Bok Choi, which is
similar to silver
beet, is grown from
flowering stems as
well as its leaves.

Bok choy and other
Asian brassicas are
also in peak
condition at this
time of the year.
Large bok choy can
be rather chewy...

While thinking of
greatness in C Coy.,
one will never
forget C.S.M.
Flackton, more
frequently referred
to as the "Bokaka."
Notwithstanding the
elasticity and
length of his
shapeless limbs, try
as he may, he will
never succeed in
getting Billy
Whitlock's mantle to
fit him.

Author: DEWAR
Quote:
At the season when
bokakas dropped
their berries the
wild pigs made a
migration from tree
to tree, and a

stonies, stripies,
tom-bobblers, white
alleys, and in more

An effective
treatment that uses
no herbicide has
been found to
control the coastal
pest plant boneseed,
says the Wellington
Regional Council.
Boneseed is
flowering now, the
best time for
control... Boneseed
is widely
established
throughout the
coastal areas of the
Wellington region,
especially
Wellington's south
coast, Eastbourne,
Pukerua Bay and
Raumati... Boneseed
produces clusters of
small, yellow daisy
flowers that cover
the plant in late
winter to early
summer. The
single-seed is very
hard and bone-like
in colour and
texture when ripe
(thus the name
boneseed. Boneseed
is a bushy shrub
which grows to 2-3
metres high
producing up to
50,000 seeds per
plant. From South
Africa, it was
introduced to New
Zealand as an
ornamental plant and
is now found
throughout the North
Island, mostly in
coastal situations,
and in the South
Island.

The sunburst of
bone-seed at the

the open faces of
Mexican daisies in
the Northland
tunnel, the blush of
lilac oxalis on
Onslow Rd.

Weeds included [in

species many people
grew unwittingly,
such as Japanese
honeysuckle, banana
passionfruit,
climbing asparagus,
boneseed, old man's
beard, pampas grass
and German ivy.

South Brighton is
hosting its first

dedicated to
eradicating the
plant pest
boneseed... Boneseed
is an evergreen
shrub up to 3 m
high,m with bright
yellow daisy-like
flowers and long
dull-green toothed
leaves.

Author: CROWE
Quote:
A native of the

introduced to New

However, birds soon
spread the seed, and
by 1870 boneseed was
noticed escaping
into the wild.
bone-seed [s] Osteospermum moniliferum L.

Author: LELAND
Quote: bong: A term borrowed from Australia where it is used to refer to aborigines; in New Zealand, it is a derogatory reference to Maoris and occasionally Pacific Islanders. This is a fighting word; use it only if your neck is red and you enjoy a punch up.

They "bonged" on
Sunday mornings to
get out of going to
church, said one
religious man.

He writes about five

taking with them a

a curious collection
of plastic tubing
and large funnels;
the equipment needed
for alcohol bonging:
... The bong
comprises a plastic
funnel joined at the
base by a long
plastic tube, it can
be large or small.
It can hold from one
to four bottles of
beer. One person
holds the
contraption high in
the air while the
intended recipient
puts the end of the
tube in his mouth
and allows the beer
to rush in a torrent
into his stomach.
... Four bottles is

digestive system to
the limit and is
almost impossible to
keep down and so
usually leads to
what is called a
`power chunder' or
projectile vomiting.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Marbles had a
language of its own.
There were names for
the marbles, the
games, and all the
various aspects of
the play. There were
terms for marbles
such as `taw' or
`shooter', referring
to the marbles used
to fire with;
`dubs', `dates',
`stakes', `dukes',
or `changers',
referring to the
marbles put down to
be fired at. Then
there were the terms
referring to
particular kinds of
marbles: for
example, agates,
aggies, aggotties,
American alleys,
blood alleys,
bomb-squashers,
bonies, bonsers,
bottlies, bull's
eyes, bum-squashers,
cat's eyes,
chinkies, connies,
duckies, eggies,
glassies, Greeks,
milkies, molly-bars,
mulley-bars
[mullibars: large
marbles], peelies,
peewees, piss-wees,
pretties, Scotties,
Scottish alleys,
smokies, stinkies,
stonies, stripies,
tom-bobblers, white
alleys, and in more
recent years
ball-bearings,
chippies, plastics,
and woodies.

Author: KEITH & MAIN
Quote:
Marbles were the
currency of
childhood and there
were an astonishing
number of names for
them, some referring
to the material or
colour, others to
value or function in
the game. There were
agates, aggies,
American alleys,
blood alleys,
bomb-squashers,
bonies, bonsers,
bottlies, bull's
eyes, bum-squashers,
cats-eye, [sic]
chinkies, connies,
duckies, eggies,
glassies, Greeks,
milkies, mollies,
peelies, peewees,
pisswees, pretties,
Scotties, smokies,
stinkies, stonies,
stripies,
tom-bobblers and
whities. The march
of technology added
ball bearings -
ballies or steelies
- which were
unbeatable when it
came to smashing an
opponent's miserable
glassie. World War
II[roman] brought
`clayeys' often
imperfectly
spherical they were
pathetic terracotta
substitutes for real
marbles.

Company Directors
were.. a former
Railcorp
executive;.. and
Jamie McGregor,
previously a boning
foreman at Whakatu.

At Longburn the
boning.room is idle
because 12 boners
have been dismissed.

Meat is processed in
a boning or cutting
room, after it comes
(whole or in
quarters) from the
cooling floor or
from the chiller.

Across in the boning
room, the sides of
beef are put through
a band saw, and the
pieces travel down a
conveyer belt to the
boners, working at
tables in pairs.
Theirs is heavy work
as they cut the meat
from the shoulder
blade, ribs and
thigh bone and slice
it into the
different cuts.

Author: SORENSON

Author: SPEIGHT
Quote: The only true mackerels recorded from Canterbury are the Pacific Bonito (Sarda chiliensis ) and the large-scaled Tunny (Gasterochisma melampus ) which may reach a length of 6 feet; but a related family includes the well-known Barracouta (Thyrsites atun ), the King Barracouta, Jordanidia solandrii (often known locally as Kingfish, but not to be confused with the North Island Kingfish which is a form or Yellowtail) and the elongated, silvery-hued frost fish (Lepidopus caudatus ) whose curious stranding habits can hardly yet be said to be satisfactorily explained.
Notes: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 199

Quote: [species name] stargazer .. [scientific name] Kathetostoma giganteum .. [other name(s)] monkfish, boofs, bulldogs, churchills, flathead monk, giant stargazer, monks, muddies, spotted stargazer, toebiters, whitefish, sandcod

Author: PAUL
Quote: Monkfish Kathetotoma giganteum ... Also occurs in southern Australia. Known by a number of local names: giant stargazer, flathead, bulldog, boof, etc. The name monkfish is well established for this species in New Zealand, whereas overseas it is used for similarly shaped but unrelated anglerfishes.

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote: Some slang terms seems to be peculiar to certain districts. An example is the Auckland term up the Puhoi or Boohoy (its form varies a good deal) meaning `gone somewhere or other' and this is a genuine local product referring to an old German settlement on the coast north of Auckland and little, if at all, in use elsewhere in New Zealand. Ibid. 2/680 Examples of slang and colloquial expressions of local origin are ... up the boohai (and other forms) for `off in some unknown locality', an Aucklander's idiom. [Wall does not seem to completely relate these two statements]

remaining particles

blubber.

Author: BATTYE & EATKIN
Quote: Bord the mine was divided into several working areas, called Bords.

The system of work
[in the Grey
coalfield] is mainly
by bord and pillar,
a small portion only
of this coal having
been worked by the
longwall method. In
the bord-and-pillar
system the bords are
18ft. wide, and
pillars 14 yards
thick. The pillars
are left intact
until the boundary
of a section is
reached, when they
are worked back. The
roof has in [418]
main proved good,
enabling a large
percentage of the
pillar-coal to be
won.

After a farmer has
decided on the area
to be bordered it
should be ploughed
and worked up. After
bordering it should
occasionally be
worked up to keep
down weeds, at the
same time
consolidating the
land to produce the
firm seed-bed so
desirable for grass
and clover seed.

There are a number
of methods [sic] of
irrigating land, of
which the following
are the principal:-
1. Border dike. 2
Border ditch. 3.
Contour. 4. Wild
flooding. 5. Furrow.
6. Basin-check.

The Border Ditch
method is used where
the fall of the land
is over 1 ft. per
chain, and can be
constructed direct
on to pasture land
without previously
working and
levelling it.

Author: RIDDOLLS
Quote:
Border-ditch
Irrigation. Where
the fall of the land
is too steep or the
surface is too
irregular for using
the border-dyke
method, or where it
is not too desired
to plough up the
pasture, ditches are
constructed over the
area to be irrigated
and the water is
caused to flood over
from the ditches.
These ditches are
called border
ditches ...

Author: RIDDOLLS
Quote:
The border-ditch
method is not as
efficient as the
border-dyke method
in its use of water.
[border ditch]

Border-dyke
irrigation is the
most economical
method, but uses
more water than
other methods and
requires large
flow-rates.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote: But the attitude of the settlers was not wholly a product of their environment. To a large extent their prejudice was imported with them. Those who had encountered few Maoris, like the Otago and Canterbury settlers, were as biassed as the rest. The Maori was called `nigger', `black', and in the Auckland Examiner, `Boshee' [subscript 44] by people who had never seen a slave. The word `Maori' conjured up in the settlers' minds a stereotype based on experience in other colonies. [fn44] Perhaps a mixture of `bosh' and `Quashee', a West Indian negro.

`Do you like going

solid hour and a
half, and Ma never
allowed to say a
word!'

Author: BAKER
Quote: Emerging originally from children's slang to bulk quite considerably in a grown-up world is the serviceable term bot. Its origin seems to be medical, since in early uses bot is rendered as a germ, doubtless from bot-fly. [52] From this comes the phrase of greeting, How are the bots biting? By the 1920s a bot is being used extensively for a troublesome person, for a persistent borrower, a financial parasite. By 1925 the noun bot was translated to a verb, and as a result we have to bot, to borrow money, to impose on others, and botting, the practice. To bot on a person is widely used. An interesting extension to the term is to be found in Australia, in which country to bite is often the equivalent for bot. On the other hand cold botting is a straight-out request for food at house-doors. ... Of fairly recent development in New Zealand is the phrase to have the bot, to be sick or out of sorts, moody or disagreeable. par

Quote: Bot. See bot-fly. 2. A germ: New Zealand medical: from ca1928. Perhaps ex the bot(-fly), which, in horses, lays eggs that are said to penetrate into the animal when they hatch. 3. been so marked in a
small pen, where
they were put on
lots of about 100.

Author: PARK

He took a green

an open-mouthed,
dismayed child ...
[177] whatcher let
him take the glassy
for? ...

Author: McGILL
Quote: bottle-oh dealer in empty bottles, c.1900s, known from his or her cry. - a green marble. Both NZA.

round to the back of

The only other queer

Street [Newtown] was

drove about with a

`Bottle-oh,
bottle-oh,' in his

bottle-oh n. NZ & Austral. sl. collector of empty bottles. [his cry]

You would have

[Advt] Sacrifice of
Modern Five-Roomed

If you don't know

Sid the bottle-o, to

Wellington.

[Hdg] Bottle-o's On
The Job Again.

Quote:
He took a green

The `Bottle-O'

and called for the

hunter of beer
shells.

Author: FANNING
Quote:
The fire brigade
horse harnessed to a

... we find our old

... he gets them
baksheesh, ...

The ... cavalry
charger yoked to a
`bottle-oh's'
decrepit vehicle,
can be galvanised at
the old sounds ...

He was dressed in a
dilapidated tweed
suit, ... and he
displayed the
manners of a bear or
a bottle-oh.

Author: HYDE
Quote: `Our Dady does drink . . . [sic] he's got lots and lots of bottles, and we sell them to the bottle-oh.'
bottle-oh n. collector of empty bottles.
bottle-oh n. collector of empty bottles.
bottle-oh n. NZ & Austral. sl. collector of empty bottles. [his cry]

Author: BRUNO
Quote:
He was bottle-oh
[that is collected
the empties at a
picture theatre]

Author: McGILL
Quote: bottle-oh dealer in empty bottles, c.1900s, known from his or her cry. - a green marble. Both NZA.

The King of
Bottle-o-ers.
Notes: 1915 Poulton in The Countess of Liverpool's Gift Book 92

Quote:
... a rank failure
at bottle-o-ing

With coffee, serve
Christmas cake and a
big bowl of
chocolate scorched

Christmas to the

Author: MATHEW
Quote:
... and largest of
all [the flowering
trees], the
`Pohutokawa' which
grows quite down to
the coast, covered
with large crimson
tufted blossoms
shaped like a
bottle-brush.]
Notes: 1873 S. Mathew Autobiography in 1940 Founding of NZ 206

Author: WHITE
Quote:
The name the
Bottle-Brush, by
which the
Callistemon, another
Australian shrub, is
commonly called,
helps to describe
both the pink and
the red.
bottle brush n. name given to a genus of shrub and trees bearing brush-like flowers; the flowers themselves.

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author: FORSTER
Quote: Great Shoals [295] of a cetaceous fish, whose nose was quite blunt & round as a bottle & the body slender, passed us; our Sailors called them bottlenoses but the[y] were not what Dale calls a Bottlenose, which is the beaked Whale: for this fish has no beak at all, was very slender, about 3 yards long, quite black & all had a white spot before the dorsal fin. [fn] The Bottle-head or Flounder's Head in Dale, History and Antiquities of Harwich ... (London, 1730), p.411, ... is the Bottle-nosed whale (Hyperoodon ampullatus), a species named by Forster in a footnote ...

Author: FORSTER
Quote:
[Of a black
cetaceous fish, Cook
Strait] It seemed to
be about three yards
long, and was
slender and
blunt-headed, from
whence our sailors
called it the
bottle-nose, a name
which Dale applies
to a very different
fish, the beaked
whale, of which the
beak or nose
resembles the neck
of a bottle.

Bottlenose dolphin
often work the
shallows, and have
been observed
chasing kahawai and
forcing them to
strand themselves
high and dry - a
scaled-down version
of the orca/eagle
ray hunt.

Author: DOOGUE & MORELAND
Quote: BOTTLENOSED DOLPHIN ... Other names: Tursiops truncatus; cowfish.

As we pass the
Shelter Islands we
catch a glimpse of a
bottlenose dolphin
and a Fiordland
crested penguiin
with a distinctive
yellow stripe over
each eye.

Eleven bottle nose
grampus came on
shore at Waitangi.
30 ft. long ...

Author: LANGDALE-HUNT
Quote:
Some of the oil
(black fish or
bottle-nosed
grampus) was still
in the workshop in
my time, until my
brother, Reg tried
it out on his
mustering boots one
day and was begged
... to leave them
outside because they
made her feel ill.

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote:
A very awkward
proposition or
problem. .. `We can
only go at a snail's
pace, if anyone as
much as sneezes, the
whole structure
could settle back
again, and that'd be
the end. It's a
little bottler.'

[Hdg] "A Bottler"...
On cleaning the fish
he discovered it had
swallowed a beer
bottle shortly
before being hooked.

For a series opener,
last night's was a
bottler.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
But I was mighty
curious all the same
- that must have
been a real bottler
of a tangi.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Bottler. 2. Expression of high praise or deep delight: NZ juvenile: 20C. B1941.
I would include among New Zealand English words: bottler

Author: SLATTER
Quote: Give me the Gurkhas any day. They're bloody bottlers. They love it. Ibid. 181 Ya know old Donovan? He was a bloody bottler. A real beaut.

[A Paraparaumu
correspondent
writes] Concerning
the book `Lolita',
your columns on
Thursday contained a
`bottler.'

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote:
A really good thing
or person. .`My
bike's a real
bottler.' ;We
would've spent the
night drifting if
Herbie hadn't
brought his bag of
tools and some spare
parts. He got us
going once before,
he's a little
bottler, is Herbie.
bottler n. exceptional person, usually in a derogatory sense.

Author: MARSHALL
Quote:
[Boys speak]
`Arthbutt's [sledge]
is a bottler.'
`Yeah, but he didn't
build it. I reckon
ours is faster, ...'
bottler n. Austral. & N.Z. inf. an exceptional or outstanding person or thing.

Author: McGILL
Quote: bottler object of admiration or great approval; eg `Thanks for all your help, mate. You're a bloody bottler.' NZA

[Hdg] Bottler of a
Journey.

Sunday being
popularly described
as a "bottler," it
is safe to say that
Saturday was
satisfactory for a
"schooner".

Author: MITCHELL
Quote:
In the preserving
season places where
teenagers are
meeting are suddenly
all male - the girls
are bottling. 'She's
a bottler' is the
highest praise a man
can give about a
woman.

[Hdg] Day's Slick
solo show is a
bottler.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
That must have been
a real bottler of a
tangi.

Author: BAKER
Quote:
Of children's
terms.. we may note
snitcher, snitch,
whopcacker, bottler
and snozzler,
descriptive of
something
superlative or
excellent, both as
nouns and
adjectives.

Other well-known
[drinking] games are
Hokonui Swindle,
Bottles, Fluffy
Ducks, Bunnies are
Hovering, Cardinal
Huff, All Blacks,
Matches, and The
Amazing Grimaldi
Brothers. All these
games involve either
a complicated
intellectual
exercise, tongue
twisters,
mathematical
calculations or
aerobatics in a
confined space; High
Candelabras for
example, involves
intoxicated
individuals
attempting to
traverse the four
walls of a room
without touching the
floor.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Marbles had a
language of its own.
There were names for
the marbles, the
games, and all the
various aspects of
the play. There were
terms for marbles
such as `taw' or
`shooter', referring
to the marbles used
to fire with;
`dubs', `dates',
`stakes', `dukes',
or `changers',
referring to the
marbles put down to
be fired at. Then
there were the terms
referring to
particular kinds of
marbles: for
example, agates,
aggies, aggotties,
American alleys,
blood alleys,
bomb-squashers,
bonies, bonsers,
bottlies, bull's
eyes, bum-squashers,
cat's eyes,
chinkies, connies,
duckies, eggies,
glassies, Greeks,
milkies, molly-bars,
mulley-bars
[mullibars: large
marbles], peelies,
peewees, piss-wees,
pretties, Scotties,
Scottish alleys,
smokies, stinkies,
stonies, stripies,
tom-bobblers, white
alleys, and in more
recent years
ball-bearings,
chippies, plastics,
and woodies. ...When
I first went to
school, bottlies
were good currency,
being classed as
two-ers, but usually
sodawaters and
black-bottlies
counted as the
equivalent of
six-ers. ...
(Petone, Wellington,
1913)

Author: KEITH & MAIN
Quote:
Marbles were the
currency of
childhood and there
were an astonishing
number of names for
them, some referring
to the material or
colour, others to
value or function in
the game. There were
agates, aggies,
American alleys,
blood alleys,
bomb-squashers,
bonies, bonsers,
bottlies, bull's
eyes, bum-squashers,
cats-eye, [sic]
chinkies, connies,
duckies, eggies,
glassies, Greeks,
milkies, mollies,
peelies, peewees,
pisswees, pretties,
Scotties, smokies,
stinkies, stonies,
stripies,
tom-bobblers and
whities. The march
of technology added
ball bearings -
ballies or steelies
- which were
unbeatable when it
came to smashing an
opponent's miserable
glassie. World War
II[roman] brought
`clayeys' often
imperfectly
spherical they were
pathetic terracotta
substitutes for real
marbles.

Author: McGILL
Quote: bottlie marble stopper from neck of aerated water bottle, prized by marble buffs. NZA.

I could spin a top
`overarm' and shoot
alleys, glassies and
bottlies with the
best of the boys.

Bottlies - the glass
marble stoppers from
the tops of bottles.
These worked
perfectly well but
were not considered
to be high class.

Author: BUTLER in GIFKIN
Quote:
I could.. shoot
alleys, glassies and
bottlies with the
best of the boys.

Marbles was another
recreational
pursuit... Silveries
and bottlies being
the most prized
marbles.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
There was [postal]
work [in the 1960s],
hard satisfying
work. Unloading
parcel bags, huge
cumbersome
containers nicknamed
pre-fabs, from a
three-door Z. There
was slots, there was
lumps, there was
packing fragies in
bottlos, there was
the tying down of
the north line for a
clearance, the
scissors, lead seals
and squeezers.

Author: HOCHSTETTER
Quote:
The Australian
diggers soon found
out, that hitherto
only the superficial
deposits had been
worked, and that
they had not yet
come to the
`bottom', where ...
the richest treasure
was to be expected.
They began `deep
sinkings', and after
having dug to a
depth of about 130
feet ... struck a
second gold-bed.

Author: STRONACH
Quote:
The beat on the top
of the hill is known
as the 'top beat'
and the one along
the bottom as the
'bottom beat.'

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
An easy beat is one
of easy walking,
usually the bottom
or top beat, though
the latter may
entail a long
initial climb.

Author: HALL
Quote:
I was given the
bottom beat because
I'd done the top the
day before.

Author: HALL
Quote:
The man on the
bottom beat got into
trouble. Some sheep
had been smothered
through a poor bit
of shepherding ...

Author: MARTIN
Quote:
If the 'face' was
not large, only a
'top beat' and
'bottom beat' would
be necessary, but
usually the 'spurs'
had to be 'sidled'
or traversed across
by several men.

Romney Marsh are
perhaps engaging
more attention ..
not liable to take
foot-rot on the
dampest bottoms.

.. with alluvial
flats in the bottoms
of the valleys.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Walking had always
been my long suit
and the thought of
doing the job from
the bottoms just
didn't appeal to me.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
.. it's all good,
open tussock and
carpet grass country
with grand bottoms.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
As it happened they
had to
straggle-muster the
Glen May bottoms the
day after I arrived.

The first hole was
imperfectly
bottomed, owing to
the quantity of dead
wood.

Author: GORDON
Quote:
.. there was just
too much water. I
don't know how much
went over the bottom
flats.

Typical of many
Taranaki hill
country properties,
the terrain varies
from wide creek
bottom flats to
rolling medium
hills, on into very
steep country.

Okirae Rd divides
the farm between the
Renegour block and
the bottom flats.

Author: Jane Bowron
Quote:
Sure it's quake porn
but people are
naturally curious
and I'm a bottom
liner, as in: see
how bad it is,
absorb it, and then
start getting on
with the business,
but I fully
understand those who
don't want a bar of
looking at any of
it.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
As they approached
the far end of the
block, the two
bottom men hung fire
...

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
.. the sheep may run
down and across the
creek before the
bottom man can catch
them.

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
If there is any
extra work at the
end of the day, such

or driving the mob

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
As it happened the
bottom man, Jack
McIver, had them
safely held ...

Source: Big Country of the North Island
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
.. those bottom men
were hardly
'drummers.'

Author: MIDDLETON
Quote:
Two other workers
and I used to take
some lunch down to

where the white-face
cattle were.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Bottom-side work:
This refers to a dog
working below his
sheep on hill
country.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
bottomside:
adjectival term
indicating that a
dog has had to work
from below his
sheep. The opposite,
of course, is a
top-side run.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
topside run: the
more usual and
opposite of,
bottomside run.
[bottomside;
bottom-side]

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
To head on the
bottom side is to
run below them when
actually running out
to 'head' or catch
sheep.

Author: STACEY
Quote:
Arthur Smith started
his dog Tommy down
the river bed for a
bottom side head. He
then completed his
head and stopped in
the shade of the
only bush for miles.

Now that we are
studying budgets I
should like to give
members the budget
of one of the
families I have just
referred to as
bottom-doggers. I
think this should be
interesting to
honourable gentlemen
who live in comfort
...

None of your Civil
servants or
Arbitration Court
Judges are called on
to throw away a
day's pay, but when
you come down to the
poor old
bottom-dogger you
say to him "Oh, you
have got to keep up
Anzac Day, it is the
law of the country."

A hungry
down-at-heel
bottom-dogger can
not see the beauties
of Auckland like a
fat sleek tourist
doing the Dominion
on a banking
account.

From wharf-truck to
Mayoral chair, from
bottom-dogger to
chief citizen of the
Empire city
[Wellington], is
something to be
proud of.

Mr Howard said he
proposed to look at
the Budget from the
point of view of the
bottom-dogger, the
worker.

Mr E J Howard
claimed that the
Federation of Labor
[sic] was now the
stronghold and only
hope of the
"bottom-dogger".

What bottom-dogger's
son was ever
apprenticed to a
trade which provided
him with L30 in cash
on starting, five
shillings and
sixpence a day for
his first four
years, and a
"GUARANTEED
POSITION" at the end
of that time ...

.. larry Johnston, a
Greymouth long-line
bottom-fisher who
had parked up his
commercial boat to
chase the
excitement.

Author: HOLDEN
Quote:
Every two years Jim
Stevenson and a team
of well-chosen
musterers headed out
for a week to round
up some of the
horses ranging the
Waiau River
bottom-lands.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Walking had always
been my long suit
and the thought of
doing the job from
the bottoms just
didn't appeal to me.

Author: Simpson
Quote:
Another New Zealand
expression is `Up
the Bouai'
(pronounced
boo-eye). There was
a place near
Auckland city which
many years ago was
somewhat isolated,
and it was called
the Bouai. The word
is not Maori, for
there is no `b' and
no `h' sound in the
original Maori
tongue. Once more I
cannot tell you
where the word came
from, but to go `up
the Bouai' has
become fairly
general in use.
Today, if a person
comes to town from
any lonely place in
the forests or
mountains, and a
friend asks him
where he has been,
most likely the
answer will be, `Oh,
I've been up the
Bouai.' It is a
general word for an
isolated region.

Author: OGONOSWKA-COATES
Quote:
On chilly days the
men might build a
bough shed, a leafy
lean-to cut from the
top of nearby trees.

Despite their
mother's prowess in
the kitchen, Clark's
sons Jack and Sam
say they prefer
bought biscuits to
the home-made
variety...

This best of British
men.. has tossed the
towel in after
Charlie, his affable
sidekick, bought the
farm trying to
defend his old mate.

..he will not try to
replace the poor
producers with
bought-in cows.

I used to aim at a
gross profit of GBP3
per head from
bought-in steers,
but in recent years
that has not been
possible.

Source: Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I
Author: TAIT
Quote:
Laid down in English
permanent pasture,
it is cropped
regularly in chou
moellier to assist
in fattening of home
bred lambs and
bought-in stock.

Author: STEVENS
Quote:
Bought-in sheep
should be isolated
until they have been
over the shearing
board for foot
paring and through
the foot-bath.

Bought-in cattle
wintering on the
final stages of a
chou moullier crop
get a supplementary
ration of hay.

Source: Big Country of the North Island
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
These are all
bought-in cattle.

Of the three rams he
used one year, 51%
of the progeny from
a bought-in ram were
affected by ryegrass
staggers ...
[brought in]

Author: SAM STEPHENS
Quote:
[Surveyor] Dinner
off(?) preserved
soup & bouilli.

Sent him my
Shakespeare, some
brandy and bouilli
soup. [Canterbury]

Author: SMITH
Quote:
Our biscuits [on
board ship] were of
the coarsest ... our
meat was a stated
allowance of salt
pork and salt junk
with an occasional
tin of soup and
bouilli.
Notes: [ca1850] 1940 E. Smith Early Adventures in Otago (ed Downie Stewart) 22

Author: IMPEY
Quote:
We enjoyed a good
dinner of soup and
bouilli.
Notes: 1850 Impey's Journal in 1933 MacDonald Pages from the Past 211

Author: HODGKINSON
Quote:
[Dietary on board
emigrant ship
includes] soup and
bouilli.

Author: BODELL
Quote:
(Population
principally Diggers
[with] good payable
gold.) ... At last
we managed to get a
hot pannikin each of
what I called Boilly
Soup a Mixture of
Tea Sugar Biscuit
and Pork fat,
anything better than
hunger.
Notes: c1890 Bodell A Soldier's View of Empire (1982) 176

Quote:
A bouilli tin (that
is a tin in which
six pounds of
preserved meat is
packed for the
voyage) to put my
small things in.
Notes: (Diary Overland Journey Wellington to New Plymouth)

Author: PRATT
Quote:
There was another of
these low chimneys
the architect of
which ... had
inserted a boulli
soup tin (minus the
bottom) in the clay
... as an aperture.

Author: NORMAN & MUSGROVE
Quote:
... we found a
soup-and-bouillie
tin.

We were caught in a
fog at Pepin's
island and had to
creep in, sounding
all the way for fear
of running on the
Boulder bank.

Our port of shipment
in the early
"fifties" was the
"boulder bank".. to
whence also came all
the bullock drivers
and shearers'
cheques, to be
"knocked down" on
their periodical
"bursts".

We made D'Urville's
Island in a week,
and were inside the
"boulder bank" of
Tasman Bay nine days
out from Port
Cooper.

Author: Hochstetter
Quote:
﻿The harbour
of Nelson... owes
its formation to a
most singular
"boulder-bank" which
extends eight miles
along the coast,
forming a natural
dam.

Author: HOCHSTETTER
Quote:
[Nelson Harbour]
owes its formation
to a most singular
`boulder bank'.

From here, one can
look across to the
northern end of the
Boulder Bank where
100 years ago,
moa-hunters used to
drive moa, trapping
them at the
peninsula's end.

The aptly named
Boulder Bank is home
to just a handful of
baches and a unique
way of life.

A man name Burke, by
trade a shoemaker,
was drinking, it is
said, at an
unlicensed house at
the Boulder Bank on
Tuesday last.

Walking from the
northern end of the
bank, I passed large
colonies of terns
gathering noisily on
the ocean side of
the Boulder Bank.

We boulder bashed
out to Klondyke
Corner. ...
Canterbury Mountain
Club Hut was reached
after a short bush
bash.

After tea we
boulder-hopped up to
the wee Macgregor
moraine.

Author: GLOVER
Quote:
There were ... a
host of others who
were boulder-hopping
and climbing in
country that was
[78] little known.

... Pete crawled
through the Wild
Irishmen and forded
the creek beside the
shingle slip just
below the
confluence. Then he
boulder-hopped along
towards the burn.

That afternoon a
trip was made to
Bell's Falls [sic]
where 4 of the party
climbed up the side
of the waterfall and
boulder hopped back
to the hut.

Author: MORRIS
Quote:
.. the 'Fang Hill'
creek always icy
cold that we had to
boulder hop.

Source: Tramping in South Island Forest Parks
Quote:
Cairns mark the
route, which
boulder-hops beside
the river (past some
delicious pools)
until it sidles up a
scree face...

Source: Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success
Quote:
The bull Thar was
panicking and even
though I was a great
boulder hopper, he
was world class,
leaving me in his
wake.

Source: Tramping in South Island Forest Parks
Quote: The Bolder Lake Daisy, Clemisia parva, and Clemisia rupestris are two examples of plants with limited distribution elsewhere.

Source: Tramping in South Island Forest Parks
Quote:
Beyond here is only
a marked route
requiring some
bush-bashing and
boulder-hopping
beside the river,
with bluffs to
bypass beyond Kakapo
Creek.

... all `beaches'
obliterated and
boulder-hopping a
necessity.
Notes: 1932 Dec 26 Diary in 1933 NZ Alpine Journal V/20/233

Quote:
The going up the
north branch was
much better ... and
we were able to stay
on the east bank all
the way, travelling
along flats or the
hillside, or
boulder-hopping; ...

Author: PICKERING
Quote:
Boulder-hopping
alongside a river
also requires that
essential rhythm
and, like skiing, a
certain minimum
speed so that you
have enough momentum
to recover from a
stumble.

However, I staggered
out, held together
by much Elastoplast,
sheer stubbornness
and a sense of
intense relief that
there was not more
full-on rock
climbing, abseiling
or boulder-hopping
fast-running rivers
- well, at least not
until next year.

Author: SHAW
Quote:
The remaining two
hours to Grey's
Hut.. is more
strenuous and
requires some
bush-bashing and
boulder-hopping.

Our boulder hopping
soon became
impossible as the
river ran into a
steep gorge

Boulder-hopping up
the river was a case
of the "blind
leading the blind."

Author: SEVERINSEN
Quote:
I tried to reach
base by
boulder-jumping and
cliff-climbing along
under the bluffs on
the seashore.

... it was a mixture
of
boulder-scrambling
and `bush-hiking'
interspersed with a
few shingle flats.

We also complete a
couple more abseils
and even try some
"bouldering" -
scaling large smooth
boulders with very
few hand and
footholds.

Author: MARSHAL
Quote: His' companion `bounced' (or lied to) the New Zealanders on this occasion [i.e. on a matter of trade]. Ibid. 190 Shall I bounce them? Shall I tell them a lie ... ? [Sydney-appointed interpreter speaks].

Te Atatu mussel
curer, ... Nathan,
28, explained ... to
be `bounced' was to
be arrested.

Author: BAKER
Quote: To bounce the ball, to test public feeling on a matter, to try the market (a phrase popularised, I understand, by a well-known New Zealand politician [the Hon R. Semple] who also introduced this country to the term snivelling snufflebuster)

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Bounce the ball. To test public opinion or sentiment; test the stock market: NZ political coll: since ca1920. B1941. Ex the preliminaries usual among footballers. [i.e. Aust. Rules]

Author: McGILL
Quote: bounce the ball political test of public opinion; eg `D'ya think Douglas is bouncing the ball again with all these rumours of a GST rise?'

In parachuting
jargon parachutists
are "meatbombs" and
those whose
parachutes don't
open become
"bouncers". When a
body hits the ground
from about 3050m, it
is said to bounce.

Author: RHODES
Quote:
The third mate
having a slight
quarrel with one of
the men in the
blubber room about a
steel to sharpen the
blubber or bounding
knife, and the work
being retarded by
his not bounding,
the captain took the
knife and bounded
...

Author: ROCHFORT
Quote:
[The Station owner]
has some excellent
paddocks fenced in.
The run is bounded
on one side by the
Turakina river, on
the other three by a
good post-and-rail
fence. The sheep
require but little
looking after, as
they cannot get over
the boundary.

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
I have been given
charge of one of the
sheep-runs [of the
Wairarapa station].
My duties are to
look after the
boundaries, as the
fences are often
knocked about by
wild pigs.
Occasionally a run
is visited by wild
dogs - Maori
mongrels gone wild.
Bound́.a-ry (bound́.&adot.-r`y0, n. [Add.] Boundary rider, a man employed at a station (see STATION) to ride round the boundaries and keep the fences in order.
boundary ... NZ & Austral. limits of sheep or cattle station.
Notes: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 127, BOUNDARY RIDER]

Quote: Boundary dog. - A dog chained to his kennel at a gateway on a road to keep the sheep from passing through. Now that most roads are fenced, boundary dogs are only used temporarily. [1890-1910]

Author: McLEOD
Quote:
One of the first and
most arduous of the
sheepdogs [sic]
tasks was the job of
`boundary dog'.

Author: KENNEDY
Quote:
The first [dog] seen
[past the Rangitata]
was a boundary-dog,
chained to a break
in a fence, to
prevent sheep
straying from one
run to another.

For fences were not,
...and kennelled
boundary-dogs strung
off the invisible
line that severed
the runs throughout
the plains.
Notes: 1902 Lancaster Our Lady of the Plains in 1987 Happy Endings 105

Quote:
The cruel fate which
had condemned him to
the living death of
a boundary dog, had
not yet wholly ...
embittered him.

Author: KENNEDY
Quote:
The first [dog] seen
was a boundary-dog,
chained to a break
in a fence, to
prevent sheep from
straying from one
run to another.

The boundary dog
came in for special
consideration [from
the SPCA.]

Author: CRESSWELL
Quote:
At fords, or where
rivers were shallow
and easily crossed
by stock, boundary
dogs might be
chained ...

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
They [gates] were
the successors to
the poor old
boundary dogs tied
to the fences on
station boundaries
to prevent sheep
passing where the
road went through.

Author: MCGREGOR
Quote:
Runholders who did
not employ line
riders used boundary
dogs.

Author: BRITTAIN
Quote:
Gradually large
blocks of land were
fenced with heavy No
4 gauge wire and the
boundary dogs could
be released from
duty.

Source: From the Beginning: chronicles of a county
Author: KERR
Quote:
In station diaries I
often came across
the entry 'Rode out
to feed and water
the boundary dog.'

Author: BOOTH
Quote:
A shepherd resides
at some convenient
place on the
boundary, whence it
is his duty to walk
or ride this
boundary at least
once a day, and see
that no sheep have
crossed it
[Canterbury, c1860].
boundary n.- bound'ary ri'der n. an employee on a station whose duties are to ride round the boundary fences and keep them in order and generally to patrol the station.

Author: McCASKILL
Quote:
From then on they
rode boundary,
hundreds of miles of
it, to ensure that
the Molesworth
cattle stayed on
Molesworth.

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
As my time is not
fully occupied with
`boundary' work, I
have taken a
contract to split
posts for fencing.

Author: PAUL
Quote:
The boundary fence
which separates the
poor man from the
rich.

Author: DRUMMOND
Quote:
These gates are
usually on boundary
fences at right
angles to the road
and between
stations.

Author: DAVIS
Quote:
We climbed the
boundary fence and
our hobnails bit
into the
smooth-stalked
danthonia grass ...

Construction will
involve clearing,
laying and erecting
a conventional 7
wire post and batten
boundary fence
including floodgates
and gates.

Author: PAUL
Quote:
The boundary fence
which separates the
poor man from the
rich.

For the erection and
maintenance of party
and other boundary
fences ...
Notes: 1861 Nov 2 Sir George Grey Memorandum in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 112a

Author: BARKER
Quote: After we passed our own boundary fence we came upon a very bad trackthis is the name by which all roads are called, and they do not deserve a better, - but it was the only path to our destination.

Author: G. W. WILSON
Quote:
... one of Dalgety
Blackwood's Stations
is in front of us
and immediately to
our left is the home
station of another
settler ... who has
taken the trouble of
planting a Hawthorn
Hedge all away along
the Boundary Fence,
...
Notes: 1873 Jan 25 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 149

Quote:
First, the fellows
hunting horses off
Moores country have
smashed the boundary
fence all to pieces
in fifteen or twenty
places ...

Mae came to terms
about our boundary
fence.

The [Fencing] Act
deals with the
nature of boundary
fences, the cost
thereof and its
apportionment, and
the obligations,
rights, and duties
of settlers in
connection
therewith.
Notes: 1895 Fencing Act in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 159

Author: SCANLAN
Quote:
Or he would take
them riding over the
back hills to look
at a boundary fence.

Author: BURDON
Quote:
... Brown sent him
[sc. the neighbour]
a notice in writing
to the effect that a
boundary fence must
be made between
them.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
`Bad fences make bad
neighbours,' is one
of the truest
sayings ... for many
quarrels have arisen
from boundary fences
not being
stock-proof.

Author: FINLAYSON
Quote:
`What's that queer
old wreck over by
the boundary fence,
Uncle Ted?'

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
He seldom spoke and
when he did it was
usually to call down
the wrath of heaven
on the wild pigs
that ignored his
boundary fences and
slashed his lambing
percentages every
spring.

Author: CRUMP
Quote: [see bushline]

Author: JOHNSTON
Quote:
`Found two sheep
worried inside the
boundary fence,' he
muttered.

Author: McNAUGHTON
Quote:
... they found the
dogs had about one
hundred and fifty
ewes mobbed against
a boundary fence,
and were worrying
for all they were
worth.

Author: STEWART
Quote:
Here, up and over
the broken bank to
the level above the
boundary fence, his
father had
constructed a
rough-and-ready hen
run.

Author: CARR
Quote:
The boundary fence
on Tony Schluter's
property was in
pretty good shape,
stock proof for 99/9
per cent of the way
around the 800 odd
acres.

Author: SLIGO
Quote:
He could look over
his land, well
enough kept what
with a manager and
then ... the
homestead! He
climbed the boundary
fence.

Author: PINNEY
Quote:
The old mustering
and boundary huts
were of stone and
the fences were
rabbit-netted.

Author: BRERETON
Quote:
His next effort to
raise money entailed
a three-days' walk
to the Wairau where
he had four months'
work as `Boundary
Keeper' to a
runholder.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
A base camp is set
up at Butlers hut
and the
boundary-keeper
spends night about
at the homestead and
the hut.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
Before fences were
erected, the man who
patrolled the edges
of the run was a
boundary-keeper if
on foot or a
boundary-rider if
mounted.

Lonely boundary
keepers who kept
boundary in some
river gorge and did
not see another
person for months at
a time, also felt
the need for poetry.

Boundary keeper A
shepherd who keeps
sheep from passing
an unfenced
boundary. He goes
along the boundary
once or twice a day
or, if he has a
convenient lookout,
watches the sheep
all day. In the old
days any boundary
keepers lived on
their boundaries all
the year and never
saw anyone, except
at mustering or by
chance. The
Australian word
`boundary rider' has
never been used in
New Zealand; in
fact, a boundary
rider's work is
different. He looks
after the fences and
sheep in a large
paddock. (C.)

The introduction of
wire fencing into
the tussock sheep
country had two
significant results:
it lessened the
labour requirements
of the runs by
replacing shepherds
and boundary
keepers, and it
lessened the
incidence and
checked the spread
of scab.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
A man detailed to
keep stock within an
often unmarked
boundary. Even a
musterer on an
outside beat may be
sometimes so termed.
In the very early
days such a man had
to lead a very
lonely existence,
year in year out,
just 'looking' his
beat day after day.

Author: THORNTON
Quote:
Two local factors in
the late 1860s and
the 1870s were also
very significant:
the availability of
cheap wire fencing
(early runs had no
fences and relied on
boundary keepers)
...

.. David Sutherland,
a shepherd who
worked for the
Murray family on
Braemar and moved to
Godley Peaks with
Bruce Murray to
become a boundary
keeper.

Author: T.S. GRACE
Quote:
The war at Taranaki
commenced by a land
agent inducing a
Chief to cut a
boundary line (for
the purpose of sale)
through land of
which he was, at
most, a part owner
only!
Notes: 1858 Mar 24 T.S.Grace letter in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 77

Quote:
Robertson cutting my
boundary line.

Author: MITCALFE
Quote:
The pakeha could not
understand why Te
Whiti opposed the
roads that came
cutting through
reserves, tribal
lands, gardens and
burial places alike.
Te Whiti sent the
fencers of Parihaka
to restore every
boundary line,
regardless of road
and roadmaker.

[Request for such
information] as will
lead to the
conviction of
parties removing,
obliterating, or
destroying
Trigonometrical
Stations, Boundary
Pegs of Sections, or
any other marks
connected with the
surveys.

I ... was occupied
two hours in
searching amongst
the tutu and fern
for the boundary
posts of the section
required; ...

Author: McNEISH
Quote:
Sometimes at a
boundary post a lone
dog would rush
forward barking
excitedly.

Author: SEVERINSEN
Quote:
[At the Mararoa]
Allan deposited us,
then drove on to
leave mail and
supplies for the
boundary rider our
Burwood Station
[which] is probably
the only station in
New Zealand to
warrant a boundary
rider : all summer a
Burwood shepherd
rides herd on
thousands of ewes on
unfenced open
ranges.

Author: BOYD
Quote:
The two front rooms
were taken by Edward
Kirk, who had come
out with his young
wife from England
and worked as a
boundary rider and
ploughman at Roy's
Hill, then drained
land and planted
trees along
roadsides and in
plantations for
Tanner.

Author: HOOD
Quote: ... boundary rider.

Author: NESFIELD
Quote:
[We were] sent to
learn the art of
sheep-farming at
different
out-stations. At
these out-stations
are shepherds and
boundary-riders
stationed.

In the succeeding
two years the
ex-coke-shoveller,
boundary-rider,
stockman,
boiling-down works
labourer, shearer,
rouseabout, ...
examined a mining
boom ...
boundary n.- bound'ary ri'der n. an employee on a station whose duties are to ride round the boundary fences and keep them in order and generally to patrol the station.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
Before fences were
erected, the man who
patrolled the edges
of the run was a
boundary-keeper if
on foot or a
boundary-rider if
mounted.
boundary rider n. man who rides round fences of a station to keep them in repair.

Author: JOHNSTON
Quote:
Boundary rider
employed between
Tamumu and Omakere
at GBP74 a year.

Source: From the Beginning: chronicles of a county
Author: KERR
Quote:
Crops and herds and
flocks are confined
where once 85,000
sheep roamed with
only boundary riders
to hold them.

Author: HOLDEN
Quote:
The solitary life of
a boundary rider was
commonplace in New
Zealand from the
late 1850s and early
1860s.

Author: HOLDEN
Quote:
In 1958 Frank Hore,
who had taken on
Nokomai eight years
before, ended the
days of a boundary
rider spending a
full winter out at
the Nevis hut.

Source: High Times in the High Country
Author: KERR
Quote:
In three years'
boundary riding he
never caught a cold,
but he caught one in
Dunedin and had to
take to his bed for
a fortnight.

Author: TIFFEN
Quote:
.. I had the job of
living in a tent and
supervising
outstation work -
boundary riding, I
suppose you would
call it.
Notes: in Cresswell (1949) Early New Zealand Families

Author: HOBHOUSE
Quote:
Morally one must
rejoice at the
prospect of
releasing boundary
shepherds from their
wretched and
perilous isolation.

Author: JAMIESON
Quote:
In time we reach the
hut where father's
boundary shepherd
lives.

Source: Awatere: a district and its people
Author: KENNINGTON
Quote:
Few men could endure
the isolation of
this occupation for
long, thus leading
to a high turnover
in boundary
shepherds.

Wanted - a Boundary
Shepherd, must have
a Horse and a Dog.

These dogs, called
"boundary
shepherds," are
placed wherever two
roads meet to act as
deterrents towards
sheep which would
otherwise cross the
boundary line.

Author: RIVES
Quote:
One of Caverhills's
boundary shepherds
who was on the
look-out for me set
me right and walked
about four miles
with me.

Author: ELWELL
Quote:
He was a regular
Cockney ... but like
many ??? soon learnt
enough to be of
service as a
boundary-shepherd.

Author: ALEXANDER
Quote:
A boundary stake;
that is, a staff
driven into the
ground to mark a
boundary.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
Here exist several
deep pits, near
which used to stand
a couple of
boundary-stones -
pou-rohe ...

Author: CHAMIER
Quote:
Shortly after the
young man had
resumed the
monotonous duties of
a boundary-walker at
the mountain hut.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
Before fences were
constructed,
boundary watchers
were employed to
patrol the run
boundaries, ...

Author: MCCASKILL
Quote:
The dry stock may
have to be 'pinched'
.. and must be
closely
boundary-kept for
about six weeks.

Author: MACGREGOR
Quote:
A Dog's Life 40 He
was boundary keeping
while doing a little
fencing, and every
day he had to hunt
the sheep back out
of the snow country.

Author: MOWAT
Quote:
Others in at
Molesworth, only
Angus here.
Boundary-keeping.

Author: MACNICOL
Quote:
The long mustering
days are in some
cases shortened and
the necessity of
winter
boundary-keeping
lessened by the
progress in
aviation.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
He was first at Rees
Valley
boundary-keeping in
1903.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
As with most
high-country
stations of this
sort,
boundary-keeping
after the autumn
muster is a regular
practice.

Author: SINCLAIR & TROTTER
Quote:
The main thing with
boundary keeping was
to get out early in
the morning before
the sheep got going
back up to the tops.
[boundary-keeping]

Author: WILSON
Quote:
Stations here must
be easily worked for
on this immense
place there are 13
shepherds but the
run is very well
fenced in and there
are only three men
boundary keeping.
Notes: 1873 Feb 2 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 165

Author: HARPER
Quote:
Jack is
boundary-keeping.

Author: BURDON
Quote:
Quite apart from the
long, expensive
business of dipping
scab-infected sheep,
the lack of wire
fences entailed
constant vigilance
in tailing and
boundary keeping.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
At one time
boundary-keeping
after the autumn
muster was a major
job, but over the
years, a big
proportion of the
block has been snow
fenced.

Author: CURNOW
Quote:
The bishop
boundary-rides his
diocese.

Author: NESFIELD
Quote:
In Australia, sheep
are either in large
paddocks which are
boundary-ridden, or
else they are
shepherded and
yarded every night.

Author: RHODES
Quote:
The third mate
having a slight
quarrel with one of
the men in the
blubber room about a
steel to sharpen the
blubber or bounding
knife, and the work
being retarded by
his not bounding,
the captain took the
knife and bounded
...

Author: RHODES
Quote:
The third mate
having a slight
quarrel with one of
the men in the
blubber room about a
steel to sharpen the
blubber or bounding
knife, and the work
being retarded by
his not bounding,
the captain took the
knife and bounded
...

Wife came to
Taupeka. Dixie
carried her
splendidly. She is
too boundy for Emma.
She bounded her off
a few days ago all
for fun.

Author: HYDE
Quote:
Some of them are
back in the bush
trapping 'possums.
There's a bounty on
'possums.

The Government last
year introduced a
bounty of 2s. 6d.
for every token
representing an
opossum killed.

Author: WILSON
Quote:
... the rabbit was
no inconsiderable
adversary. He was
provided with a
home, with food and
with a small wage,
but received also a
bounty for each
tail.

I just finished a
stint playing a
radical Maori doctor
(to Dr Ropata's
bounty bar).
Notes: an Uncle Tom, black on the outside, white on the inside

Quote:
Captain Bollons has
presented to
Canterbury Museum a
specimen of the
Bounty Island shag,
Phalacrocorax
ranfurlyi, which he
obtained on his
recent trip to the
southern island in
the Hinemoa. .. The
Bounty Island shag
was named after Lord
Ranfurly, and it is
the last bird added
to the list of birds
of New Zealand,
which, for all
practical purposes,
is now complete and
closed.

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: BOUNTY ISLAND SHAG Phalacrocorax carunculatus ranfurlyi

Source: Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ
Quote: 84.a. Leucocarbo campbelli ranfurlyi Ogilvie-Grant, 1901

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Bounty Island Shag Leucocarbo ranfurlyi OGILVIE-GRANT, 1901 ... Fewer than 600 birds at the Bounty Islands in 1978.

Author: SORENSON
Quote: COD, ROCK (a) Scientific name: Lotella rhacinus. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Rock Cod; Kelp Cod. (c) Other common names: Parrotfish; Soldiers, Kelp, Kelpies, Moreporks, Marblefish, Maori Chief, Wrasse, Bourbon, Guffy, Cloudy Bay Cod, Rasp.

The family farm is
either getting
bigger, to gain
greater economies of
scale and
productivity, or
smaller, to
accommodate the
lifestylers and
boutique farmers.

Bow (1) The bows are the curved parts at the top of the handle of a pair of sheep shears. They give the shears their spring open after the shearer has made his blow. All shears are now made with double bows; but until about the 'seventies single bows were the only kind. (2) The iron that holds the yoke to a bullock's neck (see bullocks). ([1890- 1910])

Author: BURDON
Quote:
The sheep they shore
were not so well
woolled on the belly
and carried less
wool on the points
than they do now, so
that fewer short
blows were required
to take off the
trimmings; but the
shears they used
were one inch and a
half shorter in the
blade and, being
joined by a single
instead of a double
bow, required a
wrist of iron to
drive them
continuously
throughout a
summer's day. A
piece of raw hide
known as a knocker
is now used to
prevent the shears
clashing when
closed, but before
this was introduced
the clack and snap
of steel meeting
steel was a noise
inseparable from any
busy shearing shed.

Author: McLEOD
Quote:
So most of us stick
to `the blades,' the
big shining steel
shears eight and a
half inches long,
with a double spring
`bow' on the end to
keep them apart.

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote: Bow. The curved top of the handle of the shears which incorporates the spring. Until the late 1870s shears were made with only one bow and the extra tension made them more difficult to operate. Now all shears have double bows.
bow: The curved handle top of hand shears. The grip is against the bows which causes the blades to spring open after each cut.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
... you would have
only to buy another
[bullock] plough and
two yokes and bows.

The Working
Bullocks, with Bows,
Yokes, and Chains,
can be warranted as
most unexceptional,
being in good
condition, and
perfectly quiet.

Author: W H S ROBERTS
Quote:
I yoked up the
bullocks. The
bullock yoke was a
square piece of
white pine smoothed
and hollowed out to
fit the necks of the
two bullocks, with
holes for the iron
bows which went
round the neck and
through the yoke,
being fastened above
with a key tied with
a bit of greenhide;
in the centre a bolt
with a ring called
`the start' passed
through the yoke, to
which the chain was
fastened from the
sledge.
Notes: 1856 Sep 19 W.H.S. Roberts diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 42

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
In the small river
Ashburton ... we had
a little
misunderstanding
[105] with the
bullocks; the
leaders ... slewed
sharply round, and
tied themselves into
an inextricable knot
with the polars
[sic], while the
body bullocks, by a
manoeuvre not
unfrequent, shifted,
or as it is
technically termed,
slipped, the yoke
under their necks,
and the bows over;
...
Notes: 1860 in 1863 Butler First Year ch vii 104-105

Quote:
The iron that holds
the yoke to the
bullock's neck.
[T. novae-zelandiae] It has been called the `bowing-bird' by the settlers, from its habit of bowing its body when approached.

... a suitable piece
of kauri ricker ...
shaped at each end
to receive the ends
of the bows or loops
by which the yokes
were fastened to the
bullocks' necks.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
BOW: Term used for
front of horse-drawn
vehicle.
Notes: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 185

Quote: Bullocks were also driven in sledges (two or four bullocks). The iron iron which passed under the bullocks' necks to keep the yoke in place was called the bow. The bow was held to the yoke by a yoke key which passed through a hole in it. (C. [Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p.95, etc.)

They were returning
[in a bullock dray]
... when a
carelessly tied
`key' that held the
`bow' into the
`yoke' dropped out
and let one bullock
free.

Bow - The bows are
curved parts at the
top of the handle of
a pair of sheep
shears.

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
So most of us stick
to 'the blades', the
big shining steel
shears 8 and a half
inches long, with a
double spring 'bow'
on the end to keep
them apart.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
bow: (i) curved
spring at the top of
each blade of a pair
of hand shears.

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote:
Bow. The curved top
of the handle of the
shears which
incorporates the
spring. Until the
late 1870s shears
were made with only
one bow and the
extra tension made
them more difficult
to operate. Now all
shears have double
bows.

`Come off it. You

You and your

Author: SUTHERLAND

What is known as the

Quote:
Many years later,
with certain

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
Because my left arm
was often numb and
useless, I developed

years later, with
certain
modifications, this

been taught
throughout the
world.

older than the
bowies concerned.

Bowie has been under

Department

Director .. Bowie
has a fairly
widespread

South Island. Bowie
has been known in

for some fifty years
.. Such animals also

Source: Diseases of Domestic Animals in New Zealand

Thinornis novae-zealandiae. I only found this bird on Mangare and parts of the coast of Pitt Island. It has been called the "bowing-bird" by the settlers, from its habit of bowing its body when approached.

Bowsers were then

Author: WATSON
Quote:
It's Erin Carter,
disgruntled farmer,
crossing the Otago
river. Erin Carter
born in March 1932,
brought up on his
father's farm in
Northland, near a

where there's only

stand under the
wattle trees.

Source: Under the Bridge & Over the Moon
Author: IRELAND
Quote:
A local priest told

the old bus barns,

'personally see to
it when the Japs get
here, you're the
first person in
Takapuna put up

shot'.

Author: LORETZ
Quote:
We gathered empty
benzine tins, and
there were plenty
for the bowsers had
not yet come.

The petrol bought at
the bowser today was
not bought yesterday
as crude oil.

Source: Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success
Quote:
Ross Motors had an
honesty bowser for
petrol.

This was seen as a
glorious opportunity
to do a troop good
deed, so we offered
to push the tiny
vehicle to the
nearest bowser
(petrol station).

Heading home, I'm
low on fuel and,
with no bowser for
miles, drive at a
snail's pace,
getting back in the
dark to an angry
Benecio tapping the
cat watch on his
paw, demanding:
"What time do you
call this?" as he
awaits dinner.

Fletchers forsees
battles of the
bowsers

The Government will
be unpopular enough
if its 4c a litre
petrol tax increase
goes through to pay
for unplugging
Auckland's jams; it
won't upset
motorists more by
playing wowser at
the bowser.

Off I roared, stereo
loud, warm breeze
encasing me with
those wonderfully
familiar country
smells, my thoughts
in the 70s, my foot
on the pedal ... the
fuel gauge on empty
... middle of
nowhere and I
suspected
equidistant to the
nearest bowser, as
they say in the
country.
bowser n. a petrol pump. [origin uncertain]

Bowyang.- A piece of string, flax, or lace tied round below the knee to keep the trousers from dragging on the knee. Shearers often wear them. (C.)

Author: BOWEN
Quote: `Bowyangs' are essential to shearing, more so than plus-fours are to golf. Straps are better than twine and will not cut off blood circulation. Ibid. 155 BOW-YANGS. Straps or string under the shearer's knees around the trousers.

bowyangs: bands tied

bowyang n. strap or string tied below the knee of a worker's trousers to prevent them from dragging on the ground.
bowyang ...n. strap or string tied below the knee of a worker's trousers to prevent them from dragging on the ground.

bowyangs pl. n. Austral. & N.Z. sl. a pair of strings or straps worn around the trouser leg below the knee, orig. esp. by agricultural workers. [C19: < E dialect bowy-yanks leggings]

Bow-yangs. - An

Ordinance.

just below the
knees.

Boyangs are not an
issue.

Quote: Now, mind yourselves, for if you box [fn Shepherd phrase for join or mix.]/ You'll play the mischief with the flocks. Ibid. 172 When he beheld in act to fuse/ With his, an adverse flock of ewes./ One startled glance told plain enough/ That he had boxed with Harry Ruff.
Box, v. t. [Add.] 4. To mix (two or more flocks or herds) in confusion; - used also figuratively.

Author: TAIT
Quote:
Alexander Mason
brought in the swamp
land by swing
plough, installing

When two mobs of sheep get mixed accidentally it is called a box. (1) When you put two mobs of sheep together on purpose, you box them. (2) When they join by accident they are said to get boxed. In fact, the active voice of the verb signifies intention; the passive, accident. ([1898 Morris Austral-English])

box ... 14. Austral. & N.Z an accidental mixing of herds or flocks. ... 18. out of the box. Austral. inf. outstanding or excellent. ... 21. Austral. & N.Z. to mix (flocks or herds) or (of flocks) to become mixed accidentally.

Author: CARR
Quote:
Pressing. - When
there is sufficient
wool in one bin, the
pressers (generally
two) get to work.
One gets into the
`box' as the lower
portion of the
patent presses is
called, while his
mate ... hands him
... the fleeces.
These are placed in
tiers, and tramped
down until the lower
box is full. An
upper box is then
swung ... or [16]
lowered on to the
lower one, and the
process repeated.
When full, the
`monkey' or cover is
put into position,
the spears (wire
rope) affixed, and
the two men lever
the cover down until
the top box is
clear.

... all the mercies
we had to be
thankful for ...
possession of
`tucker' galore, and
... (as the weather
became worse) how we
were safe on this
side of the Godley
and not boxed up in
Scone Creek.

If you do get lost
don't get rattled
... You are not the
first to get boxed -
almost every bush
traveller has
experienced the same
sensation.

- it is complained

Notes: >?orig. SI station usage: the Puketoi diarist uses at first join as in 1859 July 24 Puketoi Station Diary [Hocken TS] Hume over, said that Wedder & ewe flocks had joined. but later uses join for the deliberate mixing of animals; e.g. putting rams with the ewes. cf Beattie's comment: 1864 Puketoi Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 84

When two mobs of sheep get mixed accidentally it is called a box. (1) When you put two mobs of sheep together on purpose, you box them. (2) When they join by accident they are said to get boxed. In fact, the active voice of the verb signifies intention; the passive, accident

He swung the last box of coal round on to the rails and pushed it up the incline, trundling it along the unevenly fixed rails while his mate stayed to fix the jig - which controlled the boxes going to and from the coal-face fifteen feet above them at the side of the rails. Ibid. 420 box: A metal truck used in coal-mines.

down to the next

[run] wide on one of
the corners in such

the boxes off the
line.

The wheeled vehicles that transport the coal (trucks, tubs, or skips elsewhere) are in the Strongman called boxes, are linked together in a string they become a race of boxes. This race is the same word you hear in a railwayman's rake of wagons, rake being the northern-dialect form. Race was usually the southern form, used by miners in Cornwall. It looks as if a Cornishman at one time got loose on the West Coast.

The battery has
three stampers in
each box, double
cams, quicksilver
placed in battery
boxes, grating
perpendicular, with
round holes. The
copper-plate tables
are about 12ft. long
by 5ft. wide, and
raised about 14in.
above the blanket
boards; ... [The
blankets] appear to
be ordinary grey
blankets of a very
inferior
description.

`A BOX OF BIRDS'
Sir, - I am aware
that idioms in any
language are often
difficult to
analyse, but there
is one phrase used
in New Zealand which
leaves me completely
puzzled. It is the
expression `a box of
birds,' given in
reply to the
greeting `How are
you?' and is
evidently intended
to mean a state of
well-being. This
appears to be so
completely
irrelevant that I
would be pleased if
any of your readers
could elucidate, if
that is possible.
The term suggests to
me something to be
prepared for the
dinner table, but I
am willing to be
corrected. - I am,
etc. KIWIPOM. ? 1957
Evening Post (?p)
[To feel like a `box
of birds' is to feel
happy and chirpy -
Ed.]

BOX OF BIRDS: After hearing this from another New Zealander, I tried out the phrase on many people in the South of England and London. Not one person had heard of it, and most were unable, from first hearing (in context), to judge its actual meaning or inference.

Bracken fern (Pteridium esculentum) was originally widespread ... on the hill country of Hawke's Bay ...

Bracket creep -
incomes rising
through rate
thresholds - is a
surreptitious
sliding tax increase
because the share of
a person's income
going to tax rises
when the income tops
a threshold.

But his big push was
a big move to
address bracket
creep -- the effect
by which inflation
and wage increase
push a larger
proportion of
workers' income into
a higher tax bracket
rate as their
nominal income
increases, thus
boosting government
revenue with no
overt political
action by the
Government.

In horse racing,

individual horse.
... Bracketing

between racing and

Six Queenstown
residents were
pinned under the
boat when it hit a
shingle bank in a
narrow braid of the
river.

Braided rivers are
special. They are
found only in
northern Asia,
Alaska, Iceland and
New Zealand, and are
created by the chaos
of melting glaciers.

Meridian Energy's
ludicrous Project
Aqua would see the
removal of 77
percent of the water
from the mighty
Waitaki River, one
of the world's great
braided rivers.

The glaciers also
carved out the
valleys where now
flow two braided
rivers, the
Ashburton South
branch and the
Rangitata. Braided
rivers are special.
They are found only
in northern Asia,
Alaska, Iceland and
New Zealand and are
created by the chaos
of melting glaciers.

Wild, braided rivers
are rare. They
appear in only half
a dozen countries in
the world.

I'm really pissed
off with the extent
to which we're
supposed to
sacrifice our last
great braided river
so that people can
heat their towel
racks, their spa
pools and run their
electric
toothbrushes and
hairdryers.

"This is the brain

Bondi Budget."

Brand. - (1) The letter or other mark which each owner has to identify his own stock. It is stamped on to sheep with paint applied with a branding iron or brand. (2) and on to cattle and horses with red-hot iron which leaves a mark on the skin. Hence branding race, a narrow race for branding sheep, and brander, the man whose work it is to brand. (C.)

race ...
