Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
Mr. Andrew Liddell,
who lived to be over
a hundred, and who
was a bullock-driver
from the age of
sixteen until he was
twenty-two, had much
to tell me of this
adventurous portion
of his long career,
... `You ask how the
bullocks were
attached to the
vehicle, and as
bullock-driving is
now a lost art, I
had better try and
explain ... Very
seldom was harness
used, and then
without winkers, and
it was called
branks. The pulling
strain came on the
bows, and a yoke
joined two bows and
went over each neck
of a pair of
bullocks. If there
were five pairs,
say, a chain ran
from the yoke of the
first pair to the
yoke of the second
pair, and another
chain from the
second to the third,
and another chain
from the third to
the fourth. These
chains were lighter
between the first
pairs and heavier as
you got further
back. The two rear
bullocks were yoked
to the pole of the
dray or waggon. As
there were no reins,
the driving was all
by commands and
cracking the whip.
The calls were `Get
up' or `Gee up' to
start, `Whoa' to
stop, `Come here' to
turn to left, and
`Gee off' to turn
right. If you came
to a sharp corner,
you would often say
persuasively, `Way!
Way! Come here.''
There is a general
impression that
bullocks could not
be successfully
driven without
roaring oaths and
curses at them, but
this idea is a relic
of early-day humour.

They are
bean-counters, we've
got a Brash pack in
there.

The government's
political
correctness in
various Maori
matters has helped
prepare the ground
for Brashism.

She.. doesn't feel
she's had much
option after the
latest Brashism
suggesting there is
a perception that
Maori who make it
into university on
special-admission
schemes graduate
with inferior
degrees.

...in a Brashism
reminiscent of the
days when he urged
people to sell their
homes to move into
rented property for
marginal economic
advantage, he adds a
further string to
the Anzac dollar's
bow: when Australia
was buoyant and New
Zealand was
depressed, "people
could move".

About 400 rugged -
some would say crazy
- Wellington
motorcyclists
recently donned
leather and thermals
for the annual
pilgrimage to the
Brass Monkey Rally
in Otago... For
Ranfurly, the Brass
Monkey is an
economic lifesaver.

The possibility of
chilly conditions is
almost an
attraction, as the
growing event is one
of several wintry
rallies, such as the
Cold Kiwi at Waiouru
and the Brass Monkey
in Central Otago,
that attract large
numbers of hardy
riders to camp out
and socialise.

Rejoining the trail,
we pass Oturehua,
renowned for its
mid-winter "Brass
Monkey" motorcycle
rally and historic
Hayes' Engineering
workshop.

In fact, despite a
schedule which will
take them around the
world in well over
80 days, they don't
receive a brass
razoo from any
funding agency,
state or not.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
brass razoo a small
amount of money; not
have a brass razoo
to have no money.
Originally a
gambling chip in
Australasia; eg
`Sorry, chief, I'd
like to help you,
but I don't have a
flipping brass
razoo.'

Whether it is a pint
in one of Courtenay
Place's intimate
"trend bars" or a
couple of cold ones
in a more
traditional pub
setting, you know it
is going to cost you
a brass razoo or
two.

I did "the Brass" in
2000, drawn more by
the lore of the
event than the
allure of standing
around in sub-zero
temperatures
discussing
carburettor
adjustments with
petrolheads.

United Future wants
wayward teenagers
placed in "brat
camps" run by the
Army.

Late last year, the
other members of
English's brat pack
- Roger Sowry, Nick
Smith and Tony Ryall
- began pushing for
the removal of Wyatt
Creech from the
deputy prime
ministership... But
English, like others
in the so-called
Shipley "brat pack",
is conscious the
government can
deliver real
benefits only if
there is longterm
growth in the
economy.

Jenny Shipley's
Young Guns - the
Brat Pack, as the
media rather
flatteringly called
them - are
technically young,
as in below 40. That
is young in National
Party circles.

Tony Ryall, the only member of National's "brat pack" not to be made a minister, is settling in for a regime of passive-aggression in his chairmanship of the finance and expenditure committee. Ibid. 34 Socially, English remains bonded to National's erstwhile "brat pack" - himself, Smith, Sowry and Tony Ryall - who once presented themselves as an update of Labour's fish'n'chip gang by posing for a publicity short while supposedly plotting at McDonald's.

"The brat pack was
wetting its
nappies," observes
one seasoned
minister
caustically,
referring to the
quartet of up and
coming ministers led
by Bill English...
Instead, it is the
brat pack who, along
with Shipley, are
intended to be
National's
energetic, new
public face. English
in Finance, Nick
Smith in Education,
Tony Ryall in
Justice and Sowry in
Social Services are
attempting to make
the running by a
series of
announcements in
their portfolios.

[Bill English] has
become angrier and
angrier watching
Labour campaign
against himself and
his closest
colleagues, in
particular the three
other
(comparatively)
young ministers
known as the Brat
Pack.

Whether Shipley's
ministerial brat
pack succeeds in
reshaping the
political debate on
social policy,
National may need an
even more powerful
circuit-breaker to
shift voting
sentiment... Who
better to turn to
than someone who
entered Parliament
while the brat pack
was still in short
pants?.. Bratpack
minister Tony Ryall
picked up the
portfolio from
McCully in January.

But the approach of
National's new breed
of Ministers - the
so called bratpack
headed by Mr English
and Mr Sowry and
including Nick Smith
and Tony Ryall - is
drowned out by the
cacophony of ills
that continue to
plague the
Government.

But the approach of
National's new breed
of Ministers - the
so called bratpack
headed by Mr English
and Mr Sowry and
including Nick Smith
and Tony Ryall - is
drowned out by the
cacophony of ills
that continue to
plague the
Government.

With Bill English
and Mr Sowry in the
two top spots, the
"brat pack" has
truly arrived... The
brat pack's ties
extend to family
holidays at
Christmas.

What Smith's
grudging resignation
showed, however, was
that the Brat Pack's
days are over.

The "brat pack" - a
tight-knit group who
entered Parliament
together in 1990 -
are resented by some
for the influence
they wield and their
monopolisation of
the senior roles in
Parliament.

And yet it represents a remarkable triumph for the "brat pack" - a moniker I'm afraid I [sc. Michael Laws] applied to English, Sowry, Tony Ryall and Nick Smith in early 1990 and was soundly slapped down for.

National's arch
young fogey. Tony
Ryall, a member of
the party's
laughably unhip
"brat pack" had just
claimed - falsely -
that his local
hospital was full of
dope-crazed maniacs
while trying to
defend his Prime
Minister's
ill-judged attack on
the Green's
marijuana policy

What Shipley does
have going for her
is a smoothness in
presentation which
is head and
shoulders above all
of the brat pack at
present.

Nick Smith's forced
resignation as
National Party
deputy leader marks
another step in the
decline of the
'bratpack" - the
tight-knit group of
four young National
MPs who entered
Parliament together
in, or just out of,
their twenties,
holidayed together
and rose through the
ranks together. All
four were first
elected in 1990...
Mr English was No 1;
his mates Roger
Sowry, Nick Smith
and Tony Ryall were
Nos.2, 3 and 5...But
the bratpack - a
label advertising
guru Kevin Roberts
attached to them -
is history as a
unit. This is an
idea the bratpackers
themselves have been
trying to foster for
several years.

Author: FEATON
Quote: The Maori braves ...

Braxy.-A fatal disease of sheep. Sheep that die of it make wholesome mutton, and in Scotland are prepared (salted, I think) and eaten. I do not know that we have exactly the same disease in New Zealand; certainly we have not the custom of eating the victims of it; but it is a stock joke on stations to point out any stinking carcase to a Scotch shepherd and say: `There's a nice bit of b. mutton for you, `So and so.''

Author: ACLAND
Quote: Braxy a fatal disease of sheep. Sheep that die of it make wholesome mutton and in Scotland are prepared (salted perhaps) and eaten. We may not have exactly the same disease in New Zealand and certainly we do not have the custom of eating the victims of it; but it is a stock joke on stations to point out any stinking carcase to a Scotch shepherd and say, `There's nice bit of braxy mutton for you, So-and-so.'

Author: FITTON
Quote: ... milch cows, and heifers ready to be broken in for milking. [fn] A friend tells me the expression `breaking in' requires explanation. ... A young cow [allowed to run wild] when first milked is generally `baled up', that is, her head is secured between upright posts so that she can raise or lower it, but cannot turn round to use her horns. ... A pint or less of milk is considered a satisfactory result of the first attempt to milk an `unbroken heifer'. When a cow has submitted to this process a few times without much struggling, she is considered to be `well broken in to milk'. Ibid. 242 A well broken cow for milking generally sells for nearly [pounds]20.

Author: WIERZBICKA

Notes: 1874 J.G.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 191

Quote: Sheep dog.- Dog to work sheep; collie (q.v.). S.ds. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that bring sheep are called heading ds. (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to lead (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to huntaway and are called htwys (q.v.). Some dogs will both hd. and htwy and are called handy ds. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special slewing d., but a well-trained, hdg. dog or htwy. will usually slew (q.v.). (C.)

there was an
occasional
breakaway. Bill had
some wild-westing
galloping after the
breakways.
Breaḱ.a-waý. (br&amacr.ḱ.&adot.-w&amacr.́.), n. 1. A wild rush of sheep, cattle, horses, or camels (esp. at the smell or sight of water); a stampede.

Author: ACLAND
Quote:
Break away, usually
of lambs. Both as
noun and as verb.
breakaway n. panic rush of stock; bullock that leaves the mob.

Author: McNAUGHTON
Quote:
[sc. of sheep] It
was a slow process,
getting those sheep
down. The hillside
was benchy and
rough. But once they
were started on the
downward journey,
the danger of a
breakaway was past,
and all that
remained was hard
punching to keep
them together.
break away n. a bullock that separates from the herd;

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Some of our boys [=? converts] returned from Taramai where they had been to visit their sick friends. [compare: 1830 Nov 11 Ibid. Two in my own family have died lately in a very happy state ; and Williams's occasional use of youth in this context.]

Larger landholders
[on the Hawke's Bay
plain] supplied
estimates of
`breakaways' in
their land as a
result of the
excessive rainfall
that then took
place.

We headed up a great
herd of nellies
(giant petrel or
breakbones).
As we came out [of the Snares Islands], flocks of sea-birds flew and swam around us, and we headed up a great herd of nellies (Ossifraga gigantea, giant petrel or breakbones), and chased them awhile.

Source: Story of a NZ River, The
Author: MANDER
Quote: By day the whole bay vibrated with the whistle and screech of the circular saws, the tear of the break downs, the rasp of the drags, . Ibid. 197 They went past the the goose and circular saws and the moving platform of the of the breakdowns to the skids ...

Author: MALFROY
Quote: The laying of the foundations of the breakdown should first be proceeded with. ... The logging-delivery tram, mill log-skids, engine, breakdown bench. Ibid. 28 The breakdown benchman should be able to keep his own saws, and break the logs down to suit the cutting at the sawyer's bench.

Author: CHARLES
Quote:
And sawdust in a
shower/ The
`break-downs'
thump,/ And the logs
go bump,/

Source: Story of a NZ River, The
Author: MANDER
Quote:
They watched the
progress of the log

side of the
breakdown
platform... Halved
and quartered, it
was then levered ...
on to greased

circulars, which

small circulars, the

strips ...

There are break down
benches and two
large saws of five
and a half feet and
four and a half
feet.
Notes: 1921 May 24 Ensign (Mataura) in 1966 Barry In the Lee of the Hokonuis 144

Author: MALFROY
Quote: ... advantage can be taken of placing the log-skids and breakdown [7] bench on a higher level ... Ibid. 19 For small operations where the expense of a Pacific carriage or travelling bench is too ambitious, a good ... breakdown bench can be built locally on the principle of the `Bullock' bench which has been used in some parts of New Zealand for the last fifty years.

Author: MALFROY
Quote: The breakdown benchman should be able to keep his own saws, and break the logs down to suit the cutting at the sawyer's bench.

Author: BENNETT
Quote: [The timber trade] has supplied a wide variety of occupational terms The cleared tracks carry logs to the mill, where [they are] handled by a break-down man (`to break down' in New Zealand means `to make lighter').

The most experienced
breaker declined
[the mare] with

Quote:

BREAKER-DOWN. The

Experienced
Breakerout wanted

Hauler Crew. Must

The operator tried

Motu Logging Cable
Forest Harvesting
Crew .. has a

out/faller for a

Author: BIRD

The breaker-out and

The person who has

"Ho,ho!" called the

Following after him

Source: English as it is spoken in NZ
Author: BENNETT
Quote: Other [timber-trade] terms ... are breaker-out (the man who clears a timber jam; pl breakers-out)

Next in importance

BREAKER-OUT The
bushman who attaches
the cable to trees

from stump to
landing.

Author: MAF

breakeven stumpage:
the price the grower
would have to
receive in order to
make a return from
the planting which
exactly equals the
discount rate.
Notes: Source: Economic Evaluation of Agroforestry in Otago

Break :

Notes: 1836 Jan 5 J.Matthews letter in 1940 Matthews Matthews of Kaitaia 80

From 1902 onwards
the breaking-in of
the swamp was

large scale ...

Author: SARGESON
Quote:

vegetation and
preparing for sowing
or ploughing.

Author: LEVY
Quote: Another pest during the early breaking-in stage was foxglove, and for a time it seemed that this plant would be the ruination of the hills. Ibid. 250 Following the initial primary forest burn, secondary scrub fires and logging-up burns continue the breaking-in process. Ibid. 319 This is really a form of land development subsidy provided largely from farming profits in the course of breaking-in-operations until the block is subdivided by ballot for ownership.

The cost of filling

Quote:
That black whirling
Stardust stallion in

When the loco

Pacific bench which

Breaking-down is

an upper and a lower
working in the same
vertical plane.

...

BREAKING-DOWN BENCH.
A sawbench used for

The next morning we

down skids to a

in the mill.

Author: CARR
Quote:
Old fashioned

The breaking-in of

Author: TUCKETT
Quote: All the people frequenting this coast [sc. west coast of Otago] believe in the existence of an extraordinary bird, or phantom, which they can never see, but only hear rushing past them through the air with the rapidity of a falling rocket, and making a terrible rushing sound. The Maories declare that it is a bird possessing many joints in its wings. The whalers call them break-sea-devils, after the name of an island where this phenomenon is of most frequent occurrence.
Notes: 1844 May 24 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 224

Poutaima, Big
Island, Solomons and
the Green Island,
though a similar
strange bird, called
by whalers the
Breaksea Devil, was
said to be heard on
Breaksea Island.

BREAST BENCH.

BREAST-BENCH. A

...

Breastplate: Piece of timber placed in the ground that supports the stay at a strainer, angle, or corner post. Sometimes called stay foot.

The zig-zag breast
rail means the cups

We are the

Give new life to

Eversion of the
uterus or breeding
bag.

Breeding index is

show the relative
merit of a bull in

'average' bull ..
breeding indexes for
bulls of different

A philosophy has

Have you got high
Breeding Index cows?

.. many high BI cows

Author: MCCASKILL
Quote:
When he purchased
Molesworth he
decided to establish
a breeding station
near the homestead.

Breeding station
fetches $6.6m.

The property is run
in conjunction with
a 3500 acre breeding
unit at Rangiwahia
and serves as the
finishing unit for
the store stock
produced on the
Rangiwahia farm.

Te Whanga is a large
and intensive
property .. as a
sheep and beef
breeding unit, which
includes an Angus
stud.

A 50 BW Friesian
calf will make $100
...

.. we used natural
mating for 10 years
on 180 cows and it
went well. However,
we only bought high
BW bulls.

Genetics providers
used a figure called
breeding worth to
calculate benefits
of genetics in
dollar terms. BW is
Breeding Worth, or
worth for breeding,
and is expressed in
dollars. So a bull
at 130 BW compared
with another at 120
BW has
$5/year/offspring
more value for
breeding, as only
half is passed on
from the bull.

The herd has a
Breeding Worth of
90, ranking it in
the top 5% in the
country.

In the dairy section
a few good BW
crossbred heifers
came forward and
sold relatively
well.

Top BW/PWs with 100%
reliability and good
cell counts ... In
recent years the
breeding worth has
improved
considerably.

.. the three leading
factors in building
up and improving a
dairy herd are
breeding, feeding
and weeding.

Of the three
inseparables -
weeding, breeding
and feeding - the
last-named is,
perhaps, the most
important.

It is axiomatic that
economic dairy
production is
chiefly dependent on
three factors -
feeding, breeding,
weeding (or
culling.)

More depravity than
a night out with the
Spice Girls, more
twists and turns
than a Brent Garner
saga.

BREW (n) Illegal,
locally made

you can make to get

what to do.

Author: THOMSON

Base' or `Chivvy',

-

one scratches
cruelly.

The Brill (Caulopsetta scapha). The fish known by this name is occasionally taken by the trawlers outside Otago Heads. Ibid. 551 Caulopsetta scapha, Forster. Known as the `brill'; ...

... where in two
hours 48 dozen of
flat-fish, brill,
and other good fish
were trawled.

Caulopsetta scapha Forster. This species referred to as the `brill' in my former list, is a totally different fish. This specific name belongs to the megrim, or witch, a common form, not sold as a food fish on account of its lean, bony character.

PELOTRETIS FLAVILATUS Waite. Lemon Sole. Sold as `brill' in Wellington. Mr. Adams informs me that it is common in Dunedin markets during midsummer, when examples are secured off Otago Heads in about 15 fathoms.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Quote: Ammotretis guntheri Hutton. This is the species sold as `brill' in the south. AMMOTRETIS GUNTHERI Hutton. Brill. Received in Wellington from Timaru and sold as `lemon sole.' The supply is small, increasing towards the end of summer. ... Distribution: South Island and Cook Strait.

The principal fishes

[off Otago] are

flounders, and brill
among the flat

about Cully.

"Buck"
Shelford...Spotted

Even today, "Bring

To New Zealanders,

Bring Back Buck,

So to the main

Buck Shelford

"Sharko" Graham.

No, of course Jonah
Lomu is not the only
halfway decent All
Black. But bring
back Buck just in
case.

The single thing
that would do most
to improve life in
New Zealand is jobs,
jobs and more jobs.
Equally heartfelt
but perhaps less
practical
suggestions were :
Bring back Buck,
blow up the Beehive,
abolish all laws to
cut the crime rate,
drain Lake Rotorua,
send the water to
the South Island and
paint the lake blue
so it can be used as
a swimming pool, get
rid of the rest of
the world, move the
country closer to
the equator, put
cocaine in the water
supply and have more
dogs like Spot.

Although it's not
quite up there with
Bring Back Buck, the
campaign to stop the
extinction of the
Mowat - slow moving
and somewhat
anachronistic native
fauna of National
Radio's week-day
afternoons - is
gathering momentum.

We refer, of course,
to Bring Back Buck,
that unofficial Kiwi
ensign with the
slogan painted in
black, usually on
the backdrop of an
almost-white
bedsheet taken from
someone's flat. All
other suggestions
for a new flag are
meaningless compared
with Bring Back
Buck. It speaks to
us of Maori and
Pakeha striving
together for an
outcome that will
make the nation
proud.

The decision has
sparked a Bring Back
Buck-style campaign
in the Australian
community, with
petitions and
protests demanding
Young's
reinstatement.

It was clear at this
stage, that many
people had not yet
prepared their
detailed views on
the new proposals
and the Minister
stated that, if
necessary, he would
bring down a further
Bill later in the
year, thus allowing
time for further
representations to
be considered.

I would like to
compliment the
honourable Member
for Napier on again
bringing down the
measure.

I would like to
congratulate the
member.. for
bringing this bill
down.

I cannot expect that
the Government
themselves will be
in a hurry to bring
down here a Bill,
the passing of which
must rob them of
support of that
kind.

The Minister has not
given us a very
satisfactory reason
for bringing this
bill forward.

I recall a member of
this House bringing
forward a Bill year
by year until he was
finally rewarded by
its acceptance.

She should stand
proud in the House
for bringing forward
a Bill that is aimed
at reducing violence
on television.

The question was
whether the Bill, as
now brought forward,
would act
beneficially or not.

Quote: There was a time when the game of cards, known as Briskula was king, If you did not play Briskula, you were not a Dalmatian, as it went with the breed. Every house and boarding hosue and club had its Briskula dens... In Briskula there were some distinctions - you led or were led. There was the traditional banging of fists and the cursing by all. If you won, you were great, if you lost, you were a fool and were abused by all, including your own... T heir fathers [50] didn't care much - they were out back drinking and playing cards - Briskula and Treseta, match-making, after all was women's work.

It became common in colonial times for New Zealand to be designated the Britain of the South (or Great Britain of the Southern Hemisphere or South Seas, etc.). Analogous formations with more idyllic reference include Eden of the Southern Sea and Wonderland of the Pacific.

Quote:
Albions [sic]

... are wont to call
[New Zealand] `the

From the hour when

sighted new Zealand,
it was destined to
become the Britain
of the South; and
though it might yet
have much to
encounter it, it
would assuredly
overcome all
difficulties ...

Quote:
When addressed by
one of these guys,

to you as 'bro', you
can rest assured
you're in his good

calling you 'beau',
initiate a salvage
rapidly.

He lunches in the
local RSA / They all
know him there. He's
a mate, a bro', a
staunch bloke.

They like to keep
their celebrations
simpler, so I get
the call: "Come and
have a meal with the
bros."

'How bad are they?'

laugh.

"Kia ora, bro," says
the gardener.

We have more to

Hey Milt! C'mere!

The best thing I

The tried and true
NZ First vote
winners are there -

"bro'ocracy" and law
and order - but this
time there is also a
more obvious pitch
to Mr Peters' large
grey constituency
with a promise to

average wage and a
golden age card
cutting pensioners'

Gripping the podium,

"bro'ocracy" that
provides unnecessary
jobs and privileges

the opiate of the
Bro'rocracy - the

which keeps them in
a permanent trance
and mystic reality."

Strategists had also

Peters lost interest

it.

BRO'TOWN: Not even
aoh! The best
indigenous comedy to
hit TV screens since
Fred Dagg ...

To its credit, bro'Town doesn't just skid over the settling pond of superficial textual referencing; there's also nutrient in the lumps beneath... Ultimately, bro'Town is fishing in its own lagoon so it knows the territory and is able to catch much more than just the ratings fish.

Author: ed. James H. Liu ... et al..
Quote: bro'Town is very much a boy's world - the product of the all-male theatre ensemble known as 'The Naked Samoans.' [223] With a notion of open-ended kinship embedded in its very title - you don't have to be 'blood' to be a 'bro' - bro'Town points to the ways that art can serve as a much needed bridge from cultural specificity to universal humanism.

Gleefully anti-PC - the boys are described as "dumb-ass P-heads and no-hopers" by Carol Hirschfeld in a cameo - bro'Town revels in skewering Polynesian culture, Auckland, single parents, smug Pakehas, gays, and Indian dairy owners in equal measure.
bro'Town is a primetime animated sitcom that's going to hit New Zealand in a few months on TV3.

Quote: [Coprosma lucida, Forst.] The `Broad-leaf' or `Orange-leaf' tree of the settler; terms, however, which are probably not only applied to other species of the genus Coprosma, (e.g. C. robusta, Raoul,) but to species of genera belonging to very different families - and especially to Griselinia lucida, (N.O. Corneae,) whose foliage closely resembles that of Coprosma lucida ... C. lucida is also known to the Otago natives as `Kalamou' (Hector); and to the North Island Maoris as `Karamu', [fn] `Kakaramu,' or `Karangu,' [fn] (Colenso.) [fn] Also applied to C. foetidissima.

Ibid. 23/322A One of the most destructive pests in New Zealand is the grass-grub or brown beetle (Odontria zealandica). This insect, together with the caterpillar of the Porina moth, has been responsible for the destruction of ... crops.

Author: HAY
Quote: The species we have identified in the Kaipara and Hokianga are - the Putangi, or `paradise-duck' (Casarca variegata); the grey duck, or Parera (Anas superciliosa); the brown duck, an allied species or variety of the last; the Papanga, or `teal,' or `widgeon' (Fuligula N.Z.), and some other varieties that may be imported birds, or crosses, or other native species.
Anas chlorotis. - Pateke, Brown Duck. Both Islands and Chatham Islands. A very indifferent flier.

ANAS CHLOROTIS,

Author: PARKER
Quote: There are eleven species of Native Ducks belonging to nine genera, all found elsewhere, except two--the little Flightless Duck of the Auckland Islands (genus Nesonetta) and the Blue Mountain Duck (Hymenolaemus). Among the most interesting of the non-endemic forms, are the Paradise Duck or Sheldrake (Casarca variegata), the Brown Duck (Anas chlorotis), the Shoveller or Spoonbill duck (Rhynchaspis variegata), and the Scaup or Black Teal (Fuligula Novae-Zealandiae).
Notes: 1889 Prof. Parker `Catalogue of New Zealand Exhibition' 117 in 1898 Morris Austral-English 128

NEW ZEALAND is home to two types of geckos, which have generally been described as green (Naultinus genus), and brown (Hoplodctylus genus) geckos. Genetic work may yet reveal the taxonomy to be more complicated than this, as brown gecko species have proved to be unexpectedly diverse.

At first glance the
food mass in the
weasel's stomach
appeared blackish
with numerous tiny
yellow flecks. This
proved to be the
remains of a
juvenile Whitaker's
skink, which made up
about 70% of the
stomach contents.
The rest of the
stomach's contents
were comprised of
the remains of a
juvenile brown skink
Leiolopisma
zelandicum and three
tiny invertebrates
(a spider, an isopod
and a fly) that may
have come from the
skinks' stomachs.
Notes: http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/casn146.pdf 1997 Department of Conservation, P.O. Box 10-420, Wellington, New Zealand. Reference to material in this report should be cited thus: Miskelly, C.M., 1997. Whitaker's skink Cyclodina whitakeri eaten by a weasel Mustela nivalis. Conservation Advisory Science Notes No. 146, Department of Conservation, Wellington.

Quote:
We carried out
captive-based
behavioural
comparisons between
striped skinks and
the common
terrestrial brown
skink (Oligosoma
zelandicum). Brown
skinks are of
similar mass to
striped skinks and
overlap in
geographic range and
habitat, but are
easily captured by
hand and pitfall
trapping in the
wild.
Notes: New Zealand Journal of Ecology (2004) 28(2): 267-278 (C)New Zealand Ecological Society http://www.nzes.org.nz/nzje/abstract.php?volume_issue=j28_2&pdf_filename=NZJEcol28_2_267.pdf

Quote:
Brown skinks are now
present in the
Taranaki area and
the western half of
the southern North
Island, on Kapiti
Island, Mana Island
.. and possibly on
islands in
Wellington Harbour.
Brown skinks are
also found in the
northern and
north-western South
Island. Brown skinks
frequently co-exist
with common skinks
.. and at a few
localities with
spotted skinks.
Brown, common,
spotted and speckled
skinks co-exist in
Marlborough Sounds
on Stephens
Island/Takapourewa
and are likely to
have once done so in
the Wellington area
...

Quote:
He developed a
public profile with
assaults on what he
has called
Maoridom's "brown
table", sparking
fury in their
boardrooms.

They talked
disparagingly of
"the brown table" -
the old Maori power
base of Sir Graham
Latimer and the
Maori Council.

Alliance Maori
activist Willie
Jackson, a media
colleague and
friend, says Tuku
and his
brother-in-law Tau
Henare were shrewd
in setting
themselves apart
from the iwi power
networks, and
offering to
represent ordinary
Maori against the
"Brown Table" elite.

He's made an issue
of challenging the
older Maori
bureaucracy, "the
Brown Table".

John Tamihere..
attacks the "BMW
boys", the
Browntable which he
says seeks to hog
Waitangi money for
their own iwi.

Few of the so called
"Brown Table" at the
centre of the Peters
storm.. would claim
to have emerged
unscathed.

This is not a report
that will be
welcomed by either
Government of the
so-called "Brown
Table" group, who
have made an
industry out of
exploiting
grievances, but it
is an important
document and must be
addressed by
politicians and
policy makers.

Mr Tamihere's
intervention in the
process is likely
motivated by a
determination to
protect his urban
constituents' slice
of the action and to
prevent the "Brown
Table" from wetting
its beak too
liberally.

He and NZ First
deputy Tau Henare
were among the new
wave of Maori
politics that was
going to rock the
foundations of the
"Brown Table" - the
powerful male tribal
elders such as Sir
Graham Latimer, Sir
Robert Mahuta and
Sir Tipene O'Regan.

In native game, for
which no licenses
[sic] are required,
are grey duck, brown
teal, black swan,
spoonbill duck, and
pukeko.

Another protected
species of duck is
the brown teal,
sometimes known as
the red teal.

Author: THOMSON
Quote: There are in [Otago] harbour and in the bays outside the heads numbers of salmon or sea-trout (the true Salmo trutta), the finest fish which can be got here. I do not mean the brown-trout, which are also abundant. The society prohibits the sale of these fish (which the fishermen locally call salmon) except on payment of a fee for a license [sic], which, however, no one takes out.

Author: GEORGE GRIFFITHS
Quote:
Used by a
storekeeper at
Portobello on
February 6, 1987 for
the sweet,
`chocolate fish'.
Which reminds Wellywood of the "brown trout" often seen "swimming" in kids' pools.

To the eye it nearly
all looks green,
with here and there
only a patch of
brown tussock or
rocky hills.

Perhaps the most
noticeable feature
in those
improvements - at
all events the one
which first catches
the eye of the
observer - is the
immense extent of
the surface,
formerly
mononpolised by the
coarse brown
tussock, now covered
by a luxuriant green
carpeting of rich
English grass.

Then an awful
falling - the brown
tussock leapt up to
meet them.

Look at the
beautiful green
fields and the gum
plantations where, a
few years ago, was
nothing but brown
tussock, the
snow-capped Southern
Alps in the
distance.

Where the weka once
roamed in the brown
tussock, disturbed
only by the bark of
the musterers' [sic]
dog or the crack of
the stockman's whip,
are to be seen
bright homely
cottages and neat
gardens, churches,
schools, public
halls, hotels, a
Bank, and a printing
office, evidences of
progress on every
hand, and proof
enough that no lazy
people are living
here.

For miles and miles
they beheld one
unbroken series of
plains, covered with
brown tussock, with
here and there a few
clumps of native
flax and a species
of wild palm-lilies,
or cordyline,
familiar to us now
as the cabbage tree.

Quote: Following are other local money-names ... 1d. - Maori half-crown, brownie or copper ...

Russell]; the country seems everywhere the same, hills and dales covered with thick brushwood, the real scrub of New South Wales, and divided by deep ravines and gullies full of luxuriant vegetation, ...

A 14-metre Bryde's
(pronounced Broodas)
whale surfaces and
spouts a mere 20
metres from us...
Bryde's whales live
around the northern
New Zealand coast
most of the year and
are often seen as
they surface in a
fish shoal feeding
along with diving
gannets.

The BSA slapped them
with a violation of
Standard V12 of the
Television Code of
Broadcasting
Practice.

The most
objectionable part
of the bill is a
clause allowing the
Broadcasting
Standards Authority
to ban an entire
series of
programmes... For
the first time, the
BSA will be able to
ban programmes
before they are
broadcast, instead
of merely making a
judgment on
complaints
afterwards.

The Broadcasting
Standards Authority
is expected to
decide this week
whether a change is
needed to the
longstanding 8.30pm
"watershed" - the
time when
broadcasters can
start screening
adult classified
shows... However,
nude scenes were
shown before 9pm and
the BSA said it was
unrealistic to
assume all younger
viewers had stopped
watching by 8.30pm.

It's not easy being
the BSA; whereas New
Zealand on Air is a
Fairy Godmother,
dispensing its
licence-funded
largesse to
producers and
networks, the BSA is
seen to nag about
everything from
licentiousness to
liquor advertising,
and seems more like
the Wicked Witch of
the West.

Quote:

Source: Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Quote: [species name] kelp, bubble .. [scientific name] -- [other name(s)] Assume this is bladder kelp, Macrocystis pyrifera.

Fortunately he
believes that most
of the obvious
bubble-prickers
aren't a threat at
present. These
include rising
interest rates, high
unemployment or
demographic changes.

As the 90s became
the new century,
many of these
baby-boomers - now
parents - began to
circumscribe their
children's licence
to walk in their
shoes. Some go so

:"the bubblewrap
generation". No

Your editorial about

27) suggests it is

and let their
children experience

He also brought bags
of kina, paua, pipi,

They would collect

(sea snails) that
stick to the rocks
while we would set
off in search of
kina, paua and
koura.

Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
Some of the sailors

themselves by trying
to ride some horses
brought in from a
wild mob running in
the back-blocks.
These horses would
`buck a town down,'
as the saying is. I
saw one sailor get a
cropper; he regained
his feet quickly,
... and caught hold
of the stirrup;
whereupon the neddy
`cow-kicked,' and
caught him in the
stomach.
Buck (b&ubreve.k), n. The plunge of a horse in bucking. See BUCK, v. i., 2, in the Dictionary.

At school, however,
there was little

grounds and in
crowded areas;
hoops, Whip Top, and
kites, for which
there was less
space.

buck ... NZ & Austral. act of bucking by horse; NZ & Austral. an attempt, a try (give it a buck, have a buck at) [latter sense nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.].

For the first time

Hunters should keep

`buck fever' - a
condition which
affects hunters when
they sight a roaring
stag. ... hunters
get excited, they
become confused and
may make irrational
decisions leading to
accidents.

Buck fever has
broken out - and it
is a disease which
can kill! Each year
at this time hunters
swarm into the high
country aiming to
bag the perfect
stag.

It may not be out of
place to mention
Jack Burns' `buck
hop' on the top
floor of the old
bacon factory. ...
There were no lady
partners, ...

Buck Maori (slang) a male Maori, especially a well-built man. Recorded post-1920, but possibly used before. (On the American buck-nigger, it may be noted that buck-nigger has been used to describe a male Australian aborigine - 1870 ...)

Buck Reefs. The explanation of these occurrences is difficult.

Author: W H S ROBERTS
Quote:
BUCKJUMPING [title]
... August 23, 1856.
I mounted my good
mare `Lassie,' with
the intention of
leading the two
packed horses, when
to my astonishment
her ladyship started
buckjumping, and
after a long fight,
finding she could
not throw me,
suddenly stood on
her hind legs and
fell over backwards.
... Buckjumping is a
horrid vice,
although it is a
very amusing
performance - to the
spectator. The horse
tries to roll itself
up into a ball, with
all four feet close
together, head down
as near the ground
as possible between
the forelegs, tail
well down, back
stuck up like the
hump of a camel when
in good condition.
Attitude is
everything. Then
commences the
performance. With an
active spring and
rather a forward
motion up you go in
the air, and down
again with a jerk,
then up and down
like an india-rubber
ball, occasionally
varying the action
by jumping forward
and kicking out
behind with both
legs at once,
returning to the
oval position as
rapidly as possible,
then turning round
like a teetotum at
lightning speed.
Notes: 1856 Aug 23 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 35

Author: CAIRD
Quote:
Buck-jumping is, I
believe, an art only
known by the
colonial horses at
the Antipodes. I
imagine it is
generally caused by
the horse being
broken in too
quickly, and backed
too soon.

Author: COTTLE
Quote:
I had never
experienced the
sensation of
buck-jumping, which
in its true
significance is
peculiar to colonial
horses.
Bucḱ.jumṕ.ing (-&ibreve.ng), vb. n. The act of bucking. See BUCK, v. i., 2, in the Dictionary.

In Australia, the
majority of horses
are vicious, and

The athletic games

Author: SUTTON-SMITH

Apart from simple
climbing there was,
for example,
`crossing' the
plantation on the
treetops, and
Rough-riding, in
which one player sat
on a fir tree branch
while the others
took the end of it
and pulled it up and
down and then let it
go flying up in the
air. The player who
could stay on the
longest was the
rough-riding
champion. Of a
similar nature was
Buck-jumping, in
which individual
players rode a
macrocarpa or gum
branch [113] to see
who could rise the
highest.

Author: CAIRD
Quote:
Buck-jumping is, I
believe, an art only
known by the
colonial horses at

[the horse] soon
gets its head
between its legs,
and begins the
series of bounds and
flings in every
imaginable
direction, which
constitutes
buck-jumping.

buckjumping ...

Quote: `Bucket-of-water-wood', P. tenuifolium, Maori Kowhiwhi or Maupariki - despised as firewood. ... PITTOSPORUM TENUIFOLIUM (Banks & Sol.) ... This small evergreen tree, known by the native names of `Kowhiwhi' and `Maupariki', abounds on the eastern coasts of both Islands. ... Even as firewood it is despised, and bears the all too suggestive name of `Bucket of Water Wood', so little is it calculated by its combustive qualities to enliven the domestic hearth.

Quote: Perhaps the most recurrent and universal of rough games in the early period was Cockfighting (K-78). This was a free-for-all contest in which a smaller boy mounted on the back of a bigger boy and the two endeavored [sic] to dislodge all other riders by pushing or [202] pulling them over. ... Sometimes the game was known as a Piggy-back Contest or as Pulling Off. `One trick of the game was to "buck-jump" your rider, which consisted in jerking your elbows so that the rider was lifted over your head' (Naseby, Otago, 1905).

very inclement

Author: REED
Quote:
These wet-day
holidays were known
as 'buckleys', but,
says an old bushman,
"under some
contractors and most
'subbers', they were
a bit hard to come
by". The term
"buckleys" is said
to have originated
from a place called
Buckley's Gully,
which was always
heavily shrouded in
mist when a storm
was approaching.

Only the very wet
days - known as
"buckleys", after
Buckleys Gully,
where the weather
had traditionally
always been bad -
were paid days off.

The [Boxing]
Association is

against the
professional talent
which has come into
such prominence in

and the stoushers'
chance of fixing up
`shleinter goes' is

To oust Hereditary
Ward's Government,
Massey will have to
hold all the seats
that he has got and
capture fifteen
more. He has got two
chances of doing
this - his own and
Buckleys.

Author: ACLAND

Buckley's chance, Buckley's.-No chance whatever. Does anyone know who Buckley was?

`Borrower has
Buckley's chance.
Lender has a bad
attack of memory.'
Buckley's chance ... (Phr.) one chance in a million, no chance at all. Derived from name of convict who escaped into bush and survived all hazards. Used commonly in haven't Buckley's chance.
Buckley's chance n. Austral. sl. no chance at all. Often shortened to Buckley's. [C19:

Author: CLAPPERTON
Quote:
I don't suppose for
a moment I have
Buckley's chance.

Buckley's chance.-A correspondent from Kirwee, the same as explained Jimmy Woodser for me, writes that Buckley was one of the earliest convicts (perhaps the first) to escape from Botany Bay and take to the bush. It was then thought impossible to do this and live, as apart from the problem of food and water, the blacks were numerous and savage and reported to be cannibals. Extensive search was made, but no trace was found of Buckley; and it was concluded that the natives had got him. Any other convict who talked of escaping was invariably told that he would have `Buckley's chance' - hence the saying. However, many years afterwards Buckley was found to be still living. He had managed to make friends with a small band of natives who were moving to a remote part of the country, married one of their gins, and lived their life. The convict system had by that time been abolished, so the Government granted him a free pardon.

Naturally Scoticisms

bull birch n, NewZeal : BEECH 4

Author: KIRK
Quote: Nothofagus fusca

[Notho]fagus fusca,Hook. f. ... Tooth-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Auckland and in part of Otago and Southland. Black or Bull Birch of Lake Wakatipu. Red Birch of Wellington, Nelson, and in part of Otago and Southland. It is not so easy to see why any difficulty should have occured in the identification of this fine timber-tree apart from the misleading tendency of the common names generally applied. The thin yet firm texture of the leaf, the prominent veins, the sharply-toothed margins, are characters that can only be confused with those afforded by a careless observer. Yet merely owing to the use of common names based upon colour, and applied or rather misapplied to the leaves, bark, or wood at the fancy of the bushman, no species has been more misunderstood.

Bull-birch, of
southern lakes
district.

Notes: (E. Phillips Turner) [Otago] see cit. 1 b. above.

Quote: PORO PORO (Solanum aviculare ), also called bullibull (a corruption of the Maori name), and potato berry. It is found commonly on the bush edge in lowland districts throughout both islands. It is a perennial leafy spreading bush 4 to 8 ft. high, ...

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: Solanum aviculare (The Poro-poro) ... The plant is often called by the settlers, the Bulli-bull.
poroporo, a plant (Solanum aviculare) with beautiful large blue flowers and large orange-coloured berry eaten by boys and birds: often corrupted to bullybul. S. nigrum is raupeti.
bullibul, bullibulli [=] poroporo [s]
The raw material for the drugs will be extracted from the shrub Solanum aviculare , known locally as poroporo or bulli-bulli.

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote: ~ poroporo Solanum

Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Quote: SOLANUM LACINIATUM. Poroporo (bullibul) is a soft-wooded shrub ... Two species are called by one Maori name. Two Latin names, S. laciniatum and S. aviculare, are both more than a hundred years old but it was only in 1954 that Baylis defined clearly the difference between the two species and then the two names came into general use.

Author: BROOKER et al.
Quote: Solanum aviculare Forst.f. Common name: Bullibulli Maori name: Poroporo, kohoho ... Some authors have identified `poroporo' as S. nigrum [Black Nightshade], a smaller, weedy plant, and it is possible that the Maori did not distinguish the species.

Author: WILSON
Quote: Solanum laciniatum POROPORO ... Bullabulla
bull-a bull n. NZ = POROPORO. [Anglicized form]

We ate bull-a-bulls

No one around the
washers; no one at

`bull-wagons' which

Author: CHARLES

A bull-whacking
barmaid - an Irish
colleen -/ Was wild
Roaring Meg, the
gold-diggers'
queen!/

... I threw my line
into a little
water-hole ... and

Zealand trout, or

[Beatrice Grimshaw]

boys, some

'Bull Bars' should
be renamed

For any time you are
doing a sensible 35
around a blind

through a shopping
centre, the person

driving either a BMW

They admire their

It was [at
Blockhouse Bay
school c1950s]
Kingaseeny (or
Bulldog, King Dick
or Bar-the-Door for

Auckland) at
lunchtime, rugby on
Wednesday, the gang
after school, ...

But may I suggest that in a future edition [of the Collins English Dictionary two more New Zealand words which are associated with deer hunting be included, namely net -gun', and the verb `to bulldog'.

Author: SORENSON
Quote: MONKFISH (a) Scientific name: (i) Geniagnus monopterygius (ii) Kathetostoma giganteum. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (both) Whitefish. (c) Other common names: (both) Monkfish, Monks, Stargazer, Flathead (also applied at times to export gurnard); Churchills, Toebiters, Bulldogs, Spotted Stargazer, Maori Chief (Dunedin); Muddies. (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Cook Strait, Nelson, Banks Peninsula, Bluff-Stewart Island. ... Monkfish is a general term for species of the Families Uranoscopidae and Leptoscopidiae.

Source: Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Quote: [species name] stargazer .. [scientific name] Kathetostoma giganteum .. [other name(s)] monkfish, boofs, bulldogs, churchills, flathead monk, giant stargazer, monks, muddies, spotted stargazer, toebiters, whitefish, sandcod

Author: PAUL
Quote: Monkfish Kathetotoma giganteum ... Also occurs in southern Australia. Known by a number of local names: giant stargazer, flathead, bulldog, boof, etc. The name monkfish is well established for this species in New Zealand, whereas overseas it is used for similarly shaped but unrelated anglerfishes.

Author: FORRESTER
Quote:
Jeff Carter of Te
Anau bulldogged
sixty-seven live
deer in two days
when jumping for Jim
Kane.

Author: FORRESTER
Quote:
Mau Bradley has just
bulldogged a live
red deer on this
steep ridge in the
Kaimanawas.

Stitch was the only
one awake, so he
climbed out on the
skid, bulldogging
the first, roped it
and hefted it
aboard, then rode
the skid till I
caught up with the
second. He
bulldogged that one
too.

Author: FORRESTER
Quote:
On another trip,
capturing fallow,
Joe had two
bulldoggers, Mau and
Stitch, and three
deer handlers.

Author: FORRESTER

While all this
bulldogging was
going on, and
thousands of deer
being captured ...

Source: David McGill's Complete Kiwi Slang Dictionary
Author: MCGILL

bulldogging:
Catching wild deer
by dropping on them
from helicopters.

BULLDOZER is an

for a

Bulldozer dribble -

2]
bull/bulls wool/bull dust: rude term for disbelief in a statement; e.g., `He spoke a lot of bulls wool.'

Author: BEARDSLEY
Quote: bulldust nonsense
bulldust nonsense or reaction to the serving up of such; polite version of `bullshit'; eg `I'm sorry, but you're just talking absolute bulldust.'

They are called bullets by tuna fishermen and can cause a great deal of trouble to purse seiners working skipjack schools [by gilling themselves in the net and taking time to remove].

...

Entering the toilet
he saw Mr Maddox
handing over money
for marijuana. He
snatched the bullet
out of his hand and
Mr Maddox went to
hit him but was not
quick enough.

There are only three fish in the River Avon, sufficiently common to justify the supposition that either of them may be the adult form of the Whitebait; these are the Bull-head, the Silver-fish, and the Smelt. The name of Smelt is applied indiscriminately to the two latter fish, we will ... retain the trivial name of Silver-fish as a distinction. We may first dismiss the Bull-head ... It is an Acanthopterygious fish ... Head, large, one third of the length of the body ... [86] The Silver-fish again belongs to the Malacopterygii abdominales, or fishes having soft fin rays, with the ventral fins placed below the abdomen. ... We now come to the ... fish ...called, by boys, the Smelt; but why a Smelt, I know not. ... the Smelt is a Galaxia ...

For small operations
where the expense of

Author: MACKIE
Quote:
D[illon] at one time
farmed his own land
in the Waimea and
was in the habit of
driving his own
bullock cart into
Nelson. The bullock
is the general and
almost only vehicle
in this district. It
is a two wheeled
cart with a pair of
bullocks;
occasionally we see
4-6 or 8 bullocks

circumstances.

Went to Merton with

brought back a load
of board for
shutters to keep
Maories out.

Quote:
Along the banks of

now the endless
trains of bullock
carts, pack-horses
and horse drays

for transport
service during the
grand move of the
General.

Quote:
Every able-bodied
man was speedily at
work ... and soon a
hundred bullock-cart
loads of timber were
on thespot selected
for the post.

The river was very
high ..., having got
over that you had to
walk some way and
then get into a
bulock dray and
cross a branch that
people at home [sc.
England] would look
at a long time ...,
the bullocks
sticking up in the
middle each time.

Linton over in the
township and ordered
a Bullock Dray seven
feet by five feet,
for Body, three inch
axles and four feet
eight wheels, four
inch tires with an
Iron Bark pole
running right
through the Dray.

Quote:
The Government
Bullock Dray left
Maketu.

On the road we
overtook one of our
bullock-drays taking
wool to the coast:
the driver had taken
down behind the dray
a strong ...
stock-horse, ... to
be exchanged ... for
one of ours.

Quote:
[The bullock-dray]
put me in mind of
old times, when
buggies, carriages
and dogcarts were
unknown, and we were
content to ride in a
bullock-dray.

Source: Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand

By a pleasant

Author: SATCHELL
Quote:
The traffic of
winter-time, when
horses and bullock
drays moved along a
track apparently
metalled with cream
cheeses, ...

Besides using boats
on the rivers some
of the settlers soon
acquired bullock
drays.

Author: BATHGATE
Quote:
... Gilbert decided
to send Mike ... ,
as he had the
bullock dray already
loaded ... to take
over to the
out-station, and
both ... thought
that Mike could be
trusted to keep the

Author: MULGAN
Quote:
In this high country
he met some of the
original selectors -
men who had pushed
out into the unknown
in bullock drays and
had seen tent give
way to mud or stone
hut, and that
replaced by the
long, low wooden
homestead, with its
deep verandah, its
big, comfortably
furnished rooms ...

Author: LANCASTER
Quote:
... John had taken
himself, his
Herefords, and his
family off into the
bush twelve miles
away. Nemesis
herself might have
pitied Caroline (who
had come in by
bullock-dray to have
a tooth out), ...

Quote:
He has made a rough
track to this rough
home by smoothing
one or two extra
rough bits and
sloping off a few
creek banks to allow
bullock drays or
sledges to get
through. Sledges
were the [34] common
vehicle of the
earliest times,
followed by bullock
drays, and then,
after the diggings
broke out, by the
long-bodied,
four-wheeled bullock
wagon and also by
horse-drawn drays
and wagons with
greatly increased
accommodation.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
The bullock-dray,
used instead of a
waggon, has a pole,
to the end of which
the yoke is
fastened.

Author: LUSH
Quote:
At 9 Blanche and I
met the Bullocks
Dray at the College.

Author: MACKIE
Quote:
Bullock drays are in
general use, horses
are not yet
plentiful in this
settlement.

There are other
carriages very
interesting to me -
bullock-drays with
their teams of ten
oxen and loads of
groceries waiting to
finish cargo ...

Author: PAUL
Quote:
[Station
Terminology] ... a
bullock-dray with a
team of six
bullocks.

Sent Bullock dray to
Stotburn with fowls

Author: PINFOLD
Quote:
By means of a
bullock-dray
families could
sometimes be brought
to church, ...
... Bullock-dray was a rough cart with two wheels and a pole, to which the bullocks were attached by yokes over their necks, and a chain. It was usually drawn by a team of six or eight.

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
Andrew drove a
bullock-dray for
Chapman.

Author: CRESSWELL
Quote:
Before the French

Quote:
They [the horses]

plains was nothing
more than the wheel
marks left by early
bullock drays.

Author: WILSON
Quote:
[hist] When I first
came out I was taken
in a bullock dray
... to a place out
of Wellington.

Author: TOMLINSON
Quote:
Many sheep, and
later packhorses and
bullock drays, were
taken through this
track to the Wairau
until it became
almost impassible.

Author: HUNT
Quote:
... we'd all have to
go to school on the
bullock dray. It was
a great big square,
open thing; they'd
put seats across it
and away we'd go.

The space around the
grain stores in Tyne
street presents a
busy appearance from
day to day. On
Wednesday we counted
no less then 26
bullock and horse
drays, and 6 or 8
horse wagons waiting
their turn for
unloading.
Notes: 1874 May Oamaru Times in 1914 History of North Otago (1978) 155

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote: There is at last some attention being paid to the roads about here. Up to now, there have only been bullock-dray tracks. A contract was recently taken ... to do some side-cutting on a road through uncle's run. Ibid. 62 ... they travel thither by road - which is a bullock-dray track from the Waihora boundary - past the homestead, ...

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
On one of my
bullock-dray trips
... I was
accompanied by
another dray driven
by Bill Familton ...

Quote:
For miles and miles
now there was an
unbroken stream of
soldiers,
bullock-drays,
artillery,
packhorses and
orderlies meandering
over the plains and
fern ridges of the
sacred Maori delta.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
... it is commonly
reported that a
heavily-laden
bullock-dray could
cross it in perfect
safety.
bullock ... 2. v.i. NZ & Austral. colloq. work strenuously.

Author: McGILL
Quote: - to bullock is still regarded as acting belligerently, and rugby forwards, in commentator's parlance, bullock over for tries.

We should make it a
condition that
[assisted
immigrants] be
strong and willing
to go up-country and
bullock hard.

The first Rubgy test
[was] one in which
the heavier New
Zealand forwards ...
`bullocked' their
way to victory. ...
A penalty try ...
was awarded for
obstruction to
Stanley who was
racing ... for the
ball, which had been
kicked over the
Blacks' line.

Just keeps
bullocking, like the
rest of us.

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
In mine and
threshing-mill he
had his day/
Bullocking, a strong
back and a weak
head/

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
Webfoot Charlie
bullocks the dead
Cornishman's body to
the side of the
sleeping Dane, ...

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
The Ruamahanga
forwards bullock
into the ruck and
Keith Maxwell, given
the ball, takes a
snap pot at goal ...

When they got back
to the farm Chris
had arrived. He
heard them ... and
saw, bullocking in
through the gate,
two 650s, red, and
orange, on one a
Maori ... riding out
of any bikie saga
...

Bullock.- Never called oxen in New Zealand, whether working bullocks or otherwise. Bullock-dray was a rough cart with two wheels and a pole, to which the bullocks were attached by yokes over their necks, and a chain. It was usually drawn by a team of six or eight.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
The bull-head, or
bully, which is a
sluggish fish,
resting mostly on
the bottom, or
lurking beside or
under stones, or
among the weeds if
present. It can be
easily caught in
cupped hands ...
speckled gray or
blackish - brown,
sometimes washed
with yellow,
sometimes almost
entirely black.

Transport, by
packhorses or
bullock, was the
chief problem...
After recovering the
GBP50 paid for the
"bull," the brothers
made about GBP50 a
month.

Author: FANNING
Quote:
Forwards may be
roughly classified
into bullocks,
sheep, goats, and
men.

Author: REED
Quote:
Here Caldow and
Malone worked 6
million feet, which
was bullocked, and
then trammed, to the
mouth of the
Kaimarama River near
the old booms.

Author: WHEELER
Quote:
I ask Bert about
transporting [kauri]
logs. `The [Kauri
Timber] Company
bullocked the kauri
[79] logs to the
streams, and the
logs were floated
out from trip dams
on the Pungapunga.'

It seemed as though
the horses would be
unable to "bullock"
the heavy vehicle
through the mud.

The seed has to be
packaged on horses
and carried even by
men to tracks, where
a sledge will take
it to the main road,
to be bullocked to
the different bays
for transport by
steamer to Lyttelton
or Dunedin.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
The bullockies
invariably took
their hack, known as
the `bullock horse'
with them, ... These
horses were tied on
behind the drays by
a neck-rope, and
dragged along if
they were not
inclined to go
willingly.
Sometimes, when the
dray was being
driven through low
scrub, the bullock
horses would get
some nasty knocks
from the stems
flying up and
hitting them.

Author: HUNT
Quote: I can even remember way back to seeing the bullock jankers go by here, taking the logs to the mill. Ibid 34 If it was fine but muddy he'd send a man to take us in the old bullock janker; it was just too [sic] big wheels with a long pole and two bullocks, one each side, hooked on with great big yokes around their necks.

A tall young man ...
but he takes to a
blue serge shirt and
`Way! Woap!' with
bullocks in a manner
not to be enough
commended.

Author: REED
Quote: Nearly all the drivers used the same bullock language, giving the command always in the same words ... [180] wo `halt'; back; come here; [183] gee; hoit.

Author: VON HAAST
Quote:
If the English
sailors have
acquired a not
undeserved
reputation for their
curses, surely the
New Zealand
bullock-drivers must
be reckoned superior
to them in this
accomplishment, for
such an assortment
of fantastic oaths
from all kingdoms of
Nature, Heaven and
Hell I have never
heard before from
mortal lips.
Astounded I listened
to this blue-eyed
son of Albion and
was at last impelled
to ask him why he
cursed so horribly;
it could serve no
purpose and only
made the beast more
stubborn. `You don't
understand, Sir,'
the young man
answered. `I'm only
speaking the bullock
language. The animal
certainly wouldn't
understand or obey
me if I spoke to him
as I would to my
horse. The bullock
has been brought up
to carry in this
way, and if I want
to get on fast, I've
got to talk to him
like this.' To this
argument advanced by
the driver with a
good-natured smile I
naturally could find
no reply. I refer it
to the linguists to
enrol this new
language in the
appropriate family
of dialects.
Notes: [c1860 Weiner Zeitung (Vienna) Nos 57-65 in German] in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 36

Author: HART
Quote:
Bullock drivers are
seldom choice in
their language under
the most favourable
circumstances, but
to drive a team with
a load of firewood
..., from Papanui to
Christchurch, was a
work of so much
difficulty, that the
flow of bullock
language was more
than ordinarily
profuse [March
1852].

Source: Under the Bridge & Over the Moon
Author: IRELAND
Quote:
During this time he
worked for his
tucker on a bullock
team, as a goad-boy.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
The first day was
devoted to a
ploughing match, for
bullock-ploughs and
for horse-ploughs.
... only eleven
ploughs were on the
ground, seven of
which were
bullock-teams ...

Source: Crusts: a settler's fare due south
Author: KENNAWAY
Quote:
Next day we yoked up
two of our
bullock-team, and
hooking them on to a
rough sledge,
started early to cll
at our two
depo[circumflex]ts
of fresh pork.

Author: FEATON
Quote:
Mr. Hamlin ... was
... engaged with a
bullock-team, in
removing goods from
the farm house ...

Author: CAMPBELL
Quote:
A bullock-team at
this moment stopped
at the inn-door, the
driver entered, ...

Willie Dix and
bulock team arrived
in the morning and
Martin with horse
team in the
afternoon.

In the south, rough
tramways are laid
down in the bush,
and the logs hauled
on low carriages to
the mills by horse-
or bullock-teams.
here the great round
baulks of timber are
`broken down' being
cut lengthwise (by
saws moving up and
down vertically)
into `flitches',
which are passed
over to the
circular-saws to be
ripped into boards
and scantling.

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
They [grasshoppers]
actually stopped a
bullock-team this
week. The big-winged
fellows kept flying
into the faces of
the leaders ...; and
the `bullocky' had
to take his team
back to the
homestead and unyoke
them.
Notes: c1872 in c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 34

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Another play unknown
at a later date was
the widespread
Bullock Teams: It
was easy to make a
team of working
bullocks from pieces
of supplejack, with
their opposite
branches doing duty
as horns. The
manufacture of
yokes, substitutes
for chains and model
sledges gave a boy
the pleasant feeling
that accompanies
successful
achievement. Leading
the team by a piece
of string was the
next step. (1870;
Waipu)

Author: WHEELER
Quote:
[caption] Logging
pan for dragging
logs, bullock tie
(or wishbone) used
on the yoke, and in
front a logging dog
that grips the log
to prevent it from
falling off the
logging pan.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
The homesteads of
the stations thus
created were
connected with the
port of Napier
either by sea or by
rough bullock-tracks
following the lines
of old river-beds
...

The bullock track
was via the old Lake
road and some of the
swampy creeks were a
terror to cross.

Author: MCRAE
Quote:
.. for the
coming-and-going to
some of the outlying
blocks there would
of necessity have to
be a bullock track.

Author: BARKER
Quote: ... bullock-waggon
... A bullock wagon was much the same as a bullock dray, but had four wheels and was drawn by 10 or 12 bullocks. Bullocks were also driven in sledges (two or four bullocks).

Author: HYDE
Quote:
`A man has to settle
down some time. How
else did all this
grow? Our mother
came here by
bullock-wagon, when
she was eighteen.'

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
He has made a rough
track to this rough
home by smoothing
one or two extra
rough bits and
sloping off a few
creek banks to allow
bullock drays or
sledges to get
through. Sledges
were the [34] common
vehicle of the
earliest times,
followed by bullock
drays, and then,
after the diggings
broke out, by the
long-bodied,
four-wheeled bullock
wagon and also by
horse-drawn drays
and wagons with
greatly increased
accommodation.

Author: DUFF
Quote:
Bullock-wagons were
still in use when I
was a boy, but the
noises I heard the
drivers make were
certainly not music.

Author: WHEELER
Quote:
It was customary, as
at Waipiro Bay ...,
to have a wool store
and a dump press
near the beach. The
dumped wool was
taken by bullock
wagon into the surf,
transferred to
surfboats, and rowed
out to the ...
steamer lying
offshore.

Author: ROBERTS
Quote:
The whip was rawhide
plaited sinnet,
about six feet long,
thick at the upper
end, where it was
fastened to a handle
as long as itself,
but tapering nearly
to a point, to which
was attached a
narrow strip of
rawhide, called `the
fall,' finishing off
with a twisted
`cracker' made of
`weetau' or dressed
flax in [43] place
of whipcord, and was
a powerful
flagellator in the
hands of an
experienced `bullock
puncher.'
Notes: 1856 Sep 19 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 42-43

Quote: Bullock whip.- Whip used by bullock driver. It was made with a very long handle (perhaps eight feet) and a long lash. `Come here' and `gee back' were the words the driver used to turn the bullocks left and right, accompanied by a crack of the whip on the opposite side. (C.)

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
In driving bullocks
the best
bullock-whips were
made from the skins
of plump wild sows -
these skins pleated
[sic: ?plaited] well
and lasted well.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
The art of cracking
a `bullock-whip.'

Source: Ernie and the Rest of Us
Author: BOSWELL
Quote:
`Bullocky' whips
were not so long in
the leather as
stockwhips, but had
very long, flexible
handles, ...

Source: In the Lee of the Hokonuis
Author: BARRY
Quote:
This necessitated
much expert use of
the bullock whips,
and not a little
sulphurous language.

Author: CHINN
Quote:
With every rider now
concentrating on his
duties, we drove the
wild horses towards
the station bullock
yards where several
decoy horses were
quietly feeding.

Author: ROBERTS
Quote:
I yoked up the
bullocks. The
bullock yoke was a
square piece of
white pine smoothed
and hollowed out to
fit the necks of the
two bullocks, with
holes for the iron
bows which went
round the neck and
through the yoke,
being fastened above
with a key tied with
a bit of greenhide;
in the centre a bolt
with a ring called
`the start' passed
through the yoke, to
which the chain was
fastened from the
sledge.
Notes: 1856 Sep 19 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 42

Author: KELLY
Quote:
[The eels] are then
covered with the
broad leaves of the
raurikau (or
bullock's kai as it
was known by the
early settlers).

Source: Crusts: a settler's fare due south
Author: KENNAWAY
Quote:
There was a rattle
of the yokes and
bullock-chain as the
sledge tried to
follow, ...

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
... now a generation
has arisen to whom a
bullock-drawn
vehicle would be as
strange as a Roman
chariot.

Author: NESFIELD
Quote:
It was before the
days of buggies. At
any rate, buggies or
vehicles of any
[118] sort were a
rarity. The journey
had to be
accomplished in a
bullock-dray. The
station
bullock-driver was,
like all
bullock-drivers,
addicted to
swearing.

Author: CARR
Quote:
Bullock drivers who
handle from 12 to 24
animals are also
employed [in the
sawmills]. ... A
good `Bullocky' is
like a good
shepherd, his voice
is seldom heard. ...
The saying ... to
`swear like a
bullock driver', is
common.

... she heard
Bloomfield say that
Price was a dirty
bullock-driver.

... bullock-drivers,
stockmen and
carpenters.

Thursday week we met
to the number of
ninety-five
visitors, besides
bullock drivers and
some Maoris ...

... you have the
Canterbury
bullock-driver
before you.

Author: PAUL
Quote:
As soon as maybe
after his arrival,
[the new settler]
engages himself as a
shepherd, or
bullock-driver, or
hut-keeper at a
station, ... makes a
hut of sod or wattle
and dab, ...
encloses [his land]
with ... a post and
rail or ditch and
bank fence.

McGill bullock
driver ... All hands
washing Humes ewes.

Shennan's and
Black's drays came
with four bales
wool. Bullock
drivers taking a
spell.'
Notes: 1859 Oct 23 Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 102

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
I am informed that
the having
faithfully learned
the ingenuous arts,
has so far mollified
his morals that he
is an exceedingly
humane and judicious
bullock-driver.

Built grate in
fireplace; put up
bunk for bullock
drivers.
Notes: 1861 July 1 Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 78

Author: WALKER
Quote:
(Central Otago) I am
bullock driver,
although it is hard
work I prefer it to
selling [in a
store].

We are a good party
here, two shepherds
and one bullock
driver, gentlemen's
sons, Tennant a
cadet, he used to be
at Harman's.

Thousands of sheep
now depasture on
that well-remembered
corner of `the
plains,' on those
gently-swelling
downs; ... we have
the bleating of
flocks, the bark of
the colley[sic] as
it rounds up its
charge, the loud
crack of the
stockwhip, the
hearty curse of the
bullock driver
delivered `ore
rotundo'; ...

April, 1861 - It is Sunday. We rose later than usual. There are five men sleeping in the hut. I sleep in a bunk on one side of the fire, Mr. Haast ... sleeps upon the opposite one; my bullock-driver and hut-keeper have two bunks at the far end of the hut, along the wall; ... The usual mutton and bread for breakfast with a pudding made of flour and water baked in the camp-oven after a joint of meat - Yorkshire pudding, but without eggs. While we were at breakfast, a robin perched on the table and sat there a good while pecking at the sugar.
Notes: 1861 April Butler's Note in 1919 Jones Samuel Butler - A Memoir 1/87

Quote: Bullock-driver. - Man employed to drive bullocks. The old nickname for him was bullocky, bullock-puncher being a much later word. Bullocks on the road have to feed until about 10 a.m., so that bullockies were generally lazy, slow starters in the morning. They were famous for swearing, and the old story of the parson who said, `Even a bullock driver has a soul to be saved' is still told up country. (C.; 1898 Morris Austral-English) [c1962 One of the last bullock teams was driven (ceremonially) in Canterbury in 1962.]

Source: Vacation Tour at the Antipodes, A
Author: HEYWOOD
Quote:
... bullock-driver
...

Author: VON TEMPSKY
Quote:
On the Wairoa Road,
Hewitt, a
commissariat man,
and a bullock driver
by the name of
Hamlyn were shot;
...

Author: THATCHER
Quote:
If nice expressions
you would learn,/
Colonial and new,/
Some bullock driver
who is bogged,/ Is
just the man for
you:

Author: COTTLE
Quote:
As long as a man
earns what he wants
on the square, ...
we don't care a rap
whether he is a
Member of Parliament
or So-and-so's
bullock-driver.

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
Every now and then
he leaves his up
country avocations.
He then returns to
his shepherding,
cooking,
bullock-driving ...
Notes: 1860 Mar 24 in 1863 Butler First Year iv/50

Source: Grif: a Story of Colonial Life
Author: FARJEON
Quote:
... bullock-driving
is scarcely a
gentlemanly
occupation...

Author: MONEY
Quote:
I took the job of
hedge-trimming at
first, and, after
having finished this
all round the
station land, which
consisted of some
1500 acres parcelled
off into paddocks
and fields, I began
to pick up
bullock-driving; ...

Author: BATHGATE
Quote:
Talking of
bullock-driving
reminds me of an
incident that
occurred the other
day, and which
rather amused me at
the time.

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
In 1860 he was
bullock-driving for
Low of Galloway ..

I was once called
upon to endeavour to
obtain compensation
from a native who
had destroyed ...
several hundred
yards of stout
bullock-fence. ...
[29] ... rushing at
the posts and rails,
[he] vented his rage
in chopping them to
pieces with his axe.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
The first day was
devoted to a
ploughing match, for
bullock-ploughs and
for horse-ploughs.
... only eleven
ploughs were on the
ground, seven of
which were
bullock-teams ...

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
A season or two
later bullock
ploughs were used
...

Source: Some Schools & Schoolmasters of Early Wellington
Author: McMORRAN
Quote:
Sometimes [the
cattle] took charge
of the town, and
almost defied the
efforts of the
experience "bullock
punchers" in charge
to pen them in the
yards provided for
them.

Author: W H S ROBERTS
Quote:
The whip was rawhide
plaited sinnet,
about six feet long,
thick at the upper
end, where it was
fastened to a handle
as long as itself,
but tapering nearly
to a point, to which
was attached a
narrow strip of
rawhide, called `the
fall,' finishing off
with a twisted
`cracker' made of
`weetau' or dressed
flax in [43] place

puncher.'
Notes: 1856 Sep 19 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 42-43

Author: INGLIS
Quote:
The whare with its
idle group of
Crimean-shirted
stockmen ...
bullock-punchers,
horse-breakers,
fencers and general
rouseabouts ... came
back to us.

Author: D'AVIGDOR
Quote: A bullock-puncher is a man engaged to drive bullocks to market or port. The expression is painfully true, as these men, who receive but very poor wages, and are recruited from the worst class, ill treat the poor animals by punching their sides with a pointed stick.

Author: BROOKES
Quote:
One of the
bullock-punchers did
his duty for him.

A stream of
adjectives one would
hardly expect from a
bullock-puncher.

Author: BOOTH
Quote:
[In the
accommodation house
were] the
villainous-looking
'lag' from
't'otherside', the
bullock puncher,
whose every
alternate word was a
profane oath, the
stockrider, in his
guernsey shirt and
knee boots ...

~ Man employed to drive bullocks. The old nickname for him was bullocky, bullock-puncher being a much later word. Bullocks on the road have to feed until about 10 a.m., so that bullockies were generally lazy, slow starters in the morning. They were famous for swearing, and the old story of the parson who said, `Even a bullock driver has a soul to be saved' is still told up country. (C.; 1898 Morris Austral-English)

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
The next day the
snow had almost
ceased so the
`bullock-puncher'
pushed his mob on as
fast as conditions
allowed.

He said he received
the earliest part of
his training in
public speaking as a
"bullock puncher" in
the district where
the new pastor was
born.

The town of Tapanui
had now started, and
the sawyers,
bush-fellers and
'bullock-punchers'
put up their
temporary huts.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
Owners and employees
had worked shoulder
to shoulder as ..
bullock-punchers.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
bullocky, bullock
puncher: by
tradition the
bullockies were
considered the most
fluent and
imaginative swearers
of all. [bullock
puncher]

Author: ROBERTS
Quote:
The whip..was a
powerful flagellator
in the hands of an
experienced
'bullock-puncher.'
Notes: in Beattie (1947) Early Runholding in Otago

Source: Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point
Author: PHILLIPPS
Quote:
Heavy bullock
punching.

Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
After a spell of
`quill-driving' it
takes one a week or
so to get into one's
stride of splitting,
fencing,
bullock-punching
again; ...
Meanwhile, one can
make good money at
hard graft.

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
I have returned to
my old occupation of
jackaroo, and am at
present at
Fernyhurst
[Station]. ... Only
a shepherd is
employed here
besides myself; so I
have to do the
milking and
bullock-punching and
make myself
generally useful.

Author: cham
Quote:
He soon got charge
of a team and was
loud in expatiating
upon the art of
bullock-punching.

Source: Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point
Author: PHILLIPPS
Quote:
T.A.P. & J.P.
bullock punching -
carting stones into
creek &c. I.I. home
in morning and
weeding - killed 3
sheep. Tuesday 10th/
very fine & hot/
N.E/ Heavy bullock
punching - stone
carting &c. I.I.
weeding G.S.P. for
mail - Seal up from
Xchurch by mailman

Author: CLIFFORD
Quote:
It would be easy to
bring a

Author: BARKER
Quote: Bullock sledges.

bridecake, which ...

macintosh.

Author: ARTHUR
Quote:
I once saw ... a
bullocker who was
working with his
team.

Author: REED
Quote:
While bullocking on
a skidded road ...
During bullocking
operations in a
portion of Puhipuhi,
a nineteen foot log
was being taken out
on a catamaran.

Author: SATCHELL
Quote:
`There's no
bullocking attached
to the job; all
that'll be done for
you.'

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
Sam hadn't long been

Sam and three other

Quote:
In his crippled old

bullocking days when
one could march all
day with a

...

Author: GASKELL
Quote:
Big bullocking
bastards always
mauling each other
about.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
Now the bullocking
forward is king of
the field and the
game is to work
close down the

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote:
Describes manual
labour demanding
mainly brute
strength;`It's
uphill and in gravel
soil down there. To
dig a trench would

work; I wouldn't
tackle it, anyway.'
bullocking adj. hard arduous, i.e. bullocking work.

Mansfield did some
good work for
Ponsonby, though
still inclined to do
a little
'bullocking'.

Author: FROBISHER
Quote:
To use his own
emphatic expression,
he set his face
against all such
senseless
"bullocking" [sc. in
dancing]

Author: BAKER
Quote: The noun bullocky has even been evolved to describe the language used by such men.

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote: Bullocky has been used to describe the language supposed to be characteristic of bullock-drivers.

Author: FANNING
Quote:
Those were the times
[20 years ago] of
packs of [rugby]
Goliaths, brawny but
`bullocky'.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
Then the swine made
a bullocky rush for
home, though too
late, the gate
withstanding the
impact.

Author: ANGUS
Quote:
Swearing was
elevated to an art
form by the most
fluent bullockies
and shepherds

Clear the road, make
room for the

Australy.

Author: McKEE WRIGHT
Quote:
When the bullockies
came with their
load, boys

Author: COX
Quote:
Clear the road, make
room for the
bullocky from
Australy.

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote: They [grasshoppers] actually stopped a bullock-team this week. The big-winged fellows kept flying into the faces of the leaders ...; and the `bullocky' had to take his team back to the homestead and unyoke them. Ibid. 72 To my astonishment, the bullocky headed his team straight for the river where it was quite unfordable.

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
It was interesting
to watch the
leaders. The pair in
front [sc. of the
bullock team] were
the leaders, they
answered commands
immediately, and the
bullocky could get
them to do all sorts
of things.

I've been told that
I'm the only
bullocky left.
I said to Chris,"Let me help you into the dray, you are exhausted." I was told in no uncertain terms that "bullockies do not ride in the dray!"

Author: VANCE
Quote:
It became the
stopover places for
bullockies,
wagoners, drovers
and wayfarers.

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
No bullocky ever
loved a tui, for the
simple reason that
these birds are
great imitators, and
they would often
lead these
bullockies astray.
The bullocky would
follow what he
thought was the
sound of one of his
bells, and instead,
find a tui up a
tree.

Author: CHAMIER
Quote:
`And as for them
bullockies' said
she, ...

Author: WRIGHT
Quote:
When the bullockies
came with their

Author: EDEN

Author: CARR
Quote:
Bullock drivers who
handle from 12 to 24
animals are also

Notes: 1925 William Andrew's Recollections in 1980 Neave The Land of Munros 58

Quote: bull n. ...bullocky n. sl. a driver of a bullock team.

~ Man employed to drive bullocks. The old nickname for him was bullocky, bullock-puncher being a much later word. Bullocks on the road have to feed until about 10 a.m., so that bullockies were generally lazy, slow starters in the morning. They were famous for swearing, and the old story of the parson who said, `Even a bullock driver has a soul to be saved' is still told up country. (C.; 1898 Morris Austral-English)

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
The Waimea run
belonged to ...
McKellar and the
station consisted of
two sod huts, one
for the two bosses
and the other for
the men, the latter
being a `bullocky',

boy.

Author: BEATTIE

Quote: Bullocky. Also a New Zealand usage. Both in New Zealand and in Australia, prob. since ca1840 or 1850.

In its early days,

Grandfather Bill

He might be given

Certainly not butter
or jam, which were
not very plentiful

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
`Yeh. I'll bet a 7
pound tin of

he's still alive
alright.'

Author: WHEELER
Quote:
Doug still remembers
the hungry stations
where they ate old
ewe, potatoes, rice
pudding and, at the

said `brownie' was
cake. We knew it
only as bread dyed
