(treacle), and
sparingly dotted
with currants.

Quote:

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
The sledge would
slide over [the
logs]. Usually they
were helped by the
bullocky's mate., or
offsider, who would
go along with the
most evil-smelling
tin of fat.. and
spread the fat on
the skids where the

to assist the
bullocks and move
their load along
more easily.

This week they did
it with huge dollops
of character in
front of 25,000 fans
in a frenzied
cauldron dubbed the
Bull Ring.

Allen was reluctant
to comment on
whether he expected
to resume the
captaincy of the
Taranaki side in
"the Bullring", as
Rugby Park has
become known.

O'Brien, who
masterminded the..
thrilling defence in
a packed Bullring,
said he would like
to see players in
his own squad.. gain
some financial
benefit.

What's hurting at
the moment is the
fact the provincial
team has lost two
NPC games on the
trot at the Bullring
in New Plymouth.

Before preference to
unionists was passed
the pay [for coal
workers in the
Wellington Branch of
the Waterside
Workers' Federation]
was per hour for
shovellers 1s 6d and
for top hands (i.e.
winchmen,
bullrope-men,
trimmers, and
tippers), 1s 3d.

The kids formed a
slampit - a wider,
more open and more

moshpit - and
started bullrushing
the other fans from
the opposite sides
of the arena.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
Bullrush involved as
many of the school
as possible, all at
one end of the
paddock, one person
in the middle. At
the cry of
'bullrush' we all
ran and he had to
catch one of us. It
was also called
Charlie across the
water and kingaseeny

In its simplest form
bullrush involved
one person standing
in the middle of the
field, then everyone
else lined up on one
side. The middle
person would call
someone's name
(often in a rhyming
way) into the
middle. The object
being of course to
get past the middle
to the other end of
the field. If the
runner was caught he
or she joined the
middle to call and
catch more runners.
Should a single
runner get through
there would be a
bullrush, where
everyone ran through
the middle... These
games had a thousand
different names in
earlier times:
broken barley, king
dick, punch king
(where you had to
punch the runner
down!), goosey and
so on... An
excellent variation
was.. cockarusha, in
which everyone,
instead of running,
tries to hop through
the middle.

Life itself is like
a game of bullrush.
Maybe that's why it
is now virtually
banned in every
school in NZ, its
[sic] too rough...
Hayley has fond
memories of
bullrush, "That's
where you got your
boyfriends..."

It's like a game of
bullrush, in which
the single-objective
SOE rushes to the
finish line, and
everyone else gets a
quick yank of the
jersey if they're
quick.

"There are lots of
games children don't
play any more such
as bullrush - now
octopus - stuck in
the mud, and french
skipping. ..."

"I drank a lot and
watched AUSA
[Auckland University
Students'
Association] try to
play 'Bullrush', a
sleazy
hitting-n-chicks
game."

It's like a game of
bullrush, in which
the single-objective
SOE rushes to the
finish line, and
everyone else gets a
quick yank of its
jersey if they're
quick.

Their frenzied games
- tickling, playing
bullrush, giving one
another Chinese
burns - had an
element of
schoolyard sadism
that linked with a
generalised sense of
the grotesque.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
`Do you play Bull
Rush at your
school?' John asked.
`Bull Rush?' said
Ewan. ... `You get
out on the field and
draw a line at the
ends. You pick
someone to be He to
stand in the middle.
He calls out
someone's name, and
he has to get across
to the other end.
The guard has to try
to tackle the runner
and hit him three
times. But if the
runner gets across
he calls out Bull
Rush and everyone
runs ...[sic]'
`That's
King-a-Sene!' said
Ewan. `But we're
only allowed to tag
the player, we're
not allowed to
tackle him ...'[sic]
... `Do you play
with the girls at
all?' `Sometimes we
play Drop the
Handkerchief. The
girls can join in.
But most of the time
they play Eely Ily
Oh, or Queenie, or
some cissy game like
that...'[sic] `Do
you play shinty or
football?' `Yeah.
Football. And we
play scrag in the
winter and tippeny
runs in the
summer...'[sic]

Author: WATSON
Quote: Some other children have come over from the neighbouring [58] farm and they're all playing bullrush. Bullrush! they shout, and Ida runs across the lawn with flying hair and Selby, the youngest, trails the others as they dive after her.

But taking them back
to our house for
pizza and cake was a
mistake, and the
game of bullrush was
a serious
miscalculation...

The street.. was
still as good for a
game of cricket or
bullrush as it had
been a generation
before.

Is there one single
New Zealamnder who
has not played
bullrush in some
form or other?...
There are
variations. The main
one is the classic
'bar the door'
(which for some
phonetically evolved
into 'barbador'),
where the main
difference is that
runners line up at
both ends of the
field. These games
had a thousand names
in earlier days:
broken barley, king
dick, punch king
(where you had to
punch the runner
down), goosey and so
on... Kerikeri
school banned it
(they called it king
asini) three years
ago.

In the foreground,
the under-10 Dragons
finish with
bullrush. They have
already dodged
puddles and clay
clods to get to the
gym, but there is
energy left for
threading round
team-mates to reach
the other side.

Author: NATUSCH
Quote: The common bully (Gobiomorphus sp(p)) is plentiful at river mouths, and occurs also in some upland lakes like Te Anau and Alexandria. The giant bully, G. gobioides, grows up to nine inches long - three inches longer than the biggest common bully - and is most often met with in lowland lake, swamps and spring-fed creeks.

Author: NATUSCH
Quote: BULLIES: Sub-order GOBIOIDEA Bullies are not the same as cockabullies. The family these rather severe-faced fishes belong to is widely distributed over moderately warm and even tropical countries, and reaches its southern most distribution in New Zealand. The bully family is called Gobiidae by some writers, Eleotridae by others. Bullies are spiny-rayed fishes with the paired ventral fins placed well foward; they have a genital papilla for passing out eggs or sperms; and the males look different from the females. Two genera are recognised at present, Gobiomorphus and Philypnodon.

Author: spei
Quote: The whitebait runs begin definitely in August and continue through the two following months; but in November the shoals begin to include young smelts and bullies (Gobiomorphus) which prey actively upon the whitebait, the bullies being particularly voracious. ... Ibid. Of the two gobies, more often called `bullies,' are by far the better known. Gobiomorphus gobioides is small, but active and voracious, and can be seen in all slender streams and watercourses darting across the bottom, for `bullies' keep low down.
Notes: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 196

Author: SUTTON-SMITH

Marbles had a

referring to
particular kinds of
marbles: for

aggies, aggotties,
American alleys,
blood alleys,
bomb-squashers,
bonies, bonsers,
bottlies, bull's

cat's eyes, chinkies
...

to this is the
"bumbarber" - the
man who dags the
sheep for the
shearer.

Author: ELLISON
Quote:
I never saw a
Britisher who knew
anything about the

A favourite mode of
attack in New
Zealand is the bump,
that is the player
with the leather
crouches himself
while going at full
speed, and butts
with all his force
(using hip or
shoulder) at the
opponent who is
essaying to tackle.

We read.. of..
"Jack" Taiaroa with
his wonderful hip
and shoulder bump.
and in a way we ask.
ourselves if our
glory has not
departed.

Source: Rugby Players Who Have Made NZ Famous

either caused by a
blow, or swollen or
discoloured, etc.
through sickness.
.in 4;`He's got a
bung eye.'
bung adj. Austral. sl. 1. dead. 2. destroyed. 3. useless. 4. go bung. a. to fail or collapse. b. to die. [C19: < Abor.]

of latex rubber,
bound together into
a cord.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote: ... a `bunk', or wooden shelf, supported Colonel Wakefield's bed. 1845 Ibid. 1/330 For the information of those who do not know what a bunk is, I must explain that it is a bed place built against the wall of a house or ship.

Author: H S CHAPMAN
Quote:
The squatters' huts,
[...] are native
built whare's
improved in their
form and size by
imitating our
cottages. The
sleeping place is a
`bunk' or standing
bed place as on
board ship ... The
whare consists of
one large room with
a bunk in each
corner - a standing
table between each
pair of bunks and
one large clay
chimney.
Notes: 1847 Nov 24 H.S. Chapman Letters to His Father [TS,ATB] in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 140

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
On our arrival, the
only quarters we
could procure were
two rooms of a
weather-boarded
house, ... The
architect had
probably been a
ship's carpenter,
for he had fitted up
one of the rooms
with tiers of [9]
sleeping places of
the form called by
sailors bunks.

Source: Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point
Author: PHILLIPPS
Quote:
John jobbing - Harry
putting up Bunk in
back room -

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
... Laying ourselves
down for the night
on the beaches or
bunks [in an
accommodation-house].

Author: MONEY
Quote:
It [the run
manager's residence]
consisted at this
time of only one
small slab hut, with
four bunks and a
chimney; a couple of
hundred yards away
was an old wool
shed, ...

Author: BARKER
Quote: Station bunks - that is wooden bed-frames of the simplest and rudest construction, with a sacking bottom.

Author: PYKE
Quote:
The bunks - rude
structures of bush
poles, with flour
bag sacking - had
been torn down; and
clothing ... heaped
pell-mell on the
floor.

Source: Story of a NZ River, The
Author: MANDER
Quote:
As he strode into
the kitchen now, men
near his bunk made
way for him.

Author: FOSTON
Quote:
[New chum speaks]
`What is a bunk,
sir?' `Oh, a rough
bedstead.'
Bunk. A bed, whether made of wood in a hut, like a berth in a ship, or of fern and tussock in a tent. ([1874 Lady Barker Station Life], p.34)

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
It is Sunday. We
rose later than
usual. There are
five men sleeping in
the hut. I sleep in
a bunk on one side
of the fire, Mr.
Haast ... sleeps
upon the opposite
one; my
bullock-driver and
hut-keeper have two
bunks at the far end
of the hut, along
the wall; ... The
usual mutton and
bread for breakfast
with a pudding made
of flour and water
baked in the
camp-oven after a
joint of meat -
Yorkshire pudding,
but without eggs.
While we were at
breakfast, a robin
perched on the table
and sat there a good
while pecking at the
sugar.
Notes: 1861 April Butler's Note in 1919 Jones Samuel Butler - A Memoir 1/87 April, 1861 -

Quote:
Built grate in
fireplace; put up
bunk for bullock
drivers.
Notes: 1861 July 1 Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 78

Author: WALKER
Quote:
... a tolerable
shakedown in a
woodshed fitted with
bunks.

Author: LADY CAMPBELL
Quote:
The beds [of
whalers' huts], or,
as they are called,
`bunks', are
arranged after the
fashion of the
berths in a ship,
two deep, and
curtained.

Author: BARKER
Quote: We peeped in at the men's huts ... two rows of `bunks' (berths, I should call them). Ibid. 90 [The bushman] began to make plans for F- and me to stop [at back-country station hut] all night, offering to give up his `bunk' (some slabs of wood made into a shelf, with a tussock mattress and a blanket).

Author: HISLOP
Quote:
There were some
jokes going round
that night in the
two-roomed shack
full of bunks.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
The ship term `bunk'
was applied to the
beds built against
the walls in the
men's huts.
Bunk, probably American in origin, was early in use in New Zealand. Edward Jerningham Wakefield felt it necessary to describe it as a `wooden shelf' for his readers, when he found it in use here.
Notes: [see also MAORI BUNK (trampers')] Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

Author: HAMILTON
Quote:
In the [mustering]
hut were two bunks,
a tucker box, an old
frying pan, various
billies and a
teapot.
bunk: The name for a shearer's bed. Years ago shearer's bunks were often in three tiers and made up with straw filled palliasses for mattresses and borrowed woolpacks for warmth.

Author: G.B. Lancaster (contributor)
Quote:
Think I'll go to
bunk.

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
Hunting pignuts on
all fours/ In the
great funfair none
do well./ Tom likes
boys and Bob likes
whores/ And both
will share a bunk in
Hell.

Author: DEVANNY
Quote:
He was bunking in
with Jimmy Burns in
the big hut.

Author: DEVANNY
Quote:
The single men ate
in the cookhouse and
bunked singly or in
groups, in huts.

Author: ADSETT
Quote:
I'm not fussy so
long as she keeps
her skirts out of
the bloody spokes.
Last [girl] I bunked
home took me hours
to unwind her.
bunk: to miss school

Author: WILKINSON
Quote:
`Truancy' is by no
means an objective
word ... `Why are
you bunking?' I said
to a Maori pupil I
met in the Square an
hour before school
officially finished.
`I'm waiting for a
bus, sir.' `Well,
you're still
bunking' ... `Sir,
I'm on my way home.
Bunking is when you
hang around the
square instead of
going to school or
home'.

After a couple of
close shaves of
expulsion (for quite
harmless stunts such
as smoking and
"bunking out" to
hitchhike to the
local beaches) I
then finished my
schooling at
Pakuranga College.

Author: LORD
Quote:
We say a man is ...
/ I nearly forgot to
mention `blue
blind', `bunkered',
and `brimful'

Author: WHEELER
Quote:
[caption] Remains of
the cookshop and
bunkhouse in
`Cookshop Gully'.

Author: OWEN
Quote:
I'll off to bunky,
or I shan't wake.
bunnies [=] harestail [s]

Other well-known
[drinking] games are
Hokonui Swindle,
Bottles, Fluffy
Ducks, Bunnies are
Hovering, Cardinal
Huff, All Blacks,
Matches, and The
Amazing Grimaldi
Brothers. All these
games involve either
a complicated
intellectual
exercise, tongue
twisters,
mathematical
calculations or
aerobatics in a
confined space; High
Candelabras for
example, involves
intoxicated
individuals
attempting to
traverse the four
walls of a room
without touching the
floor.

Author: Geary
Quote:
He set up chairs by
the power
sub-station back in
Bunny.

Accompanied by Roger
Douglas and David
Caygill they left
their Mangere Hotel
via a rear entrance
and using a bunny
car as a decoy gave
the press the slip
and made their way
circuitously to the
airport where they
got clearance to
drive on to the
tarmac ...

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote:
BUNNY (n) Stupid
incompetent person.
British slang since
early 20th century.

Then, on the other
side of the coin
from the `apathetic
students', there is
a group which
decries the
administration I
have talked about as
`bourgeois,
capitalist and
politically
unsound'. They want
to advance Students
Associations as
bases for radical
political movements
rather than
`conservative'
servicing of the
membership;
students. There are
a number of
descriptive terms -
`loonies', `bozos',
`bunnies' and
`touchie-feelies' -
in general, the
`looney left'.
bunny: young person disco bunny: young teenager

Author: MANTELL
Quote:
So you're the bunny
coming up from
Wellington. Thought
you were driving up.
[policeman to
another policeman]

Changes to our
lunchtime habits has
[sic] really
benefited the
bunrunner - an
office-trawling,
basket-toting food
seller.

[She] developed an
interest in the
souffle-like rise of
the bunrunning
industry after a
"horrid" bout of
food poisoning she
suspects came from a
chicken sandwich.

"During milking they
will come up and
give me a bunt on
the shoulder to
remind me they want
a scratch."

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: buntuck. A New Zealand soldiers' variant of bundook q.v.: in G.W. [bundook a riflef. Arabic: 18c.]

From Arabic came
`buntock,' a rifle,
and `moira,' a
drink; from
Egyptian, `buckshee'
and `disaster' for
piastre.
Notes: McNab NZ Slang [Slang of the NZEF

Quote: bur medick [s] Medicago polymorpha L. ... bur medick, small [=] woolly bur medick [s] ... bur medick, woolly [s] Medicago minima (L.) Bart. Ibid. 74 spotted bur medick [s] Medicago arabica (L.) Huds. Ibid. 88 woolly bur medick [s] Medicago minima (L.) Bart.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: BUR MEDICK (Medicago polymorpha) ... Introduced from Eurasia, this clover is common throughout New Zealand

Thank heaven, Turner
and Riley, after
having the series
turned down by the
networks, persevered
with these burbelles
(belles from the
'burb)...

Author: McARA
Quote: Burden: The amount of ground to be broken by a charged blasthole.

The Lyttelton
waterfront has been
working under the
bureau system of
engaging labour for
nine years now. ...
`And,' the bureau
manager said, `the
men wouldn't like to
go back to the old
way again.' Under
the old system,
foremen of the
various shipping
companies stood on a
small platform or
block with the men
awaiting employment
before them and
nominated those they
required to work
their own ships. The
trouble with this
`auction block'
system, as it was
called, was that
each company tended
to give preference
to a certain group
of men. It engaged
the same men first
all the time and
employed others only
when the preferred
group were all at
work. This meant
very often the
available work on
the waterfront was
not evenly shared;
and that's what the
bureau system tries
to avoid.

The Lyttelton
waterfront has been
working under the
bureau system of
engaging labour for
nine years now. ...
`And,' the bureau
manager said, `the
men wouldn't like to
go back to the old
way again.' Under
the old system,
foremen of the
various shipping
companies stood on a
small platform or
block with the men
awaiting employment
before them and
nominated those they
required to work
their own ships. The
trouble with this
`auction block'
system, as it was
called, was that
each company tended
to give preference
to a certain group
of men. It engaged
the same men first
all the time and
employed others only
when the preferred
group were all at
work. This meant
very often the
available work on
the waterfront was
not evenly shared;
and that's what the
bureau system tries
to avoid.

I am in Westport, a
small burg about 650
km south of
Auckland.

Author: EDDIE ATTWOOD
Quote:
After a long day's
railway travelling
broken by a stop at
Taihape and again at
Marton, which
allowed us time to
become acquainted
with those rising
burgs, we arrived
safely back in the
bosom of the family.
Notes: Eddie Attwood's Diary in NZ Memories No. 36, June-July, 2002, p. 35

Author: CLYDE
Quote:
In smaller towns
there is sometimes
indifference to
anything outside
`the murmur of their
burg.'

Author: DEVANNY
Quote:
The men and women in
this little burg ...

Author: MORRIESON
Quote:
They don't need cops
in this town. Girl
guides could control
this burg.

Author: MORRIESON
Quote:
`What say we go down
to my burg and scoff
some home-brew ...'

Author: MANTELL
Quote:
`Coupla years. Must
be. When I first
came to this burg.'

Author: O'SULLIVAN
Quote:
TINY: ... not as if
this [prison camp]
is a submarine or
something. JACKO:
Might as well bloody
be. Locked up in
this burg.

Source: Best New Zealand Fiction, Vol 4, The
Quote:
Did some more burgs
and went back
inside.
Notes: 'The Feijoa is Brother to the Guava', David Eggleton, 2007

Quote:
"Lock me up" he
cried. "I've done a
burg."

He got in with the
wrong crowd, and
went on "burgs" with
them... He quit the
mob, but kept on
with the burgs.

I got in with mob
kids and started
crime... I wasn't
going to do it again
after my first burg
but it gets to you,
it's exciting,so I
did it again.

He was had up for
burgs (burglaries)
and assault on a
girl (not me!)

The other thing that
makes you
exasperated with the
Sunday Theatre you
were so looking
forward to is the
Kathy solution to
everything - go do a
burg and really big
one that all your
friends and lovers
are involved in and
which as sure as
night follows day
goes all terribly
wrong and everybody
dies except for you.

"You can do heaps of
burgs without being
sent to jail," a
15-year-old boy
said.

Author: HARGREAVES
Quote:
He still comes down
to the wharf
occasionally to
burgle a feed of
dabs.

Author: MEEK
Quote:
BURGON AND BALL:
Hand shears with a
single bow.
Present-day shears
have a double bow.
Burgon and Ball: Brand of sheep-shears with a single bow.

Author: LYON
Quote:
Some of the old
country farmers
supplied beer with
the food [for
mowers], but as a
general rule,
excesses led to tea
or water from soaked
oatmeal, called
burgoo, as being
more suitable.

Sailors [sic] word for porridge. Here the word is applied to the oat-meal and water taken to the woolshed or harvest field to be drunk between smoke-ohs. I have also heard it called beer and brose. (C.)

Author: COULSON
Quote:
Lime juice went out
of fashion owing to
complaints of
heartburn, and
oatmeal and water,
or 'burgoo' as it
was called, became
the universal drink.

A waiter is usually
supposed to be
familiar with such
democratic
breakfasts as
"burgoo" and ham and
eggs, such dinners
as corned beef and
carrots, and plum
duff.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
It knocks burgoo on
the head / When
you've got no
blooming bread.

Author: HODDER
Quote:
Breakfast ...
generally consisted
of a pot of bergou
each - a farinaceous
dish, known by the
Scotch as `porridge'
and by the English
as `chicken's food.'

The [prisoners]
partake of ... a
pewter plateful of
porridge, or bergoo.

Author: MONEY
Quote: Though rationed off for a short time to a pannikin of burgoo morning and evening ... we ran short ... Ibid. 112 [Goldfields] Boiling our billy of burgoo for tea.

Author: CHAMIER
Quote:
... `burgoo' [is]
oatmeal porridge.

Author: McHUTCHESON
Quote: [Burgoo very frequent]

With the long list
of Labor [sic]
members in mind
since the time of
Ballance, when
McLaren was eating
burgoo on his native
heath, people looked
for an explanation
of this statement.

Burgoo : porridge
(used by seamen).

Author: MACFARLANE
Quote:
[The Scot's] home
menu of burgoo and
remnants.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
Ya couldn't get work
shovellin burgoo to
a Scotchman.

Author: MacKENZIE
Quote: burgoo porridge
burgoo: An old term for porridge.

I want 'em for the
"bergou" in the
morning.

See-saw, Johnny
McGraw Ate Burgoo
till he strained his
jaw.

A propos of the Scot
and his "burgoo."

Oscar, a dark horse,
surprised everyone
by a cooking
demonstration of a
"burgoo."

Source: Lay of the Old Identities, The
Author: BLAIR
Quote:
Or like to hungry
Scots' burgoo - /
Off to the Diggings.

Author: KING
Quote:
In some of these
holes we could see
these carved atamiro
- burial chests, the
pakeha called them,
like little canoes.

Author: BURGESS
Quote:
Sullivan said: `It
was a pity; he was
such a nice young
fellow. I then made
him sit down and
there we strangled
him. ...' [105]
Sullivan in his
revelation of the
tragedy said, `We
burked him.'

If every man with a
wife could burke his
deservings there
wouldn't be a
bachelor in the
country.

Author: LANCASTER
Quote:
... came rain in
ruled lines that
caused Clint to burk
the soaked fern
[-bed] and crouch
over the fire.

Author: LANCASTER
Quote:
He had saved his
craven life at the
undercut bluff when
it parted the mob
wayback in the dry
creek, and had so
burked all the work
that came after.

Author: LANCASTER
Quote:
I'll exchange [my
job] ... But I won't
burk.

Author: McGILL
Quote: burk to avoid work, c.1880-1920; G.B. Lancaster in Sons o' Men: `I'll exchange ... but I won't burk, see?' [plagiarised from P8]

The average New
Zealander, still
endowed with the
sturdy independence
and the strong
individuality of his
pioneer forebears,
is inclined to birk
at restrictions as
what he may do -
particularly with
his property.

He needs to prove
the party is a
collection of
complementary
talents, not a
motley Burkes [sic]
Bin.

`GET YOURSELF a
Burke,' he says.
`I've already got a
boss,' I say. `But
does he help you
shift rubbish?' he
asks ... And then I
realise we are at
cross purposes. In
my time I've met
plenty of Right
Burkes (they
invariably wear
walkshorts) and even
one Left Burke
(who's the Member
for West Coast), but
the Burke's bin is a
newy on me.

Author: WATSON
Quote:
And if they hadn't
made up their
quarrel there'd be
no Ida to have in
turn, ... and no
Selby to rummage in
the Burkes bins
around the city
streets.

Worst Case Scenario.. gave one that distinct feeling that helpful handy hints such as how to jump off a burning building and into a dumpster, or what we'd call a Burke's bin, and survive a 35-foot leap, was a telly show response to September 11.

It started over a
Burke's bin in the
wrong place, the
violence the more
terrifying for its
apparent
unpredictability.

The other side of
the 'Burke's bin
case' was pretty
awful, too.

Source: Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success
Quote:
She threw a burko,
which only added to
my case.

Something's got to
be done to encourage
the right class of
hommes to give it a
burl.

Source: For the Rest of Our Lives
Author: DAVIN
Quote:
And so while [my
wounded leg] was
still ugly and they
weren't worrying I'd
give it a burl. And
I made it, got clean
away.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
Come round, she
said, it'll be open
slather. Might [181]
as well give it a
birl.

Author: MASON
Quote:
MRS JOHNSON ...: I
don't know how I'll
sing without a
piano. JOHNSON: Give
it a burl, old girl.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
He'll give it a
burl, that boy, I'll
give him that in.

Author: McCLENAGHAN
Quote:
He's all right.
We'll give it a burl
for a while.
burl or birl n. Austral. & N.Z. inf. 1. a ride in a car. 2. an attempt; try (esp. in give it a burl). [C20: ? < BIRL in Scots sense: to spin or turn]

Author: McGILL
Quote: give it a birl/burl make an attempt; from causing the coin to spin in the game of two-up; also give it a go and give it a pop; eg `If nobody else will ride the damn horse, I'll give it a birl/go/pop.' Mostly NZA.

Author: HURSTHOUSE
Quote:
The fleeces should
not be tied up with
strings; the lint
mixes with the wool,
and makes what are
called `burls;' no
tying is requisite.

BURL. A tumour-like
woody swelling on
the trunk or branch
of a tree. Syn. E.
Burr.

... the far more
valuable bituminous
field opened up at
Stockton is served
by a road whose
description is the
ominous half-truth,
the `Burma Road'.

Went on the hills
burning and Greenly
lit a fire on a spur
that had grass and
flax six feet high
on it.

Source: Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point
Author: PHILLIPS
Quote:
T.A.P. ... went
towards Rockwood
[run] in the
afternoon to burn -
...

Source: Farming in the Mohaka State Forest
Author: WRIGHT
Quote:
The burn-and-graze
technique most
commonly used in
farms such as those
in the Mohaka region
during the
nineteenth century
was developed by
Archdeacon Samuel
Williams and
J.H.Coleman, who
discovered that fern
could be burnt in
January when the sap
was up, and that
regrowth would
mature in about a
month.

Source: Farming in the Mohaka State Forest
Author: WRIGHT
Quote:
Because this
expansion into
marginal land was
coupled with farming
techniques - such as
the 'burn and graze'
method of running
sheep - that led to
the rapid
degradation of the
land, it was not
long before farming
became impossible in
some areas...

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
Saw large mob of
sheep on the new
burn outside
Hughie's fence
Notes: source uncertain; seems a bit early for Tutira(DEH);[try also?Rockford or other Jnl; not Chudleigh]

Quote:
Perhaps to their
position on the edge
of a previous burn
and of the later
fire [the moa-bones]
may in a measure owe
their preservation.

This fern springs up
... on neglected
burns.
On the `burn', under the `Judge's Chair', at 725 feet the Dracophyllum scoparium and D. longifolium are being replaced by Poa litterosa and Bulbinella Rossii.

This fern springs up
in countless
thousands on
neglected burns.

Author: BAUCKE
Quote:
Suddenly, like a
slap in the face
from an unseen hand,
where one had looked
for fresh wonders of
forest beauty,
spread a settler's
recent burn! Gaunt
and charred, prone
on their mother's
bosom, lay the
mighty monarchs of
the woods.

The shearing muster
should be made over
the cleanest routes,
contamination from
Sources such as
road-droving, dirty
country, seed, heavy
thistle, burns or
blowing sand being
avoided where
possible.

... Pete crawled
through the Wild
Irishmen and forded
the creek beside the
shingle slip ...
Then he
boulderhopped along
towards the burn.

Author: McKENZIE
Quote:
Settlers of a later
generation
discontinued the
practice of clearing
a new `burn' of all
logs.

Author: LEVY
Quote:
Sowing the Burn
[heading]

Author: CHARLES
Quote:
There is a good
cheque you can earn,
seeding a burn,/ Or
cutting some
cow-cocky's scrub./

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
At first the
homestead was just
sitting in a bare
paddock or `burn'.

Author: WILSON
Quote: [Central Otago - Wakatipu : (cf creek) NB not wee] Below us to the East the creek, a small tiny burn, rushes and tears away over crags and stones making a great noise evidently trying hard to make itself important, ... and so down to Mataura.
Notes: 1873 Jan 26 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 152

Quote:
... the burns coming
in from the hills
... in searching the
banks of several
burns on the other
side of the Taieri.

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
We have crossed
several burns of
respectable size and
many minor creeks
during our journey,
but we have now to
cross a river ...

Author: HISLOP
Quote: There are now several bonnie burns coming down the mountain sides to the river, the largest of which are the famous Roaring Meg and Gentle Annie; and a visitor ... may wash his colours of gold from almost anywhere while his wee wife boils the billy. Ibid. 69 I was invited ... to stop the weekend [near Cromwell], and as Donald was going out ... to try the wash in a nearby burn, I thought it a great idea.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
On the other side of
the [Taieri] river
the flow of `animal'
burns [Ewe, Gimmer,
Sow, etc.] is
interrupted by the
intrusion of a mere
`creek', even if it
is named Eden after
the place where Adam
named all the
animals.

This river is fed by
the Swine and other
burns.

Author: BARKER
Quote: [The wind] must not be too violent, or the flames will fly over the grass, just scorching it instead of making `a clean burn.'

The time for felling the bush in order to ensure a good burn in at [prob. typo.: in not deleted] the proper burning season - which is generally most favourable about the beginning of February - is from August to October.
Notes: 1877 Oct NZ Country Journal (Kelly) quoted in 1958 NZJ Ag 96 (4): 375

Author: WALLACE
Quote:
... an amount of
small wood is thus
secured to guarantee
a `good burn', ...

Author: KELLY
Quote:
The bush is felled
carefully so as to
give a good burn.

Everything depends
on a successful
burn.

The fire if it is a
good burn destroys
all the small stuff,
leaves, and burns
the surface of the
ground well.

We got the burns
over ...[sic] James
& Arthur fired ours
after nine o'clock
on the night of the
15th.

Arthur is going to
make a clearing on
our land this year,
and ...[sic] after
the burn would put
up a slab house of
two rooms which
might serve
afterwards for
cowshed or kitchen
or workshop ...
`Bird's heart is in
the bushland, his
heart is not here.'

Source: Five Years' Residence in New Zealand
Author: FULLER
Quote:
Grass springing up
after a burn.

... while the
Australian bush
recovers more or
less from the burn
that of New Zealand
perishes ...

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
The season promised
to be a good one for
bush-burning; and
those who had
bush-felled were
congratulating
themselves on the
prospect of getting
excellent `burns,'
while many, who, ...
had been unfortunate
in getting bad
`burns,' were now
hopeful of clearing
off much of the
timber by means of a
second fire.

There is very little
logging-up done
now-a-days, and with
a good burn it is
quite unnecessary.
... two or three
chains around the
site should be
logged up and burnt.

The swampy nature of
the soil ... and the
too abundant rains
make a successful
burn impracticable.

... the same good
quality of sheep
pasture that in the
past had given this
district an
excellent name as a
fertile country
immediately
following the
`burn.'

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
The `burn' of 1902
... was not what is
technically known as
a `clean' fire. ...
this fire left
unburnt ridge-caps,
the tops, sometimes
even the upper
slopes.

Author: SCANLAN
Quote:
The big burn was the
spectacular event
for which their
visit was timed.

These [sown
pastures] may be
divided into two
groups - (a) sown on
cultivated land, and
(b) surface sown
after forest, scrub
or fern burn.

Author: WILSON
Quote:
A bad burn [of
cleared bush] may
spell ruin to a man
with limited
capital.

Burning hard fern
should not be a
regular practice,
but often good burns
can be made in
spring and sometimes
in autumn and if the
burns [n2] can be
oversown and the
pasture well-managed
afterward, it is a
help in the control
of hard fern.

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
The `burn' of this
bit of bush has not
been a good one.

Author: McLAUCHLAN
Quote:
If the summer rains
came and spoilt the
burn, it meant a
great loss for the
farmer; once the
leafage of fallen
timber drops and
becomes a soggy mess
on the ground, it is
almost impossible to
get a successful
burn.

Author: MOWAT
Quote:
Miller & Witherow
over to new burn to
get old cull dairy
cows...

Author: MOWAT
Quote:
Drafting sheep from
New Burn and Wade
Creek etc.

The new grass on the
burns is always
stocked with hoggets
...

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
At first the
homestead was just
sitting in a bare
paddock or burn.

Saw large mob of
sheep on the new
burn outside
Hughie's fence.

Author: WESTMACOTT
Quote:
The new burn was
looking well; the
turnips, rape and
mustard would feed a
lot of sheep in a
few month's time,
and everywhere the
grass was showing up
well.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
Bidi-bidi came very
thick on the new
burns and it was a
race to get the
shearing done before
it started to stick.

Took car to go for `burn'. an 18-year-old [Palmerston North] youth who converted a $1,300 Jaguar car and drove it ... [at] speeds of 110 miles an hour, told the Police he had wanted to go for a `burn' with his mates ...

Author: LELAND
Quote:
TAKE A SPIN in a
motor vehicle.
to go for a burn: to go for a drive in a car

Author: PHARAZYN
Quote:
Commenced burning on
the flat on this
side the creek up
the Valley.

As there was a nice
breeze we lighted
our clearings. Bill
and the Ronalds also
burnt - in all about
46 acres. I had not
time to see how mine
had burnt.

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
A few, fearful of a
change in the
weather, had already
burned with fairly
satisfactory
results; and the
general topic of
conversation ... was
of bush-burning.

They wanted to burn
the large clearing
that day.

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
You will have burnt
a large patch of
feed at the outset.
[152] Burn it in
early spring, on a
day when rain
appears to be at
hand.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
If the weather has
been very dry ... we
attempt to burn a
great flax swamp.

Source: Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point
Author: PHILLIPS
Quote:
[sc. land] In the
afternoon T.A.P. &
W.P.P. burnt the
faces round the
Point.

Went to sheep and
then tried to burn
the run over Stoney
creek but the grass
was not close
enough.

Source: Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point
Author: PHILLIPS
Quote:
T.A.P. & W.P.
burning the Rockwood
run ...

We are going to burn
the country to
prepare it for
sheep.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
I am quite sorry
that the season for
setting fire to the
long grass, or, as
it is technically
called, `burning the
run', is fairly over
at last.

... they disappear
as the country is
burnt by the
runholder ...

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
There are many
things to be taken
into consideration
when burning.
Climate - is your
country early or
late? Are you
carrying ewes or
wethers on the block
that you propose to
burn? In what state
is your neighbour's
country? If your
country is warm and
early, with a small
rainfall, it is a
good rule to burn
early in the season
...

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
When they got on to
the Waimea Plains a
dense smoke assailed
them from fires set
alight by
newly-arrived
runholders `burning
the country' around
the Five Rivers
vicinity.

Author: HARPER
Quote:
One day we went on
an expedition [on
Mt. Peel station]
into the mountain
valleys to `burn
country', a process
adopted here for the
improvement of
pasture. ... The
fire spread up the
hill-sides ... and
soon covered a large
extent of country,
burning for several
days, ...

Source: Five Years' Residence in New Zealand
Author: FULLER
Quote: ... to burn a run.

Author: McGILL
Quote: burn drive a vehicle fast, phr. go for a burn, originally a bikie's burn-up; a burn off to drive so fast you leave the competition behind; eg 'Let's go for a burn, eh?' `Dunno, don't think we could burn off old Scotty, now he's got that rebore.' NZA.

A Foundation for
Alcohol and Drug
Education workshop..
will look at the
growing problem of
methamphetamine,
otherwise known as
P, pure, burn,
crystal or ice.

Methamphetamine
(called Pure, P,
Crystal Meth, Burn
or Crank) is
chemically only
slightly different
to amphetamine -
generally the
effects are the
same, but it is more
potent.

Most of the settlers
are "burning off"
now, and the valleys
are full of smoke.

Author: DUPPA
Quote:
Burn off portions of
the run for winter
feed to destroy tuft
grass.
Notes: in Crawford (1949) Sheep and Sheepmen of Canterbury

Quote:
All bush ready for
burning should be
burnt off this
month.

Author: BRABAZON
Quote: Burning off.

One or two attempts
to burn off the
rushes and sow down
grass seed have
proved unavailing.

Should the fern be
burnt off in
mid-summer or in the
autumn, the ensuing
growth will be much
less vigorous than
the previous growth.

The fern is not
burnt off. Mr
Thacker considers
burning unnecessary
and harmful to the
grass.

Source: Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I
Author: TAIT
Quote:
After cutting the
tea-tree and burning
it off

Source: Farms & Stations of NZ Vol III
Author: TAIT
Quote:
After 1905, 600
acres were milled
from heavy bush and
sown down in English
grasses after
burning off.

Author: FEARON
Quote:
He burnt off the
scrub at the base of
the hill.

Author: HOLDEN
Quote:
He employed Maori to
help him clear and
then burn off the
land.

Author: DILLON
Quote:
The fern was all
burnt off by the
surveyors.

Author: BRABAZON
Quote: Burning off.

Following the
intitial drainage
work, the earlier
farmers, after
cutting down the
remaining bush and
scrub, burned off
and surface sowed
the land.

Development land is
usually covered with
a preburn spray by
aircraft, burnt off
then root-raked with
a bulldozer.

They [young
tussocks] stop
growing much earlier
in the year than if
they had not been
burnt over.

One the winter
country, in the
spring, as soon as
the ground is
sufficiently dry, as
much as possible is
burnt over.

The surface
vegetation ... had
been systematically
burnt over, year
after year, in order
to encourage fresh
growth for the use
of stock.

Author: MACINTOSH
Quote:
The years went by,
the sheep ceased to
have their fleeces
classed as 'burn
stain' ...

Author: CHUDLEIGH
Quote:
We are going to burn
the country to
prepare it for
sheep.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
I am quite sorry
that the season for
setting fire to the
long grass, or, as
it is technically
called, "burning the
run", is fairly over
at last.

The impact commenced
centruries ago, with
Maori burn-offs
incinerating at
least half of the
island's primordial
forest cover.

Author: WILLIAM MORGAN
Quote:
In the afternoon
burnt(?) off. Not an
over excellent burn
off - there having
been of late a good
deal of wet.

Author: MAY
Quote:
In due time we fired
[the bush] and had a
clean burn off.

Author: MORTON
Quote:
... smoke of fresh
burn-offs ...

So I ask my Dad
about a burn-off,
and we take the
kerosine and matches
and set the whole
hillside alight.

Author: HILLIARD
Quote:
We passed ... three
Maori women ...
stooping to cut puha
from a manuka
burn-off. `A
readymade Van Gogh,
... Or rather The
Puha Gatherers.'

... the completion
of the burn off.

Author: HARTLEY
Quote:
Not so the farmers
who roundly cursed
the settler who had
started them with an
imprudent burn-off,
the swagman boiling
his billy or
children playing
with matches.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
We sometimes read
today of a large
controlled "burn
off".

Author: McLAUCHLAN
Quote:
[Caption] After the

Source: May's Guide to Farming in NZ
Author: MAY
Quote:
In due time we fired
it and had the
satisfaction of
having a clean
burn-off.

Author: MACINTOSH
Quote:
Every farmer in our
area seemed to

burn off.

Source: Farming in the Mohaka State Forest
Author: WRIGHT
Quote:
Much of it remained
in farmable
condition, although
there were areas
where repeated
burnoffs had taken
their toll ...

Author: HOLDEN
Quote:
In the case of
timber, that was
often the direct
result of the fires

moa-hunters, and

burn-offs of
short-sighted
European settlers.

Author: PLUMMER
Quote:
.. in spite of some
fairly good
burn-offs, the scrub
kept coming up
again.

Throughout
September, burn-offs
were carried out.

Only a fringe of
river flat eases the
strain of creating
dairy pastures where
the annual burn-off
was once the
recognised way to
get a brief flush of
green grass.

Farmers planning a
burn-off can take
advantage of the new
computerised system.
[burnoff; burn off]

It warns would-be
seekers of the good
life that it can
come with noise ..
smell .. smoke
(stubble burn-off)
dust and spray.

Author: A TRAMP
Quote:
Whether he prefers
the burn-out to the
wash-out I have not
as yet been able to
ascertain.

The truth or
otherwise of the
premises laid down
by both burners and
anti-burners has
never been
accurately
determined.

Graffiti Speak...
Burner: A great
piece.
burnet: Kinds of brown-flowered plants. One sort called `Australian sheep's burnet', grows in Australia and is naturalized in New Zealand.
burnet, sheep's [s] Poterium polygamum Waldst. and Kit.

An influenza
epidemic,
colloquially known
as the 'Burnham
bot', knocked some
of the exuberance
out of the troops in
November [1939].

Burnham Boys - A Bad
Training

Three more Burnham
boys escaped last
week.

Go and ask some of
those Burnham boys
that you carry on
with, and get out of
the cell, and don't
come near me again.
[prisoner in
Lyttelton jail to
another (homosexual)

Lois began talking
of the
"burning-off." "It
was a wonderful
sight," she said.

Author: C. CHAPMAN
Quote:
As Xmas is the time
for burning off, and

Author: PHARAZYN
Quote:
... employed

From their skill

Notes: 1853 C.F.Hursthouse NZ[??], The Emigration Field of 1851 14 in 1963 Apr NZ Geog 56 (Hargreaves)

Considering the

Quote:
The burning off
should be driven as

grass fostering
influence of stock

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
WALLACE
Quote:
FALLING [bold] is
done in winter, and
burning off in the
middle or end of
summer ...

Author: BACON
Quote:
When they've done
the burning off, the
aeroplanes are going
to come in and plant
the grass.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
`Those concrete

Notes: 1973 Henderson `The Dead Bush' In 1975 NZ Short Stories III 212

Quote:
The burning-off of
the alpine scrub and
the bush in the

deprive the bird of
its normal food ...
*Burnt chops.-An expression somewhat akin to the expression *Burnt Spur. which denoted the business of high country mustering: `So and so has taken to the b.s.'. meaning he has taken on mustering.

Author: PAUL
Quote:
Fern land requires
no previous labour
(except burning off)
to prepare it for
the plough.

The good seasons we
have experienced for
burning off has
given bushfarmers
confidence and there
will be some large
contracts let by
private individuals.

When grass was sown
in the ashes after
the burning off of
the scrub, the
strike usually was
excellent and the
first season a good
bite of feed was
thrown.

Author: HAMILTON
Quote:
Unfortunately, too,
burning off became
part of the
tradition of hill
country sheep
farming in New
Zealand.

Author: ASPINALL
Quote:
Burning off has for
many years past been
a tool of
management, used by
runholders and
graziers ...

We have experienced
good burning seasons
for the past three
seasons and it is to
be hoped that next
summer's burns will
be as good as last
year's.

The time for felling
the bush in order to
ensure a good burn
in at the proper
burning season -
which is generally
most favourable
about the beginning
of February - is
from August to
October.
Notes: 1877 Oct NZ Country Journal (Kelly) quoted in 1958 NZJ Ag 96 (4): 375

Quote:
I once discovered a
pigeon's nest near a
bush-felling camp,
... and before the
burning season had
arrived they had
successfully hatched
... three young ones
...

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
Burnt feed means
contented and
well-conditioned
sheep. ... Your
sheep will not
ramble, for if they
have plenty of burnt
pasture they are
contented where they
are.

Quote:
We commenced
operations, and
discovered ...
several fine leaders
containing burnt
quartz. Our
neighbours as they
passed all
congratulated us on
our prospects, but
we shall see.

Quote:
This was burnt-off
country,
black-and-green on

underneath, too poor
for the grass to be
more than a
bristling crop.

Author: BOYD
Quote:
Ploughing burnt-off

leather next to the

nailed on the shoe.

Quote:
There were the
scrublands of

reproachful columns

...

Burnt-over areas
with logs and
bracken adjacent to

especially
favourable for
hares.

Author: LANDS & SURVEY
Quote:
This situation
persisted until 1950
when the
possibilities of
using aircraft for
sowing seed and
manure on burnt-over
hill country became
apparent.

Quote:

Quote: ACAENA ... sanguisorbae ... var. A. ... Burr, Biddi-biddi.

Author: FEATON
Quote: ACAENA SANGUISORBAE (Vahl .) The Native Burr. ... The `HUTIWAI', or `PIRIPIRI'.- ... an infusion of the leaves is said to afford a substitute for tea, but it is the opinion of the writer that the results are not commensurate with the trouble of brewing.

Author: LINDSAY
Quote: Hence the plant [Acaena sanguisorbae ] is only too familiar, as the `Native Burr' to the sheep farmers alike of New Zealand, Australia, and Tasmania. ... To the Otago settler the plant is also known as the `Bidi-bidi,' or `Beta-beta;' to the North Island Maori as `Hutiwai,' `Piri-piri,' (Colenso), or `Piri-kahu,' (Colenso).
[NZ BURR] Acaena Sanguisorbae
Notes: Turner Botanical Examination of the Higher Waimarino District

Quote: new zealand bur n, usu cap N & Z : a creeping mat-forming New Zealand plant (Acaena microphylla ) that is sometimes cultivated for its grayish to rosy bronze foliage and showy crimson spines

Notes: 1909 Cockayne Report on a Botanical Survey of Stewart Island (And)
Cockayne Report on the Dune-areas of NZ in AJHR C-13 (And)

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: SHEEP'S BURR (Acaena ovina ), called also Australian burr, false bidi bid, and very loosely piri piri or bidi bid, is not uncommon in fields and waste places in certain localities of both islands, but is commoner in the north.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote: ... in the wool of sheep, as Australian burr (Acaena ovina ).
Australian sheep's bur [s] Acaena ovina A. Cunn. Ibid. 69 sheep's bur [=] Australian sheep's bur [s]

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: AUSTRALIAN SHEEP'S BUR (Acaena ovina ) ... is widespread in New Zealand, frequently seen in poor pasture and on roadsides.
bur, buffalo [s] Solanum rostratum Dunal. ... buffalo, bur [s] Solanum rostratum Dunal

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: ... you will see [on Disappointment Island in the Auckland group] ... patches of vivid green. This last arises from the presence of the antarctic burr (Acaena Sanguisorbae , var antarctica ).

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Bur-reed. Sparganium simplex.
(And) Sparganium subglobosum

Author: MONRO
Quote:
But, as the
mutton-bird seldom
makes a new burrow,
but returns to the
old ones year after
year, and as these
burrows are nearly
horizontal, the
natives have made
vertical openings
into them, through
which they extract
the young one. The
hole thus made is
closed up with a
plug of grass, and
serves for many
years.
Notes: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 254

Quote:
It is thought that
water may have
entered some of the
burrows and that
some of the younger
birds may have been
drowned.

During the full moon
the birds often
stayed at sea until
early in the
corning, returning
in their strange
blundering way just
long enough to feed
their anxious young
cheeping in the
burrows.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
Many of the Kuaka
burrows were really
alive with
revelry... Often a
Kuaka would sit for
long periods just
outside a burrow
mouth, gazing, and I
believe at
intervals, singing
into its cavernous
depths.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
From twos and
threes, from dozens,
from scores, from
hundreds, from
thousands, from tens
of tousands of
burrows, rose an
intensifying babel
of sound.

When a stick is
thrust into the
burrow the sitting
bird gives a loud
double hiss, and
then often
"Ti-ti-ti."

.. keeping burry
fleeces, cotts & c.,
from clean wool
could be considered
with advantage.

Author: MAF
Quote:
Burry Wool: Wool
containing burrs
such as clover burr
and Bathurst burr.

Author: LELAND
Quote:
Bursary. 7th formers
(or bright sixth
formers in the
`right' schools)
(17-18 years old)
take this exam to
earn some financial
support (above
tuition, for
University).

Author: Faith Oxenbridge
Quote:
Natasha beats Rima
by three marks in
the Bursary English
exam, but Rima
doesn't care.

Even with the
debacle of the
calculus Bursary
exam, Morris
believes the NZQA
does a good job in
setting and
organising exams.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
I finished school,
bummed around for a
year or so in
Australia and then
returned to apply
for a bursary and
whatever else they
would give me to
study medicine.

I have no wish to
see the Palmerston
(Manawatu) Club
bursted.

Author: HARPER
Quote: [The station hands] gravely plead that to `have a burst' is necessary for health after the long monotony of station life and fare. Ibid. 65 You may argue with them [sc. station hands], and they gravely plead that to `have a burst' is necessary for health after the long monotony of station life and fare, ...

Source: Crusts: a settler's fare due south
Author: KENNAWAY
Quote: Once or twice a year, he went ... to Christchurch, - or to town, as it was more emphatically called, - and, like hundreds of his class, he went down with the set resolution `to have a burst'. ... While there [at the inn] he would spend every farthing of his year's wages, ...

Author: BATHGATE
Quote:
`He is a groom at
the pub ..., and is
a remittance man.
Every now and again
he gets a remittance
from Home, and has a
tremendous burst for
a week or two. One
not infrequently
came across

Author: SCANLAN

It's the first burst

(Torlesse's Report
on Canterbury) The
north-west wind ...
something like the
... `hot winds' of

succeeded by one
from the south-west,
which in the summer
time is a cool and
pleasant guest, but
in the winter season
what is aptly termed
`a burst', and
sometimes lasts for
two or three days,
being generally
accompanied by rain
if not by snow and
sleet. This wind is
similar to the
well-known
`south-easter' of
New Zealand, which,
here, tends up with
the land, and so has
a south-westerly
direction.

Going off for his

Author: BELL
Quote: Though he could take his whisky regularly and freely, and did so, he had ... his periodically recurring seasons when he would get on `the burst,' and soak himself in it. ... O'Byrne took little notice ...; and Davie ... had thought it best on the one occasion in which Dan had `broken out,' to give him a wide berth. Ibid. 129 He then trudged off homewards, and ... went on the `burst' for a week.

He would purchase
half a dozen bottles
of rum ... and go on
a regular burst ...
Burst, bust. Drinking bout. e.g. `He has been on the burst for a week,' `He has had an awful bust.' ([1874 Kennaway Crusts], p.167)

Author: SHAW

We had a favourable

burster came on in a
manner so furious
that the captain..
declared it was
blowing a hurricane.

The weather ... was
exceedingly cold,
but has now changed
to fine again,
proving that the sum
of a few `bursters'
which blow from time
to time, at long
intervals, is our
real winter; that as
a season, we have
scarcely one to be
called.

Author: SHAW
Quote:
When within a few

direction, or, as

Suddenly, with the

Notes: [an example of use of burst with a southerly] [c1860] a1906 Stack Through Canterbury (1972) 53-54

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
The southerly
`burster', as it is
called, gradually
creeps up and at
last drives the
other [NW wind] off
the field. A few
chilly puffs, then a
great one, and in a
minute or two the
air becomes cold,
even in the height
of summer.

That was the real
way to provide a
remedy, and not to
say we will impose a
"bursting up" tax.

piopio, a bush-bird (Turnagra tanagara), the North Island thrush and (T. capensis) the South Island form: both extinct soon after 1900. A riverbed bird, the dotterel, and a narrow-leaved plant, dianella, also bear this name, but the thrush is usually associated with the name: in any case the dianella has a name tu[u]rutu.

Dampers, that is

We three act as cook

The firestick became

years, rather than

Considerable numbers
of Lincolns and
English Leicesters
were run on the new
'bush-burn' country
( that is country
which has been
cleared of forest by
felling and burning,
leaving many
blackened stumps and
logs) , as their
wool stood up well
to the rough
conditions.
[bush-burn country]

An important topical
matter is the sowing
to grass of
bush-burn country.

As may easily be
seen after a
bush-burn ...

... now that the
effect of the early
bush-burns is
disappearing sheep

malnutrition over
considerable areas.

After the
bush-burns, the
sheep did well for a

there were always
some `wasters.' the
number of which kept
increasing.

Bush sickness is
always found in the
volcanic district on
coarse rhyolitic
pumice soils and
`dopiness' on soils
derived from fine
volcanic dust or mud
showers. A soil on
which `dopiness'
develops is a
leached loam and is
found on
deteriorated lands,
i.e., lands which
originally were
highly fertile due
to the ashes from
the `bush burn,' the
land subsequently
becoming gradually
less productive ...

To burn everything
cleanly but the
heavy trunks is so
important to the
success of the bush
burn.
bush burn NZ burning of bush on cultivable land, land so cleared.

in the winter before
last was burnt and
sown with 20 lbs of
bush-burn seed.
[bush-burn seed]

The weather is very
dry all along the
coast and bush
burners and
harvesters of grain
and grass seed are
rejoicing.

.. in the first
place, cocksfoot was
sown, broadcast on
bush burnt country
some 70 years ago in
this district ...

Author: WILSON
Quote:
Sixty years ago some
country homes were
still using colonial
ovens, which had
superseded the camp
ovens, except in
bush camps.

Author: CLEVELAND
Quote:
Is this the way to
enact the fabled
tradition of energy
and trust in each
other you have
inherited from
goldfields and bush
camps?

Author: WASWO
Quote:
Cats, dogs and rats
wandered away from
the bush camps and
farms, and stayed in
the bush, living on
birds and their
eggs.

Author: HINDMARSH
Quote:
Initially Guy Reed,
younger brother of
the two partners,
was installed in a
bush camp in 1915 to
begin development of
the steep and
awkwardly-shaped
property.

Author: DAHM
Quote:
The galley was the
living room of the
bush camp - dining
room, kitchen and
social room - it was
all three.

Source: Farms & Stations of NZ Vol II
Author: TAIT
Quote:
For many years the
large bush camp
remained at
Pukekaroro.

Author: WASWO
Quote:
Big bush camps had
their own cook and a
good cook helped
keep a camp happy.

Author: DAHM
Quote:
Before we moved into
the new house Mum
had done her cooking
exactly the same as
the bush cooks did
in the bush camps.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
But all the little
troubles of the
day's tramp were
forgotten when the
night came down upon
us in our snug
little bush camp.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
Early in March of
1869 Titokowaru had
established himself
in a bush camp at
Otautu ... -->sc a
temporary erection
in the bush for
living in

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
The the camp had to
be near running
water ... It was
usually made of the
trunks of sapling
trees ... and the
walls were mde from
leaves of the nikau
palm. ... I have
slept many times in
those bush camps,
and I was always
conscious of being
very comfortable
indeed.

Source: Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The
Author: MAHONEY
Quote:
In the early decades
of the 20th century
some longer bush
tram operations
included a bush camp
located close to the
felling areas... A
typical bush camp
comprised men's
huts, a store shed,
and a cookhouse.

I remember one man
telling me how
interested he'd
become in Charles
Dickens. He'd been
introduced to it in
a bush camp, and he
said, 'My word, he's
a good writer.,
isn't he!'

Author: PFAFF
Quote:
[advt] For 33 years
`K' Jam has been
known and
appreciated in all
parts of the coast -
in bush camps and
mining townships,
... as well as in
the thriving towns.

Author: MORTON
Quote:
... a real bush-camp
...

Author: M
Quote:
The best thing that
could happen to him
would be six months
in a bush camp
getting down to
things.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
His father had been
called out to a
remote bush camp to
perform a marriage
ceremony.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
For the first time I
realised the
importance of
teamwork and the
bond that exists in
times of danger. The
bond that grew and
existed in that bush
camp was never
broken.

Author: HOWE
Quote:
But I can remember
that I was glad to
get back to the bush
camp, ... to
familiar
surroundings and
people.

Source: You'll Learn No Harm from the Hills
Author: MCCONOCHIE
Quote:
When here in great
profusion, the bush
canary, our
favourite songster,
together with the
rifleman .. moved
from tree to tree.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
There were bush
canaries with a
yellow head and
breast and brown
wings.

Author: WATERS
Quote:
.. or maybe the din
of the bush canaries
as they gather into
flocks before rain
...

Author: WHITWORTH
Quote:
I found ... tied to
a stick, (a bush
candlestick), about
two inches of
candle.

Author: MONEY
Quote:
... we caught every
day shoals of
white-bait; a piece
of gauze fastened to
a circle of
supple-jack or bush
cane, much
resembling an
ordinary
butterfly-net, was
all that was
required for their
capture.

Author: LEE
Quote:
Too many
bush-carpenters and
vets. in the Medical
Corps.

Our local
"bush"-carpenters
did their best.

Registration of
builders now being
carried out by the
New Zealand Master
Builders' Federation
would eventually
provide a safeguard,
both for the public
and for the builders
themselves, against
the activities of
`bush carpenters,'
according to a
statement issued by
the federation
today.

(PA) - The Auckland
Master Builders'
Association is
preparing to wage
war against what it
calls `bush
carpenters' -
jobbing carpenters
who `are bringing
the whole industry
into disrepute,' in
the words of
Mr.F.G.Rabone,
president of the
association.

Author: WILSON
Quote: Frank and his bush carpenter set to work by erecting the frame of a lean-to of scantlings. Ibid. 65 That bush-carpenter's economy in doing without piles had been a disastrous mistake ...

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote:
bush carpenter a
man, self taught,
usually limited to
simple carpentry.
.in 4;`Well, they
were only bush
carpenters they gave
it a go because
there was no one
else, or they
couldn't afford a
tradesman.' `That's
about Ted's form -
he's just a bush
carpenter.'

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
[They] were out in
the alley, leaning
on each other ...
and vowing eternal
friendship in the
face of all drongos,
no-hopers, wowsers
and bush carpenters
and all those poufs
who had promised to
the big game and
then backed out ...

Leaving three
carpenters (real,
apprentice and
bush), an architect
and cook to look
after building
operations, the rest
... went down the
road ...

Author: BATHGATE
Quote:
I found that
Fletcher ... had
secured an iron
building, which was
being converted by a
bush carpenter into
suitable premises
for a bank.

Author: ACLAND
Quote:
~: Handy, rough
carpenter.

Author: JONES
Quote:
As it was too far to
get a tradesman up
for any repairs, we
were all, what was
called, `Bush
Carpenters'.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Bush. In New Zealand also; esp., bush carpenter (or carpentry): since ca. 1910. (Niall Alexander, letter of Oct. 22, 1939.)
Notes: 1939 Alexander in 1949 Partridge Dict. Slang Addenda 1005

Author: WILSON
Quote:
The structure built
[?c1900] by the bush
carpenter was about
12 feet by twelve
feet.

`Like most farmers
I'm a good bush
carpenter,' he
smiled when asked
about his
qualifications as a
builder.

Author: MORRIESON
Quote:
At one end the seats
had been cut away by
some bush-carpenter
allow living
quarters.
bush carpenter n. Austral. & N.Z. a rough-and-ready unskilled workman.

Author: BATISTICH
Quote:
Taddi was a good
bush carpenter; he
soon knocked up a
rough cottage for
the men to live in,
better than the flax
whare they agreed.

Barbara Baynton ...
began life as the
daughter of a bush
carpenter in New
South Wales ...

Author: McGILL
Quote: bush carpenter self-taught or rough and ready carpenter. NZA.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
He was what is
called a
bush-carpenter: that
is, [OEDS i.e.] a
wandering carpenter,
who travels from
station to station,
doing any little odd
rough [OEDS omits]
jobs wanted.

[?transitional use]
A large proportion
of the country
settlers of New
Zealand are
compelled ... to
become their own
architects, or to
appeal to some bush
carpenter, who has
no skill in the art
of designing,
though, perhaps, a
good enough
mechanic.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
Herb was the bush
carpenter.

Author: NEWPORT
Quote:
With the help of
Tommy Whilten,
sometimes referred
to as a 'bush
carpenter', a
substantial
swingbridge was
erected.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
He was what is
called a
bush-carpenter ie a
wandering carpenter,
who travels from
station to station
doing any little odd
jobs wanted.

Author: JONES
Quote:
As it was too far to
get a tradesman up
for any repairs, we
were all, what was
called, 'Bush
Carpenters', and
most stations had
small forges, and
people could shoe
their own horses ...

Author: GROVER
Quote:
In no time I would
have a horse, and
who would they ask
when they needed a
drover for a herd of
bush cattle that had
to be driven a
hundred miles?

It is now some eight
years since I first
saw several small
herds of wild bush
cattle.

Yes, bush cattle
certainly had a good
life, with plenty to
eat and drink and no
fear of drought.

Author: SALISBURY
Quote:
This area abounded
with bush cattle
which we would see
from time to time.

Author: SHARPE
Quote:
Bush cattle are very
nervous at sight of
a man on foot ...

Author: COWAN
Quote:
There are Government
shelter huts,
iron-roofed little
bush chalets ... 10
and 19 miles from
Glade House [Te
Anau] ...

Author: BOSWELL
Quote:
The Katui school !
... How I adored the
succession of
teachers who came to
impart at least the
rudiments of
knowledge to us
`bush children'.

Author: ELLISON
Quote:
The old bush chimney
was never quite the
same again.

Author: Masters
Quote:
Among his other
accomplishments, he
was adept at
erecting bush
chimneys.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
Among his other
accomplishments, he
was an adept at
erecting bush
chimneys.

Blue Knee went to
the bush chimney and
stirred embers below
the water tin
suspended from the
cooking rail, the
usual girder
spanning the full
width of the
chimney.

Author: HARTLEY
Quote:
But sitting on her
hard chair warming
herself by the fire
in the bush chimney
[in the tent], my
indomitable grandma
pursed her lips.

Author: ELLISON
Quote:
.. the huge fire
that was burning in
the corrugated iron
'bush chimney.'

Source: Colonial Outcasts: A Search for the Remittance Man
Author: HARTLEY
Quote:
It was welcome fuel
for his small stove
set in a bush
chimney on an
evening when he was
'dining on a soup
bone.'

[1910 photograph of
competitors with a
block on which is
written] MOKAI BUSH
CHOP 1910
Notes: 1910 in 1980 McGill Ghost Towns of NZ 188

Author: JOHN HURNDELL
Quote:
many burnings off
and bush choppings.
Notes: 1881 John Hurndall's Diary in 1988 Warr From Bush-burn to Butter 52 1881 February 24:

Author: COWAN
Quote:
In his crippled old
age he was cheered
now and again by a
visit from some old
friend of his
bush-scouting,
bush-clearing,
bullocking days when
one could march all
day with a
seventy-pound swag
...

Author: SOUTHEY
Quote:
As workmen they are
sought after for
bush-clearing.

Bush-clearing has
destroyed many of
the habitats of this
moss ...

Self-sown wheat that
I have seen stood
taller than my head
... but that is in a
bush-clearing, and
probably stronger
than on the plains.

Author: NEAL
Quote:
Last year I used to
look at [the peach
trees] from our bush
clearing and your
house looked as if
it was on fire.
Notes: 1867 July 30 Charley Turner in 1969 Neal From London to Lonely Rai 47

Quote:
I and 5 men cut down
groundsel all the
afternoon. ... It
has all come on a
bush clearing from a
few branches.

Every evening at
dusk scores could be
seen flitting across
the bush-clearings
...

... a couple of
Australian
Tree-swallows
hunting flies about
the head of an old
rata in a
bush-clearing ...

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
To the artistic eye,
the bush clearings
... may appear as a
sore blemish on the
face of the
landscape. Thickly
strewn with
blackened logs and
branches, ... these
clearings stand out
in ugly contrast
with the virgin
native bush.

Author: HAWDON
Quote:
I'll be back in time
for shearing,/ And
to burn the new bush
clearing.

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote:
... on unused
bush-clearings where
the Californian
thistle alone
flourishes.

Author: REISCHEK
Quote:
The bridle-track led
past little
bush-clearings with
fenced-in Maori
plantations; ...

No more fearful than
was the pa Te
Huripapa/ In the
bush clearing, where
the river/ Opened
its mouth, ...

Author: MARSH
Quote:
She lived in a
deserted lumberman's
shack in a
bush-clearing.

Author: BULLER
Quote:
In the settlers'
bush-clearings at
Eketahuna, in the
Forty-mile Bush, I
found them [sc.
ducks] long after
dark ...

Author: MOORE
Quote:
The bushclearing
when chopped, burnt,
and sown, was as a
rule open to the
wide ...

I would like to know
whether it [canary
grass] is suitable
for bush clearings
and if stock are
fond of it.

Author: HOWITT
Quote:
It was a great day
for the youngsters
on the bush farms
when Chew Chong, the
old Chinese
storekeeper, found
out the value of
fungus which grew on
the stumps in the
bush clearings.

.. the inland bush
clearings also added
a considerable
production of
first-class
cocksfoot seed,
which was harvested
by hand, as at
Akaroa.

Author: WASWO
Quote:
The traditional
[dairying] practice
was to hand milk
cows in a nearby
bush clearing, out
in the fields or in
a yard close by ...
[bush-clearing]

Author: NEWPORT
Quote:
The large,
long-wooled Lincoln
sheep were popular
at one time and
thrived extremely
well on the lush
grass of the new
bush clearings.

Author: WASWO
Quote:
As organised
settlement increased
bush clearing
gathered momentum, a
peak being reached
in the 1870s and
1880s. Initially the
[bush] clearing was
concentrated on the
lowland forested
areas ...

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
Around one twist in
the creek we came to
a fantastic display
of bush-clematis.
The white flowers,
all shimmering with
sunlight, dripped
from every tree in
sight.
Bush Clematis, Clematis paniculata. Large strong woody vine which climbs trees. Produces lovely white flowers ...

Author: DENNIS
Quote: From early in spring the ... kowhai and occasional treetop white of the climbing bush clematis (C. paniculata) are common sights.

Author: GIBSON
Quote:
[A bush-boss c1890
speaks:] You're now
a bush-clerk, and
that's the Kauri
analogy to a
midshipman's job in
the Navy.

Author: MARRIOTT
Quote:
I was confronted by
a thin old man in
rough but clean bush
clothes and with an
axe tucked under his
arm.

Author: BATES
Quote:
You know, it must be
better to be a
copper around here
than a bush cocky.

Author: BATES
Quote:
The boat crew
unloaded some stores
for a group of bush
cockies working in
the area.
... bush concert ...

... it is the utter
recklessness
displayed by
saw-mill
proprietors, bush
contractors, and
splitters which is
destroying our
forests at a rate
constantly
increasing.

Author: MOORE
Quote:
The bush contractor
was the man who ...
usually contracted
with a sawmill owner
to fell the trees,
crosscut them into
logs, and deliver
the logs to some
agreed point.

Author: STALLWORTHY
Quote:
Mr.H.T.Smith, an
enterprising bush
contractor,
purchased and
improved land at
Arapohue; ...

His first job,
though, was in a
bank - until a bush
contractor lured him
out to prune pine
trees.

Author: ST JOHN
Quote: Good, nay delicious, as the ko[u]ra is when boiled, ... or even when knocked up in a curry by the untutored paws of a bush cook.
Notes: 1873 St John Pakeha Rambles in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 554

Quote:
... when the bush
cook is not using
heavy damper as a
slow poison.

Author: MANDER
Quote:
He had known that
Allen was not a bush
cook, but he had
said it because a
cook was the most
urgent need of the
moment. In fact,
there is seldom a
moment in a bush
camp when a good
cook ... is not the
most pressing need
of the place.

Author: REED
Quote:
.. someone for a
craving for more
dainty fare than
that provided by the
bush cook.

Author: MOORE
Quote:
The bush gang ...
would include first
of all a good bush
cook, used to
cooking over an open
fire in the open
fireplace of a hut,
and able to bake and
roast in the `camp
ovens' generally
used.

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
NNow, bush cooks
that I knew were
tremendous fellows
at preparing sweets
of various kinds ..

Source: From Top to Bottom : Reinga to Bluff
Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
He.. was replaced by
a rough Kiwi
bush-cook who in a
collarless grey
shirt shouldered his
way through the
officers, pointed a
hairy arm at Colonel
Campbell and
shouted, "She's
cooked."

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
Bush cooks that I
knew were tremendous
fellows at preparing
sweets of various
kinds - cakes and so
on.

Author: MOORE
Quote:
The bush gang ..
would include first
of all a good bush
cook ...

Author: DAHM
Quote:
Before we moved into
the new house Mum
had done her cooking
exactly the same as
the bush cooks did
in the bush camps.

That said, it is
worth mentioning
that without the
bush corridors that
link the sanctuary
with other parts of
the city, we would
not be delighting in
the native bird life
that we now do. And
these bush corridors
are not inviolate.

I would add,
however, that we
only enjoy the
sanctuary's success
thanks to the bush
corridors that link
the sanctuary to
other parts of the
city.

In the long-term
[sic] restoring the
streams' [sic]
riparian zone will
create a bush
corridor for bird
species and habitat
for the plants and
animals living in
them.

In a belted, blue
bush man's frock,
hatchet in hand ...
he looked in truth
the scholar
disguised as a wood
chopper.

Author: ANGAS
Quote: Clad in our `bush' costume, but without weapons, and each with a toko toko or long walking-staff in our hands, my fellow traveller and myself set off in excellent spirits, accompanied by five Maori lads, who carried our baggage ... in their pikau or knapsacks, strapped over their shoulders with the leaves of flax.

Author: POWER
Quote:
The bush costume of
the [Artillery]
officers in New
Zealand [c.1846]
consists of a blue
serge shirt, coarse
trowsers, hobnail
boots, and a
cabbage-leaf hat or
cap; as like the
dress of the street
orderlies as
anything can be. It
is a pity that those
who identify a
soldier with his red
coat, gold lace,
feathers and
trappings, cannot
see the reverse of
the picture.

The colonial
practice of standing
idly smoking at the
shop doors in broad
daylight, and of
wearing a bush
costume ...

Author: EARP
Quote:
The colonial
practice of standing
idly smoking at the
shop doors in broad
daylight, and of
wearing a bush
costume, is more
honoured here in the
breach than the
observance.

Author: SWAINSON
Quote:
A little more
attention to dress,
and somewhat more
formality of manner,
are observable in
Auckland than in the
other settlements.
The colonial
practice of standing
idly smoking at the
shop doors in broad
daylight, and of
wearing bush costume
is more honoured in
the breach than the
observance.

Source: Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A
Author: ADAMS
Quote:
My costume consisted
pair of white duck
trousers, checked
shirt, stout boots,
large cabbage-tree
hat and a sort of
blue flannel frock
confined at the
waist by a leather
belt.

Author: RICHARDSON
Quote:
... blue woollen
shirt girthed around
the waist by a brown
leather belt.

Author: HODDER
Quote:
Proprietor of a farm
... seen in the
village in a blue
smock-frock ...]

Author: YOUNG
Quote:
He was accompanied
by some of the
Missionaries in
their `bush'
costume, consisting
of a white
`wide-awake' and
other articles to
correspond with it.

The back bush
country is being
rapidly cleared for
pastoral purposes,
chiefly
sheep-grazing.

The best fern-root
grew on freshly
burnt bush country
..

Author: COWAN
Quote:
To his abilities as
a tracker and scout,
and his capacity for
hard marching in
rough bush country
with a heavy swag of
... provisions.

Author: WILSON
Quote:
Theirs was to be a
bush farm, for the
Government was
opening up some bush
country said to be
the finest land in
all New Zealand.

Author: HOLDEN
Quote:
The dawn chorus of
the birdlife in bush
country during the
late spring ... is
an awe-inspiring
sound.

Author: ROCHFORT
Quote:
In looking across
this lake you
perceive a flat
bush-country.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
`Having followed it
[the road] up for a
few miles to the
bend in the
Turangarere Valley,
we returned to the
Maori track over Te
Horo-o-moeku, from
whence a splendid
view of the [47]
bush country
extending far south
towards Marton, was
obtained.'
Notes: c1880s an anonymous tourist in 1959 L. Masters Tales of the Mails 46-47

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote: `... you would be the right man for the [12] bush country,' McKeown said, `... Flash Harry, who has a contract ... was saying only this morning that he would take on a couple of wages men at bushfalling - so there's a job at hand ...' Ibid. 223 One gets some lovely views in this bush country of yours.

Source: Big Country of the North Island
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
The Matai Moana
block, which is
strong bush country,
normally carries
about 5,000 ewes and
300 Black Poll cows.

4 and 6 tooth woolly
wethers off bush
country.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
The balance, about
twenty-five per
cent, was good bush
country.

Author: DONEY
Quote:
On bush country,
after burning, the
rye grass and
clovers are almost
certain to do well.

5,000 acres - men's
whare, carrying
capacity 2 sheep per
acre, Hawke's Bay
district - first
class land for
cattle; all bush
country.

I am felling and
burning this year 25
acres of bush
country.

The settler on bush
country did not
require a great deal
of capital to start
his farming
operations.

We have always
farmed in steep bush
country...

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
My father was keen
for me to hold on to
my bush country. I
was in favour of
having it fallen out
and converted into
pasture.

Source: Sheep Farming in the NZ Bush
Author: WILLIAMSON
Quote:
Whether bush country
will make good
pastoral country can
usually be
ascertained by the
sort of trees which
are most
predominant. Tawa
bush country will
make good grass
country, whereas
birch bush country
will usually turn
out to be poor.

Source: Pioneer Missionary Among the Maoris, A
Author: GRACE
Quote:
Now they are making
every effort to
reclaim their bush
cows, and great
numbers are milked
regularly
Notes: 1852 Dec 31 T.S.Grace Report of Turanga District in 1928 Grace A Pioneer Missionary 19

Quote:
But between the
prices given at a
bush creamery and
for milk sold for
town supply there is
a wide margin.
Here the edge of a bush-creek is fringed with Muehlenbeckia.
Notes: Checked dec 1989 against AND/OED2: nf references on bush checkfile

Author: WESTMACOTT
Quote:
The actual beds were
made of long
straight saplings
about an inch thick,
on top of which was
spread soft fern and
feathery bush
creeper

bush cricket - an
annual district
picnic and cricket
match, often between
neighbouring
districts.

Author: MONEY
Quote:
... I always had a
couple at least of
wood-hens and ducks,
or bush-crows,
suspended from the
ridge-pole of my
tent.

Author: BOOTH
Quote:
According to bush
custom it was usual
to dub all fresh

until they had
satisfactorily
passed certain
ordeals in bush
life. They should be
able to ride a
buckjumper...

We find no-one "at

billy handy, in
which there is some
good lukewarm tea,
which following the
bush custom, we
proceed to
commandeer.
Refreshed by the
national draught, we
make onwards ...

Author: WASWO
Quote:
In the 1850s bush

with the

The demand for
Northland's "bush
dak" has dropped, he
believes, because of
a shift towards new
genetically
engineered strains
of cannabis, known
as "skunk".

Northland as the
"bush dak" capital
has been mortally
wounded.

City drug users..
are turning away
from the
unsophisticated
"bush dak" of the
Far North to
trendier designer
drugs.

Many growers have

"bush dak".

Author: SHARPE
Quote:
In the middle of
that cable there was
a hell of a sag, and
we could see no way
to evade the
tightening job. As
equipment we had a
`bush devil', a sort
of wire-straining
outfit on which two
men are expected to
apply a pressure up
to twenty tons, and
a massive wrench.
Hooking the strainer
on to the base of a
handy tree we got
its claws, or
whatever you call
them, gripped on the
long cable, above
the turn buckle, and
worked the lever
until the joined
sections were slack.

Author: WESTMACOTT
Quote:
I think he is one of
these bush diamonds,
rough on the
outside.

Mr Gilruth visited
the Rotorua bush
lands re `bush
disease' ...

27. Aston, B.C.:
Bush Disease.

"Bush" Disease. This
affliction appears
to be due rather to
innutrition [sic]
than to any disease,
and is apparently
confined to the
Rotorua district.
The animals seem to
pine away, but if
removed to other and
older pastures they
usually recover.

Bush-disease in
Cattle. Beyond a few
cases belonging to a
settler of Arahiwi,
I have not seen
anything.

[Hdg] "Tauranga" or
"Bush Disease". This
peculiar wasting
disease, which is
confined to the
tract of land lying
in the vicinity of
Tauranga, and
extending from there
to Rotorua and
Lichfield, was made
the subject of an
investigation by Mr.
Park three years
ago... It appears
that both sheep and
cattle will do well
and put on condition
for the first few
months after being
placed on this
diseased country,
but as time goes on
a gradual wasting
sets in, which ends
in death if they are
not removed to
another district.

All the evidence
gathered points to
the condition being
one of malnutrition
rather than of
disease, properly
speaking, and I have
therefore adopted
the term 'bush
sickness' in
connection with it,
instead of 'bush
disease' as
heretofore.

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush

Quote:
Bush drain: the next
cheapest
alternative. Dig the
trench at least 900
mm deep. Put in a
600mm layer of
branches with fine
leaves and twigs at
the top to stop soil
filtering down into
the bigger wood. If
you have a cheap
metal Source, use
about 450mm of scrub
then 150 mm of
coarse shingle.

Self-consciously
clad in their bush
dress, `essential
attire', they were
hanging-on in there
