...

Author: HINDMARSH
Quote:
A 'bush drive' was
contrived by cutting
the trees up the
slopes only
partially through,
then the ones at the
top on the ridges
were felled
completely and these
would carry those
below down the whole
hillside in a
spectacular fashion.

Those great crashing
bush-drives, when
one tree was aimed
to hit another
partly-cut tree,
which in turn
smashed into another
half-severed tree,
and so on smashing
and roaring downhill
to the gully's
bottom, ... the bush
snails dying, the
woodhens confounded,
the brown pebbled
creek and all its
reflections from the
beginning shrinking
back in dismay.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
It was a wonderful
sight to watch a
bush drive. It was a
work of art and
those bushmen were
experts.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
A "bush-drive":
that's a really
terrific thing if
you haven't seen
one.

Quote:

Bush fighting is a
comprehensive term

ground and on the

heaven, there bush
fighting can be
practised, and it is
highly useful to
practise it as a
part of army
manoeuvres.

fragrant in early
spring); ...

... the once silent
woods now resound
with the blows of
the felling-axe ...
the Wattle-bird is
no longer to be
found in its old
haunts; it seeks
shelter amongst the
higher parts of the
bushy gullies ...
the condition of the
forest is changing
under the effects of
...
constantly-recurring
bush fires. ... The
Kokako loving a
moist temperature
will probably soon
entirely forsake its
ancient places of
resort.

Very bright Aurora
australis due south
at 9.30, 10 etc.
Abner has seen this
light two or three
times lately ...
They thought it was
a bush fire.

Author: LADY MARTIN
Quote:
Far away up this
vista, some thin
blue smoke went up
from a bush fire.

Author: HOPEFUL
Quote:
... there were
fearful bush-fires
on the west coast of
the North Island at
Taranaki, whence
many of the settlers
had to flee for
their lives.

Author: D'AVIGDOR
Quote:
When the base of the
mountains is veiled
... by the blue
smoke of the too
frequent bush-fires,
the sharp peaks seem
to rise to empyrean
heights ...

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
Bush fires were now
more frequent.
Decaying timber, the
remnants of former
fires, ... and
stumps were now like
tinder.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Bush-fire, ... forests and grass on fire in hot summers. 1868. C. Dilke, `Greater Britian, `vol. ii. part iii. c. iii. p. 32:

... we find
extensive tracts of
forest composed
chiefly of beech,
unfortunately fast
disappearing in the
saw-mills and in the
bush-fires which so
frequently devastate
the hillsides.

Author: WHITE
Quote:
The New Zealand
Quail, which was
very plentiful, is
nearly extinct now:
Bush-fires have
burnt it, and dogs,
cats, and rats have
eaten it, but the
Australian and
Californian
varieties have
filled its place.

Author: SCANLAN
Quote:
Jessie was used to
bush fires.

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
This was in the big
bush fire that
destroyed so much
property at Waimate
in November, 1878.

And from the
engine-room there
was enough smoke to
make you think there
were not two
kerosene engines
below, but a bush
fire. But even an
Australian bush fire
couldn't smell as
bad.

It was like reading
those school essays
we used to write,
before Professor
Gordon, in which
every noun had to
have at least one
`expressive
adjective', in which
a bush fire was a
fierce holocaust
raging down stately
corridors of ancient
rimus.

We may speak of
kauri forest or
beech forest, but we
get lost in the
bush, fight bush
fires, and climb
above the bushline.
The kauri forest,
like the mixed
podocarp forest, the
sub-tropical rain
forest, ... and
such-like are terms
that come from the
botanist and
forester, not from
the layman - or from
the bushman.

Author: BRABAZON
Quote:
Bush fired. Went to
Norsewood evening.
Home early.

Author: BULLER
Quote:
But, partly owing to
the introduction of
dogs, ... and partly
to the prevalence of
the so-called
`bush-fires' or
burning of the runs
(a necessary
incident of
sheep-farming in a
new country), the
Quail has rapidly
disappeared ...

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
As the casualty was
getting worse while
the final touches
were being put on to
the building, the
party had to leave
without having a
chance to try the
bush fireplace,
always a touchy
thing to build.

The houses in this
neighbourhood have
been in some danger
from bush firings
... then just as
several people had
lighted their
clearings a strong
gale from the
south-east, what is
called here `the
mountain wind',
sprang up. In a few
hours all the dead
trees and stumps in
the neighbourhood
were on fire.

Bush-firing and
logging up is a job
which is often given
to a new chum.

Author: RICHMOND
Quote:
The houses in the
neighbourhood have
been in some danger
from the bush
firings.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
The mustering of
this block involved
combing the bush
flats with the dogs.

Source: Along the Track: a collection of NZ hunting yarns
Author: AXBEY
Quote:
We worked our way up
the valley, seeing
the old cow and
young bull as we
went, until finally
we located a good
camping spot on a
bush-flat beside the
river.

Another very
considerable stream
running through fine
bush flats.

... secluded lagoons
on the bush-flats in
the vicinity of Lake
Brunner.

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
Four deer and three
hours later we came
to a long bush-flat
where the trees were
enormous.

Notes: (And) [bush flax] Cockayne Report on Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island
(And) [b-flax] Cockayne Botanical Survey Tongariro National Park

Author: RICHARDS
Quote: ASTELIA ... nervosa ... Bush Flax. KAKAHA (strong).

Author: WILSON
Quote: Astelia fragrans BUSH FLAX ... Kakaha ... Big fresh green tussocky clumps up to about 1 m tall. ... (= A. nervosa var. sylvestris ).

Kaiwharawhara was
the food of the bush
flax, the edible
young leaves and
stems of a plant
found growing in the
forked branches of
the puketea tree.

Cockayne Botanical
Survey Stewart
Island

In the southern part
of the Hawera
district, early bush
flows of nectar can
be expected from
five finger, Maori
privet, and kowhai
from September
onward.

The Parroquet may be
frequently observed
in confinement, and
the Tui ... has to
exchange for the
dewy nectar of bush
flowers, a
monotonous diet of
soaked bread ...

Author: BULLER
Quote: [The Bell-bird's] food consists of ... small berries, such as those of the karamu (Coprosma lucida) and other shrubs, and the honey of various kinds of bush-flowers.

Author: MAY
Quote:
Bush flies,
mosquitoes and
sandflies were
numbered among the
lesser scourges.
Food, blankets and
clothes were quickly
`blown'; ...

Author: NEAME
Quote:
He dried his
whitebait on coconut
matting and
preserved it that
way to the delight
of many blowflies
referred to by
native West Coasters
as bush flies.

Author: FORRESTER
Quote:
Goodwin was a
pioneer in bush
flying in New
Zealand.

Author: FORRESTER
Quote:
.. It's the sort of
thing a pilot is not
supposed to do, but
I had to get out
that day and I made
it. That's what bush
flying is all about.

Author: DONEY
Quote:
I am glad to say
that most of the
bush folks know how
to work.

Author: HYDE
Quote:
Rannock fed his
prison labour on
honest bush food:
fresh meat, billy
tea, enormous flat
damper scones cooked
on the three-legged
camp oven.

Author: COWAN
Quote: A rather good bush vegetable is the pikopiko, the curled shoots of the mauku fern. The natives have long given up the use of these bush foods; ...

Author: FINLAYSON
Quote:
Jake hesitates.
There's a loneliness
about the bush and
something that pulls
taut the nerves. ...
No wonder the
pioneers burnt the
bush. Jake remembers
old settlers
speaking about such
experiences. Bush
fright, they
reckoned.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
The sweetest of the
bush fruits was the
tawhara (the fruit
of the kiekie) but
unfortunately it
only bore fruit and
ripened once every
seven years.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
They unloaded a
packhorse and
brought in a dozen
bags of bush fungus,
the hakeke of the
Maori, which grows
on old stumps and
logs so plentifully.
Now fungus was
always a marketable
commodity, for the
China market; it
brought sixpence a
pound or more from
the storekeepers,
who sold it to the
town dealers; it
went to make a
choice soup for rich
Chinese.

Author: HUNT
Quote:
Our chief source of
revenue was to
gather in the bush
fungus, which
usually grew upon
the dead and partly
decayed stems of
karaka and mahoe
trees, dry it in the
open air, and sell
it to the Chinese
merchants

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
A bush gang must
always work as a
team and work a
block accordingly,
... A bushman has
two meals during the
day, one at 10 a.m.
and the next at 2
p.m. They are always
referred to as
`smoko'.

Source: Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The
Author: MAHONEY
Quote:
The camps were
company-owned and
provided bush gangs
with accomodation
and meals close to
the job.

Author: CLEVELAND
Quote:
The bush gang drag
out the logs they
have cut.

Author: NGAWHIKA
Quote:
In November of '84
the opportunity of
employment with the
freezing company
came up so left the
bush gang to start
work at their Mamaku
plant.

Author: HINDMARSH
Quote:
He ranged the bush
blocks and employed
the predominantly
Ngapuhi bush gangs
to cut 1665 acres in
the winter of 1911.

Source: In the Wake of the Axe
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
For some years she
cooked for bush
gangs, her home some
bush shanty away up
a hidden gully.

Author: HOLMES
Quote:
Initially ... they
[Maoris] set about
felling and clearing
areas of bush in
readiness for
cultivation ... This
forming of `bush
gardens' was the
traditional means of
claiming invaded
territory.

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote:
Very frequently, as
bush boys and girls
well know, their
[Muehlenbeckia]
rope-like stems hang
swaying from the
forest roof ....

Author: CARR
Quote:
.. there was a grove
of kahikatea trees
with a small patch
of bush-grass just
in front.

Anyone with a large
capital can take up
a block of bush
ground.

The venture
[sheep-grazing in
bush] will be
watched with
interest, as there
are many persons who
argue that bush
ground is not suited
to sheep farming.

Author: DONEY
Quote:
Anyone can, with a
large capital, take
up a block of bush
ground and have it
felled, burned,
grassed and stocked.

A piece of bush
ground is in general
preferred for the
purpose ...

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
... across the horse
paddock to the mouth
of the bush gully.

Author: EVANS
Quote:
Pigs were very
plentiful in the
bush gullies of Mt
Misery, only a few
hundred yards away
from his camp

Author: BEACH
Quote:
The terrain here was
gorsey faces, and
native bush gullies
which ran from the
flat to the main
ridge.

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
His window looked
out towards the bush
gully.

Author: BEACH
Quote:
.. it was about 300
acres in area and
consisted of bush
gullies, native
grass and on the far
side, manuka and
tauhinu.

Author: LANCASTER
Quote: ... sneaking down to the bush-gully to conduct her orisons among the birds. Ibid. 175 Great bronze pigeons cooed ... down in the bush-gully ...

Author: MALCOLM
Quote:
Bush gum was
obtained by climbing
the trees.. and one
man would pull the
other up into the
tree where he used a
hatchet to harvest
the gum.

The [kauri-gum]
samples analysed
were - (a) Resin
recently secreted by
the tree; (b) resin
which had been a
long time exposed to
air or lying in
store (bush gum);
(c) fossil resin
(range gum); (d)
resin obtained from
peat-bogs
(swamp-gum).

The kauri Gum
Commission of 1921
recommended a
standard grading
comprising some
thirt different
grades of fossil gum
and four grades of
bush gum.

Source: Along the Track: a collection of NZ hunting yarns
Author: AXBEY
Quote:
.. there are plenty
of .450-577 and .577
lying around,
rusting - not much
good for open
country, but ideal
bush guns.

Author: but
Quote:
[?station hand] How
many hands shall you
want? We will say a
couple of good bush
hands, who will put
up your hut and
yards and wool-shed.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
First came two of
the most experienced
`bush-hands,', who
carried a tomahawk
or light axe ..

I have to thank the
men who accompanied
me, who proved
themselves
first-rate bush
hands, and well
earned the extra
wages paid.
Notes: Wilmot `Report to Parliament' in 1950 Reed and Reed Farthest West 182

Quote:
... a bush-hand,
living the life of a
hermit in his little
whare of tree-fern
stems, up in the
Waio river-bed.
Notes (Potts)

In the kauri
distrct, bush-hands
are commonly paid
20s., or rarely 18s.
per week, with board
and lodgings ...

Author: MANDER
Quote:
He had the gumfield
trade in full, and
most of that now
done by the bush
hands.

Author: HOWE
Quote:
When he heard that
bush-hands were
wanted, he and Mum
moved into the
Kanaeranga bush.

... a bush-hand,
living the life of a
hermit in his little
whare of tree-fern
stems, up in the
Waio river-bed.

Amongst the sporting
events of John
McKellar's time were
the wild pig hunts
he organised for
townspeople, bush
hands etc and many
great days were held
on the hills ...

Author: BEETHAM
Quote:
Oct.9th. Commenced
hauling off logs
with bullocks when
the fellows came
with their
assistance made a
bush harrow and
saved all the land I
had grubbed; ...
Notes: 1858 Oct 9 William Beetham Diary in 1967 Rickard Strangers in the Wilderness 98

Author: WAITE
Quote:
The seed was merely
thrown down, and a
large bush harrow
drawn by four or
five Maoris, with
two women riding on
the brush to keep it
down, was all the
cultivation thought
of.

Author: BEETHAM
Quote:
Made a bush harrow
and sowed all the
lands I had grubbed.
Notes: in Rickard (1967) Strangers in the Wilderness

Author: BAGNALL
Quote:
The early trials of
fending off wild
dogs, pit-sawing,
grubbing and bush
harrowing had given
way to massive
improvements,
grassing and
stocking.

Author: WATERSON
Quote:
An hour later, after
a lot of bailing
using Wart's bush
hat, they had
managed to make the
rocky shoreline.

bush hat - forestry
hard hat.

This usually
consisted of my
brother's ... boots
... my cherished
bush hat (a cross
between an
Australian outback
hat and a Daniel
Boone cap) and my
... parka.

Author: MARRIOT-WATSON
Quote:
Throwing himself
again on the
bracken, he pushed
his bush-hat from
his head.

Author: HUTTON & DRUMMOND
Quote:
The Bush-hawk or
Sparrow-hawk, lives
in the mountains,
where the forest is
low and dense.

Author: JARDINE
Quote:
The kea shares the
mastery .. with
another .. rejoicing
in the name of Falco
novaseelandiae,
commonly called the
sparrowhawk in the
south, bush-hawk
elsewhere.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
Bush hawk: a North
Island term for the
bird known as
sparrow hawk.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
The accident took
place out at
Andersons Camp,
twenty miles in from
Mt White and the
wounded man was
sledged out on a
'bush hearse.' A
bush hearse, I
should explain, is a
forked branch
dragged V end first
with a litter rigged
up on the fork of
the branches.

Author: HAY
Quote: The Weka ... is found plentifully in the woods. Settlers call it the `bush-hen'. Ibid. 2/337 We wish it had been a weka, or bush-hen, as that is more succulent eating; ...
bush hen NZ = WEKA.

The sea-gulls would
come down by the
shore and bush-hens
would call as it
grew dark and then
only our sad native
owl would cry upon
the night.

As far as we can see
roll the bush hills,
fold on fold.

Author: MACINTOSH
Quote:
.. the creeks began
in the bush hills
and flowed out as
clean pebbly
rivulets ...

In taking a bush
hive, honey wax,
pollen, propolis,
brood and dirt
generally get mixed
a good deal..which
accounts for people
being upset after
eating bush honey.
..Maoris have been
upset after eating
honey taken from a
bush hive.

They [beekeepers]
trust that the bush
hives will build up
again in time to
deal with the manuka
flow. ibid. 427
Usually there is a
light flow from
Maori privet
(Geniostoma
ligustrifolium) in
this area, and this
surplus is taken
from the bush hives
in early November.

From the description
you give of your
bush holding, you
have fenced the
front and sides but
not the back.

.. I strongly
advocated the
'community'
sheep-dip, and
yards, for bands of
new settlers,
starting upon new
bush holdings in the
hinterlands of our
forest country.

Author: HOWITT
Quote:
.. my father found
himself at the age
of 23 the owner of a
bush holding in
Taranaki.

Author: LYON
Quote:
... I never knew the
pakeha to suffer any
after-effects from
the use of bush
honey, and I have
felled many bee
trees.

Author: KEENE
Quote:
We usually had a
good supply of bush
honey [ca1900]. The
most likely place to
find it was in a
hollow tree.

Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Quote:
A strongly flavoured
New Zealand bush
honey is best for
this dish.
[Canterbury lamb
with honey]

Author: BEARDSLEY
Quote:
It meant shorter
hours at the mill,
less milk ..., less
bush honey from
their hives.

It seems to be the
opinion of some that
the New Zealand bush
honey is not much
good. ..But it is
only a description
of the bush honey
got in January...

In taking a bush
hive, honey wax,
pollen, propolis,
brood and dirt
generally get mixed
a good deal..which
accounts for people
being upset after
eating bush honey.

Most important in
the production of
bush honey is the
location of the
apiary. If manuka
honey is the aim,
care should be taken
to see that the site
chosen is suitable,
not only for that
particular honey,
but also for native
bush honey if
possible.

Author: LUSH
Quote:
The Bishop has often
told me she is a
first-rate bush
horse and so she
proved herself to be
- she went on and on
- in and out -
struggling through
this and plunging
through that and at
last, ... emerged on
the road and near
the spot where
Jessie had parted
from me.

Author: BOOTH
Quote:
The trained bush
horse will stand
quietly where his
rider leaves him ...

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
In his reminiscences
to me Mr James
Pollock said, `Old
White at Pyramid had
a cloot hotel,' so
it was presumably a
canvas edifice. The
`old hands' used to
tell some queer
stories about this
`bush hotel' and did
so with an amusing
mixture of
condemnation for its
worst features and
pride in its
eccentricities.

Author: MEEK
Quote:
Went over the 'crow'
at the bush hotel
for a riotous
non-stop jag.

Source: Colonial Outcasts: A Search for the Remittance Man
Author: HARTLEY
Quote:
It took Harry some
time to locate Ned
and not unexpectedly
found him drinking
in the bar of a bush
hotel.

Source: Reminiscences of a New Chum in Otago
Author: SCOTT
Quote:
It is a dish fit for
kings and if ever
you pitch your camp
at a bush 'hotel'
ask for kaka stew as
a favour.

Author: BRUNNER
Quote:
Having constructed
our framework, the
thatch, or covering,
was the difficulty
... We would ...
brave the storm for
another handful of
grass, toitoi,or any
other accessible
material - so that
about midnight, we
could call our
covering water-tight
for a bush house.
Notes: 1848 Mar 21 Brunner Exped. Middle Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 310

Author: SATCHELL
Quote:
`Come around to the
bush-house' ... They
seated themselves
together on a rustic
seat among the
ferns.

Author: WHITE
Quote:
Glass structures can
be too hot here in
summer, so my plants
are migratory, and
go out under the
shade of trees, or
into a skeleton [23]
shed with bushes
round the sides and
forming the roof,
commonly called a
`bush-house,' and
for summer these
places afford much
pleasure and
occupation; ...

Common in damp bush;
also cultivated in
bush houses on the
island ...

The main objects of
a bush-house is
[sic] to subdue the
intense sunlight,
keep a cool moist
atmosphere around
the plants, and to
protect them from
hot or dry winds.

Author: HOLDEN
Quote:
Most bush hunters at
one time or other
have encountered
stags trapped in
this grim fashion.

Author: FORRESTER
Quote:
.. the moment a
pilot starts to
hunt, it becomes
evident whether he
has been a good
foot-slogging bush
hunter.

Author: HUNT
Quote:
The little hut was
quite comfy for a
bush hut ...

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
It was not long
before the Rongo
family instructed
the brothers in
building a ponga and
nikau whare (bush
hut) alongside their
tent, in which they
could cook and eat
their meals.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
To add to the spice
was the bush hut
that was being built
upriver in the
Wanganui opposite
Plover Flat.

Author: McLEAN
Quote:
We slept at the Heu
Heu posts, where
Pohe erected a good
bush-hut.

Author: MURDOCH
Quote:
The floor of [Moa
Hut] is of clay, and
the roof without any
ceiling. Still, it
is warm and
comfortable enough,
and is a very good
example of a bush
hut.
Notes: 1860 Feb Wallace Murdock Journal quoted in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 116

Author: BARKER
Quote:
... the mistress of
this charming
`bush-hut'
[previously `a
picturesque
gable-ended little
cottage surrounded
by a rustic fence]
insisted on our
having some hot
coffee and scones
and wild honey ...

Author: HUNT
Quote:
The little hut was
quite comfy for a
bush hut: just two
rooms and no
luxuries.

Author: LANGDALE-HUNT
Quote:
I remember Jim ...
telling me in his
early years on Pitt
Island he was riding
past a bush hut
which Ned Moore and
his wife were
occupying while Ned
was felling bush.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
It was not long
before the Rongo
family instructed
the brothers in
building a ponga and
nikau whare (bush
hut) alongside their
tent, in which they
could cook and eat
their meals.

Author: ROCHFORT
Quote:
At sunset we reached
Rangitikei. The
`house of call' was
here situated on the
opposite side of the
river, ... At least
Scott, the landlord,
came over and
ferried us across to
his house, which is
the best bush inn in
New Zealand -
containing six or
seven good-sized
rooms with glass
windows.

Author: GAMBIER
Quote:
We ... marched
[c1860] on foot
through the
wonderful forest to
a small bush inn
kept by a man called
Selby, ...

Merv is one of 13
bush inspectors
employed throughout
New Zealand by the
Department of
Labour. Each is a
man of many years of
experience in his
field. Their
principal concern is
the safety and
welfare of all
persons in `bush
undertakings and
sawmills'

Source: Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A
Author: ADAMS
Quote:
A little more
experience in
`bushing it' would
have taught us to
have left the bush
at once to its fate
...

Source: Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A
Author: ADAMS
Quote:
A little more
experience in
'bushing it' would
have taught us to
have left the bush
at once to its own
fate.

Author: GOLDIE
Quote:
I resolved to
scramble along the
side of the lake ..
even though we had
to 'bush it' for a
night or two.

Author: WILMOT
Quote:
Homer unable to work
today because of the
`bush itch' and the
men got their
blankets flyblown.
Notes: c1882-1883 Wilmot's Diary in 1968 Hall-Jones Early Fiordland 159

Quote: Mr Johnstone [a Kaikohe fisherman] was wearing knee-length gumboots and a bush-jacket. `I kicked my gumboots off and had to get down under the water to pull my swanny over my head,' he said last night.

A bush jacket
containing personal
possessions
belonging to the
missing Rastafarian
was found not far
from the body,
police said.

Source: Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The
Author: MAHONEY
Quote: Bush jiggers were the motor-driven creations used to transport humans along bush trams... Small hand-worked jiggers were used extensively on the NZR but they were not common on trams... The first bush jiggers were constructed early in the 20th century... The earliest confirmed jigger appeared in April 1908 when it was reported that a trolley had been built by Gamman at Te Ohu to convey 10-12 men to and from work... The principal use of bush jiggers was to get the bushmen to and from work. Compared to other options they were faster, safer,warmer, and drier. Ibid. 58 The development of the bush jigger spelled the end for most bush camps because they made it possible to travel to work over long distances in comparative speed and comfort.

HOMESTEAD SYSTEM.
Under this system
the settler makes no
payment for the
land, the only cost
to him being the
expenses of survey.
On the fulfilment of
conditions, which
are five years'
residence, the
erection of a house,
and the cultivation
of one-third of the
selection if open
land, and one-fifth
if bush-land, the
Crown grant is
issued. `Do you own
any land?' `Yes,
three hundred acres
of bush land.' `Have
you any cleared?'
`Sixty acres'.
[ca1900]

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush

Author: THOMSON
Quote: It took us three hours to reach the open basin above the bush level ...Ibid. 51 ... the large open faces above the bush level. Ibid. 71 The snow that was still on the tops above bush level was the main reason why the deer were so plentiful. Ibid. 121 The high `tops' are practically free from snow, and the `waps' will be out above bush level seeking the young tussock growth. Ibid. 123 The bush-covered mountains reached from the water's edge up to the natural bush level, about three and a half thousand feet up.

The native fuchsia [fn Fuchsia excorticata .] - an exile from South America - and the fierce bush-nettle [fn Urtica ferox .] are conspicuous amongst the undergrowth, together with the bush-lily [fn Astelia nervosa.], but we see but few species of the characteristic New Zealand daisy-trees [fn Species of Olearia .] or of the bushy Veronicas (koromiko), which are so conspicuous in other parts of these islands.

Author: MAHONEY
Quote: The typical bush lokey of this early period was the four-wheel direct-drive type imported from England weighing between 5 and 10 onnes. Ibid 79 A special type of bush lokey was developed to operate over these newer lines which were built far beyond the alignment limits of 'normal' railways. Because more power was required, the special bush lokeys were bigger than those used previously. Ibid. 83 The introduction of the first bush lokeys in New Zealand was concurrent with the initial railway construction boom and the first steam-powered mineral railways.

Quote:
They bought a good
supply of provisions
.. not omitting a
bottle of Perry
Davis' Painkiller,
the latter a
valuable bush
medicine ...

While on the subject
of bush medicine, I
may as well mention
a few others.

Source: Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The
Author: MAHONEY
Quote:
A 'Bush mill' was
timber industry
vernacular for a
sawmill sited close
to the bush working
rather than sited
close to
'civilisation' -
usually meaning the
local town or at
least the local
railway station. The
rationale for
establishing a bush
mill was economic.

... the labours and
sufferings of a New
Zealand
bush-missionary.

While her husband
won honourable
mention as one of
the earliest bush
missionaries, she,
unhonoured and
unsung, kept the
small farm going ...

Bush Mixtures: Under
the term "bush
sowings" or "bush
mixtures" hundreds
of sacks of
screenings and old
low-germinating
seeds are
distributed in New
Zealand every year.
In a great many of
cases, bush mixtures
are stocked ready
mixed and are
offered to bargain
hunters as good
quality seed.

Harold's wife Joan
played an important
part and became a
friend and 'bush
mother' to
generations of
students.
A beautiful bush-musician in the South Island ... is the bell- bird (korimako or makomako).

It was rather a
hazardous
undertaking ... as
it sometimes happens
in these paths,
straggling
bush-natives attack
and kill such
persons who they
fall in with,
helpless.

Not a week has
passed without my
having had to make
communication to
Europeans living at
a distance from the
Waimate; and
whatever might be
the value of what
was to be sent, I
had no hesitation in
giving it in charge
to a bush-native,
accustomed to
Europeans, but has
all his life resided
among his own
people.

It was rather a
hazardous
undertaking ... as
it sometimes happens
in these paths,
straggling
bush-natives attack
and kill such
persons who they
fall in with,
helpless.

Author: YATE
Quote:
Not a week has
passed without my
having had to make
communication to
Europeans living at

the value of what
was to be sent, I
had no hesitation in

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
... from all I have
seen in New Zealand,
I am convinced that
the formidable
pictures of
bush-natives which
have been drawn are
purely the result of
imagination. The
natives in general
are much too
civilised and
social, and know
their own interests
too well, to live in
a gloomy and
inhospitable forest.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
They were not bush
natives of the
Ngaticahoon tribe.

[reference is to a
very warlike tribe]
They are bush
natives and all
heathens.

Bush natives who
know their advantage
better than to live
in an inhospitable
bush.

Source: Notes of an Expedition to Kawatiri and Araura
Author: HEAPHY
Quote:
Ekehu discovered
signs of the place
having been recently
occupied by natives
... We were yet 75
miles from ... the
Ngaitahu tribe ...
Were they bush
natives? Jacky and
Etau appeared to
think the vicinity
of such individuals
rather
objectionable.
Notes: 1846 Heaphy Expedition to Kawatiri in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 223

Quote:
It was rather a
hazardous
undertaking my going
so unprovided, as it
sometimes happens in
these parts, that
straggling
bush-natives attack
and kill such
persons as they fall
in with, helpless.

Author: PETER
Quote:
bush nightie: a
black bushman's
singlet.

bush nightie: black
bush singlet.

bush nightie: a bush
shirt or Swanndri.

The bush nurse has
been simply
invaluable for
child-birth.

Probably the most
lasting effect began
with the early
formation of the
'bush nurse' or
emergency
housekeeper scheme.

Author: BATES
Quote:
( Another good
night, no crashes )
and I was awakened
by my bush orchestra
which seemed to play
an extra piece for
my special benefit.

Packed up my boxes
and prepared bush
outfit. Took section
up Dublin St.

Author: BARBER
Quote:
During operations in
the bush the armed
constables wore
`bush outfits', and
called themselves
`shawl parties',
referring to the
woollen shawl used
as a kilt, and
easily discarded
while crossing
streams, thus
avoiding the
discomfort of wet
trouser legs.

(Report on Grasses)
In the North it is
usually relied upon
for the staple,
especially on bush
paddocks.

John & W Torkilsen
went to see Potts at
Takapau about
purchasing the
totara in one of his
bush paddocks.

Another experiment
with a similar
dressing was carried
out in a bush
paddock, two sheep
and a young steer
being placed on it.

Bush paddocks are
shut up in summer in
preparation for
shearing time, as
shelter is paramount
depending on weather
conditions.

Author: BAUGHAN
Quote:
That bit o' bush
paddock I fall'd
myself.

Two plants that
furnish "bush
painkiller," the
pepper tree and the
pepper-wood, or
horopito, both with

hot taste, have been
investigated.

NESTOR MERIDIONALIS,
Gml. Kaka. Bush
Parrot.

Author: ALEXANDER & CURRIE
Quote: Kaka: bush parrot.

Quote:
The kaka, or bush
parrot, was killed

Quote: Kaka Nestor meridionalis (GMELIN, 1788) ... OTHER NAMES: Brown parrot, bush parrot; ...

Mr McGillivray
followed on the side
of the Government.
This is another
Scotchman and a bush
parson, with strong
leanings to the
Mosaic law and a
very severe ritual.

The bush party have
now been away a
fortnight.

Author: RICHMOND
Quote:
The bush party have
[sic] now been away
a fortnight and some
days.

Author: RICHMOND
Quote:
Last night the bush
party returned
earlier than usual.
There had nearly
been a sad accident
in felling a pine;
in falling it struck
another tree and the
head split .. Hal
and Arthur were
quite buried ...

The road had been a
tolerable bush-path.

Author: LUSH
Quote:
It is a very long
time since I had
such a thorough bush
path to traverse,
... The forest was
very beautiful and
as I rode slowly
along, pushing my
way through the
undergrowth, ...

Author: MANSFIELD
Quote:
We got great sprays
of clematis - and
konini, and drove
first through a bush
path

Author: MULGAN
Quote:
She and Philip
walking together
along bush paths ...
[sic] long silences
... [sic]

Author: HYDE
Quote:
She started to walk
to the Domain
[Auckland] by a
little bush path
which lanced the
side of the reserve,
coming out near a
flagged lily-pond.

Author: PHARAZYN
Quote:
... one wether lamb
staked in bush pen
and after drowned.

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
The way in which the
bush people - the
bushmen and their
wives - stuck to one
another is shown by
the way they rallied
round in the case of
a family that was in
need. A common
method of raising
money was called a
`basket social'. A
hall would be used
for the function,
and the people of
the district would
be invited to bring
along baskets. Now
these baskets were
made of any material
at all at hand, and
it was remarkable
the ingenuity and
workmanship shown in
making them. ... In
the basket its maker
put a supper, the
food cooked at home
... [151] Now on the
night of the basket
social, all the
baskets would be
handed in ... They
would then be
auctioned, and the
purchaser of the
basket would have
the pleasure and the
honour of having
supper with the
provider of the
basket. ... Now I've
seen them pay twelve
... pounds in those
days for a basket,
just to make sure
that the girl of the
boy's choice saw
that he really meant
business. ... Every
penny of that would
go to the family in
need ...

Author: HAY
Quote:
The Old Colonial is
a bush-philosopher,
and delivers himself
of moral orations in
the shanty of
nights.

[introduction] ...
the moralisings of
his bush philosopher
Bill.

When it begins to
get chilly we wander
homewards, all
feeling refreshed
after our bush
picnic.

Author: FERGUSON
Quote:
A BUSH PICNIC
[title]

Author: ANTHONY
Quote:
My mind kept
returning to the
events of that bush
picnic.

Author: HOLDEN
Quote:
It was obvious that
Felicity was not at
all an outdoor girl,
nor was she dressed
for a bush picnic,
but the arrangements
were too elaborate
to be cancelled.

bush picnic: a
shambles.

The latest addition
to our urban
population is a
two-months-old bush
pig, who, having
made friends with Mr
H. Walsh somewhere
in the Toko regions,
was brought by him
into town.

He always did have a
temper like a bush
pig.

Author: W WILLIAMS
Quote:
Got from them a
supply of pork as
they had killed two
bush pigs during
their delay, and
gave them in return
some of our bread.

Other parties out
this way take
considerable
interest in the
young lambs, namely
the wild bush-pigs,
which are very
plentiful, and a
great nuisance...

Author: LEE
Quote:
We lived on
potatoes, bread and
butter, bully beef
where there no bush
pigs, little else.

Author: CARR
Quote:
We ought to have
known that we would
not come across bush
pigs away down here.

It appeared that one of the eldest ... was upset in the path by a wild bush-pig, at full gallop, running against him with its utmost force; ... Ibid. 1/313 Here, on the contrary, the Australasian pigs rove amid the bushes and plains, free as the air, until their presence is requested ... Many wild bush pigs have been brought to me weighing three hundred pounds.

The bush pig is ...

In most places there

The bush-pig is
occasionally hunted
by both white men
and Maories, but
never with any other
view than to obtain

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
A person who could

In the 1865 .. the

hair and wild,
bush-pig look.

Author: KOEBEL
Quote:
Mutton down to the
price of bush-pig.

I allude to the
pitiable sight of
well-to-do settlers,
and settlers' sons,
hurrying to the
steamer with
back-loads and
horse-loads of bush
pigeons for sale.

Investigation almost
always shows that
that the bird thus
pursued is either
the rare and useful
"morepork" or owl,
or a Native bush
pigeon, both of
which, by the way
are at present
supposed to be under
the protection of
the law.

Author: McLEAN

party was hospitably

There are numbers of

birds; ...

A bush pigeon
sometimes sat in
that tree in the
quiet morning
sunshine.
The bush-pigeon (carpophaga ovae-zealandiae), known in the north by the Maori name kukupa, is fast becoming scarce.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
Bush Pigeon - - -
Few, but increasing.

time of it surveying
a block on the
ranges up the
Wai-o-hine in the

Once ...[sic] they
had nothing to eat
but a tui and a
more-pork. ... They
were stewing the two
birds when a kuku-pa
(bush pigeon) flew
up and perched. Bob
shot it ... This is
not exactly what the
Britishers call
`sport' - but there
is more of nature
about it than 30
gents in pink and
tops ... waiting for
a wretched little
fox who, when he is
killed, is not equal
for culinary
purposes to a
more-pork. Once
coming up the
Waikato in 1851 your
Uncle James got a
pot-shot at a lot of
parera (grey duck)
...

Following World War

emerged in New

areas.

legion - is not

discouraged.

He is widely

Quote:

sheep-station.

Quote:

Quote:

of bush rats, huge
brutes that were
eaten by the
moreporks. Mr Thomas

standard practice to
give the pungas a
hearty whack and
then leap back to
dodge at least a
couple of rats ...

Quote:
Bush telegraphy is a
mystic phenomenon
and I pondered and
wondered how the
news of the visit to
this distant village
could have reached
these hospitable
people when only
late the night
before was the visit
suggested.

Author: FAIRBURN
Quote:
I have an elaborate
spy system, In
Wellington as well
as here ...
Bureaucracy and
bush-telegraphy go
together.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
HEEL HORSE: Last
horse in single file
team (bush term).
Notes: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 186

Source: Along the Track: a collection of NZ hunting yarns
Author: AXBEY
Quote:
A couple of hours
later, the others
arrived back with a
rifle and I followed
the track out on to
a bush terrace.

Author: CURTIS
Quote:
It was only midday
when we arrived so
we had plenty of
time to hunt some
interesting bush
terraces.

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
... the promoters of
these bush townships
- whether it were
the Government,
private companies
[21] or individuals,
or a supplementing
of the former by the
latter - made the
boundaries of them
wide enough ...

Another forde,
another bush track.

Wishing to reach the
Wairoa Road, Mr Hill
assured me there was
a bush track which
would take me there
in 6 miles. ...

Author: BAINES
Quote: On most bush tracks men follow each other - Indian file - and all excepting the leader pay little attention to the road they are going; those who would become good bushmen would do well to lead ..Ibid. 281 After dinner we rode along a bush track through the forest to call on Mr. Page ...

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
It [sc a badly made
bale] makes an ugly
and bulky bundle of
merchandise, ...
[eliciting]

sundry, starting

who has to [97] load
and cart it over the
natural bush tracks
... [to] the made
roads.

Author: MONEY
Quote:
... the landlord ...
asked me if I had
searched the bush
track leading from
his shanty to the
inn from whence I

Source: Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
Author: HAAST
Quote:
... I found
afterwards, the
so-called bush-track

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
"This bush track had

Adams camp at
Paengaroa, on the
Main Trunk Line."
Notes: c1880s an anonymous tourist in 1959 L. Masters Tales of the Mails 47

Author: BULLER
Quote:
At the time ... this

Foxton, or by a rude
bush-track - one of
the Maori war-paths
of former times.

Author: MANSFIELD
Quote:
He guided us through
the bush track by
the river.

Author: BOREHAM
Quote:
On the Lone Bush
Track [chapter
heading]

Author: JOHNSON
Quote:
Donald McCormick ...

track from their
father's station
four miles further
down the Sound.

Source: In the Grip of an Island
Author: SANSOM
Quote: When I was eleven my ... brother and I were walking ... round the bush track to school. We left early to carry the billies of milk ... to the settlement to the homes of children. Ibid.31 Trampers who walk the four-mile bush track from Halfmoon Bay ...come out on the open green patch ...

Author: RICHARDS
Quote: There would be miles of carrying their gear through bush tracks before they reached and found `home', just a few survey pegs in the bush. Ibid.24 Fortunately, there was a timber mill operating nearby. By borrowing horses, they were able to snig the timber home through the bush track.

Author: GASCOYNE
Quote: There in an open spot in [sic] manuka I left my horse and saddle (for the bush track was impassable for a horse in the dark), and soon found that it would take me all night to find the way on foot.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
In spite of the
naval patrol ... the
hostile Maoris

Te Rauparaha ...,
either by canoe at
night or by the bush
tracks on the
northern side of the
Paua-taha-nui arm.

Author: REISCHEK
Quote:
From the Thames a
romantic bush-track
leads some 30 miles
to Coromandel, ...

Author: SCANLAN
Quote:
... it was great fun
... riding over bush
tracks, seing a new
generation carry a
step further inland
the work their
grandparents had
begun on the coast.

Author: WILY & MAUNSELL
Quote:
Toward the end of
1860 a young native
named Eriata was

lying dead from
gunshot wounds on a
bush track, ...

She carried with her
a flax kit of
kumaras, ... and

the bush tracks,
loaded with her
heavy kits, taking
three days to reach
the school.

Author: BAKER
Quote: ... derivatives ... commonly used both in New Zealand and Australia [include] ... bush track.

Author: SIMPSON
Quote:
A forest path is a
bush track.
Even those later scientists who use forest as a general rule usually write of bushmen, bush tracks, patches of bush, and the bushline.

Quote:
"Where? There's only
been one turn-off
since we spoke to
him, and that was
only a bush track.
This must be the
right-road." I
pointed to the map.
"... Here's where we
turned off the main
road before we
started to climb.
..."

Quote:
Then there were the

before she could get
to hospital.

Quote:

Quote:
.. having to

Quote:
This is a bush track

Author: COWAN
Quote:
Most of us had to
ride our horses, [to

BUSH TRAM A light
logging railway,
usually on wooden
rails.

BUSH TRAM , usually
steam driven,
locomotive hauling,
bogeys of logs from
the bush to mill,
usually on wooden
rails.

BUSH TRAM , usually
steam driven,
locomotive hauling,
bogeys of logs from

Author: DAVIN
Quote:
The cart track
petered out and
became the track of

They could see the

been brought.

Source: Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The
Author: MAHONEY
Quote:
There were once over
500 bush trams in
New Zealand... The
opening of the first
bush tram has not
been identified but
records show they
were in use in the
1850s.

The discovery of
gold on the West
Coast demanded
transport, which was
by means of
wooden-railed track
serving the shanties
and settlements with
crudely built horse
trams taking
passengers and
freight on 'bush
trams'.

Author: McLAGLAN
Quote:
It was an
extraordinary
journey, mostly on
one of those amazing
bush tramlines built
for timber trucks by
amateur engineers
who worked in the
mills.

Author: MOORE
Quote:
Sometimes it was
milled in a bush
mill at that point
[sc. the hauler].
Ofte[n] it was
`fleeted up' on the
skids ready for
loading on to a bush
tramway, the motive
power for which was
supplied either by
draught animals or
small steam
locomotives.

Author: McARA
Quote:
... baulks of kauri
descending, to the
[233] accompaniment
of squealing brakes,
the self-acting
incline from the end
of the bush-tramway
on the hill south of
the battery.

Author: MARSH
Quote:
It [sc. timber] had
come out ...
horse-drawn through
virgin forest to a
bush tramway, ...

Author: BEARDSLEY
Quote:
The little mill
unions ... were
always in the most
inaccessible parts
of the Coast and ...
you had to ride by
rickety bush tramway
...

We crossed the
Routeburn [Otago] on
a good swing bridge
and picked up an old
bush tramway which
led us well up the
river.

The words "bush
tramway" always
bring a smile to the
face of an old
tramping hand,
because translated
it means" "flat,
benched, graded, and
above all, easy".

Source: Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The
Author: MAHONEY
Quote: However, there as no direct English 'bush tramway' experience to call upon, and so all the adaptations to bush conditions occurred in the new land...An overseas forester reported in 1877: "The universal use of the tramway forms a marked feature of the treatment of New Zealand forests." Ibid. 78 Steam locomotives designed for normal railways were not suitable for the rugged conditions on bush tramways and gradually special designs evolved. Ibid. 83 1871 Opening of William Brownlee's Mahakipawa-Kaituna valley tramway on 4'0" (1219 mm) gauge. This was New Zealand's first steam-worked bush tramway and used a British 0-4-0 vertical boiler locomotive.

Author: LEITCH
Quote:
Here [sc. on the
Rotorua main line,
the NZR has one of
the last substantial
bush tramways in the
country

If you have the
inclination, tree
and roots can be
cooked up to provide
you with some solid
bush tucker.

The concept of a
Maori restaurant is
great, and a whole
galaxy of New
Zealand bush tucker
awaits imaginative
treatment by
contemporary Maori
chefs.

But if hairy-chested
Kiwi bush tucker
isn't your thing,
there's less
challenging fare on
offer too.

Food safety
officials are taking
a look at icons of
Kiwi culture - bush
tucker such as wild
pork and venison,
summer "harvests" of
blackberries, wild
mushrooms and
indigenous foods
such as puha and
whitebait.

On p 40 of the
October issue, in
Bush tucker by
Neville Pomare it is
incorrectly stated
that the flesh of
the karaka berry is
poisonous.

The fame of
Hokitika's Wildfood
Festival and its
gourmet bush tucker
is spreading.

There's more
disturbingly
delicious delicacies
than ever on offer
(100 stalls this
year) at this West
Coast tribute to the
wildest bush tucker.

Author: BROOKS
Quote:
School games such as

little "bush
turkeys" like we
were.

Author: COWAN
Quote: A rather good bush vegetable is the pikopiko, the curled shoots of the mauku fern. The natives have long given up the use of these bush foods;...

Quote:
... a world which
now and again,
behind the

childhood with a
memory ...

Author: COWAN
Quote: The foot of the pekerangi, about 15 feet high, was strengthened with a facing of rocks and [42] stones ...; this was a variation of the usual Maori method of leaving the foot of the pekerangi open for the garrison's fire. ibid. 51-52 The outer wall, the pekerangi, or curtain, was formed of stout timbers ... sunk deeply in the ground at short intervals, with saplings and split timbers closely set between the larger posts, all bound firmly [52] together with cross-rails and torotoro, or bush-vines

Author: WEBB
Quote:
Peter used to take

Paid saddler
GBP4.5.6 for repairs

Collinge, amount of

John and Mr Beckett

Wayne Mason's
"Nature" is less
evocative of a

the neighbour's
stereo.

A sign on the corner

River, go straight

Keeley's Bush
Farmyard Holiday
Park runs night-time

tourists see
wallabies and
possums, or Kiwi
bears as they tell
visitors.

GERYGONE SYLVESTRIS.
(BUSH-WARBLER.) ...
The above Warbler,

[in] .. `The Ibis'

Author: MORRIS

Source: English as it is spoken in NZ
Author: BENNETT

Quote:
"Kakarikis are

and, strange to say,

this "

The "chough, chough"

recollections of my
life in the Westland
forests.

That bush warbler
usually warns you of
rain to come.
[The natives'] present mode of bush or guerilla warfare
... bush warfare ...

Author: COWAN
Quote:
It was typical bush
warfare for a few

.. (ranging from
anywhere from $200
-$350 - or more for
super 'my friend
smuggled this
himself from
whereverthefuckistan'
bud (normally bush

I am speaking of the

don't hesitate to
say the bush weta
does bore into

Author: ANDERSEN
Quote:
There are four
kinds: the

I have seen a Rock
and Pillar weta, a

100 2-tooth ewes
from up-river, 40 18

...

Livestock sales: two
and four tooth bush

He [Joe Green] had
lived most of his
life at Kawhia in a
bush whare making a
living from his one
or two cows, vege

Author: HINDMARSH
Quote:
The three young men
lived in a bush
whare and by 1919
had 600 acres cut,
fenced and in grass.

Quite a lot of
people do not seem
to like hare. They
seem to think it is
like bush whisky:
"the flavour is
pretty strong".

Bush whisky makes
the boozer think the
world is upside
down. After three
glasses of a brand
retailed by a down
South publican ...

Author: CLARK
Quote:
... vile bush
whiskey.

Author: HULME
Quote:
In the city,I won't
hear the sea, the
bush-wind or the
birds.

Author: MARSHMAN
Quote:
There are other
kinds of unskilled
labour going on as
road-making,
fencing, bush-work
etc.

Author: ELWELL
Quote:
Sledges were
necessary for bush
work, for the bush

dray to be worked in
them.

Author: BULLER
Quote:
It was his first
acquaintance with
our [sc. missionary]
bush-work ... [sc.
travelling]

Source: Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand
Author: HOCKEN
Quote: Desirous that no delay should occur with the surveys, Colonel Wakefield ... had despatched the Carbon ... having on board Messrs. Richard Nicholson and Albert Allom, who were surveying cadets, and seven men selected for their knowledge of bush work.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
They couldn't walk
in the bush and
carry a rifle, far
less fight in the
bush. The practised
bushmen among us,
like myself - I had
done pioneering
bush-work before the
Waikato war began -
had grown to look on
a tree as a friend.

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
1850 - as bush work
proved too heavy the
father returned to
Waikouaiti ...

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote: And when everything was sorted out, the Old Man came out of that contract without a zak to show for it. ... at the end of seven months' bushwork we didn't have a brass razoo.Ibid. 76... months of bushwork, with hardly a cracker coming from it, made me carry a swag.

The higher wages
paid to bush workers
are accounted for
partly by the more
exacting nature of
the work, longer
hours, remoteness
and consequent lack
of social
intercourse, and the
less favourable
living conditions.

Did you ever hear a
New Zealand
bushworker talk like
that?

... a fire ran
through the old
bush-workings ...
BUSH

Author: BULLER
Quote: XENICUS LONGPIPES. (BUSH-WREN.) ... Native names . Matukituki, Piwauwau, {Puano,} and Huru-pounamu.

Quote: Bush-wren [ Xenicus longpipes ] ... is generally met with singly or in pairs.

Quote: Bush-wren . see Wren .
Wren n. [Add.] Bush wren. (Bot.), a passerine bird of New Zealand (Xenicus longipes).

Amongs[t?] the
creepers there are
the bush-wren, the

Quote:
Another tiny bird is
the Bush Wren; this,

Fulton (1908) [TrNZI
40/485-500] states

Author: REISCHEK
Quote: ... green bush wrens

Quote: As elsewhere, as in the case of the Saddleback (Creadion carunculatus) and Bush Wren (Xenicus longpipes) ... restriction of food ... may have reduced an originally large clutch.

Source: English as it is spoken in NZ
Author: BENNETT
Quote: (Xenicus) were hopping around, ...

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Houtuutu , n. Acanthidositta chloris, rifleman , a bird. Ibid. 195 [also green wren] Matuhituhi ... Xenicus longpipes, bush wren.

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote: In addition to the rock wren, there is another species, Xenicus longipipes , the bush wren or matuhi. This bird is also very small, of darker green colouring and with a white throat. It is found in damp rimu and beech forests on the West Coast of the South Island, and builds its nest in hollow trees and, like the rock wren, lines it with feathers. Ibid. 3/705-12 Wren, bush .. .. matuhi .. .. Xenicus longipes

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: BUSH WREN Xenicus longpipes Other names: Matuhi, Tom Thumb Bird (Stewart Is.).

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Bush Wren Xenicus longipes (GMELIN, 1789) ... This tiny, inconspicuous bird may be extinct; ... South Island Bush Wren X.l. longpipes (GMELIN, 1789) North Island Bush Wren X.l. stokesii GRAY, 1862. Stead's Bush Wren X.l. variabilis STEAD, 1936. OTHER NAMES: Matuhituhi, green wren, Tom Thumb bird.
bush wren small NZ forest bird.

Source: You'll Learn No Harm from the Hills
Author: MCCONOCHIE
Quote:
On comparing
observations that
evening, Alex
casually mentioned
seeing a small
colony of the large
green bush wren,
familiar to us in
our early boyhood
days at Glenhope ..
they were
subsequently
catalogued by Dr
Oliver as a hitherto
unknown species,
under the name of
the 'Fiordland
wren.'
Xenicus longipes (Bush Wren). Common some distance up the bushy slopes, where the vegetation is not so dense as near the lake [Brunner].

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
As in the case of
the .. Bush Wren
(Xenicus longipes)
.. restriction of
food .. may have
reduced an
originally large
clutch.

It is nevertheless a
useful bird, and
might be tried in
New Zealand to
further supplement
the bush wren
(Tenicus longipes)
and the grey warbler
(Gerygone
flaviventris), both
becoming scarcer.

Author: MACNICOL & TROTTER
Quote:
The sheep were kept
there for the night
by a bush yard, made
of scrub cut and
heaped up to a
circular pen, it was
only for one night.

Author: JONES
Quote:
We built temporary
bush yards and
killed and skinned
the lot [scabby
sheep].

There's one bush
bash on every trip.

Source: Tramping in South Island Forest Parks
Quote:
..with one possible
'bush-bash' above
Bristed Stream,
where the river runs
hard against the
bank.

Once I reached the
river the bush-bash
should have been
over.

I knew he'd been
joking, but when we
bush-bashed our way
through the forest
to the possies on
the river's edge, I
received the answer
I'd been looking
for...

Author: MARRINER
Quote:
At a certain bemd,
if you bush-bash
across the northerly
ridge, you hit
farmland.

The ridge walk had
become impassable
and they had to
bush-bash through
the leatherwood on
the tops.

But half the track
had been washed away
so we decided to
`bush bash' to get
to Cone Ridge. I was
last in the party.
We were cutting a
trail into the bush.

...Crockett's team
bush-bashed through
hectares of rugged
terrain searching
for signs that the
[Chatham Island]
taiko must still be
alive...

Toward the end these
paddlers did decide
to walk a rapid or
two..we bush-bashed
up the bank to the
bottom bridge...
Notes: http://www.huttkayakers.org.nz/tripIndex.php *Accessed 17/04/06. No date for site construction or posting.

Author: PICKERING
Quote:
So to cope with the
rituals of tramping,
its pains and
camaraderie, a slang
language has
developed to suit.
Lots of quick short
words to fit in the
breathless pauses as
you pant uphill.
`Crud' (cloud),
`bush-bash', a
`gunn' tramper
(which must have
originated from Davy
Gunn's famous trek
up the Hollyford
Valley to help
victims of a plane
crash in 1936; he
travelled 40 km by
rowing boat, horse
and foot in 21
hours), `windfall'
(a collapsed pile of
trees), `pit' (the
tramper's true
friend, a sleeping
bag), `pog'
(porridge), `bastard
grass' and `lawyer'
(two unpleasant
plants), `piker'
(one who stayed
home), `Huey'
(all-powerful god of
weather), and many,
many more.

All three of these
intrepid suburban
pupil-carriers can
bush-bash with the
best of them and I
have to admit that I
did get even the
Lexus very dirty.

They teetered on
platforms, loafed in
Gucci, bushbashed
through Burger King
in oversized camel
Timberlands.

The trail plan
called for me to
bush-bash a few
kilometres across
the flanks of Mount
Kaihinu...

I bush-bashed down
to the river but
found no trail, only
kilometres of bush
and precipitous
river spurs between
me and my
destination.

I bush-bashed down
to the river but
found no trail, only
kilometres of bush
and precipitous
river spurs between
me and my
destination.

Bush-bashing comes
easily in Suzuki's
dinky little wagon
[heading] ... It has
always been a source
of amazement to
true-blue four wheel
drive fanatics, just
how many people use
the little Suzuki
off roader as a
round-town hack.
Obstensibly designed
as a mini
bush-basher, the
Suzuki has
nevertheless proved
to be a winner among
the rich and trendy
people from places
such as Parnell,
Herne Bay or
Eastbourne.

The 4WD is no longer
just a bush basher.
These days they're
more likely to be
shuttling around
town with a woman at
the wheel.

Bush-bashers go
navigating, with
compasses and maps
and call each other
on radios (except
Dave who'll call his
mum) to find targets
or bush-blobbers.

We had the
alternatives of
facing a wet
crossing but then
having a good track
up the other bank,
or staying on our
own side and perhaps
getting involved in
a bush-bashing
session.

Almost every car
maker has a 4x4
machine which will
go bush-bashing to a
wilder or milder
extent depending on
how capacious your
wallet happens to
be.

Some of the proposed
links weren't in
place, so that meant
an occasional bit of
bush-bashing.

Source: Tramping in South Island Forest Parks
Quote:
Beyond here is only
a marked route
requiring some
bush-bashing and
boulder-hopping
beside the river,
with bluffs to
bypass beyond Kakapo
Creek.

The following day
our bush-bashing

Obstensibly designed

nevertheless proved

Eastbourne.

opt for something

the boys.

Author: BELICH
Quote: At its fullest, the `bush-scouring' theory entailed a `flying column' of a few hundred men, untrammeled by a large supply train,hunting down the Maoris in the bush, and forcing them to fight by attacking their villages and cultivations. ... [214] Bush-scouring was not a panacea for all circumstances, based on the inherent abilities of settler-frontiersmen, but a military method appropriate only in a certain context ... One assumption behind the bush- scouring theory was that the Maoris were evasive guerilla fighters ... [215] Masking the pa, and bush-scouring against the Maori base areas ... would be a long and slow process.

stalking: (2) Bush
stalking.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote: Most of our shooting was a fairly close range in this district, due to the bush-stalking and the many small clearings at regular intervals on the valley floor. Ibid. 119 Bush-stalking in the large valley between the Arm and the Waiau Rivers was actually a pleasure after climbing over rough, rocky tops for so long.

Author: HUNT
Quote:
Potatoes, kumeras,
taros, and water
melons were the
chief crops grown in
the ... humid
bush-surrounded
plots ...

Author: COWAN
Quote:
The bush-trained
settlers of Papkura,
Hunua, and the
Wairoa were the
dependable nucleus
of the corps ...

Author: HURSTHOUSE
Quote:
Visitors and
colonists `bush
travelling' in New
Zealand, generally
provide themselves
with a native
attendant, as guide
... New Zealand
`bush travelling'
... beats a Highland
tour by a hundred
per cent., ...

Sunrise, after which
no bush-traveller
ought to be in bed.

Author: HURSTHOUSE
Quote:
[Pigs] keeping in
the deepest recesses
of the forest, are
seldom or ever seen
except by bush
travellers or
pig-hunter.

Author: SWAINSON
Quote:
But a lengthened
expedition into the
interior of a new
country, cannot of
course be undertaken
without some
preparation ... Nor
should a stranger,
or novice in bush
travelling ... be
advised to start
alone. On the
contrary he should,
if possible, secure
as a companion some
experienced bush
traveller.

Author: CAMPBELL
Quote:
... [supple-jack]
sometimes catches
you by the neck, the
most
temper-provoking and
the most
anathema-producing
thing that ever
tried the temper of
a bush traveller,
but so useful withal
in its proper
places.

Author: HURSTHOUSE
Quote:
Visitors and
colonists `bush
travelling' in New
Zealand, generally
provide themselves
with a native
attendant, as guide
... New Zealand
`bush travelling'
... beats a Highland
tour by a hundred
per cent., ...

We have with us tea
and sugar which are
considered
indispensable in
bush travelling.

Author: SWAINSON
Quote: "Bush-Travelling in New Zealand" [chapter title] To the sportsman New Zealand offers no attraction; but, for the active and adventurous, a pedestrian excursion into the interior of the country affords an agreeable recreation; ... Ibid. 123 What wonder that bush-travelling, then, should be a holiday amusement?

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
Great fault is found
with me for wearing
one of the common
felt hats which
having very broad
brims is well
adapted for bush
travelling.

Author: LUSH
Quote: Mr. Mason, who has been twenty years in the country and accustomed to bush travelling, borrowed a knife ...and said he would soon get me some luncheon. ...We speedily spied a young Nikau, the native palm tree, and cutting off the upper end he cut out the inside. . . .It tasted like sweet turnip.

Source: Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
Author: HAAST
Quote:
With great regret I
parted with this
gentleman, who had
... been accustomed
for years to New
Zealand bush
travelling, and
possessing ... a
quick eye for
discerning readily
the topographical
features of the
country.

Author: BARLOW
Quote:
I found rapid bush
travelling by no
means easy of
accomplishment.

Author: DOUGLAS
Quote:
... a great deal
more Bush
travelling.
Notes: 1891 Mar 7 Douglas Diary in 1957 Mr Explorer Douglas 137

Quote:
... three of them
(strong and
determined, and used
to heavy
bush-travelling)
arranged to visit
that out-of-the-way
spot ...

The old-timer was
talking of
bush-trvelling and
the difficulaty in
rough forest country
of maintaining one's
direction ...

Author: ORBELL
Quote:
The old pipe-line
gives direct
altitude and
eliminates the worst
of the bush
travelling.
KOKOPU (Galaxias fasciatus) is a sluggish native fish found ... in most "bush-type" streams throughout New Zealand.
bush-walk NZ & Austral. go tramping or camp in bush.

Author: LELAND
Quote: bushwalker: a man who walks in the backwoods or BUSH.

Bushwalker mix-up
gets police
attention [headline
of a party of
schoolchildren lost
in bush].

Rambling, hiking,
wanderlust, walking
and bushwalkers'
clubs are foreign
terms to us, and the
Australian
bushwalkers' clubs
are some years
younger than ours.

[Hdg] Bush walkers
warned.

We came soon by a
little bush-walking
... to Okewi.

There is what we call a good bush road to Rata Nui but beyond it there are two miles of bush walking along what is called `a line'; a line is made by cutting the supple jacks and small shrubs with a bill hook ... [sic] time bush walking takes is very surprising to me ... [sic]

Author: BARKER
Quote:
No paths but real
bush-walking.

Private walkways now
offer a bushwalking
experience that
combines quality
food and wine with
comfortable
accommodation...

Author: MONEY
Quote:
In considering upon
the compliment paid
me by Mr. Money,
when he asked me to
write a preface to
this record of rough
and ready
bush-wandering, I
think of the
`Pioneer' of that
dinner party, ...
Notes: 1871 Marcus Clarke in Money Knocking About in NZ vi

Quote:
One shop [at Thames]
specialized in the
manufacture of
sawmilling and
bush-working
machinery,
log-haulers in
particular.

Author: REED
Quote:
... he had to find
dependable answers
to problems peculiar
to kauri bushcraft
... [122] they took
a pride in their
work, and knew all
there was to know
about the bush-craft
of their day -
cross-cutting and
jacking.

Author: MONEY
Quote:
He gave me my first
lessons in
bushcraft, such as a
knowledge of edible
herbs and roots,
modes of crossing
rivers, snaring
birds, and many
other invaluable
`wrinkles.'

A young settler, who
in addition to being
a son of the soil,
was well-skilled in
bush-craft, assured
me that he once met
with a Kokako's nest
...

Author: BULLER
Quote:
[The parrakeet] is
an inhabitant of the
woods, and ... its
plumage is so suited
to its natural
surroundings ...
that ... it is
rarely seen, and
except to the lovers
of nature and
bush-craft its very
existence is almost
unknown to the
colonists.

Author: McHUTCHESON
Quote:
Mac proved himself
an adept .. at all
other wrinkles of
bush-craft.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
... the white and
Maori explorers
experimented with
such onga-onga
poison antidotes as
their bushcraft
suggested.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote:
There is still room
for skill and
bushcraft which is
acquired only after
years of experience.
Bushcraft refers to those skills necessary for anyone to find his way around and to exist comfortably in bush country. It was in use [24] in Australia in 1897.
Notes: 1958 Sep Ruth Mason `Track and Trail' in Tararua 23-24

Quote:
It was the final
weekend of my
bushcraft course...
It had seemed a good
idea on New Year's
Eve when, dancing on
a barrel at a Greek
restaurant, I vowed:
"This year I will
drink less, eat more
veges, and join a
bushcraft
course."... So, with
the jeers of friends
and flatmates
ringing in my ears
(apparently
"bushcraft" carries
connotations of
hairy legs, bushy
beards and unsavoury
hygiene), I enrolled
for a bushcraft
course.

He regarded the
skill and ability in
bushcraft of
Johnston and Crump
as extremely high.

Author: ORBELL
Quote:
It is good bushcraft
to find a place to
build a fire and a
log you can sleep
under.

I had arranged to
meet two of my
fellow bushcrafters
for moral support as
I trekked through
Wellington to our
departure point at
the railway station.

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote:
BUSHED, BE 2 to be
tired out. .;`After
the long drive in
the heat, well, I
was a bit bushed, I
will admit.'

Author: McGILL
Quote: bushed exhausted; lost; eg `Can we take a breather? I'm bushed.' NZA.

Author: GUTHRIE
Quote:
... the secret of
safely finding their
way through densest
forest ... was
theirs, better than
their adults they
could track a
`bushed' calf and
return it to its
proper mother.

Source: High Times in the High Country
Author: KERR
Quote:
I was bushed, sick
of bouncing over
papa and looking at
sheep's arses ...

Author: WILLIAMS & REEVES
Quote:
I live in a country
where drought is
unknown,/ Where the
poor stockman,
bushed, need be
never athirst.

Author: SCOTT
Quote:
I was bushed here
[on the Plains]
once. ...[202] ...
Geting bushed among
the tussocks on the
Canterbury Plains.

Author: ACLAND
Quote: Bushed Lost (of people) whether in the bush or anywhere else. (A taxi-driver got `bushed', he said, in finding a street)

Author: FULLARTON
Quote:
`Have you any idea
where we are?'
`We're bushed behind
the enemy lines
about a hundred
miles from nowhere.'

Author: BACON
Quote:
`You've got me
bluffed properly,' I
said. `I'm properly
bushed.' Each tree,
each fallen log, was
the same as the last
to me, but gradually
I became aware of a
slight thinning of
the bush, ...
bushed ... 3. Austral & N.Z. lost or bewildered, as in the bush.

[Hdg] Barry's big
day had 'em bushed!
Being flipped about
in a four-wheel
drive ... high above
bush-draped ravine
[sic] made things
just authentic
enough for `townies'
to think they'd gone
native.

Bushed Lost or
astray anywhere. One
who loses his way
among city streets
will say he is
bushed.

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote:
BUSHED, BE 3 To have
no information on
that matter, or, to
be puzzled. .in 4;`I
understand what you
meant up to a point,
but now I'm bushed.
You'd better explain
it all from the
start. I'll get the
gist of it, I just
have to take my
time.' W3

Author: LAWSON
Quote:
The deeper you read
... about things
that end in ism ...
the more likely you
are to get bushed.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Bushed quasi past participle, lost in the bush; then, lost or at a loss. 1861. T. McCombie, `Australian Sketches,' p. 115:]

Author: PRESHAW
Quote:
I was utterly
`bushed', -
literally `lost in
the bush' ...

Author: COTTLE
Quote:
Next time you get
bushed stick to the
spot till someone
comes to find you,
for you are an awful
duffer in the bush.

Source: Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ
Author: HARPER
Quote:
Even the oldest
bushman may find
himself temporarily
`bushed,' but a good
man can ...
generally find his
way out somewhere
...

Author: PFAFF
Quote:
... you had to
follow down a track
or run the risk of
being bushed.

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
[Wherever have you
been?] `Bushed,' he
answered, ... `Got
into this infernal
New Zealand bush of
yours, and, egad, I
was nearly spending
the night in it,
too; ...

... late at night,
having been
temporarily
`bushed', he
wandered, footsore
and gumless, into
camp.

Source: Morioris of the Chatham Islands, The
Author: SKINNER
Quote:
In the southern part
of the island the
bush was so dense
that two members of
Mr.Percy Smith's
party, surveying the
district in 1868,
were `bushed' and
very nearly lost
their lives.

Author: WILY & MAUNSELL
Quote:
One night the Bishop
and the Doctor were
`bushed' and forced
to bivouac where
they were till
morning.

Author: CHARLES
Quote:
If you ever get
bushed, boy, follow
a creek./

Author: HOLDEN
Quote:
Frequently they had
shouted out Roddy's
name. ... `He must
be hurt,' Ken said
suddenly. `Or
bushed,' said Sam.

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote:
BUSHED, BE 1 To lose
one's way. .in 4;`We
had to turn back. We
were bushed when the
fog came down.'

Before long he [a
tramper] was
fair-dinkum bushed.
He had a compass ...
but it was
puckeroo'd.

Author: GUTHRIE
Quote:
... the secret of

Second-half burst
leaves Bay [Hawkes
Bay rugby team]
bushed.

[A prisoner speaks]
Something seemed to
move behind him; he
jumped. Nothing.
Legs trembling
slightly he slid
quickly down the
ladder, slamming the
bolt on the door.
`Now, don't go
getting bushed', he
said.
She got "bushed."

We moved along the
shores of Lakes
Katherine and
Sumner, the latter a
very fine lake ...
and bushed down to
the waters [sic]
edge.

Author: GUTHRIE
Quote:
High, heavily bushed
hills appeared to
rise straight out of
the water, ...

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote:
As the months went
by, I kept poking
around the bushed
spurs and the high,
open basins shooting
a few deer each day.

From South Ohau, the
track leaves the
river ... before
easing off to a more
gentle gradient up
the bushed ridge to
Te Mataurai Hut. ...
some ... hours later
we had negotiated
the last bushy knob
and were descending
the final slope
towards the hut ...

Author: BALE
Quote:
The following
morning he found
himself in a thickly
bushed gully with a
small stream at the
bottom.

...

... when the streams
came from heavily
bushed country.

Author: REES
Quote:
(et passim) ...
densely bushed

Author: CHAPPLE
Quote: 'Now that,' I declared.. 'was hard. I went down into the gorges and got bushed,' 'Gosh.' One of the English tourists off the Kiwi Experience bus looked up from her New Idea magazine and went back to her reading. 'Golly, really,' said her companion, then went back to writing her letter home.

One party attempted
Mt. Greenlaw, but
got well "bushed."

Author: SCOTT
Quote:
"You wouldn't
suppose a fellow
could get lost on
those Plains, would
you? I was bushed
here once!" " After
that you'd get
bushed in an empty
packing case."

We were.. cautious
about getting
"bushed" among the
wire fences in the
dark.

Author: ORBELL
Quote:
[Title] Getting
Bushed.

To make one's way
through the heavily
bushed country
towards the lake
will take at least
two days.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote:
We struggled out of
the basin on to the

Quote:

beasts were making

An inland journey to
the bushed mountain
lake of Waikaremoana
and long coastal
walks ...

Immigrants ... were

Author: BELL
Quote: `Then, Maurice,' said Ashwin, `sing us that bushfaller's song of Flash Harry's. ...' Ibid. 48 `... You're getting some more bush down on that section of yours in the Arataki block ...?' `I have just let fifty acres to some chaps, and hope to get down another fifty or hundred acres next season if all's well. ... Those bushfallers ... were asking where they could get a regular supply of good butter, ...'

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Bush-faller, n. One who cuts down timber in the bush. 1882. `Pall Mall Gazette,' June 29, p. 2, col. I:

Quote:
In the mountain's
deep gulch .../ Once
the bushfaller's
camp, now the
deer-slayer's haunt
-/ There Hughie
resides ...

Author: FERGUSON
Quote:
In a bush-faller's
whare ...

Quote: ... bush-faller ...

Quote:
the bushfallers
fled, were fired
upon ineffectually

Quote:
I found a haven with
Mr. Wilson at his
bush farm, which was
only connected with
the outside world by
water.

Author: MURRAY
Quote:
Bush Falling is
never done in
quantity.

Author: HAY
Quote: We worked steadily at bush-falling. Ibid. 187 When bush-falling is performed by hired labour, it usually goes by contract.

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote: This was Maurice McKeown, employed ... to assist ... in the work of the farm, in attending to the stock, in logging up and clearing, in fencing, and also ... in doing a little bushfalling, though the latter work was usually let by contract, one of which was ... being carried out by ... Flash Harry, and his mates. Ibid. 94 This is one of the most awkward mischances ... in the work of bush-[95]falling, ...

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: ... bush-falling ...

Quote:

Quote:

Quote:
There is still a

bush falling NZ & Austral. felling of trees in the bush; bush-faller person who does this.

Author: ACLAND
Quote: Never `bush-felling'

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL

- you're one of the
[86] bushfalling
chaps that get
butter here - '

bushfalling camp ...

Author: BELL
Quote:
But de'il tak' the
hour I agreed to
gang amang the
cockatoos wi' ye,

wish mysel' back
amang the squatters

ane is aye made at

fa'ers' or roadmen's
camp to a share o'
what's goin'; ...

Quote:

Author: BAUCKE
Quote:
Two were paid-off

Quote:

Author: COWAN
Quote:

Quote:
That wouldn't have

BUSHFELLER [=]BUSH
WHACKER

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
When the bushfellers
came to take timber
from a pure kauri
stand, they worked
the bush on a face.

This industry gives
employment to a
large number of
persons, both
directly to those
engaged in breeding,
shearing, freezing,
and shipping, and
indirectly to those
who labour at
bushfelling,
grass-seed sowing,
fencing, and
otherwise opening up
new country.

Bush-felling is
expensive, but the
establishment of
dairy factories is
already raising the
price of land and
giving a needed
stimulus to the
clearing of the
forest.

... in the process
of clearing the land
the necessary
burning which
follows the
bush-felling often
destroys such
reserves as may have
been left for the
sake of the timber
contained.

Author: DOBSON
Quote:
... but on reaching
Lake Sumner, the
bush began, and we
commenced bush
felling.

The impression I
gathered by personal
inspection of some
of the lands and
from representations
made at crowded
meetings in seven
settlements, where
we met some 3000 of
the northern tribes,
was that they were
doing more than any
other section of the
race - not excepting
the East Coast - for
themselves.
Road-making on a
50/50 basis with the
local bodies, ohu or
mahi-apu [ed fn: A
group of volunteer
workers] in relation
to scrub-cutting,
bush felling,
splitting posts and
battens, gave ample
evidence of
self-help.

Author: GUTHRIE
Quote:
However, he could
make no headway ...
without first
clearing the land of
forest, so they were
obliged to continue
the ... work of bush
felling.

Bush-felling thus
provides a useful
means of
supplementing the
farm income, and
accumulating capital
for farming
purposes.

Author: ELLIOT& ADSHEAD
Quote:
Then came a plague
of bush rats, huge
brutes that were
eaten by the
moreporks. Mr Thomas
Nix, now in his 80s,
told me that when
the men were out
bushfelling it was
standard practice to
give the pungas a
hearty whack and
then leap back to
dodge at least a
couple of rats ...

He and another man
were engaged in
bushfelling near
Reweti ...

The best tools for
bush-felling are an
American axe, about
five pounds weight,
and a light
slash-hook with a
thin edge.

In [63] mining and
bushfelling country
bad news travels
quickly.
Notes: 1962 Vogt in 1978 Listener Short Stories Vol 2 62-63

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
I was on a
bush-felling
contract, back of
Gisborne, in the
winter of 1914, when
the war began.

Some bushies at the
back [of the Taihape
theatre] objected.

Author: GIBSON
Quote:
The unlucky `bushie'
whose mannerisms and
objectionable traits
attract overmuch
attention from his
mates ...

Author: BENNETT

A bushman [speaks]
... `Look here',
said the bushie ...
said the man from
the outback.
bushie n. rough yokel; equivalent of Indian jungle wallah.

So Jim talked to
himself in fluent
Maori (which he
spoke as well as any
native) about the
loneliness of a
bushie's life and

comfort which
awaited any wahine

In the first year

Quote:
One of the

The country man

Author: HINDMARSH
Quote:
On one occasion
Cecil had signed up
a couple of young
bushies to cut a
block ...

There being no
material for

Notes: 1848 Apr 12 Brunner Exped. Middle Isd in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 313

Quote:
... these Mokau

Notes: 1850 Jan 26 J.J.Symonds Journal in 1983 Pascoe Explorers and Travellers 31

Robert ... proved

`bushing' by

a cup and saucer and

... and other most
