Source: Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A
Author: ADAMS
Quote:
A little more
experience in
'bushing it' would
have taught us to
have left the bush
at once to its own
fate.

He explained that
`tinned cow' was a
`bushism' for
condensed milk.

I have seen most of
the great bush-lands
of New Zealand
...[213]... and
leave the higher
bush-lands for the
lower valleys.

... when bush-lands
are put up for sale
...

Author: MACDONALD
Quote:
The fallen bush
lands and some of
the scrub lands have
been surface sown in
English grasses ...

Author: MACDONALD
Quote:
The fallen bush
lands and some of
the scrub lands have
been sown in English
grasses ...

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
The pastures being
encircled by
unhunted bushlands,
signs of pigs moving
in from the ranges
had to be watched
for constantly.

Author: HOLDEN
Quote:
They inhabited the
rough broken country
fringing the western
boundary of the
station and ...
infested the wild
bushlands that lay
beyond it.

Deer, chamois, and
thar ... in
themselves are an
obstacle to the
preservation of
bushlands.

All that winter cold
held the bush-lands
in a fierce
unrelenting grip.

Author: RIDGWAY
Quote: [New comers] are puzzled by what is said about fern-lands and bush-lands.

Although above the
bush line, there
will be abundance of
wood within
convenient distance.

To be considered a
true alpine plant, a
species must grow in
a zone which lies
between the bushline
- the altitudinal
limit beyond which
no trees can grow -
and the snowline.

South of Mt Hector
the route crosses a
series of other
sub-alpine peaks,
reaching the
bushline near Alpha
Hut.

There is any amount
of bush all along
this line. In fact,
the line is
generally referred
to as the "bush
line."

We may speak of kauri forest or beech forest, but we get lost in the bush, fight bush fires, and climb above the bushline. The kauri forest, like the mixed podocarp forest, the sub-tropical rain forest, ... and such-like are terms that come from the botanist and forester, not from the layman - or from the bushman. ... Even those later scientists who use forest as a general rule usually write of bushmen, bush tracks, patches of bush, and the bushline. Ibid. 24 Bushline, the upper limit of the bush, would be the timberline in North America. Hudson [G.V. Hudson 1890 TrNZI 2/181] used it in 1890 as if it were then well established. It does not seem to have been noted in any dictionary and is probably a word indigenous to New Zealand.

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
His place was spread
against one side of
a leading ridge,
along the top of
which was the
bushline, with his
boundary fence hard
against the bush.

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote: Bush-line or sometimes [161] forest-line (for American timber-line, English tree-line and Australian tree-line or forest-line), bush-clad, bush burns (areas where the bush has recently been burnt off) are tramping as well as general terms, as is the use of shingle for angular as well as rounded stones in shingle slide , or (earlier) shingle slip , also recently called scree as in Scotland and northern England.

Author: HALL-JONES
Quote:
He followed the
greenstone to his
camp ..., keeping
above the bushline,
headed for the sea.

Author: DENNIS
Quote: The ... New Zealand cedar ... stands over a skeletal mountain neinei Dracophyllum traversii ) near the bushline in Heniker Creek. Ibid. 164 Mountain cottonwood ( Cassinia vauvilliersii ) and Senecio bennettii are also common plants in plants in the region immediately above the bushline.

Author: PICKERING
Quote:
Above the bushline
the environment is
less inviting. The
bush is generally a
friend to trampers
as it provides the
two crucial
necessities of
shelter and fuel.
Only when you emerge
from the forest onto
the bare tops do you
realise how generous
a protector the bush
is. ...
Traditionally all
the landforms above
the bushline have
been regarded as
tops country.

Author: BERTRAM
Quote:
Sheep on the hills,
and a grazing horse
by the ragged/ Edge
of the bushline./

Author: SHERSON
Quote:
There luck seemed to
desert them and ...
they were beginning
to wonder if they
would be able to
find their way out
[of the bush] again.
... As they reached
the bushline they
came across one more
pig ...

Author: PAULIN
Quote: Fresh snow ... came down to within 2000 feet of sea level - i.e., considerably below the bush-line.
In this paper Hudson uses forest(s) except in the following:] ... where the track was soon discovered, and followed up until the bush-line was passed, at about 4,000 ft.

... led to the open
hill above the
bush-line.

From the bush-line
to the top of the
mountain the ...
ascent is very easy.

... I observed vast
swarms ... flying
over the birch-trees
at the bush-line on
one of the western
slopes ...

... a steep climb of
about 2,500 ft. over
burnt-forest area
brings you to the
sharply defined
bush-line.

I do not think I
have ever heard one
above the bush-line
(about 3,000 ft.).
Alsophila Colensoi grew above the bushline on Flagstaff, where it still grows, but of the others few remain.

Source: Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ
Author: HARPER
Quote:
... if we are above
the bush line, snow
or creeks wet us
daily ...

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Above the bushline
it reared in
innumerable ridges.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote:
The high cathedral
peaks midway up the
lake on our right
were a most
impressive sight,
with the snow still
covering the high

Author: DOUGLAS
Quote:
perhaps the scarcity
of grass on the high
ranges and height of
the Bush line is the
cause.
Notes: 1892 June 8 Douglas Letter to Strauchon in 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas p? ...

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
We sorted our packs

Source: Tararua : the Story of a Mountain Range
Author: MACLEAN
Quote:
They set out up a

they could study the

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
A hut above the
bush-line of the
Southern Alps.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Above the bush line
the country opened
into great

Author: ASPINALL
Quote:
These [cattle] had
strayed into the
scrub above the
bushline ...

Author: WARDLE
Quote:
Timberline, or bush
line as we usually
call it, is a

on high mountains of
New Zealand which
still carry their
original forest ...
Notes: in Tussock Grasslands and Mountain Review

Quote:
As a bushlover I
regret the practice.

Author: REEVES
Quote:
Even in the North
Island the average
bushman will speak
of the pukatea tree
as "bucketeer", and
not to call the
poroporo shrub a
"bull-a-bull" would
be considered

A female huia had

by an old-time
bushman in the

Source: New Story of the Kauri, The
Author: REED
Quote:
These wet-day
holidays were known
as "Buckley's" but
says an old bushman,
"under some
contractors and most

a bit hard to come
by".

The balance pole..

which corresponds to
the bushman's swag

Her dad was a
bushman. Her mum was
pretty busy being
mum.

After coming back to

difficult to get to

The woollen blanket

sack ... - an

of experienced
`bush-men'.
Notes: CHECKED DEC 1989 AGAINST AND/OED2: nf references on bush checkfile

Quote:
[Caption] Bushmen

Quote:
Like most bushmen,

wasn't a good man on

Quote:
A bushman always

He couldn't swim a

Quote:
The 'bushmen' - as

Quote:
His sole

Author: PRATT
Quote:
I have previously

He had seen.. the

Quote:
bushman's friend:

A bushman's singlet

The same type of

She demonstrates

plant).

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
A bushman always
wore a special type
of boot known as
`ferntights', named
because the upper
part of the boot was
sewn inside the
lower leather,
preventing sharp
stakes from
penetrating the seam
and tearing the
stitching.
Round-headed
hobnails were
replaced with
square-headed
"bushman's springs"
[sic].It was
essential when

sprigs" helped to

Author: ANNABELL
Quote:
About an hour after
the second boil up
for the day the
affected person
would feel an
unnatural weakness
stealing over him,
his axe would grow
excessively heavy,
every blow would be
an effort and a
feeling of unreality
as if working in a
dream and a faint
tremnbling of the
limbs would assail
him. Usually he
would sit down and
sharpen his axe for
a minute or two then
carry on chopping,
the feeling slowly
fading away in about
half an hour. Among
ourselves, to give
this affliction an
important sounding
name, we always
called it
"Hydrophobia" but it
is more generally
called "Bushman's
staggers," and is
supposed to be
caused by
overworking the
stomach at the same
time as overworking
the muscles.

Source: Pigs and Me: Tales of the Bygone Bush.
Author: COWAN
Quote:
We had to make sure
we fed ourselves
well or we would
suffer from the
bushman's staggers.

Author: BRANDON
Quote: BUSHMAN'S STEAK ... For two men ... steak on a long stick ... roasted to a nice brown ... pour little water into pan; add ... flour ... vinegar ... pepper ... salt ... pour over steak.

Source: Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ
Author: CROWE
Quote: Rangiora.. Brachyglottis repanda Bushman's toilet paper... The more practical and better known use of rangiora is described by the plant's European name.

Plymouth.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
Led by Julian with

... travelled

Led by a chainman

Quote:

Author: HARPER
Quote:
A friendship based
on bushmanship.
bushman n. one skilled in bush lore, and able to find his way in the bush; whence bushmanship, skill in bushcraft.

These are extra
heavy underpants,
dark colour, hip
pocket, and cost
10/-. ca1954 R.Mason
notes: `According to
two old bushmen, Joe
Gibbs and Sandy
Donaldson, bushmen
wore (and may still
wear) long, red,
woollen underpants
at work. They do not
get wet as quickly
as trousers, do not
flap uncomfortably
around the legs when
wet, and keep the
legs warm. Trampers
often do likewise in
snow and in cold wet
windy weather when
it is too cold for
shorts.

A bushman is one who lives and works in the bush, or sometimes one skilled in bushcraft. Judging by a remark in the Tramper of 1933 there were articles known as bushmen's trousers on sale. These were a type of garment pretty much the same as long woollen underpants, but made for outer wear and provided with pockets.

I had a skirmish
with Arthur, who
tho' off duty ...
wished to go as he
scented fighting.
...I have let him
bush range for
months
uncomplainingly ...

Author: PARK
Quote:
Consequently her
thoughts went: `Two
shillings for that
smoked snapper! That
Solivich is a
bushranger. Oh,
that's a bonzer hat.
...'

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
... of Newton's 4000
sheep, 1200 or so

about 200 of them
would have became

"bushrangers"; from
500 to 700 would
have straggled off
the run, ...

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH

The black cricket,

Author: SEDDON

Bushranger tragedies

... a notorious

when in 1865, two
bushrangers, Davis
and Everest, stuck

...

known to the
Australian police.

Bushranger The
Australian
highwayman of the
early days . -
bushranger ...n. originally an escaped convict, then any highway robber or hold-up man frequenting the bush; bushranging, the practice of the bushranger.

Source: Down the Years in the Maniototo
Author: COWAN
Quote:
On August 18, 1863,

hotel at Eden Creek.

I put several miles
between myself and
the would-be
bushrangers.

Author: BRERETON
Quote:
Roger Salisbury had
killed a big
bushranger wether

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
Of Newton's 4000
sheep, 1200 or so
would have died ..
about 200 of them
would have became

Nearly everyone in

Author: LINDSAY
Quote:
The risks of travel

the Chairman of the

One surprise has

remains away, our
auguries are
hopeful, and though
half an inch or so
may fall, we do not
aticipate a
`buster.' When the
cloud cap settles
heavy rain always
follows.

I've grown fond of
the innovative Kiwi
"but" meaning "I
must admit" at the
end of a sentence.
TV watchers must
have all seen that
high-country
musterer detailing
the delights of a
new girlfriend, then
reassuring his mate
with, "She doesn't
drink Speights,
but". Now we have
test driver Greg
Murphy judging a new
four-wheel drive
after a spectacular
run: "She's tough.
But."

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote: There is no local grammar. The local usage which comes to mind, and it is not widespread, is the use of but as an adverb at the end of a sentence, an equivalent of however. ... The man who took our luggage in the air terminal at Sydney ... agreed [the Sydney climate] was good, then added `We've got central heating, but'. I first heard this usage in 1945 in Auckland among students at a Teacher's College, where it was a bit of an affectation or craze rather than established unconscious usage, but.

Author: C. CORNE
Quote:
but - `though',
sentence / clause
finally. `Jeez, this
is strong piss!
Nice, but'. `X's are
good cars, I
wouldn't buy one,
but' Whangarei,
widely used in 50s
and 60s. Also
current in Hawaian
Creole English [see
also Beaton]

[(schoolchildren's)
as a sentence
ending] I didn't
believe it first
time a Whistler kid
said he had two
mothers. It's true
but. ... Caleb still
caught untold kutus
that year but.

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
Remember that one

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: Penny Doctor beetles, also known as `Butcher bats' is a game widely reported by Wellington Training College students as being played in many parts of the North Island. In this game straws moistened by spittle are pushed down the hole of the appropriate beetle. The beetle seizes the end of the straw. When the player feels the straw moving he or she flicks out the beetle. The player who can catch the most beetles wins the game.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
The most widely
known game with
insects is a game
named variously by
T.C. students as
Butcher Boys
(Gisborne, New
Plymouth, Kaponga,
[405] Te Pohu,
Newall, Sth.
Wellington), Butcher
Bats (Ohau, Takaka),
Penny Doctor Beetles
(Tauranga, Pipiriki,
Rotorua), or Fishing
(Morunui). It is a
game in which straws
which have been
suitably moistened
with spittle are
placed in an insects
[sic] hole and are
flicked out when the
insect bites the end
of the straw. Most
of the reports of
this practice come
from the North
Island, though it
was known in the
South as early as
1900 (Waikouaiti).

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
A universal animal
play in the North
Island, but known
also in the South
Island, was a game
variously termed
Butcher Bats,
Butcher Boys, or
Penny Doctor
Beetles. In this
game, straws
suitably moistened
at the end with
spittle were placed
down insect holes
and flicked out when
the insect bit the
end of the straw.
The player won who
could flick a beetle
up first.

There is a tendency

`Here's for the

These games are

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
In the nineteenth
century the ring
game seems to have
been the most
popular marble game.
(In more recent
years marble games
with holes have had
the greater role.)
There was Big Ring,
in which a circle a
yard or more in
diameter was drawn
on the ground; there
was the mullibar
variation, in which
an outsize taw was
catapulted amongst
the marbles in this
circle. There were
Little Ring, Liney,
Follows, Follow the
Taw, Holey, and
then, on a less
important scale,
Butcher's Board, in
which the marbles
were bowled through
the holes in a
board, Eye-Drop,
Knock-Backs,
Leggings-Out (or
Leggin's-Out),
Span-'Em, and
Backits. The last
was more usually a
girls' game.

Author: STEWART
Quote:
A butcher-bee is a
small, black, busy
insect, perhaps
really a kind of
wasp rather than a
bee, which lives in
a hole in a clay
bank. You fished for
them by poking a
straw down the hole,
whereupon we
believed, the
butcher-bee would
seize it and you
could pull him out,
still clinging to
it.

Author: MIDDLETON
Quote:
Catching
butcher-boys was
good fun ... You
chose a piece of
footpath where there
was no tar-sealing
and looked for
little round holes
in the earth. When
you found a hole,
you pushed the soft
end of a grass stalk
into it ... As soon
as it moved you
pulled it out and
caught a small white
grub clinging to the
end with its
nippers.

As a young child I
would play around
the sturdy old house
and among the trees
and in the small
creek below, or sit
on the veranda
playing with my
dolls or with pieces
of grass, fish for
butcher boys in the
holes in the clay
path.

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Buttercup. Ranunculus, various sp.
Our alpine buttercups (Ranunculus) are perhaps the most striking. Each mountain system has its own characteristic, usually showy, species.

There, nestled among the scree, is a delicate yellow bloom - the flower of one of our endemic alpine buttecups, Ranunculus godleyanus, found only in the central parts of the Southern Alps between Aoraki/Mt Cook and Arthur's Pass national parks.

On the flanks of Mt Taranaki Dieffenbach collected the first specimens of creeping coprosoma (C. perpusilla), snow buttercups (Ranunculus nivicola) and Egmont mountain foxglove (Ourisia m. macrophylla).

Notes: (And)Turner Botanical Examination Higher Waimarino in AJHR

Quote: SPOTTY (Labrichthys bothrycosmus). ... [92] According to Mr. Thompson's observations, the spotty is also known in Dunedin as the butter-fish, as when writing in 1877, he said: `The spotty, or butter-fish of our local fishermen, has been very plentiful this year, and had been brought to town in large numbers at times; was in the market 128 days, as against thirty-four days for last year.' ... adding in the most tantalizing manner possible, `There are two sorts of spotty - a big and a little.' And then, after saying the fishermen called them kelp-fish, writes: `Spotties in market 154 days'.

In New Zealand waters there were two species of closely allied fish with similar feeding habits, locally known as butter-fish (Coridodax pullus and Odax vittatus). ... The New Zealand butter-fish was called `marare'.
Pseudolabrus bothryocosmus, Richardson. Locally known as `butter-fish' or `spotty'; very common.
PSEUDOLABRUS CELIDOTUS (Forster). Spotty. Common in all shallow water in rocky localities. Large examples are sold as `butterfish' in Dunedin.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: In Auckland the fish known to South Islanders as Spotty (Pseudolabrus celidotus) is called Butterfish on account of its bright golden colouring on the lower parts of the body and fins fancifully resembling the colour of butter. Ibid. 272 SPOTTY (PAEKIRIKIRI) Pseudolabrus (Lunolabrus) celidotus (Bloch and Schneider) ... [Ibid. 275] The name Spotty is derived from the presence of spots on each side of the fish. The name Butterfish used in the North Island for them is from the yellow or buttery colouring on the undersurface. In Canterbury they are called Guffy, but for what reason I have yet to learn. It is a very pretty fish, more especially when seen in the water.

Author: PARROTT
Quote: The popular name [spotty (Pseudolabrus celidotus) however refers to the general spotty nature of these fishes, and is quite appropriate. It is frequently, but quite incorrectly referred to as the Butterfish, and in Canterbury it is generally known as the `guffy'. Ibid. Spotty Pseudolabrus celidotus Butterfish; Guffy

Quote: Butter-fish, n. a name given in Australia to Oligorus mitchellii, Castln. (see Murray Perch); in Victoria, to Chilodactylus nigricans, Richards. In New Zealand waters there were two species of closely allied fish with similar feeding habits, locally known as butter-fish (Coridodax pullus and Odax vittatus). ... The New Zealand butter-fish was called `marare'.

Author: DRUMMOND & HUTTON
Quote: The warehou, tarakihi, and gurnet are common in the north, and the moki, butterfish, and frost fish in the south, while the kahawai, hapuku (the groper of Dunedin), blue cod, barracouta, the little sea mullet, sometimes called the herring, and the flat fish are found all round the coast. Ibid. 73 The butterfish lives amongst kelp, or sea-weed, and is generally found where kelp is plentiful. Neither it nor the moki takes bait freely. Ibid. 74 ...the butterfish and the red cod, which are not known anywhere else.

Butterfish. Coridodax pullus ...

CORIDODAX PULLUS (Forster). Butterfish; Marari. Sold as `greenbone' or `kelp-salmon' in Dunedin. An outside fish secured in the vicinity of kelp around the northern coasts during most months of the year. ... Distribution: New Zealand coasts.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Author: SPEIGHT

Notes: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 199

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: GREENBONE, BUTTERFISH, KELP SALMON, or KELPIE (MARARI) Coridodax pullus (Bloch and Schneider) ... The name Greenbone is given on account of the bones being a bright green colour, which is so permanent as to with-stand boiling or bleaching. ... The name kelp-fish is given on account of its habit of feeding on kelp or seaweed, and also because it likes to make its home among kelp. In such a habitat it has both food and a favourite home. Kelp-salmon is given for two reasons. The first part, kelp, is explained in the last paragraph, while the second half, salmon, is because the fish is not unlike a Salmon in shape, so much so that new chums who caught this fish have been under the impression they had caught the protected introduced Salmon, but of that later in this chapter. But why this dark coloured fish should receive the name Butterfish I am unable to say. It is certainly not as some people suggest because it needs butter with it when cooked or eaten. In Auckland the fish known to South Islanders as Spotty (Pseudolabrus celidotus) is called Butterfish on account of its bright golden colouring on the lower parts of the body and fins fancifully resembling the colour of butter. The name Kelpie, of course, is derived from its habit of living amidst kelp and it is easily understood how the `ie' was tacked on by fishermen.

Author: PARROTT
Quote: The Butterfish is very similar in form, and is related to, the Kelpfish (Odax vittatus), which is also a brightly-coloured species and found in similar situations, feeding on kelp and other marine plants in rocky localities. Ibid. 130 It is unfortunate that the Butterfish has been given a variety of local names which have originated either from their habit of associating with kelp, their body form, or from the colour of their bones, as for example, Kelpfish, Kelp-salmon, Greenbone, and several other names not so easy to explain. Butterfish or Greenbone are possibly the more generally used names for this fish but it should be remembered that in the North Island the Spotty (Pseudolabrus celidotus), a very different fish, is related to the Butterfish there is superficially little resemblance between the two species. Ibid. 169 Butterfish Coridodax pullus Greenbone; Kelp Salmon; Kelpi; Kelpfish

Author: SHERRIN
Quote: Gasterochisma melampus Rich. Butterfly-fish

Butterfly-fish, ... New Zealand sea-fish, Gasterochisma melampus, Richards, one of the Nomeidae. The ventral fins are exceedingly broad and long, and can be completely concealed in a fold of the abdomen. The New Zealand fish is so named from these fins; the European Butterfly-fish, Blennius ocellaris, derives its name from the spots on its dorsal fin, like the eyes in a peacock's tail or butterfly's wing.

Gasterochisma melampus Richardson. The `butterfly-fish', as it is called when young, has been taken in Otago Harbour, and is now known to be the young of the scaled tunny, described as Lepidothynnus huttoni Gunther.

Quote: buttonhole to crutch sheep's sensitive areas; from `buttonhole' as vagina or penis. [Shepard]

The ewes and hoggets
are button-holed and
eye-clipped before
the rams go out in
April, and crutched
in August, just
before lambing.

Author: MCGILL
Quote:
buttonhole: to
crutch sheep's
sensitive areas;
from 'buttonhole' as
vagina or penis.

Author: STEVENS
Quote:
A flock so treated
will remain sound in
the feet and clean
in the crutch
through the autumn
flush of feed. The
same job, done in
the yards when the
ewes are
'button-holed' with
the shears ...

Source: Big Country of the North Island
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
.. at one time they
employed the full
gang of ten men for
the button-holing
and second shearing,
putting through
anything up to 5,000
sheep a day.

Author: BARDSLEY
Quote:
button-holing:
part-crutching.

Author: CROSS
Quote:
If he could stick it
he graduated to real
work - dipping in
February, dagging,
footrotting,
buttonholing (part
crutch) when the
rams went out ...

Author: WILSON
Quote: Cotula coronopifoliaBUTTONWEED ... probably introduced into New Zealand where it is now widespread.

I also have a report
from the North Shore
of the continued
presence of jam
butties (ie
thickly-cut jam
sandwiches), and one
lady assures me that
one of the great
treats of her
childhood was a
cold-chip butty,
which was a sandwich
made with the
left-overs of the
Friday night fish
and chips.

Author: GORDON
Quote:
Sure, we used to buy
in and fatten, but
not on this scale.

This April marks 100
years of the Buy
Kiwi Made movement,
as well as the 20th
birthday of private
organisation Buy NZ
Made (whose member
companies label
products with that
familiar kiwi-in-the
-triangle logo that
tells shoppers goods
are produced
locally).. Buy Kiwi
Made Government
spokeswoman Sue
Bradford says the
campaign's biggest
success has been the
growing numbers of
New Zealanders aware
of their purchasing
power.

Author: FIRTH
Quote:
Currently a farmer
gets a buyer out to
draft his sheep.

person who selects
stock for sale:
buyer.

Mr Scully said that,
when Soutar was
asked for an
explanation, she
stated she was
`having a buzz'.

[Blue is a Mongrel
Mob gang member]
When he joined gang
members used blades
but today's weapon
was the gun and
14-year-olds were
not mature enough
for this. `You do
not want a
14-year-old boy with
a gun in his hand.
That is not the
buzz,' he said. ...
Blue said he thought
the mobs' `buzz' was
the best it had been
for 20 years. `We
have our own little
buzz. You cannot
describe it. It's
living life to the
hilt.'

New Zealanders have
a long standing love
affair with the
bewitching
combination of
chocolate and
marshmallow. Many of
our favourite sweets
are based on this
happy pairing: in
addition to Easter
eggs we have the
Buzz Bar, the
chocolate fish, the
Toastie and the
Pinky Bar.

The Buzz bar bash -
Steve McDowell
versus Mark
Bourneville - has
been talked up all
night.

Buzz Bars on the
ice. Just as they
always were,
unwrapped, sticky,
so good we send them
halfway round the
world.

When I was at the
awards I was just
buzzing out, sitting
in the crowd with
all these famous
people... and then
they called my name
out and I had to
walk down those big
steps.

Author: ANTHONY
Quote:
Gus hasn't got a
lady friend just for
the time, and sooner
than go by himself,
he wants me to ride
in his car [other
texts `cart'] with
him to the next
dance ... when Gus
arrived with his
buzzer at my gate, I
just slipped on an
overcoat over the
rig-out, and stepped
into the side-car.
Notes: c1924 Anthony Me and Gus (1977 Gus Tomlins ed Sturm) 11

Quote:
Other picks [for
inclusion] include a
Buzzy Bee circling
parliament by Geogre
[sic] Baloghy...

Buzzy bee, made from
1948 by Auckland
company H.E. Ramsay,
was copied from a
toy brought from the
United states, the
Ramsay family
confirmed
yesterday... A
worker at the
factory in 1948
brought an American
Buzzy bee toy to Mr
Ramsay, and
suggested something
similar be
made...The American
Buzzy bee was
flat-sided, about
one and a half
inches thick, made
from timber with a
metal clacker and
covered by painted
paper. That
accurately describes
the Fisher Price
bee, which Oamaru
man Gerald
Lynch-Blosse bought
in Arkansas about
five years ago.

The Buzzy Bee is our
greatest national
icon. It is in the
great book of icons.
It cannot now be
un-iconised.

Although making it
clear he didn't want
a "buzzy bee in
every shot" Hurst
went after some of
New Zealand's iconic
images - "swathes of
green hills, fence
lines, Robin
Morrison-type
pictures".

You love those
rarely-seen-on-TV
curves, that
determinedly New
Zealand accent, that
Cyndi-Lauper-meets-Buzzy
Bee smile, her
unabashed, well ...
ordinariness.

There are images as
Kiwi as Marmite and
Buzzy Bee.

A noisy wooden bug
with a daft clicker,
Buzzy Bee has
enjoyed a 61-year
reign as New
Zealand's favourite
toy. and it has the
cult status of
Weetbix, Marmite and
gumboots.

Mention culture,
they say, and it's
beginning to sound
too important, the
role of Buzzy Bee or
Wattie's peas in our
national psyche
notwithstanding.

Meanwhile, the
Historic Places
Trust has given the
mill the best
protection it can, a
category one
listing. It says
Sergeant Dan is as
well-known an image
as Buzzy Bee or the
Edmonds Baking
Powder tin.

The Buzzy Bee, you
might think, is a
simple enough toy...
[He] had intended to
make most of his
returns on
franchising the
Buzzy Bee label.

Author: RENeE
Quote:
There were, no
doubt, sniggerers at
the launches of
Buzzy Bee, Marmite
and Swanndri, but
look what happened
to them. Icons, my
dears, icons.

Author: McGILL
Quote: Buzzy Bee although now made in China of some wood other than native tawa, this dinkum Kiwi wooden bumblebee, which has been pulled along by generations of toddlers who have delighted in its clacking wings (once wood, now plastic), was the creation of Auckland toymaker Hec Ramsay back c.1946. Once Prince William declared an interest it became a worldwide plaything.

They reveal that
Beehive matches are
now made in Sweden
and that our old
mate Buzzy Bee, that
venerated toy of
thousands of New
Zealand children and
developed by
Aucklanders Hec and
John Ramsey, of
Onehunga, is now
being manufactured
in China.

Quote:
By corry, Hori would
give him a kit of
kumara some day to

his nails.

By Crikey, didn't a
quid go fast over
here.

I don't want to add
to the damned
grumbles that are
around, but by

fair while!.

When asked for an

the dam good act."

When asked for an

My sister say you

Author: GRAHAM
Quote:
When both parties
had collected their
fish the fishermen,
for a joke, would
say to the Maoris:
`Got many Pigfish
today, Ehoa? Let's
have a look!' and on
examining the kits a
Flounder here and
there would be seen
in with the Pigfish;
but the Maori women
were not to be
out-done and would
exclaim with great
vehemence: `By
gorry, Mister, I
never seen him go
in, he must have
jumped in when I not
looking!'

Author: SANDYS
Quote:
`By gorrie,' Wiri
muttered ...

"Wild," said the
Maori, "by gorry,
not half as wild as
me."

"It's good to be

"Probably, though,

Quote:

Author: McGILL
Quote: by the limping cricket agreeable or exasperated oath akin to `by thunder' or `by crikey', used by Kaipara area 1920s; eg `By the limping cricket, you're a useless darned goory.' [Jean and Jim Henderson]

Author: McGILL
Quote: by the thundering sardine agreeable or mock horror oath of the `by crikey' variety; eg `By the thundering sardine, that's a crop and a half of spuds you've got this year.' [Jean Henderson]

Most of our cities
and even small towns
have restaurants
that offer and wine
service and / or
allow patrons to
bring their own
wine. Not many
diners know that the
BYO concept
originated in
Australia and New
Zealand during the
1960s and 70s and is
rarely found
elsewhere. The
antipodean origin is
acknowledged in the
authoritative Oxford
Companion to Wine.

The interior recalls
an almost vanished
era - that of the
BYO bistro.

We stopped BYO for
larger groups two
years ago. All they
were interested in
doing was bringing
in a couple of cases
of booze and having
a party at our
expense... You want
BYO, he says, then
you go to a
restaurant, probably
an ethnic restaurant
or cafe, where you
get good cheap food
that doesn't take a
great deal of
preparation and few
staff. That's the
sort of restaurant
that can afford to
do BYO.

They had that BYO
sort of look about
them and let me bare
all. It's that sort
of place.

I don't want to buy
into a punch-up over
the BYO syndrome,
but this tell-tale
brown-bag routine is
something I shy away
from. It's pretty
much an Australian
and New Zealand
thing to ferry our
own drinkies into
restaurants,
sometimes even
transporting them in
a designer bag,
suitably labelled,
and drawing
attention to the
fact that l'il ole
me is bringing my
own.

Inside, on the
walls, are black and
white photographs of
early Plimmerton,
and the cafe is one
of the last of a
species fast facing
extinction in
central Wellington -
the BYO restaurant.
Twenty-five years
ago, "BYO
restaurant" had
exciting,
avant-garde
connotations of a
new breed of
restauranteur,
intent on providing
a hip, casual
alternative to the
handful of stiff,
expensive, fully
licensed fine dining
restaurants which,
aspart from hotels
and a scattering of
tired old steak and
chip grill-roomns,
previously comprised
the sum total of the
New Zealand
dining-out
experience.

Author: WILKINS
Quote:
"What is it, Henry?"
she said. "Irene and
her b.y.o. handbag?"

Author: McGILL
Quote:
There was a BYO
restaurant, but
[152] I had not
brought my own
booze.

Author: HILL

A ute boot sale, BYO

Author: McGILL

Progressive Dinner: Begins at 5 Mount St at 6 pm for Drinks and then to Kohanga for Mains and on and on!! BYO and $2.00 to cover costs.

B.Y.O. and a plate

Sale of Liquor
Act... 61. Liquor
permit for
unlicensed
restaurant... The
Chairman of the
Licensing
Committee.. may at
any time grant to
any person
conducting the
business of a

Author: MARSHALL
Quote:
The breakaway group
hadn't been able to
decide whether to go
to a licensed
restaurant or a
B.Y.O ...

There have been
times when I have
spent a whole five
minutes deciding
which BYO to go out
to, and another half
hour deciding which
wine to take.

It has always
surprised me that
more restaurants
don't open them -
particularly the
smaller BYOs which
are mainly
owner-operated.

The menu of Le
Saucier, the new BYO
in lower Cuba
Street, more or less
speaks for itself.

Author: LELAND
Quote:
B.Y.O.B. on a party
invitation, means
BRING YOUR OWN
BOTTLE.
B.Y.O.(G.) n. Austral. & N.Z. an unlicensed restaurant at which diners may drink their own wine, etc. [C20: bring your own (grog)]

The need for a
provision of this
nature - sometimes
known as BYOG,
"bring your own
grog" - has been
widely recognised
and provides a clear
enough example of a
case where the
present law has
fallen into
disrepute because of
its
unreasonableness.
